('64', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. LETTER TO KASTURBHAI LALBHAI
('64', 0, 2, 3, 76) May 20, 1934
('64', 0, 3, 4, 89) BHAI KASTURBHAI, I have written to Chamanbhai.
('64', 0, 3, 5, 136) I hope that you will prevent implementation of the Mill Owners’ Association’s resolution.
('64', 0, 3, 6, 226) I will not let the tradition which has been followed for so many years be broken without sufficient reason.
('64', 0, 3, 7, 334) The insistence on paying Mr. Patankar his fee also seems to me to be derogatory to our good name.
('64', 0, 4, 8, 432) Vandemataram from
('64', 0, 5, 9, 450) MOHANDAS
('64', 0, 6, 10, 459) From the Gujarati original: S.N. 33150
('64', 0, 7, 11, 498) 2. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('64', 0, 8, 12, 526) May 20, 1934
('64', 0, 9, 13, 539) Gandhiji left Patna early morning by the Sealdah Express and was seen off by a large number of people.
('64', 0, 9, 14, 642) Tired as he was, he hardly failed, except for a brief while when he was asleep, to stretch his hand across the window at every passing station and ask for “coppers” for his Harijan work and got silvers in plenty.
('64', 0, 9, 15, 855) This was for darshan alone, but if one wanted a brief interview ten rupees cash down was the price.
('64', 0, 10, 16, 955) He said : In trains, I do nothing else except collect funds for Harijans.
('64', 0, 11, 17, 1029) At Mokameh station, a Bengali rushed in and told Gandhiji that he had Rs. 1,001 to be given away to the Harijan Fund.
('64', 0, 11, 18, 1147) The Mahatma was all smiles and stretched out his hand.
('64', 0, 11, 19, 1202) But the Bengali gentleman said: “But you must come to Calcutta and take it.
('64', 0, 11, 20, 1278) We shall give you plenty more.”
('64', 0, 12, 21, 1310) [CORRESPONDENT :] Now that the All India Congress Committee has passed a resolution accepting your statement of 7th April and making you sole civil resister on behalf of the Congress, can you kindly tell me how and when you propose to give effect to it if at all ?
('64', 0, 13, 22, 1575) GANDHIJI: I cannot tell you how, because I myself do not know.
('64', 0, 13, 23, 1638) So far as the date is concerned, it was fixed when I was put out of the Yeravda Prison.
('64', 0, 13, 24, 1726) Beyond that all is a perfect blank to me as to anybody else.
('64', 0, 13, 25, 1787) But I must repeat what I stated at the time I was discharged, that I would strain every nerve to prevent civil resistance from becoming a
('64', 1, 0, 1, 1925) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 1, 1, 2, 1965) necessity.
('64', 1, 2, 3, 1976) [C.] Your resolution 1 sanctioning council entry is different from the Ranchi
('64', 1, 3, 4, 2054) resolution in so far as yours makes no reference to the White Paper and does not
('64', 1, 4, 5, 2135) define the Congress attitude towards it.
('64', 1, 4, 6, 2176) Can you tell me the signifiance of the
('64', 1, 5, 7, 2215) resolution as apart from the Ranchi resolution and the attitude which in your opinion
('64', 1, 6, 8, 2301) should be taken by Congressmen in regard to the Ranchi resolution?
('64', 1, 6, 9, 2368) [G.] The Ranchi resolution was an independent resolution enabling the Swarajists to know their own mind and to enable them to function if it became impossible, from circumstances beyond the control of their organization, to obtain recognition from the All India Congress Committee.
('64', 1, 6, 10, 2650) But the All India Congress Committee having been allowed to meet, there was no occasion for that body to adopt the resolutions of the Ranchi Conference.
('64', 1, 6, 11, 2803) It was enough for the All India Congress Committee to appropriate the Council Party and turn it into its own agency for the purpose of working the political programme of the Congress.
('64', 1, 6, 12, 2987) And it was unncessary to define the attitude of the Congress towards the White Paper, as that attitude is well known.
('64', 1, 6, 13, 3105) The Congress can accept nothing that is inconsistent with its objective, namely, the attainment of purna swarajya.
('64', 1, 7, 14, 3220) Asked whether he intended the Swarajya Party to be dissolved, Mahatma replied : This question I have already answered in reply to your previous one.
('64', 1, 7, 15, 3369) The Swarajists have become part of the Congress organization.
('64', 1, 8, 16, 3431) By the time the interview concluded, the train had reached Jahajah where, it
('64', 1, 9, 17, 3508) may be remembered, not long ago an anti Harijan demonstration pelted stones at
('64', 1, 10, 18, 3587) Mahatmaji’s car smashing the glass window.
('64', 1, 10, 19, 3630) The demonstration today at this place
('64', 1, 11, 20, 3668) was of the friendliest nature, more than a thousand people having gathered on the platform and continuously shouted “Mahatma Gandhi ki Jai” and pelted the author of
('64', 1, 12, 21, 3833) the Harijan movement with flowers.
('64', 1, 12, 22, 3868) Gandhiji, however, told the crowds that what he
('64', 1, 13, 23, 3916) wanted was not flowers, but money.
('64', 1, 13, 24, 3951) The Hindu, 21 5 1934
('64', 1, 14, 25, 3972) 1 Vide “Resolution on Council Entry”, 19 5 1934
('64', 2, 0, 1, 4020) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 3
('64', 2, 1, 2, 4064) 3. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDUSTAN TIMES” 1
('64', 2, 2, 3, 4104) May 21, 1934
('64', 2, 3, 4, 4117) Q. What are your impressions about the All India Congress Committee meeting?
('64', 2, 3, 5, 4194) A. Considering the revolutionary character of the two resolutions, the criticism was restrained, and the voting showed an extraordinary sense of responsibility and appreciation of facts.
('64', 2, 3, 6, 4381) The attendance, too, was quite good.
('64', 2, 4, 7, 4418) Q. Do you think it will be necessary for you to offer civil disobedience in pursuance of the permission given to you by the All India Congress Committee?
('64', 2, 4, 8, 4572) A. There is the 3rd August next in front of me, but what will happen that day is more than I can say 2. I have no pre conceived plans.
('64', 2, 4, 9, 4707) Sufficient unto the day is the work thereof.
('64', 2, 5, 10, 4752) Q. How do you look upon the emergence of the Socialist group within the
('64', 2, 6, 11, 4824) Congress?
('64', 2, 6, 12, 4834) Have you any message in this connection?
('64', 2, 6, 13, 4875) A. I welcome the emergence.
('64', 2, 6, 14, 4903) And if it acts, as I am sure it will act, with due restraint and in keeping with the special conditions of the country, it can only do good.
('64', 2, 6, 15, 5044) I understand that it is pledged to non violent methods to the exclusion of violent methods.
('64', 2, 7, 16, 5136) Q. How do you expect Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Vallabhbhai and Abdul Ghaffar Khan to view your advice to the country ?
('64', 2, 7, 17, 5261) A. I have no doubt that, if they had been out they would have acted precisely as I have.
('64', 2, 7, 18, 5350) How, being in jail, that is, being ignorant of the outside world at first hand, they would view its proceedings is surely an illegitimate question.
('64', 2, 7, 19, 5498) The Hindustan Times, 22 5 1934
('64', 2, 8, 20, 5529) 4. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('64', 2, 9, 21, 5557) May 21, 1934
('64', 2, 10, 22, 5570) JAMNALAL, I have read Elwin’s 3 letter.
('64', 2, 10, 23, 5610) I return it separately to save postage.
('64', 2, 10, 24, 5650) After I have seen his institution it seems that we shall have to help him.
('64', 2, 11, 25, 5725) 1 Gandhiji got down at Byree and walked to Gandhi Seva Ashram at Champapurhat.
('64', 2, 11, 26, 5804) It being his day of silence, he wrote down his answers.
('64', 2, 11, 27, 5860) 2 Vide footnote 2, “Speech at A.I.C.C. Meeting, Panta I”.
('64', 2, 12, 28, 5918) 3 Verrier Elwin
('64', 3, 0, 1, 5934) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 3, 1, 2, 5974) From where does he get the money at present?
('64', 3, 1, 3, 6019) How does he teach music?
('64', 3, 1, 4, 6044) Who else is there with him besides Shamrao?
('64', 3, 1, 5, 6088) Non vegetarian food seems indispensable for him.
('64', 3, 1, 6, 6137) He has not enough faith [in non violence] to be able to live on fruit and milk.
('64', 3, 1, 7, 6217) But he need not be denied help because of his food habits.
('64', 3, 1, 8, 6276) If, however, he stops spinning or slackens in it, I don’t think we should ignore that.
('64', 3, 1, 9, 6363) He may give up spinning entirely if he has not faith in it.
('64', 3, 1, 10, 6423) I do not wish to say that he should be helped only if he continues to spin.
('64', 3, 1, 11, 6499) What I want is that he must be truthful.
('64', 3, 1, 12, 6540) All that is necessary is that whatever work is done, should be done sincerely.
('64', 3, 1, 13, 6619) Elwin, being a good and simple hearted man, may deceive himself.
('64', 3, 1, 14, 6684) It is therefore necessary that friends should watch him.
('64', 3, 1, 15, 6741) Dr. Ansari’s plan for a party 1 must have been finalized.
('64', 3, 1, 16, 6799) You should take enough interest in the matter at least to see that everything goes well.
('64', 3, 1, 17, 6888) Rajaji also should take interest in it.
('64', 3, 1, 18, 6928) Having brought in Malaviyaji, we should help him and also see that he does no harm, which he can either by delaying or acting hastily.
('64', 3, 1, 19, 7063) Did you see the programme up to July?
('64', 3, 1, 20, 7101) It will help workers at most places to see me if they wish to do so.
('64', 3, 2, 21, 7170) Blessings from BAPU
('64', 3, 3, 22, 7190) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 2933
('64', 3, 4, 23, 7235) 5. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('64', 3, 5, 24, 7266) CHAMPAPURHAT (UTKAL), May 22, 1934
('64', 3, 6, 25, 7301) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I got your letter the day before.
('64', 3, 6, 26, 7353) It is about three o’clock just now.
('64', 3, 6, 27, 7389) Everybody in the .
('64', 3, 6, 28, 7408) 2 Ashram has fallen.
('64', 3, 6, 29, 7429) We arrived here yesterday (Monday).
('64', 3, 6, 30, 7465) Our good friend Masani of the Socialist Party is with us.
('64', 3, 6, 31, 7523) He is returning to Bombay today.
('64', 3, 6, 32, 7556) Agatha 3 also is with us.
('64', 3, 6, 33, 7582) She will leave in about four days.
('64', 3, 6, 34, 7617) Ceresole 4 will join today.
('64', 3, 6, 35, 7645) He will remain
('64', 3, 7, 36, 7660) 1 The Congress had appointed a Parliamentary Board under the presidentship of Dr. Ansari for contesting elections to the Central Legislative Assembly; vide p.
('64', 3, 8, 37, 7819) 2 Omission as in the source 3 Agatha Harrison 4 Pierre Ceresole, Swiss Engineer, who had come to India in connection with the Bihar earthquake relief work
('64', 4, 0, 1, 7974) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 5
('64', 4, 1, 2, 8018) with me for three or four days.
('64', 4, 1, 3, 8050) Muriel 1, too, is coming.
('64', 4, 1, 4, 8076) She will stay for two days.
('64', 4, 1, 5, 8104) I don’t give the names of the other local workers who are accompanying me.
('64', 4, 1, 6, 8179) This tour on foot will end in Balasore on the 12th.
('64', 4, 1, 7, 8231) It has been decided that after that we should stop walking and I should spend a few days in each province, doing the work from a fixed place.
('64', 4, 1, 8, 8373) The programme is as follows: I should reach Bombay on the 14th and from there go to Poona on the 17th.
('64', 4, 1, 9, 8476) Thereafter I go to Ahmedabad on the 26th and from there proceed to Sind.
('64', 4, 1, 10, 8549) I will spend three days in Sind and three in Lahore and then go to the U. P. I am enclosing a copy of the programme.
('64', 4, 1, 11, 8666) It is, however, subject to changes.
('64', 4, 1, 12, 8702) I had called workers from all provinces to meet me in Patna.
('64', 4, 1, 13, 8763) They were of the view that I must visit every province.
('64', 4, 1, 14, 8819) It was finally decided that I should visit every province and stay in one place for a few days.
('64', 4, 1, 15, 8915) It will be the time of the monsoon then and walking will probably be difficult.
('64', 4, 1, 16, 8995) You have already read about the decision taken at Patna.
('64', 4, 1, 17, 9052) Please rest assured that what has happened is the best.
('64', 4, 1, 18, 9108) That is what the people desired, and they were only waiting for me to agree.
('64', 4, 1, 19, 9185) But acute differences arose as soon as the first step was taken.
('64', 4, 1, 20, 9250) There is no limit to the goodness and patience of Ansari and Malaviyaji and to Dr. Roy’s overbearing temper.
('64', 4, 1, 21, 9359) Let us see what happens now.
('64', 4, 1, 22, 9388) I will send with this a fine word picture drawn by Sushila 2. Probably Om 3 also will write.
('64', 4, 1, 23, 9481) I will ask Agatha to write, too.
('64', 4, 1, 24, 9514) Ba has been released.
('64', 4, 1, 25, 9536) She will first go to Wardha and Delhi and then join us somewhere.
('64', 4, 1, 26, 9602) I wished to spend Rs. 5,000 from the Flood Relief Fund for Harijan victims of similar calamities but I was told that you had given instructions not to spend any amount from that Fund.
('64', 4, 1, 27, 9786) I, therefore, got only Rs. 1,000. I thought it necessary to ask you before drawing more.
('64', 4, 1, 28, 9875) Please write and tell me what instruction you remember to have given or what your wishes are.
('64', 4, 1, 29, 9969) Surendra 4 is fasting in Wardha.
('64', 4, 1, 30, 10002) He is doing so only for the sake of his health.
('64', 4, 1, 31, 10050) The jail food has broken the health of even stalwarts.
('64', 4, 1, 32, 10105) Narandas suffered from bleeding nostrils and came out of jail an old man.
('64', 4, 1, 33, 10179) Swami’s iron constitution also has broken down.
('64', 4, 1, 34, 10227) The same thing happened to Surendra.
('64', 4, 1, 35, 10264) A diet of pure starch and fat was not adequate.
('64', 4, 2, 36, 10312) 1 Muriel Lester 2 Sushila Pai, then head mistress of the Vanita Vishram, Rajkot, who later became Secretary of the Kasturba Memorial Trust 3 Umadevi Bajaj 4 An inmate of the Ashram
('64', 5, 0, 1, 10493) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 5, 1, 2, 10533) I see that milk and curds are essential.
('64', 5, 1, 3, 10574) Manilal’s Sushila has given birth to a son.
('64', 5, 1, 4, 10618) Manilal hasn’t informed me at all about this.
('64', 5, 1, 5, 10664) I have lost all interest in this growth of the family tree.
('64', 5, 1, 6, 10724) My only feeling is one of profound sadness.
('64', 5, 1, 7, 10768) However, who can thwart Nature?
('64', 5, 1, 8, 10800) Or we can adopt the European way (birth control) and sing: “Come, let us enjoy ourselves, Beautiful eyed One, but prevent the natural consequence of our indulgence.” I can’t help feeling that we shall not gain spiritual knowledge if we follow that path.
('64', 5, 1, 9, 11054) So long as Death remains unconquerable, nothing that Man does will avail him.
('64', 5, 1, 10, 11132) Hence the first verse of the Ishopanishad.
('64', 5, 1, 11, 11175) Do you remember it?
('64', 5, 1, 12, 11195) I used to recite that Upanishad every day in jail, trying to memorize the verses.
('64', 5, 1, 13, 11277) If you don’t remember them and if you wish, I will send you a copy of the Upanishad.
('64', 5, 1, 14, 11362) It contains only 18 verses.
('64', 5, 1, 15, 11390) The author has compressed all knowledge within that short compass.
('64', 5, 1, 16, 11457) There is no difference between its teaching and the Gita’s.
('64', 5, 1, 17, 11517) What is present in it in the form of a seed has become a beautiful tree in the Gita.
('64', 5, 1, 18, 11602) I will stop here now.
('64', 5, 1, 19, 11624) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro 2: Sardar Vallabhbhaine, pp.

('64', 6, 6, 12, 12371) 8. LETTER TO MARGARETE SPIEGEL
('64', 6, 7, 13, 12402) May 22, 1934
('64', 6, 8, 14, 12415) AMALA, My condolences on the loss of your companion, the squirrel.
('64', 6, 8, 15, 12482) You are right in thinking that those round you do not act up to the principle they profess.
('64', 6, 8, 16, 12574) They do not realize that mere refraining from killing is not enough.
('64', 6, 8, 17, 12643) It is necessary to show active sympathy for sufferers.
('64', 6, 8, 18, 12698) You should not be anxious about me.
('64', 6, 8, 19, 12734) The march will do me good.
('64', 6, 8, 20, 12761) I am certainly keeping well.
('64', 6, 9, 21, 12790) BAPU [PS.] Enclosed 1 for Lalji living there.

('64', 6, 11, 24, 12896) 9. LETTER TO N. S. HARDIKAR
('64', 6, 12, 25, 12924) May 22, 1934
('64', 6, 13, 26, 12937) MY DEAR HARDIKAR, I have your strange letter twice sent, first without the quotation.
('64', 6, 13, 27, 13023) It is a favourite saying of mine that you have quoted.
('64', 6, 13, 28, 13078) There was no anger in the use of that expression.
('64', 6, 13, 29, 13128) But it should be enough for you to have the admission from me that I am not without anger.
('64', 6, 14, 30, 13219) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('64', 7, 0, 1, 13246) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 7, 1, 2, 13286) therefore right for critics to fling it in my face.
('64', 7, 1, 3, 13338) But friends tolerate my shortcoming, and knowing that, I make a Herculian effort to throw it off.
('64', 7, 1, 4, 13436) Let me point out to them their shortcomings feeling that among equals perhaps I am the most experienced in these matters.
('64', 7, 1, 5, 13558) Remember too that two wrongs don’t make one right.
('64', 7, 1, 6, 13609) If I appeared to be angry, I must have been unconsciously angry.
('64', 7, 1, 7, 13674) I was certainly not pretending.
('64', 7, 1, 8, 13706) The question is, can a man be unconsciously angry?
('64', 7, 1, 9, 13757) He can be unintentionally so.
('64', 7, 1, 10, 13787) No anger is permissible, it may be unavoidable through human weakness.
('64', 7, 1, 11, 13858) Does this sufficiently answer your questions?
('64', 7, 1, 12, 13904) I hope you are well.
('64', 7, 2, 13, 13925) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('64', 7, 3, 14, 13955) From the original: N. S. Hardikar Papers.
('64', 7, 3, 15, 13997) Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('64', 7, 4, 16, 14041) 10. LETTER TO HIRALAL SHARMA
('64', 7, 5, 17, 14070) May [19 and ] 1 23, 1934
('64', 7, 6, 18, 14095) BHAI SHARMA, Amtussalaam has much praise for you and only one complaint, i.
('64', 7, 6, 19, 14171) e., you have lost much weight and that you have cut down on your food.
('64', 7, 6, 20, 14242) I would like to say only this much that exposing the body to unnecessary hardship is as much a crime as the pampering of it.
('64', 7, 6, 21, 14367) Hence all that is required to conserve the body should be done.
('64', 7, 6, 22, 14431) All this was written four days ago.
('64', 7, 6, 23, 14467) 2 I have your letter now.
('64', 7, 6, 24, 14493) You can come to me whenever you wish but without deserting the patients there.
('64', 7, 6, 25, 14572) My intinerary must be with you.
('64', 7, 6, 26, 14604) My work will keep me here till June 12, after that possibly in Bombay.
('64', 7, 6, 27, 14675) It will take some time for your wish to fructify.
('64', 7, 6, 28, 14725) I want you to gain in steadfastness.
('64', 7, 6, 29, 14762) But all this can only be talked over.
('64', 7, 6, 30, 14800) For the time being it is to the good that you are winning the hearts of the people there.

('64', 9, 4, 7, 16846) 14. LETTER TO P. NIRUPAMA
('64', 9, 5, 8, 16872) May 23, 1934
('64', 9, 6, 9, 16885) NIRUPAMA, I have your letter.
('64', 9, 6, 10, 16915) The language is good.
('64', 9, 6, 11, 16937) Ornaments are unnecessary; they tend to create in the girls fascination for external beauty.

('64', 12, 7, 17, 21376) 21. NOTE
('64', 12, 8, 18, 21385) AVOID EXAGGERATION Pandit Lalanth draws my attention to the fact that some newspapers which favour removal of untouchability have exaggerated the Deoghar incident and ascribed to those who delivered lathi blows on the hood of my car, designs upon my life.
('64', 12, 8, 19, 21641) There is no warrant for ascribing any murderous motive to the authors of the demonstration.
('64', 12, 8, 20, 21733) From the same source comes an unsigned printed leaflet which threatens death to those who might arrange demonstrations against the reformers.
('64', 12, 8, 21, 21875) I refuse to believe that this anonymous leaflet is the work of any responsible body or person at all.
('64', 12, 8, 22, 21977) So far as I know, no injury was done and no counter demonstration was made against sanatanists in Calcutta on the day which they had fixed for anti Temple entry Bill demonstration.
('64', 12, 8, 23, 22158) Neverthless, I cannot be too insistent on reformers being and remaining non violent in thought, word and deed.
('64', 12, 8, 24, 22269) Let them ignore these sanatanist demonstrations.
('64', 12, 8, 25, 22318) So far as I have seen, and I could not help seeing, these sanatanist demonstrations have little, if any, backing from the public.
('64', 12, 8, 26, 22448) In any case, we have to win them over
('64', 12, 9, 27, 22486) 1 The names have been omitted.
('64', 13, 0, 1, 22517) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 13, 1, 2, 22558) by showing regard for their sentiments.
('64', 13, 1, 3, 22598) We must not repel or acerbate them by making irritating or offensive remarks about their activity.
('64', 13, 1, 4, 22697) Harijan, 25 5 1934
('64', 13, 2, 5, 22716) 22. WILL THEY DO IT?
('64', 13, 3, 6, 22737) Since I have taken up the walking pilgrimage, hundreds of villagers have been following the pilgrims.
('64', 13, 3, 7, 22839) Some even talk about their woes.
('64', 13, 3, 8, 22872) Thus, whilst I was reaching Sakhigopal, a representative weaver himself told me that the weavers were in great distress as there was no demand for their cloth.
('64', 13, 3, 9, 23032) 1 I told him I had prophesied fifteen years ago that it would not be possible for them to co exist with mills, so long as they used mill yarn, and that the natural supplier and sustainer of the handloom was the spinning wheel.
('64', 13, 3, 10, 23259) In his reply I heard, to the best of my recollection, for the first time, ‘Give us hand spun and we shall weave it.’ ‘I will, if you will do as I tell you’, said I. ‘We will’, the old man replied.
('64', 13, 3, 11, 23456) The weaver was an old man with a bent back.
('64', 13, 3, 12, 23500) I was overjoyed at his replies and said, ‘That is very good.
('64', 13, 3, 13, 23561) Then I would teach you, your wife and your children how to gin, card and spin.
('64', 13, 3, 14, 23640) You will then have enough yarn for your loom.
('64', 13, 3, 15, 23686) You will spin good, strong, even yarn, you will avoid waste.
('64', 13, 3, 16, 23747) I shall expect you from your first out turn to take your khaddar for your own use and then I shall buy all the surplus khaddar you weave.
('64', 13, 3, 17, 23885) I shall try to become a member of your family and give you the benefit of my experience.
('64', 13, 3, 18, 23974) Thus, I shall ask you to give up drink and intoxicating drugs if you are addicted to them.
('64', 13, 3, 19, 24065) I shall go through your family budget and wean you from incurring debts.’ The old man’s face lightened up and he said, ‘We shallsurely follow your advice.
('64', 13, 3, 20, 24220) At present, starvation stares us in the face.’ I asked him to bring some of his friends to see me at 3 o’clock at the Gopabandhu Ashram in Saikhigopal.
('64', 13, 3, 21, 24372) He came with his friends, I repeated much of the morning conversation and said, ‘I know you can’t spin at once enough yarn to start your looms.
('64', 13, 3, 22, 24516) I shall, therefore, supply you with enough yarn to
('64', 13, 4, 23, 24567) 1 The meeting took place on May 10, 1934.
('64', 14, 0, 1, 24609) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 15
('64', 14, 1, 2, 24654) start with for the most promising families.
('64', 14, 1, 3, 24698) By the time you have woven it, you will have spun enough to feed your looms.
('64', 14, 1, 4, 24775) The first khaddar you weave from this supplied yarn will be taken over from you.
('64', 14, 1, 5, 24856) For the second lot, if you have not yet enough yarn of your own, I will again supply you with some.
('64', 14, 1, 6, 24956) After that you should become self supporting and you should make all your own family requirements of cloth and then only sell the surplus.
('64', 14, 2, 7, 25095) I regard this as an experiment of the highest importance and potency.
('64', 14, 2, 8, 25165) There are probably ten million weavers in India.
('64', 14, 2, 9, 25214) No one has the correct number, to the thousand even.
('64', 14, 2, 10, 25267) But ten million is a safe guess.
('64', 14, 2, 11, 25300) If these added all the previous processes to the art of weaving, they would not only ensure their own existence, but cheapen khaddar to the lowest possible limit and turn out much more durable and beautiful khaddar than has yet been produced.
('64', 14, 3, 12, 25543) The readers of Harijan know that there are in the Central Provinces several Harijan weaver families which do their own carding and spinning.
('64', 14, 3, 13, 25684) I would add to this ginning.
('64', 14, 3, 14, 25713) The future of khaddar can be assured if the weavers realize the necessity, for their own sakes, of themselves doing all the processes antecedent to weaving.
('64', 14, 4, 15, 25870) Harijan, 25 5 1934

('64', 15, 2, 6, 26886) 24. DISCUSSION WITH M. R. MASANI AND N. R. MALKANI 1
('64', 15, 3, 7, 26939) May 25, 1934
('64', 15, 4, 8, 26952) M. Is your main difference as to method or do you suspect that socialism is based on violence?
('64', 15, 5, 9, 27047) G. It is not a matter of suspicion but of fact.
('64', 15, 5, 10, 27095) Violence need not be physical.
('64', 15, 5, 11, 27126) Your socialistic system is based on coercion.
('64', 15, 6, 12, 27172) M. But coercion is used not as an end.
('64', 15, 6, 13, 27211) It is for the good of the many.
('64', 15, 7, 14, 27243) G. Violence is impatience and non violence is patience.
('64', 15, 7, 15, 27299) Great reforms cannot be introduced without great patience.
('64', 15, 7, 16, 27358) In violence lies the germ of future failure.
('64', 15, 7, 17, 27403) For instance, take 100 persons—5 armed and powerful, who could chop off the heads of the helpless 95 if they would oppose them.
('64', 15, 7, 18, 27531) That would be complete failure for the five.
('64', 15, 7, 19, 27576) But suppose that someone of the 95 kills these five and acquires power, without the desire of the remaining 94, you cannot say that the new rule will be good for all.
('64', 15, 7, 20, 27743) It may only mean one bad rule followed by another bad rule.
('64', 15, 8, 21, 27803) M. But one could not snatch power without the desire and active co operation of the 94. G. We have assumed absence of desire.
('64', 15, 9, 22, 27929) M. But with us the desire exists.
('64', 15, 9, 23, 27963) The socialistic programme can be understood and accepted by all.
('64', 15, 10, 24, 28028) 1 In his introductory note to this, N. R. Malkani, who was Gandhiji’s acting secretary, stated that these notes had the “advantage of having been passed by Gandhiji”.
('64', 15, 10, 25, 28195) Malkani wrote : “It was Friday, the 25th of May, 1934, and we had to walk five miles in the morning from Sisua to Patpur.
('64', 15, 10, 26, 28317) .Gandhiji walked barefooted with a cloth on his head, the right hand on Masani’s shoulder, the left on mine; his words instructing us, his hands now soothing and now restraining us; and ‘M’ in this talk stands to the credit of both Masani and Malkani indifferently .
('64', 16, 0, 1, 28584) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 17
('64', 16, 1, 2, 28629) G. Talk to the peasant in Orissa about monopoly of trade and socialization of industry and he will not know what you are talking about.
('64', 16, 2, 3, 28765) M. But the Gujarati or Deccani peasant can understand the rationalization of land.
('64', 16, 2, 4, 28848) G. Well, I have known Gujarati peasants defending and approving the institution of the Bania in villages.
('64', 16, 2, 5, 28954) They say the Bania is their benefactor in distress and so forth.
('64', 16, 2, 6, 29019) These people have to be awakened.
('64', 16, 2, 7, 29053) It is no use having an over ambitious programme.
('64', 16, 2, 8, 29102) I am a practical man.
('64', 16, 2, 9, 29124) I would cut down your programme to what I actually do.
('64', 16, 3, 10, 29179) M. The present tendency is towards decentralization in agriculture.
('64', 16, 3, 11, 29247) Intensive agriculture can only be on a small scale.
('64', 16, 3, 12, 29299) But the tendency in industry is towards large scale production and later large scale control.
('64', 16, 3, 13, 29393) In such cases there is bound to be a conflict between labour and capital.
('64', 16, 3, 14, 29467) There are some industries which always will tend to be on a large scale.
('64', 16, 4, 15, 29540) G. Industries like transport, insurance, exchange must be State owned.
('64', 16, 4, 16, 29611) But I would not insist that all large industries should be taken over by the State.
('64', 16, 4, 17, 29695) Suppose there is an intelligent and expert individual who volunteers to run and direct an industry, without much remuneration and only for the good of society, I would keep the system elastic enough to allow such an individual to organize that industry.
('64', 16, 5, 18, 29949) M. I too have no objection to such elasticity provided all private profit is eliminated.
('64', 16, 5, 19, 30038) If any individual promises to work for society, he should be permitted to do so.
('64', 16, 5, 20, 30119) But I would like to make sure that the industries are run on national lines.
('64', 16, 5, 21, 30196) I would, therefore, like the industries to be represented on a functional basis in the State, each trade to have its own representation.
('64', 16, 6, 22, 30333) G. That would be superfluous in a State which was based on adult franchise.
('64', 16, 6, 23, 30409) India is mostly agricultural and adult franchise would, therefore, give preponderance to agriculture.
('64', 16, 7, 24, 30511) M. In Russia they have a slightly different system.
('64', 16, 7, 25, 30563) The urban worker’s vote is weighted—four agriculture votes are equal to one urban vote.
('64', 16, 7, 26, 30651) For the rest the system of election is indirect, like our Congress election.
('64', 16, 8, 27, 30728) G. Well, I would not give that preference to the urban vote.
('64', 16, 8, 28, 30789) In the Round Table Conference I urged the adoption of adult franchise and voting by the village community.
('64', 16, 8, 29, 30896) The proposal was rejected because the Round Table Conference was not representative.
('64', 16, 9, 30, 30981) M. But any conference which has representatives of landlords and capitalists
('64', 17, 0, 1, 31058) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 17, 1, 2, 31099) will reject adult franchise.
('64', 17, 1, 3, 31128) They will say one thing but will do the other.
('64', 17, 2, 4, 31175) G. Then they have to be persuaded and converted to your views; I do not believe in the so called class conflict.
('64', 17, 3, 5, 31288) M. But we can convert individuals, never a system.
('64', 17, 3, 6, 31339) For instance take the
('64', 17, 4, 7, 31361) Champaran planters.
('64', 17, 4, 8, 31381) To the last they were not converted.
('64', 17, 4, 9, 31418) But for the pressure brought
('64', 17, 5, 10, 31447) on them by the Governor nothing would have been done.
('64', 17, 6, 11, 31501) G. I am not sure.
('64', 17, 6, 12, 31519) Some planters were converted.
('64', 17, 6, 13, 31549) What part the Government and planters played in the matter I do not know.
('64', 17, 6, 14, 31623) But I do know that the Government could have done nothing, if the planters had not stood by them.
('64', 17, 7, 15, 31721) M. But if the Governor had been hostile the planters would have resisted to the
('64', 17, 9, 16, 31801) G. That is shifting the ground.
('64', 17, 9, 17, 31833) I simply say that some planters were converted.
('64', 17, 9, 18, 31881) In India Europeans are of four classes—businessmen, soldiers, civilians and ecclesiastics.
('64', 17, 9, 19, 31972) Surely you do not suggest that individuals from these cannot be converted.
('64', 17, 9, 20, 32047) You must eliminate violence.
('64', 17, 9, 21, 32076) And when you do, you will find that there is not much difference between you and me.
('64', 17, 9, 22, 32161) Both of us desire the welfare of the starving millions.
('64', 17, 9, 23, 32217) The Hindustan Times, 4 8 1935

('64', 23, 4, 6, 41478) 35. OBSERVATIONS ON M. R. MASANI’S SOCIALISTIC PROGRAMME
('64', 23, 5, 7, 41535) [May 29, 1934] 1
('64', 23, 6, 8, 41552) I welcome the rise of the Socialist Party in the Congress.
('64', 23, 6, 9, 41611) But I can’t say that I like the programme as it appears in the printed pamphlet.
('64', 23, 6, 10, 41692) It seems to me to ignore Indian conditions, and I do not like the assumption underlying many of its propositions which go to show that there is necessarily antagonism between the classes and the masses or between the labourers and the capitalists such that they can never work for mutual good.
('64', 23, 6, 11, 41986) My own experience convering a fairly long period is to the contrary.
('64', 23, 6, 12, 42055) What is necessary is that labourers or workers should know their rights and should also know how to assert them.
('64', 23, 7, 13, 42168) ‘Abolition of the rule of Indian princes’ is an arrogation of power which does not belong to the party or which belongs as much as the power to abolish Portuguese and French authority in what is called Portuguese and French India would.
('64', 23, 7, 14, 42405) It may be unfortunate, but the dismemberment of India is a fact which may not be ignored.
('64', 23, 7, 15, 42495) It is surely enough to concentrate upon what is called British India.
('64', 23, 7, 16, 42565) It is large enough territory for any party to operate in, and its successful operations in British India cannot but have their effect upon the other parts of India.
('64', 23, 7, 17, 42730) On principle too I am not for the abolition of the rule of the princes; but I believe in its reformation and modification in consonance with the true spirit of democracy.
('64', 23, 7, 18, 42901) ‘The repudiation of the so called Public Debt of India incurred by the foreign Government’ is too vague and too sweeping a statement in the programme of a progressive and enlightened party.
('64', 23, 7, 19, 43091) The Congress has suggested the only real and statesmanlike
('64', 23, 8, 20, 43150) 1 Vide the following item.
('64', 23, 9, 21, 43177) 2 This paragraph was repeated in Gandhiji’s letter dated June 14, 1934, to the addressee.
('64', 24, 0, 1, 43267) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 25
('64', 24, 1, 2, 43312) proposition, namely, reference to an impartial tribunal of the whole of the so called Public Debt before any part can be taken over by the future free Government of India.
('64', 24, 1, 3, 43484) ‘The progressive nationalization of all the instruments of production, distribution and exchange’ is too sweeping to be admissible.
('64', 24, 1, 4, 43616) Rabindranath Tagore is an instrument of marvellous production.
('64', 24, 1, 5, 43679) I do not know that he will submit to be nationalized.
('64', 24, 1, 6, 43733) Regarding ‘State monopoly of foreign trade’, should not the State be satisfied with all the power it will prossess?
('64', 24, 1, 7, 43849) Must it also exercise all the powers in one swoop, whether such an exercise is necessary or not?
('64', 24, 1, 8, 43946) ‘Cancellation of debts owing by peasants and workers’ is a proposition which the debtors themselves would never subscribe to, for that will be suicidal.
('64', 24, 1, 9, 44099) What is necessary is an examination of the debts some of which, I know, will not bear scrutiny.
('64', 24, 1, 10, 44195) I should educate the masses to cultivate habits of thrift.
('64', 24, 1, 11, 44254) I should not be guilty of maiming them by letting them think that they have no obligation in the way of taking preventive measures in the matter of old age, sickness, accident and the like.
('64', 24, 1, 12, 44444) I do not understand the meaning of the phrase ‘the right to strike’.
('64', 24, 1, 13, 44513) It belongs to everybody who wants to take the risks attendant upon strikes.
('64', 24, 1, 14, 44589) Does ‘the right of the child to care and maintenance by the State’ absolve the parent from the duty of caring for the maintenance of his children?
('64', 24, 1, 15, 44736) ‘The elimination of landlordism’ clearly means usurpation of the Zamindari and Talukdari tracts in clause 13. I am not for elimination but for just regulation of the relation between landlords and tenants.
('64', 24, 1, 16, 44942) How do you seek to oppose the ‘introduction of religious issues into politics’ if you regulate and control all religious endowments?
('64', 24, 1, 17, 45075) What we really want to do is to observe strictest religious neutrality.
('64', 24, 1, 18, 45147) But when professors of one of the religions in the State desire some kind of internal reform without which progress will be impossible for them, State aid will become inevitable.
('64', 24, 1, 19, 45326) These are some of the observations as they occur to me on a cursory glance of your printed programme.
('64', 24, 2, 20, 45428) M. K. G.
('64', 24, 3, 21, 45437) From a photostat: C. W. 4883. Courtesy: M. R. Masani.

('64', 25, 9, 16, 46282) May 29, 1934 I am out to demolish all manner of inferiority complex from the mind of my Harijan brothers.
('64', 25, 9, 17, 46388) It is this which is taken advantage of by the opponents to the Harijan uplift movement and also induces the Harijans themselves to take the humiliating and absolutely irrational status assigned to them in society lying down.
('64', 25, 10, 18, 46613) Proceeding, Gandhiji ejoined on his audience the need for conducting themselves in their everyday life in such a manner as to deserve treatment as equals with their so called high caste fellows.
('64', 25, 10, 19, 46808) And for this it was essential, said Gandhiji, that the Harijans should scrupulously avoid carrion eating, uncleanly habits and drunkenness.
('64', 25, 10, 20, 46948) A touching scene was witnessed in Mahatmaji’s camp today, when an inmate was found weeping over the news of the death of a near relation of hers.
('64', 25, 10, 21, 47094) Gandhiji consoled her saying that the best way to conquer death was to take no notice of it.

('64', 26, 2, 5, 47679) 38. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('64', 26, 3, 6, 47722) May 29, 1934
('64', 26, 4, 7, 47735) In an exclusive interview with the ‘Associated Press’, in the course of which
('64', 26, 5, 8, 47813) he was asked whether he had definitely abandoned tbe Bengal tour, Mr. Gandhi said : It is not I who have abandoned the Bengal tour.
('64', 26, 5, 9, 47945) I put myself at the disposal of the Bengal Board, placing before them my difficulties.
('64', 26, 5, 10, 48032) They first dispensed me from the tour in the districts.
('64', 26, 5, 11, 48088) I offered to go to Calcutta for a few days if it was thought at all necessary for me to do so, though I had no mind to go to Calcutta only.
('64', 26, 5, 12, 48228) The Bengal Board also thought likewise and came to the conclusion that if I went to Bengal I should go there for three months.
('64', 26, 5, 13, 48355) And since that was impossible Calcutta was abandoned.
('64', 26, 5, 14, 48409) I should certainly love to go to Bengal for three months or more.
('64', 26, 5, 15, 48475) But I do not know whether this opportunity will come to me during my lifetime.
('64', 26, 6, 16, 48554) To another question whether he contemplated any discussion of the Poona Pact
('64', 26, 7, 17, 48631) with Bengal Hindu leaders and whether the Pact was still open to discussion and,
('64', 26, 8, 18, 48712) incidentally, to revision, Mr. Gandhi replied : I have always been ready and willing to discuss the Poona Pact with the Hindu leaders of Bengal.
('64', 26, 8, 19, 48857) Anything is possible by agreement of all parties.
('64', 26, 8, 20, 48907) So far as I am concerned nothing is possible that would not be consistent with justice to Harijans.
('64', 26, 9, 21, 49007) Asked whether he would support untouchables if they started satyagraha for the
('64', 26, 10, 22, 49086) vindication of their right to entry into public temples and whether untouchables had
('64', 26, 11, 23, 49171) an inalienable right to worship in public temples, Mr. Gandhi said : I do believe that Harijans have as much right of worship in public temples as any other Hindus.
('64', 26, 11, 24, 49336) But I could never be a party to the use of force in order to vindicate that right.
('64', 26, 11, 25, 49419) Satyagraha has come to signify many things.
('64', 26, 11, 26, 49463) I should therefore want to know the nature of the satyagraha to be offered.
('64', 26, 11, 27, 49539) And in any case satyagraha by Harijans would not be advisable while reformers were trying their utmost to persuade the orthodox to waive their objections.
('64', 27, 0, 1, 49694) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 27, 1, 2, 49735) Asked whether he would give any lead regarding the entry of untouchables into
('64', 27, 2, 3, 49813) the Puri Jagannath Temple, Mr. Gandhi replied : I have known of the importance of the temple at Puri being open to Harijans as it certainly was years ago and, as I know from first hand evidence, always has been so long as Harijans have gone without asserting their rights.
('64', 27, 2, 4, 50086) But I have no lead to give about opening the temple beyond this—that public opinion should be cultivated in that behalf.
('64', 27, 2, 5, 50207) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 30 5 1934

('64', 29, 1, 2, 52678) 41. INTERVIEW TO UTKAL WORKERS
('64', 29, 2, 3, 52709) May 30, 1934
('64', 29, 3, 4, 52722) Asked if he was satisfied with the formation of the Swaraj Parliamentary Board in which Utkal was not represented, Mahatma Gandhi said: I am not particular about it, nor am I at all concerned with the selection of the personnel of the Board.
('64', 29, 3, 5, 52964) I am mis represented by the Press as such.
('64', 29, 3, 6, 53007) Only Malaviyaji and Dr. Ansari have taken all responsibility for it.
('64', 29, 4, 7, 53076) As regards the discontent of the Utkal people for being neglected in the matter of representation on the Board, he said : I am of opinion that those who can do constructive work should not worry about representation on the Board.
('64', 29, 4, 8, 53306) But if you feel keenly on the matter, you should write asserting your right of representation of at least one seat.
('64', 29, 5, 9, 53422) He further advised the Utkal workers that instead of utilizing his services in such matters, they should take his more useful services in solving the flood problem which he was thinking about day and night.
('64', 29, 5, 10, 53629) Repair of the embankments, which was prohibited by the Government, was the greatest problem which every representative of the people of Utkal must think about.
('64', 29, 5, 11, 53789) To solve this he was writing to an expert engineer for making a survey.
('64', 29, 5, 12, 53861) He was confident that if a solution was suggested, the Government would not ignore it.
('64', 29, 5, 13, 53948) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 1 6 1934

('64', 30, 2, 3, 54555) May 31, 1934
('64', 30, 3, 4, 54568) BHAI HARIBHAU, I came to know only just now about your son’s death.
('64', 30, 3, 5, 54636) All of us will have to go that royal road sooner or later.
('64', 30, 3, 6, 54695) If, however, you two do wish to observe mourning for him, do so by observing complete self control.

('64', 30, 3, 11, 55105) But I see no such necessity.
('64', 30, 3, 12, 55134) What displeased the Government was not civil disobedience itself, but the incivility which was displayed in its name.

('64', 30, 3, 15, 55510) Thus, because our disobedience was uncivil, neither of the two parties could understand it.
('64', 30, 3, 16, 55602) Is this clear?

('64', 32, 1, 2, 57606) 47. ‘THE COOLIE PROBLEM OF ASSAM’
('64', 32, 2, 3, 57640) Whilst I was touring in Assam, a correspondent sent me his outpourings under the above heading.
('64', 32, 2, 4, 57736) From his letter I take the following : 1
('64', 32, 3, 5, 57777) I can agree from personal experience with much of what the writer has to say.
('64', 32, 3, 6, 57855) The very word ‘coolie’ is a misnomer and reminds one of what happens in South Africa.
('64', 32, 3, 7, 57941) Instead of meaning a labourer or a porter, the word came to be applied in South Africa to designate the bearer’s nationality, and became a word of reproach.
('64', 32, 3, 8, 58098) An Indian merchant, barrister or doctor was known as a coolie merchant, etc.
('64', 32, 3, 9, 58175) So, in Assam, the Indian who went from another province to work on the tea estates remained a coolie even after the termination of his cotract as a labourer and even though he ceased to be a labourer and became a land owner.
('64', 32, 3, 10, 58400) But being industrious, he has multiplied in Assam and yet remains in perfect isolation and ostracism.
('64', 32, 3, 11, 58502) It is a suicidal policy that keeps him so.
('64', 32, 3, 12, 58545) He cannot be driven out of Assam.
('64', 32, 3, 13, 58579) Being grossly neglected, he has become an economic waste.
('64', 32, 3, 14, 58637) If these men were properly taken care of, they would become an asset of first class importance.
('64', 32, 3, 15, 58733) It is up to the educated people of Assam to study this problem and solve it to the benefit of all concerned.
('64', 32, 3, 16, 58842) It does not require an outlay of money so much as it requires an outlay of intelligence and industry.
('64', 32, 3, 17, 58944) Harijan, 1 6 1934
('64', 32, 4, 18, 58962) 48. UNTOUCHABILITY AS IT EXISTS TODAY
('64', 32, 5, 19, 59000) The Editor sends me the following from his box.
('64', 32, 5, 20, 59048) A correspondent who gives his name and address but prefers to remain unknown to the readers of Harijan says :
('64', 32, 6, 21, 59158) In the Harijan of the 9th March, Gandhiji is reported to have said that
('64', 32, 7, 22, 59230) ‘there was no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability’.
('64', 32, 7, 23, 59289) One of the most prominent pundits who support Mahatmaji’s movement is Mahamaho padhyaya Pramatha Nath Tarkabhushan of Benares Hindu University.
('64', 32, 8, 24, 59433) 1 The extract is not reproduced here.
('64', 32, 8, 25, 59471) The correspondent had pointed out the need to remove the indignities suffered by the so called ‘coolies’ and those belonging to other Depressed Classes.
('64', 32, 8, 26, 59624) He had requested Gandhiji to “evolve a scheme of work” to raise their standard of life and to earn them recognition in society.
('64', 33, 0, 1, 59752) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 33, 1, 2, 59793) published the letter which he wrote to Gandhiji last year quoting scriptures in support of Gandhiji.
('64', 33, 1, 3, 59894) The pundit wrote that, although there are texts in support of untouchability, there are other texts which stated that untouchables could be made pure by diksha (initiation) and devotion to God.
('64', 33, 1, 4, 60088) Thus, according to the pundit, those chandalas who were not initiated nor devoted to God were
('64', 33, 2, 5, 60182) untouchables according to the Shastras.
('64', 33, 2, 6, 60222) Gandhiji’s opinion that there is no sanction for untouchability is, therefore, not supported by this pundit.
('64', 33, 3, 7, 60331) Will you kindly state pundits have told Gandhiji that there is no sanction for untouchability in the Shastras?
('64', 33, 4, 8, 60442) Gandhiji himself wrote before that sanatanists had supplied him with many texts from the Shastras in support of untouchability, but that he did not accept the authority of such passages as they were against the fundamental principles of morality.
('64', 33, 5, 9, 60689) Gandhiji’s present statement that there is no sanction for untouchability in the Shastras does not seem to accord with his previous statement which was that there is such sanction but he did not accept the authority of such passages because they were immoral.
('64', 33, 6, 10, 60949) Will you kindly explain the apparent inconsistency through the columns of the Harijan?
('64', 33, 6, 11, 61036) I have not verified the quotation from the Harijan of 9th March.
('64', 33, 6, 12, 61101) But everybody knows by this time that, whenever I speak on untouchability, it has reference to untouchability as it is practised today or known to us today.
('64', 33, 6, 13, 61258) And I do repeat here, as I have said on a thousand platforms, that there is no warrant in the Shastras for untouchability as we practise it today.
('64', 33, 6, 14, 61405) I well remember Mahamaho padhyaya Pramatha Nath Tarkabhushan’s letter to me.
('64', 33, 6, 15, 61482) His argument is an enforcing argument combating the doctrine of ineradicable untouchability.
('64', 33, 6, 16, 61575) That letter not only does not controvert 1 my propo sition but supports it in the sense that no single untouchable need always remain untouchable.
('64', 33, 6, 17, 61722) When once it is admitted that an untouchable can become touchable by simply reciting the Bhagavata’s twelve lettered mantra, the citadel of untouchability is destroyed.
('64', 33, 6, 18, 61891) For the support of my position, I cite even the sanatanists themselves, for, they have not as yet produced a single verse in support of untouchability as it is practised today.
('64', 33, 6, 19, 62068) Innumerable castes are at one time enumerated as untouchables in the census report and
('64', 33, 7, 20, 62155) 1 The source has “contraverse”.
('64', 34, 0, 1, 62187) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 35
('64', 34, 1, 2, 62232) at another removed from that list and some new ones are enumerated.
('64', 34, 1, 3, 62300) Surely, there is no warrant in the Shastras for accepting census figures for branding persons as untouchables, and untouchability as we practise it today has reference only to these several crores of men and women who are classified as untouchables in census reports.
('64', 34, 1, 4, 62568) Nor is there any warrant in the Shastras for the treatment that is meted out to these people in their respective provinces or districts.
('64', 34, 1, 5, 62705) I have, indeed, said that the verses produced by sanatanists in support of untouchability as they describe it are wholly inconsistent with the fundamental principles of Hinduism.
('64', 34, 1, 6, 62884) Therefore, under the canons of interpretation laid down in the Shastras themselves, such verses must be repudiated as devoid of authority.
('64', 34, 1, 7, 63023) There is, therefore, no inconsistency in my writings or sayings, when I say that there is no warrant for untouchability as it is practised today.
('64', 34, 1, 8, 63169) Of course, there is ample authority in the Shastras for temporary untouchability on sanitary grounds.
('64', 34, 1, 9, 63271) That is not an untouchability that is contrary to reason or to ethics.
('64', 34, 1, 10, 63342) The untouchability against which I am carrying on war is an internal taint which is supposed to apply to a man by birth and of which no amount of expiation can purge a man.
('64', 34, 1, 11, 63515) Harijan, 1 6 1934
('64', 34, 2, 12, 63533) 49. LETTER TO TARA JASWANI

('64', 36, 5, 8, 66281) 52. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, JAJPUR
('64', 36, 6, 9, 66318) June 2, 1934
('64', 36, 7, 10, 66331) In the address presented to me you have reminded me that this is a place of pilgrimage.
('64', 36, 7, 11, 66419) How nice it would have been if you had also added that in this place of pilgrimage all the temples have been thrown open to Harijans.
('64', 36, 7, 12, 66553) I have repeated several times that in the temples where Harijans have no right of entry, there are idols no doubt, but they have not been consecrated.
('64', 36, 8, 13, 66704) We call God the saviour of the fallen; we call him Daridranar ayana; we call him the Merciful and the Benign.
('64', 36, 8, 14, 66814) God has thousands of such epithets that go to prove that He does not belong to any particular caste.
('64', 36, 8, 15, 66915) God belongs neither to the Brahmins nor the Kshatriyas but He belongs to all.
('64', 36, 8, 16, 66993) But steeped in pride we say,‘God is for us only and not for others.’ To those who think so I have been crying myself hoarse that if there is any truth in the Shastras, if there is any truth in the tenets of the Shastras, a temple where Harijans are barred entry, has no God but only a stone.
('64', 36, 9, 17, 67285) If we fail to see what is obvious and if with the idea of high and low in our hearts, we segregate the Harijans, the Hindu dharma and Hindu society are doomed to perish.
('64', 36, 10, 18, 67455) From your address, it would appear that a tremendous propaganda is going on for the removal of untouchability and yet it cannot be uprooted in our time.
('64', 36, 10, 19, 67608) With my naked eyes I can see clearly that, whether we like it or not, untouchability is destined to disappear.
('64', 36, 10, 20, 67719) No man, up till now, has succeeded in stopping the wheels of time.
('64', 36, 10, 21, 67786) If we willingly own our Harijan brothers and give them all the rights we enjoy, this shall be deemed as a blessed act in the kingdom of God
('64', 37, 0, 1, 67926) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 37, 1, 2, 67967) and in the Book of God.
('64', 37, 1, 3, 67991) I shall explain to you what will be the result if untouchability is abolished against our wishes and also the result if it is removed with our consent.
('64', 37, 1, 4, 68143) If untouchability is removed against our wishes, it means the destruction of the Hindu dharma.
('64', 37, 1, 5, 68238) If Hinduism perishes there will certainly be no untouchable left.
('64', 37, 1, 6, 68304) But that will not be for the good of humanity.
('64', 37, 1, 7, 68351) If however untouchability is removed with the willing co operation of the Hindus, with the purification of and atonement by caste Hindus, it will be something to be proud of and will be a blessed act.
('64', 37, 1, 8, 68552) And the Hindu dharma which is on the decline today will have a renaissance, and it will progress.
('64', 37, 1, 9, 68650) With the rise of the Hindu community the concept of brotherhood and fraternity will prevail not only in India but in the whole world.
('64', 37, 1, 10, 68784) I have shown you two ways—one of progress and the other of decline.
('64', 37, 1, 11, 68852) Now, it is for you to decide which path you should choose.
('64', 37, 1, 12, 68911) A Muslim brother has sent me a letter.
('64', 37, 1, 13, 68950) He wishes me to give a reply here itself.
('64', 37, 1, 14, 68992) The purport of his letter is that, in all that I have attempted so far, I have only met with failure.
('64', 37, 1, 15, 69094) He writes, “Then why have you unnecessarily taken another task on your hands?” He cites this example: “You took immense trouble to bring about Hindu Muslim unity.
('64', 37, 1, 16, 69257) But it was no use; only there is a little more tension now.” In answer to this I wish to say only this: I do not accept that I have failed in my attempts especially for Hindu Muslim unity.
('64', 37, 1, 17, 69446) It is my strong belief that as a result of the efforts that have been made, though tension appears to have increased due to the prevailing political conditions unity has on the whole been strengthened.
('64', 37, 1, 18, 69648) It is also my unshaken faith that the endeavour to unite the Hindus and the Muslims will go down in history as a great and worthy cause.
('64', 37, 1, 19, 69785) But, even if I concede that all my attempts have failed, still I have no regrets, because I have conducted these experiments all my life as a worshipper of truth.
('64', 37, 1, 20, 69948) Therefore I have no regrets whatever for what I have done.
('64', 37, 1, 21, 70007) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 15 6 1934
('64', 38, 0, 1, 70045) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 39
('64', 38, 1, 2, 70090) 53. A LETTER 1
('64', 38, 2, 3, 70105) [Before June 3, 1934] If you will regard my walking tour in villages from day to day as walking to all villages of India, then there should be visible participation by all the provinces.
('64', 38, 2, 4, 70292) There may be walking parties to villages delivering the message of equality and brotherhood, for abolition of untouchability means nothing less.
('64', 38, 2, 5, 70437) These parties can do the double work, that of speaking in the friendliest manner to the caste Hindus on the evil of untouchability and distinction of high and low, collecting from them repentance money and sending this to me in the form of purses even as they would have done if I had travelled to them, and the work of delivering the message of peace and deliverance to the untouchables.

('64', 40, 3, 15, 74339) 57. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('64', 40, 4, 16, 74373) June 4, 1934 ‘Civil resistance’ is a wider term, and also indicative of respect.
('64', 40, 4, 17, 74454) Civil disobedience is not necessarily an accurate expression of the attitude indicated in ‘civil resistance’.
('64', 40, 4, 18, 74564) ‘Civil disobedience’ may also indicate an attitude of the mind.
('64', 40, 4, 19, 74628) The term ‘civil disobedience’ was first used by Thoreau.
('64', 40, 4, 20, 74685) I didn’t like it because it didn’t suggest all that I had in mind.
('64', 40, 4, 21, 74752) Looking for a new phrase, I fixed upon ‘civil resistance’.
('64', 40, 4, 22, 74811) The current phrase was ‘passive resistance’.
('64', 40, 4, 23, 74856) But my way of resistance or the force which I had in mind was not passive.
('64', 40, 4, 24, 74931) It was active, but ‘active’ might also mean violent.
('64', 40, 4, 25, 74984) The word ‘civil’ suggests nothing but non violence.
('64', 40, 4, 26, 75036) I, therefore, joined it with ‘resistance’.
('64', 40, 4, 27, 75079) The pledge taken at the start of the Dandi March certainly did not mean that I would remain in jail till swaraj was won.
('64', 40, 4, 28, 75200) Nor is it always in our hands to be in jail.
('64', 40, 4, 29, 75245) If the Yeravda Pact required a change in the Award 1 by the Government, it also required the people to discharge their debt to Harijans.
('64', 40, 4, 30, 75382) Because the Government was aware of this condition, it was by implication bound to give me facilities for fulfilling it.
('64', 40, 4, 31, 75503) The Government had accepted a similar argument during my first term of imprisonment and given me the necessary concession.
('64', 40, 4, 32, 75626) This correspondence has been published.
('64', 40, 4, 33, 75666) How can they go back on it now?
('64', 40, 4, 34, 75698) I have had no hand in Jamnalalji’s appointment.
('64', 40, 4, 35, 75746) But I approve
('64', 40, 5, 36, 75760) 1 Communal Award
('64', 41, 0, 1, 75777) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 41, 1, 2, 75818) The post of secretary was not filled because one secretary is out.
('64', 41, 1, 3, 75885) If nobody was available, even that post would have had to be filled.
('64', 41, 1, 4, 75954) There is no principle involved in such matters, the only criterion being propriety.
('64', 41, 1, 5, 76038) What is wrong in the same person being President and Treasurer?
('64', 41, 1, 6, 76102) What you say concerning the Parliamentary Board is correct.
('64', 41, 1, 7, 76162) The priest ministers at the wedding, but cannot help the partners to run their home.
('64', 41, 1, 8, 76247) If we let ourselves be seen as we are some day we shall become what we ought to be.
('64', 41, 1, 9, 76331) Now nothing till the 14th 1. However, if there is anything special I will write or ask somebody to write.

('64', 42, 8, 11, 77751) 61. LETTER TO BRIJKRISHNA CHANDIWALA
('64', 42, 9, 12, 77788) June 4, 1934
('64', 42, 10, 13, 77801) BRIJKRISHNA,
('64', 42, 11, 14, 77814) I have your letter.
('64', 42, 11, 15, 77834) I feel that you should join the family business.
('64', 42, 11, 16, 77883) You should earn what you can and enter the field of service only when you are free from attachment to the family and when the desire for money ceases and effortless brahmacharya is attained.
('64', 42, 11, 17, 78074) It is useless to make any sacrifice because I or someone else so advises.
('64', 42, 11, 18, 78148) Only you can have a measure of your own strength, only you can judge the degree of your attachment.
('64', 42, 11, 19, 78248) Until you have measured yourself truly it is your dharma to keep up the domestic links and retain the family profession.
('64', 42, 11, 20, 78369) There is no sin in maintaining family relationship or even in making money.
('64', 42, 11, 21, 78445) One can also after all render service by keeping the domestic ties within limits.
('64', 42, 11, 22, 78527) He also serves who observes truth, etc., while remaining in his own sphere of work.
('64', 42, 11, 23, 78611) One who enters the field of service yet indulges in subtle pleasures, selfishness and the like renders no service, but only harms the cause and turns a hypocrite.
('64', 42, 11, 24, 78774) It is a grave delusion to say that one cannot preserve truth while earning wealth.
('64', 42, 11, 25, 78857) There are quite a few people today who adhere to truth while making money.
('64', 42, 11, 26, 78932) I think your duty lies in this for the present, but the first thing you should do is to make yourself absolutely healthy.
('64', 42, 12, 27, 79054) Nothing will be gained by coming to me in my travels.
('64', 42, 12, 28, 79108) But if you wish you may join me on my reaching Poona or Ahmedabad.

('64', 48, 0, 1, 87032) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 49
('64', 48, 1, 2, 87077) 71. SPEECH AT GARADPUR ASHRAM, BHADRAK
('64', 48, 2, 3, 87116) [June 7, 1934] 1
('64', 48, 3, 4, 87133) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, It was arranged that there would be a meeting on the public road today at 9 a.m.
('64', 48, 3, 5, 87236) But I was informed that no meeting could be held on the public road without a license issued from the Superintendent of Police.
('64', 48, 3, 6, 87364) It was our mistake that we did not obtain a license for the meeting.
('64', 48, 3, 7, 87433) The S. P. is not here now.
('64', 48, 3, 8, 87460) He stays at Balasore.
('64', 48, 3, 9, 87482) His subordinates here are not empowered to issue a license.
('64', 48, 3, 10, 87542) So I could not go to the place of the meeting.
('64', 48, 3, 11, 87589) Therefore I called you all to this place.
('64', 48, 3, 12, 87631) I know law cannot be broken here; because I do not want to break the law and convene a meeting on the public road.
('64', 48, 3, 13, 87746) I say all of you should give up untouchability.
('64', 48, 3, 14, 87794) We are all sons of one God, then why should we live aloof from Harijans?
('64', 48, 3, 15, 87867) We should give all facilities to them which the caste Hindus enjoy.
('64', 48, 3, 16, 87935) We should not hold out any distinction between high and low.
('64', 48, 3, 17, 87996) The next thing that I have to say is that we have become idle and idleness should be given up.
('64', 48, 3, 18, 88091) If we do not give up idleness we will starve.
('64', 48, 3, 19, 88137) It is for this reason that some sort of work must be done.
('64', 48, 3, 20, 88196) If no other work is available then charkhas should be plied so that something may be earned.
('64', 48, 3, 21, 88289) If anyone gets more money by doing any other work, he should engage himself in such work.
('64', 48, 3, 22, 88379) Thirdly, intoxicants should be given up because intoxicants do harm to us.
('64', 48, 3, 23, 88454) If you have followed me, then give whatever you can for the service of Harijans.
('64', 48, 3, 24, 88535) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 7 6 1934
('64', 48, 4, 25, 88566) 72. SPEECH TO HARIJAN WORKERS, BHADRAK 2
('64', 48, 5, 26, 88607) June 7, 1934 Those who took a direct part in the pilgrimage cannot but have been struck by the fact that real work lies in the villages.
('64', 48, 5, 27, 88744) The vast mass of Harijans live there.
('64', 48, 5, 28, 88782) Untouchability has its strongest roots there.
('64', 48, 5, 29, 88828) Poverty, too, is most rampant in the villages.
('64', 48, 5, 30, 88875) Therefore the Sangh, while not neglecting the cities, should send its best workers to the villages and there do twofold work—serve the Harijans and the savarnas—the former, by procuring for the young and the old

('64', 49, 1, 3, 89565) In all things there should be no compulsion or the show of it.

('64', 49, 6, 14, 90915) 73. NOTES LIMITATIONS OF PENITENTIAL FASTS It will be remembered that Shri Sitaram Sastri sometime ago underwent as unconditional fast by way of penance for the weakness of a friend who, having promised to open a temple under his charge, had, under pressure of his friends, gone back upon his promise.
('64', 49, 6, 15, 91217) Shri Sastri discussed the fast with me.
('64', 49, 6, 16, 91257) I promised to set forth the argument briefly in these columns.
('64', 49, 7, 17, 91320) 1 What follows is reproduced from The Bombay Chronicle.
('64', 50, 0, 1, 91376) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 51
('64', 50, 1, 2, 91421) Fasting with a spiritual purpose behind it is praiseworthy only under well defined conditions.
('64', 50, 1, 3, 91516) It must not be for a selfish end.
('64', 50, 1, 4, 91550) It must not be in the nature of violence, as, for instance, it would be, if one fasted against a sanatanist for not opening a temple when it was well known that it was against his religious conviction to do so.
('64', 50, 1, 5, 91761) The question that Sitaram Sastri had to deal with was of a different nature.
('64', 50, 1, 6, 91838) He had to deal with a broken promise of an intimate friend.
('64', 50, 1, 7, 91898) Ordinarily such a breach or its imminence is cured by a fast, and the fast would be advisable, if not obligatory, for those who believe in fasts as a lawful institution in a non violent crusade against social or religious abuse or evil, both of which untouchability is.
('64', 50, 1, 8, 92168) But in dealing with the timid, almost emasculated, society such as we have to deal with, even breaches of promise have to be gently dealt with, especially when they are made in connection with social matters as distinguished from individual affairs.
('64', 50, 1, 9, 92418) Superstition is ingrained in us.
('64', 50, 1, 10, 92451) Untouch ability—itself a poisonous boycott of the extreme type—has filled us with imaginary horrors of an imaginary boycott.
('64', 50, 1, 11, 92576) Living in such fears, mere threat of a social boycott to one for whom life outside his particular caste is inconceivable is enough to make him withdraw or break a solemn promise.
('64', 50, 1, 12, 92755) In such cases, a fast is too drastic a remedy.
('64', 50, 1, 13, 92802) Prudence demands abstention from taking promises from such men and treating lightly promises already made.
('64', 50, 1, 14, 92909) Such persons require most sympathetic treatment and gentle handling.
('64', 50, 1, 15, 92978) A drastic treatment like that of fasting may, instead of strengthening, actually weaken a person and, therefore, endanger or injure the very reform for which a fast is undertaken.
('64', 50, 1, 16, 93158) Harijan, 8 6 1934
('64', 50, 2, 17, 93176) 74. A CAREFUL SPINNER
('64', 50, 3, 18, 93198) A Harijan sevak, who is working in a Harijan school and trying to introduce hand spinning amongst his pupils and their parents, in addition to many other things writes:
('64', 50, 4, 19, 93367) During the national week I spun more industriously than hitherto and much more carefully.
('64', 50, 4, 20, 93457) My speed was 300 yards per hour on an average.
('64', 50, 4, 21, 93504) Out of 40 tolas of cotton I obtained 37 tolas of yarn of 16 counts.
('64', 50, 4, 22, 93572) The output was 9,700 rounds—a round is equal to four feet.
('64', 50, 4, 23, 93631) In cleaning cotton and carding it, I lost two and a half tolas, and another half tola was lost in spinning.
('64', 50, 4, 24, 93739) I have preserved all the waste.
('64', 50, 4, 25, 93771) This I propose to utilize for filling pillows and the like.
('64', 50, 4, 26, 93831) I have seen many spinners whose waste sometimes amounts to as much
('64', 51, 0, 1, 93898) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 51, 1, 2, 93939) as the wages obtained from spinning for the amount of cotton on which the waste has been made.
('64', 51, 1, 3, 94034) You would remember that I spin only during leisure hours.
('64', 51, 1, 4, 94092) I shall have spun for myself much more khadi than I need for personal use.
('64', 51, 1, 5, 94167) I propose to sell the Purplus and apply the proceeds towards the expenses of conducting the Harijan school under my charge.
('64', 51, 1, 6, 94291) My yarn is considered to be so strong and good that the weavers prefer my yarn to any other.
('64', 51, 1, 7, 94384) I know this spinner.
('64', 51, 1, 8, 94405) He has become what he is by his sincerity and application.
('64', 51, 1, 9, 94464) He was no better than the average spinner.
('64', 51, 1, 10, 94507) But, today, very few volunteer spinners would be able to show the record that this Harijan sevak has been able to show.
('64', 51, 1, 11, 94627) Wandering through the villages of Utkal, speaking to the people and coming in closest touch with them I have a daily demonstration of enormous possibilities of hand spinning.
('64', 51, 1, 12, 94802) The idleness that has crept over the poor villagers is a first class tragedy.
('64', 51, 1, 13, 94880) I see hundreds, and often thousands, hovering round me all day long doing absolutely nothing.
('64', 51, 1, 14, 94974) Those who hover round me are not in any shape or form well to do.
('64', 51, 1, 15, 95040) Their food is of the most meagre kind.
('64', 51, 1, 16, 95079) They hardly get milk or ghee.
('64', 51, 1, 17, 95109) The food consists chiefly of boiled rice, dhal and oil.
('64', 51, 1, 18, 95165) The people appear to me to be without ambition and without hope, and yet they show in their own lives a remarkable culture which you cannot help noticing.
('64', 51, 1, 19, 95320) But all that culture will presently be of no avail to them, if they cannot be induced to learn the art of profitably utilizing every idle hour.
('64', 51, 1, 20, 95464) And I come irresistibly to the conclusion that there is nothing but the spinning wheel to present to the millions for their acceptance and use during idle hours.
('64', 51, 1, 21, 95626) Surely, any industry is remunerative which is designed to give occupation to millions of people.
('64', 51, 1, 22, 95723) Harijan, 8 6 1934

('64', 52, 1, 2, 96045) 76. LETTER TO J. C. KUMARAPPA 1
('64', 52, 2, 3, 96077) June 8, 1934 I have your note of the 4th instant.
('64', 52, 2, 4, 96127) You enquire about things here.
('64', 52, 2, 5, 96158) I shall content myself with giving you just a subjective report of the policy of the management as I expect detailed report of work done to reach you through Pyarelal and others from time to time.
('64', 52, 2, 6, 96355) My asking you for the expenses of your party has had a salutary effect and people are more careful in debiting items against the Bihar Central Relief Committee.
('64', 52, 2, 7, 96516) But still there is a tendency to mix up reconstruction work with relief work.
('64', 52, 2, 8, 96594) They want bridges built— even pucca ones—out of our funds without first tapping District Boards, the Government and other sources.
('64', 52, 2, 9, 96725) Even the wells sunk seem excessive and they have not yet got over the idea of free doles.
('64', 52, 2, 10, 96815) It appears to me,a great deal of the relief work is undertaken with political motives especially after the A.I.C.C. decisions.
('64', 52, 2, 11, 96942) The Bihar Central Relief Committee does not get the impartial and unadulterated attention of those in charge and the work is not what it should be because of mixed motives.
('64', 52, 2, 12, 97115) Middle class relief is an answer to pressure.
('64', 52, 2, 13, 97161) As an organization our weak point lies in the absolute control and discretion vested in the officers in charge at the districts.
('64', 52, 2, 14, 97290) True, the Managing Committee sits down in all seriousness to budget.
('64', 52, 2, 15, 97359) But when the President, out of the goodness of his heart, is persuaded to give blank cheques to officers in charge without consulting the Managing Committee such budgeting becomes a farce and is to no effect.
('64', 52, 2, 16, 97568) The work merely reflects the imagination or the lack of imagination of one man in each district.
('64', 52, 2, 17, 97665) Dictatorial powers are good in an emergency but it seems to me in constructive work some control of the executive is important to co ordinate effort.
('64', 52, 2, 18, 97815) The Audit Department, in the nature of things, is a day after the fair and is subject to executive discretion generally; while the inspection department becomes an organization for recording pious opinions.

('64', 53, 2, 3, 98184) BALASORE, June 8, 1934
('64', 53, 3, 4, 98207) In the course of an exclusive interview with the Associated Press Mr. Gandhi
('64', 53, 4, 5, 98284) said that if he had it in his power he would undoubtedly use it in order to bring about a
('64', 53, 5, 6, 98374) settlement of the labour strike during his visit to Bombay, but he knew that he had
('64', 53, 6, 7, 98458) As regards his impressions on the conclusion of his walking tour in Orissa, he
('64', 53, 7, 8, 98537) said: I have always considered Orissa to be the poorest of our provinces.
('64', 53, 7, 9, 98611) That impression was strengthened by intimate contact with the villages visited during the tour.
('64', 53, 7, 10, 98707) The enforced idleness among people is appalling.
('64', 53, 7, 11, 98756) The Harijans in the villages I found to be exceptionally clean in their habits.
('64', 53, 7, 12, 98836) Indeed, in some of the villages their homes appeared to be cleaner than the homes of their fellow villagers.
('64', 53, 7, 13, 98945) Intellectually, too, they appeared to me to be in no way inferior to others in spite of the social handicaps they are living under.
('64', 53, 7, 14, 99077) I have nothing but happy memories of the pilgrimage and, due opportunity coming to me, I should repeat it on a much larger scale.
('64', 53, 7, 15, 99207) Utkal co workers showed great powers of endurance.
('64', 53, 7, 16, 99258) Their organizing ability was of no mean order.
('64', 53, 7, 17, 99305) Twice during nights storms swept over us.
('64', 53, 7, 18, 99347) Volunteers proved equal to the emergency and we were able to pass the nights in more or less comfort.
('64', 53, 7, 19, 99449) Our party included girls from Rama Devi’s 1 Ashram.
('64', 53, 7, 20, 99501) I marvelled at their capacity for walking bare footed.
('64', 53, 7, 21, 99556) Every morning, as soon as we reached our destination, these girls went out to Harijan quarters and brought me reports of what they had seen or done.
('64', 53, 7, 22, 99705) They never knew what fatigue was And though many of them had been brought up in the lap of luxury they put up with all the trials of a march which was by no means a soft job.
('64', 53, 7, 23, 99880) If the work is continued with the same enthusiasm and earnestness that were exhibited during the march and the workers concentrate upon Harijan service in the villages more than the cities, the result will be startling.
('64', 53, 7, 24, 100100) I have no doubt that savarna Hindus’ minds are ready.
('64', 53, 7, 25, 100154) But, in order to induce action they require the living touch which could only be supplied by pure minded workers working in the villages, not by fits and starts, but regularly.
('64', 53, 8, 26, 100331) 1 Wife of Gopabandhu Babu and Secretary of the Harijan Sevak Sangh

('64', 54, 6, 8, 100964) 78. SPEECH AT BALASORE
('64', 54, 7, 9, 100987) [June 8, 1934] 2
('64', 54, 8, 10, 101004) Mr. Gandhi spoke for about 15 minutes.
('64', 54, 8, 11, 101043) He began by explaining the reason for abandoning his tour on foot and said that as he had been drenched by rain for two nights and as it rained the whole day at a place called Turunga he had to abandon his walking tour.
('64', 54, 8, 12, 101263) He then touched on untouchability and said that we are sons of the same God and as He does not make any distinction between His sons it would be sin for us if we do so.
('64', 54, 8, 13, 101432) No distinction should be made between the different castes among the Hindus, between the caste Hindus and the Harijans, and also between the Hindus and the non Hindus, as they are all brothers.
('64', 54, 8, 14, 101626) It is a sin not to remove this distinction and a religion which does not obliterate this distinction is doomed to extinction as a result of this sin.
('64', 54, 8, 15, 101776) He asked the audience to remove untouchability.
('64', 54, 9, 16, 101824) He then touched on the evil of intoxicants and said that the use of intoxicants deadens one’s intellect and might bring on even insanity.
('64', 54, 9, 17, 101962) He exhorted the audience to give up intoxicants.
('64', 54, 10, 18, 102011) Concluding, he said that everyone should do some work, as idleness is alwys bad.
('64', 54, 10, 19, 102092) He asked the audience to take to spinning by charkha, if they had nothing else to do, as that will remove Orissa’s poverty.
('64', 54, 11, 20, 102216) He then asked for contributions for the Harijan Fund.

('64', 57, 2, 19, 107470) Why not?
('64', 57, 2, 20, 107479) If such pilgrimages are undertaken in good faith and in a spirit of sacrifice, how long can untouchability last?
('64', 57, 2, 21, 107592) But how can such faith be created among our colleagues ?
('64', 57, 2, 22, 107649) Hence, we will have to go round in the other provinces as best as we can.
('64', 57, 2, 23, 107723) Camping in one place also seems to be a difficult proposition but our colleagues must bear with this much at least.
('64', 57, 2, 24, 107839) Let people from the whole province come wherever I camp.
('64', 57, 2, 25, 107896) Let them meet, exchange ideas and bring purses by way of expiation from their places—I want copper coins from many, not silver from a few.
('64', 57, 2, 26, 108035) Untouchability will not be wiped out with the help of rupees.
('64', 57, 2, 27, 108097) I have never heard of anyone’s heart being melted because of money.
('64', 57, 2, 28, 108165) If an individual’s donation is the token of his change of heart, it would not help the Harijans but will help those who consider themselves caste Hindus.
('64', 57, 2, 29, 108319) Hence, I expect the people of Gujarat, Kathiawar and Cutch 1. to know that this activity is purely religious; 2. to mix with the people and, facing all opposition, give them the message of removal of untouchability; 3. to collect individual donations if they are offered by way of expiation—and not for my sake; 4. to come and see me after cleansing their heart of all the impurities and freeing yourselves from selfishness and feelings of hatred and jealousy.
