('64', 62, 1, 2, 115318) 88. LETTER TO M. R. MASANI
('64', 62, 2, 3, 115345) June 14, 1934
('64', 62, 3, 4, 115359) MY DEAR MASANI, I have read the questions you left with me as also the Congress Socialist Party’s programme.
('64', 62, 3, 5, 115468) I welcome the rise of the Socialist Party in the Congress.
('64', 62, 3, 6, 115527) But I can’t say that I like the programme as it appears in the printed pamphlet.
('64', 62, 3, 7, 115608) It seems to me to ignore Indian conditions and I do not like the assumption underlying many of its propositions which go to show that there is necessarily antagonism between the classes and the masses or between the labourers and the capitalists, such that they can never work for mutual good.
('64', 62, 3, 8, 115902) My own experience covering a fairly long period is to the contrary.
('64', 62, 3, 9, 115970) What is necessary is that labourers or workers should know their rights and should also know how to assert them.
('64', 62, 3, 10, 116083) And since there never has been any right without a corresponding duty, in my opinion a manifesto is incomplete without emphasizing the necessity of performance of duty and showing what that duty is.
('64', 62, 3, 11, 116282) You would not want me at this stage to examine your programme clause by clause, but if you so desire and if you do not mind consulting my convenience, I would appoint for you a time when I could discuss with you, and those whom you may wish, the whole of your programme in detail.
('64', 62, 4, 12, 116563) Yours sincerely,
('64', 62, 5, 13, 116580) M. K. GANDHI
('64', 62, 6, 14, 116593) From a photostat: G.N. 4126. Also C.W. 4884. Courtesy: M. R. Masani

('64', 63, 5, 8, 117285) 90. INTERVIEW TO MEMBERS OF HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH 1
('64', 63, 6, 9, 117335) BOMBAY, June 14, 1934
('64', 63, 7, 10, 117357) The first work done by Gandhiji on arrival was to meet the members 2 of the Provincial Sangh.
('64', 63, 7, 11, 117451) Sheth Mathuradas after introducing the members gave a resume of their work.
('64', 63, 7, 12, 117527) The Sangh spends well in scholarships and runs three chawls providing accommodation for nearly 200 families.
('64', 63, 7, 13, 117636) In answer to the question what more was to be done by the Sangh, Gandhiji told the members that, whilst he held temple entry to be an integral part of the programme, he would like them to concentrate their attention on the education of the savaarna Hindus as to the scope of the work and the
('64', 63, 8, 14, 117928) necessity of removal of the evil.
('64', 63, 8, 15, 117962) This work should be done by purely voluntary workers of recognized status.
('64', 63, 8, 16, 118037) The other thing was extension of constructive work.
('64', 63, 8, 17, 118089) He would like to see a decent eating house run by the Sangh where Harijans could feel they could go without the slightest restraint.
('64', 63, 8, 18, 118222) A well managed eating house could become a centre of culture for the Harijans and an object lesson to all showing that Harijans had eating habits as clean as those of the average savarna Hindus.
('64', 63, 9, 19, 118417) true that some of them were not cleanly dressed.
('64', 63, 9, 20, 118466) But they were no more likely to visit these places than the numerous equally dirtily dressed savarna Hindus.
('64', 63, 9, 21, 118575) The two
('64', 63, 10, 22, 118583) things he mentioned were only by way of illustration.
('64', 63, 10, 23, 118637) If they would have an exhaustive census of all the Harijans in Bombay and have a catalogue of their disabilities due to untouchability, they could prepare a definite programme of work.
('64', 63, 10, 24, 118822) Gandhiji expected the Sangh to approach the Bombay Corporation in the many matters in which it alone could render effective help.
('64', 63, 11, 25, 118952) Mahatma Gandhi, after some discussion, expressed appreciation of the action

('64', 65, 2, 4, 122483) 92. NOTES THE ‘J. K. WELL FUND’ 1
('64', 65, 3, 5, 122517) I can easily emphasize the appeal made by Thakkar Bapa, published in the last issue of the Harijan, asking for donations to a fund for constructing wells for Harijans.
('64', 65, 3, 6, 122685) In walking through the Puri and Cuttack Districts, I have observed scarcity of water almost everywhere, and the reader can imagine the plight of Harijans when there is scarcity all over.
('64', 65, 3, 7, 122872) This is a charity to which all sanatanist reformers and others can subscribe; and let it be remembered that, whilst unreasoned prejudice may prevent Harijans from making use of one of the primary necessities of life, every well constructed for the use of these will relieve not only their distress but will add to the general supply of water.
('64', 65, 3, 8, 123215) All wells constructed for the sake of Harijans will be available to all who care to make use of them.
('64', 65, 3, 9, 123317) I hope, therefore, that there will be a generous response to the appeal made by Thakkar Bapa.
('64', 65, 3, 10, 123411) A RIGHT STEP The C. P. Government deserves congratulations for announcing that henceforth the so called Depressed Classes are to be known as Harijans, and criminal tribes as wandering tribes.
('64', 65, 3, 11, 123603) Both the names ‘Depressed Classes’ and ‘criminal tribes’ were certainly offensive.
('64', 65, 3, 12, 123686) And let us hope that the other Governments will copy the good example set by the C.P. Government.
('64', 65, 4, 13, 123784) Harijan, 15 6 1934
('64', 65, 5, 14, 123803) 93. HARIJAN V. NON HARIJAN
('64', 65, 6, 15, 123830) “Rather than do constructive work among Harijans, will it not be better to create intense dissatisfaction amongst them with their condition and thus promote such self helf as they can generate among
('64', 65, 7, 16, 124029) 1 A gentleman who wanted to remain anonymous had donated in June 1933 a sum of Rs. 25,000 to be paid in instalments of Rs. 2,000 per month for constructing wells for Harijans all over the country.
('64', 65, 7, 17, 124226) The amount was called under this name after it was fully paid up.
('64', 66, 0, 1, 124292) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 67
('64', 66, 1, 2, 124337) themselves?
('64', 66, 1, 3, 124349) It is no use your trying to convert the savarnas.” This was one of the questions that was asked at a meeting of workers.
('64', 66, 1, 4, 124470) As it is an important question, it is as well to give the gist of the answer given by me at the meeting.
('64', 66, 1, 5, 124575) The question betrays ignorance of the whole scope of the movement.
('64', 66, 1, 6, 124642) To create dissatisfaction among the Harijans can bring no immediate relief to them and can only tend to perpetuate a vicious division amongst Hindus.
('64', 66, 1, 7, 124792) The object of the movement is to do away with this utterly unnatural division and to secure for Harijans the simple justice to which they are entitled at the hands of savarna Hindus.
('64', 66, 1, 8, 124975) Thus the movement is one of repentance and reparation.
('64', 66, 1, 9, 125030) Hence it is confined, on the one hand, to constructive work among Harijans and, on the other, to conversion of savarnas by persuasion, arguments and, above all, by correct conduct on the part of the reformers.
('64', 66, 1, 10, 125240) If the latter have gentleness, forbearance and patience, what is scoffed at as irreligion by sanatanists will presently be regarded as the essence of religion.
('64', 66, 1, 11, 125400) Has not Manu said, “Know that to be dharma which is generally observed by the learned, the good and those who are free from passion and hate and which is felt in one’s heart”?
('64', 66, 1, 12, 125576) If, therefore, the reformers possess the qualities insisted upon by Manu, there will be no doubt whatsoever that the hearts of the sanatanists will respond.
('64', 66, 1, 13, 125733) Whether they do or not, the service rendered to suppressed humanity by reformers will be a substantial contribution to human progress and will be its own reward.
('64', 66, 1, 14, 125895) It will certainly find honourable mention in God’s eternal book of life.
('64', 66, 1, 15, 125968) Another question discussed was, “Do you not think that the improvement of the condition of starving peasants in more important than the service of Harijans?
('64', 66, 1, 16, 126125) Will you not, therefore, form peasant organizations which will naturally include Harijans in so far as their economic condition is concerned?” I wish that what the questioner says were true.
('64', 66, 1, 17, 126316) Unfortunately, the betterment of the economic condition of peasants will not necessarily include the betterment of that of the Harijans.
('64', 66, 1, 18, 126453) The peasant who is not a Harijan can rise as high as he likes or opportunity permits him, but not so the poor suppressed Harijan.
('64', 66, 1, 19, 126583) The latter cannot own and use land as freely as the savarna peasant.
('64', 66, 1, 20, 126652) He cannot command the labour that he needs.
('64', 66, 1, 21, 126696) In many places he cannot even buy the seed he requires.
('64', 66, 1, 22, 126752) And assume for one moment that the Harijan peasant is able to better his economic condition equally with the non Harijan.
('64', 66, 1, 23, 126874) Even so, he will still labour under the numerous social disabilities he was labouring under before.
('64', 66, 1, 24, 126974) Only, because of the very betterment, he will
('64', 67, 0, 1, 127020) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 67, 1, 2, 127061) feel them much more keenly than when he was a pauper.
('64', 67, 1, 3, 127115) Therefore, a special organization for the service of Harijans is a peremptory want in order to deal with the special and peculiar disabilities of harijans.
('64', 67, 1, 4, 127271) Substantial improvement of these, the lowest strata of society, must include that of the whole of society.
('64', 67, 1, 5, 127378) Moreover, the ordinary peasant is by no means neglected.
('64', 67, 1, 6, 127435) For instance, the All India Spinners’ Association is solely engaged in bettering the peasant’s economic condition by educating him to add a handicraft to husbandry and thus have an automatic insurance against famine and always a substantial addition to his scanty income.
('64', 67, 1, 7, 127707) Harijan, 15 6 1934
('64', 67, 2, 8, 127726) 94. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('64', 67, 3, 9, 127766) June 15, 1934
('64', 67, 4, 10, 127780) Gandhiji, at the outset, asked his audience if he was sufficiently audible and the ladies occupying the balconies replied cheerfully they were able to hear him .
('64', 67, 5, 11, 127942) In the course of his address to them, Gandhiji said that he was glad he was speaking to women before he would speak to the men, for women were superior to men in faith and love, and his battle would be more than half won if he could enlist their whole hearted support.
('64', 67, 5, 12, 128211) He hoped that the women of Bombay would rise to the occasion.
('64', 67, 5, 13, 128273) Women held the key position in society and it would be a tragedy if they blocked the path of reform.

('64', 69, 1, 2, 131373) 96. SPEECH AT MEETING OF CONGRESS PARLIAMENTARY BOARD, BOMBAY
('64', 69, 2, 3, 131435) June 16, 1934
('64', 69, 3, 4, 131449) After his consultation 1 Gandhiji addressed the Board in a speech which is described as one of the most moving and earnest speeches that he has ever delivered.
('64', 69, 3, 5, 131609) The main trend of the speech was that the Congress claimed to stand for the Muslims as well as the Hindus and the Sikhs and other communities and that, therefore, nothing should be done that would have the effect of making the Muslims feel that the Congress had departed from that position.
('64', 69, 4, 6, 131900) The majority of the Muslims had accepted the Communal Award.
('64', 69, 4, 7, 131961) It was their duty to bring about such a voluntary settlement of the Communal Award as would satisfy all communities.
('64', 69, 4, 8, 132078) They should not go to a third party to secure a modification of the Award.
('64', 69, 4, 9, 132153) So long, however, as a voluntary settlement was not brought about, it would be betrayal of the Muslims to shake their confidence in the Congress by taking up a position of uncompromising opposition to their view of the Communal Award.
('64', 69, 4, 10, 132388) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 6 1934

('64', 69, 6, 14, 132721) I must confess it was with great hesitation that I decided to come to Bombay.
('64', 69, 6, 15, 132799) For one thing, the labourers in the local mills are at present on strike.

('64', 73, 1, 2, 140680) 101. INTERVIEW TO ALL INDIA SWADESHI LEAGUE DEPUTATION 1
('64', 73, 2, 3, 140737) BOMBAY, [June 17, 1934 ] 2
('64', 73, 3, 4, 140764) During the last few months, Mr. Gandhi has been approached by several workers in swadeshi for a comprehensive definition of ‘swadeshi’ for their guidance.
('64', 73, 3, 5, 140919) In trying to prepare an exhaustive definition and in the course of discussion with co workers in the extreme South, he discovered that such a definition was almost impossible—it was a spirit that was growing and undergoing variations daily.
('64', 73, 3, 6, 141160) He suggested the following workable formula for the guidance of the All India Swadeshi League and kindred organizations: “For purposes of the All India Swadeshi League, swadeshi cov ers useful articles manufactured in India through small industries which are in need of popular education for their support and which will accept the guidance of the All India Swadeshi League in regulating prices and in the matter of wages and welfare of labour under their control.
('64', 73, 3, 7, 141625) Swadeshi will, therefore, exclude articles manufactured through large and organized industries which are in no need of services of the All India Swadeshi League and which can or do command State aid.” My formula as stated clearly is for the guidance of the Swadeshi League.
('64', 73, 3, 8, 141899) It does not purport to cover the whole field of swadeshi.
('64', 73, 3, 9, 141957) It is only by way of suggestion to the League to restrict the scope of its work to the encouragement and propagation of minor, particularly home industries to the exclusion of major organized ones.
('64', 73, 3, 10, 142155) The object of making this suggestion is not to decry major industries or to ignore the benefit those industries have bestowed and in future may bestow on the country.
('64', 73, 3, 11, 142322) But a body like the Swadeshi League need not become self appointed advertising agents of those industries as it has hitherto been.
('64', 73, 3, 12, 142453) They have ample resources at their command and they are well able to take care of themselves.
('64', 73, 3, 13, 142547) The spirit of swadeshi has been sufficiently generated and it helps them without any effort of swadeshi organizations.
('64', 73, 3, 14, 142666) These, if they are to be useful, have to concentrate their attention on the struggling industries.
('64', 73, 3, 15, 142765) Any attempt to
('64', 73, 4, 16, 142780) 1 It consisted of Lalubhai Samaldas, K. M. Munshi, Mrs. Raiji, J. A. D. Naoroji, S. A. Brelvi, Vaikunth L. Mehta, B. G. Kher, Maganlal, Purushottamdas and Dhirajlal Modi.
('64', 73, 4, 17, 142951) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle
('64', 74, 0, 1, 142979) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 75
('64', 74, 1, 2, 143024) advertise the wares of large organized industries can only result in sending up the prices.
('64', 74, 1, 3, 143116) This will be unjust to the consumer.
('64', 74, 1, 4, 143153) It is a waste of effort to bring into being a philanthropic organization to help a successful business organization.
('64', 74, 1, 5, 143270) We may not delude ourselves by the wish and belief that our efforts have helped the growth and advancement of those industries.
('64', 74, 1, 6, 143398) It will be cheap self satisfaction not substantiated by facts.
('64', 74, 1, 7, 143461) I recall a conversation I had with Fazalbhai in 1920, when I was on the eve of launching movement for swadeshi.
('64', 74, 1, 8, 143573) He characteristically said to me: ‘If you Congressmen become advertising agents of ours, you will do no good to the country except to put a premium on our wares and raise the prices of our manufacturers.’ His argument was sound.
('64', 74, 1, 9, 143802) But he was nonplussed when I informed him that our object was to encourage hand spun and hand woven khadi which had been woefully neglected and which needed to be revived if starving unemployed millions were to be served.
('64', 74, 1, 10, 144024) But khaddar is not the only such struggling industry.
('64', 74, 1, 11, 144078) I therefore suggest you direct your attention and efforts to all small scale minor unorganized industries that are today in need of public support.
('64', 74, 1, 12, 144226) They may be wiped out if no effort is made in their behalf.
('64', 74, 1, 13, 144286) Some of these are being pushed back by large scale industries which flood the markets with their manufactures.
('64', 74, 1, 14, 144397) It is these that cry for your help.
('64', 74, 1, 15, 144433) Take the sugar industry.
('64', 74, 1, 16, 144458) The largest major industry next to textile is that of the manufacture of sugar.
('64', 74, 1, 17, 144538) It stands in no need of our assistance.
('64', 74, 1, 18, 144578) Sugar factories are fast multiplying.
('64', 74, 1, 19, 144616) Popular agencies have done little to help the growth of this industry.
('64', 74, 1, 20, 144687) It is indebted for its growth to favourable legislation.
('64', 74, 1, 21, 144744) And today the industry is so prosperous and expanding that production of jaggery is becoming a thing of the past.
('64', 74, 1, 22, 144858) It is admittedly superior to refined sugar in its nutritive value.
('64', 74, 1, 23, 144925) It is this very valuable cottage industry that cries out for your help.
('64', 74, 1, 24, 144997) This, by itself, furnishes a large scope for research and substantial help.
('64', 74, 1, 25, 145073) We have to investigate ways and means of keeping it alive.
('64', 74, 1, 26, 145132) This is but an illustration of what I mean.
('64', 74, 1, 27, 145176) I have no doubt in my mind that we add to national wealth, if we help small scale industries.
('64', 74, 1, 28, 145270) I have no doubt also that true swadeshi consists in encouraging and reviving these home industries.
('64', 74, 1, 29, 145370) That alone can help the dumb millions.
('64', 74, 1, 30, 145409) It also provides an outlet for creative faculties and resourcefulness of the people.
('64', 74, 1, 31, 145494) It can usefully employ hundreds of youths in the country who are in need of employment.
('64', 74, 1, 32, 145582) It may harness all the energy that at present runs to waste.
('64', 74, 1, 33, 145643) I do not want anyone of those who are engaged in more remunerative occupations to leave
('64', 75, 0, 1, 145731) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 75, 1, 2, 145772) them and take to minor industries just as I did with regard to the spinning wheel.
('64', 75, 1, 3, 145855) I would ask only those who suffer from unemployment and penury to take to some of these industries and add a little to their slender resources.
('64', 75, 1, 4, 145999) It will thus be seen that the change in activity that I have suggested to you does in no way conflict with the interests of major industries.
('64', 75, 1, 5, 146141) I want to say only this much: Treat your national servants well, restrict your activities to minor industries and let major ones help themselves as they are doing today.
('64', 75, 1, 6, 146311) Minor industries, I conceive, will not replace major ones but will supplement them.
('64', 75, 1, 7, 146395) Of large industries, I even aspire to induce owners to take interest in this work, which is purely humanitarian.
('64', 75, 1, 8, 146508) I am a well wisher of the mill owners, too, and they will bear me out when I say that I have not failed to help them when I could.

('64', 76, 8, 12, 147983) The Congress will survive the shock.

('64', 76, 8, 14, 148082) Such a big organization as the Congress cannot allow its fate to be decided by purely personal considerations.
('64', 76, 8, 15, 148193) I anticipate no untoward results, if we regulate our work resolutely, calmly and honestly.
('64', 76, 8, 16, 148284) I am certain that nothing else can be done now.
('64', 76, 8, 17, 148332) I cannot measure the amount of damage that it will do to the country if we retrace our steps now.
('64', 76, 8, 18, 148430) Whatever it is, we cannot put a stop to this at this stage.
('64', 76, 9, 19, 148490) You, the members of the Parliamentary Board, who are here (in Bombay) may meet once again, and if you arrive at the conclusion that if these two resignations stand, it would be impossible to proceed with the election work, you may advise the Working Committee accordingly.

('64', 79, 9, 21, 153101) 111. SPEECH AT MAHILA ASHRAM, POONA 3
('64', 79, 10, 22, 153139) June 21, 1934
('64', 79, 11, 23, 153153) At the Ashram Gandhiji was garlanded by Harijan girls and, in the course of his address to the girls, he said that he owed his first acquaintance with Professor Karve and the great work he was doing for the women of India to the late Mr. Gokhale, who desired him to see for himself what one man could do in the cause of women’s progress.
('64', 79, 11, 24, 153491) Since then his ship had long sailed on troubled waters, with the result that he could pay them a second visit only after about 20 years, and that, too, by accident.
('64', 79, 11, 25, 153656) He did not have enough time even for his immediate work, but still he was glad to be in their midst.
('64', 79, 11, 26, 153757) He hoped that the girls, when they grew up, would so regulate their lives as to be worthy of the great sacrifices of the Karves in their interest.
('64', 79, 11, 27, 153904) With such an example before them, they dare not lead lives of luxury and self indulgence.
('64', 79, 12, 28, 153994) 1 Romain Rolland and Madeleine Rolland 2 Efy Aristarchi 3 This and the following item have been extracted from “Weekly Letter”.
('64', 80, 0, 1, 154122) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 81
('64', 80, 1, 2, 154167) was an old saying in Sanskrit that learning is not learning, if it does not lead to deliverance from yet become popular, though necessary.
('64', 80, 1, 3, 154306) They could not serve the nation properly without a working knowledge of the national language.
('64', 80, 1, 4, 154401) And they could easily acquire a mastery over Hindi, as it was closely akin to Marathi as well as to other languages of North India.
('64', 80, 1, 5, 154533) He would, therefore, expect the girls to spend themselves in the service of their less fortunate sisters.
('64', 80, 1, 6, 154639) He was sorry to note that Hindi was only optional and not compulsory in a national institution such as the Women’s University.
('64', 80, 1, 7, 154766) He would suggest that they should have English optional and Hindi compulsory, for all girls would take up English as a matter of course owing to the prevalent fashion, but they would not so readily take up Hindi.
('64', 80, 1, 8, 154979) When he himself was a student at school, his head master had made physical culture, which was then unpopular, compulsory, with a penalty of one anna for a day’s absence from the gymnasium, which he had once to pay.

('64', 81, 7, 14, 156755) 115. INTERVIEW TO NATIONAL EDUCATION WORKERS 3
('64', 81, 8, 15, 156802) POONA, June 22, 1934
('64', 81, 9, 16, 156823) In the course of his conversation Mr. Gandhi said that institutions that are under ban by the Government should not try to get the ban lifted by applying to the Government or by other means.
('64', 81, 9, 17, 157014) He further emphasized that as municipal and local bodies were semi Governmental, help from such bodies should not be taken for national education.
('64', 81, 10, 18, 157161) Asked if Harijans, while getting the benefits of national education from Congress organization, should also receive education from Government schools, Mr. Gandhi said that as long as we are not considering Harijans as part of our society we cannot apply the same rules of national education to them.
('64', 81, 10, 19, 157461) They can adopt all means to get education either at national schools or Government schools.
('64', 81, 11, 20, 157553) Questioned if the objects of national education should be to produce village workers in contra distinction to producing self supporting national minded workers, Mr. Gandhi said that the attention of workers should be directed to the creation of village workers as opposed to city workers.
('64', 81, 11, 21, 157842) That should be the primary object of national education.
('64', 81, 11, 22, 157899) Mr. Gandhi opined that primary education was most needed in the system of national education.
('64', 81, 11, 23, 157993) He approved of the ideal of an All India
('64', 81, 12, 24, 158034) 1 The addressee’s elder brother Mahendra Prasad who had been in charge of all domestic responsibilities had died earlier in the month; vide “Telegram to Rejendra Prasad”, 5 6 1934 2 Son of Mahendra Prasad 3 Arranged under the auspices of the Tilak Maharashtra Vidyapith; a questionnaire was presented to Gandhiji by the workers.
('64', 82, 0, 1, 158363) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 83
('64', 82, 1, 2, 158408) National Education Board, but said that the time was not yet ripe for such measures, but it depended on workers to prove its utility and for bringing such a proposal before the next Wroking Committee meeting.

('64', 82, 9, 20, 159295) 117. SPEECH AT MEETING TO COMMEMORATE THE PROPHET’S DEATH 1
('64', 82, 10, 21, 159355) POONA, June 23, 1934 My friendship with the Mussalmans does not date from yesterday but from the time when I was a young man fifty years ago.
('64', 82, 10, 22, 159497) My first visit to South Africa was in connection with the affairs of a Mussalman firm in that country.
('64', 82, 10, 23, 159600) And there I had the privilege of coming into intimate touch with Muslim friends, for years together.
('64', 82, 10, 24, 159701) In India too, you know, what close association there was between the Ali Brothers and myself.
('64', 82, 10, 25, 159795) And although Maulana Shaukat Ali and I have
('64', 82, 11, 26, 159839) 1 Held under the auspices of Anjuman i Fide e Islam.
('64', 82, 11, 27, 159892) Gandhiji spoke in Hindi
('64', 83, 0, 1, 159916) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 83, 1, 2, 159957) appeared to have been estranged from each other, he knows that he has me always in his pocket.
('64', 83, 1, 3, 160052) Such being my relations with Mussalmans, I felt it to be my duty to study the life of the Prophet.
('64', 83, 1, 4, 160151) I had tried to do this in South Africa but then I did not know sufficiently.
('64', 83, 1, 5, 160228) In India imprisonment brought me good luck and thus I had the opportunity to read Maulana Shibli’s biography of the Prophet which the late Hakim Saheb Ajmalkhan was good enough to send me at my request.
('64', 83, 1, 6, 160431) At the same time I also read the volume on companions of the Prophet.
('64', 83, 1, 7, 160501) I had read English works on Islam and the Prophet.
('64', 83, 1, 8, 160552) These studies led me to the conclusion that the Koran and the Bible were sacred books for me and not alone the Vedas and the Gita.
('64', 83, 1, 9, 160683) Hazrat Mahomed was a great Prophet and so was Jesus Christ.
('64', 83, 1, 10, 160743) From my reading I received the impression that the Prophet was a seeker of Truth.
('64', 83, 1, 11, 160825) He was godfearing.
('64', 83, 1, 12, 160844) In this I know I am not telling you anything new.
('64', 83, 1, 13, 160894) I am only describing to you how I was impressed by his life.
('64', 83, 1, 14, 160955) He suffered endless persecution.
('64', 83, 1, 15, 160988) He was brave and feared no man but God alone.
('64', 83, 1, 16, 161034) He did what he considered to be right in scorn of consequences.
('64', 83, 1, 17, 161098) He was never found to say one thing and do another.
('64', 83, 1, 18, 161150) He acted as he felt.
('64', 83, 1, 19, 161171) If there was a change in his opinion, the next day he responded to the change without counting the cost and regardless of popular censure or opposition.
('64', 83, 1, 20, 161324) The Prophet was a Fakir.
('64', 83, 1, 21, 161349) He had renounced everything.
('64', 83, 1, 22, 161378) He could have commanded wealth if he had so desired.
('64', 83, 1, 23, 161431) Even as you would, I shed tears of joy when I read of the privations he, his family and companions suffered voluntarily.
('64', 83, 1, 24, 161552) How can a Truth seeker like me help respecting one whose mind was constantly fixed on God, who ever walked in God’s fear and who had boundless compassion for mankind ?
('64', 83, 1, 25, 161720) You all read the Koran.
('64', 83, 1, 26, 161744) But how few put into practice what you read?
('64', 83, 1, 27, 161789) You will perhaps retort that, if you do not live up to the precepts of the Koran, nor do the Hindus act according to the precepts of the Gita, and you will be right.
('64', 83, 1, 28, 161955) It only comes to this that if both the communities followed the teachings of their respective faiths, communal quarrels would be a thing of the past.
('64', 83, 1, 29, 162105) But at present some men in both communities appear to have taken leave of their senses, and are absorbed in slinging mud at one another.
('64', 83, 1, 30, 162242) I will not have addressed this meeting in vain, if a single Mussalman will thereby come to a true understanding of the situation, and instead of picking holes learns to love other communities as well as his own.
('64', 83, 1, 31, 162454) The Hindu, 29 6 1934

('64', 85, 1, 2, 163743) 121. LETTER TO KRISHNADAS JAJU
('64', 85, 2, 3, 163774) June 24, 1934
('64', 85, 3, 4, 163788) BHAI JAJUJI,
('64', 85, 4, 5, 163801) I have your sweet letter.
('64', 85, 4, 6, 163827) In courtship there is necessarily some mental unchastity.
('64', 85, 4, 7, 163885) In order to avoid this and the risk of an unsuitable choice being made in an impure state of mind, I have been placing on the parents the responsibility of making preliminary enquiries and selection.
('64', 85, 4, 8, 164085) So far there has been no disadvantage in this method.
('64', 85, 4, 9, 164139) Two sons of mine got married when they were around thirty.
('64', 85, 4, 10, 164198) The brides of both were chosen by me in the first instance.
('64', 85, 4, 11, 164258) And in the case of Devdas the initial choice was certainly his but as soon as the idea came to him he voluntarily confided in [me] and Rajagopalachari and made a proper and successful effort to satisfy us.
('64', 85, 4, 12, 164464) When marriages are contracted by adults the fear of courtship is always there.
('64', 85, 4, 13, 164543) This is a part of dharma itself and dharma literally means the choice between good and evil that a man has to make every moment.
('64', 85, 4, 14, 164672) Your question implies another, that of co education.
('64', 85, 4, 15, 164725) I have doubts about girls and boys studying together, I have not yet formed any decisive opinion.
('64', 85, 4, 16, 164823) As our experiment is only in its primary stage mistakes are bound to occur and imperfections there are.
('64', 85, 4, 17, 164927) But the experiment is worth a trial.
('64', 85, 4, 18, 164964) On the whole it appears to be worth while though we have had quite a few bitter experiences too.
('64', 85, 4, 19, 165061) If you have anything more to ask in this connection, do so.

('64', 86, 1, 2, 165223) 122. SPEECH AT DISTRICT LOCAL BOARD MEETING, POONA 1
('64', 86, 2, 3, 165276) June 24, 1934
('64', 86, 3, 4, 165290) Gandhiji congratulated the Board on their work, 2 but wanted them to insist on quality.
('64', 86, 3, 5, 165378) He was confident that the economic distress among Harijans and insanitation in Harijan quarters would speedily vanish, if only Local Boards and Municipalities satisfactorily discharged their duties towards Harijans.
('64', 86, 3, 6, 165594) They must see that the Harijan children were properly taught in the preparatory schools, and teaching in their case meant at first not the three R’s so much as keeping their persons and clothes clean.
('64', 86, 3, 7, 165795) They would do well to institute prizes to be won by teachers who best attended to their Harijan pupils.
('64', 86, 3, 8, 165899) Then, again, Harijans were often not allowed to draw water from public wells, though they were legally entitled to do so.
('64', 86, 3, 9, 166021) Wherever such was the case, they must help them to exercise their undoubted rights and, in the mean while, not leave them without water but construct special wells for them.
('64', 86, 3, 10, 166195) Harijan, 6 7 1934
('64', 86, 4, 11, 166213) 123. INTERVIEW TO HARIJAN WORKERS
('64', 86, 5, 12, 166247) POONA, June 24, 1934
('64', 86, 6, 13, 166268) Gandhiji was with over 100 workers for one and a half hours and answered all sorts of questions with his usual patience.
('64', 86, 6, 14, 166389) The central point of his answers was that the workers should settle in the villages and work both among savarna Hindus and
('64', 86, 7, 15, 166512) Harijans.
('64', 86, 8, 16, 166522) A Harijan asked if it was right to encourage Harijan boys to become B. A. s or M. A.s, when unemployment was rife among graduates, and whether it would not be better if they took to technical education.
('64', 86, 8, 17, 166725) Gandhiji replied that they could hardly expect Harijans to go in for industrial education before it had successfully appealed to the savarnas.
('64', 86, 8, 18, 166868) And it was possible that, even if mere academic training was now no good for savarnas, it had its own value for Harijans.
('64', 86, 8, 19, 166990) For instance, he had long thought Dr. Ambedkar to be a Brahmin.
('64', 86, 8, 20, 167054) He was equal in intelligence and ability to the tallest among us.
('64', 86, 8, 21, 167120) Such distinction had its undoubted use for Harijans.
('64', 86, 8, 22, 167173) Gandhiji himself fully believed in industrial education and wished the numerous Harijan students would turn their attention to it.
('64', 86, 8, 23, 167304) Harijan Sevak Sanghs could not force
('64', 86, 9, 24, 167341) 1 This and the following two items have been extracted from ‘‘Weekly Letter’’.
('64', 86, 10, 25, 167420) 2 The District Local Board presented Gandhiji with an address in which they had given an account of the Harijan service they were rendering.
('64', 87, 0, 1, 167561) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 87, 1, 2, 167602) Harijans to such education.
('64', 87, 1, 3, 167630) They had to encourage the academical side by side with the industrial.
('64', 87, 1, 4, 167701) It was for the Harijans to preach the gospel of industrial training.
('64', 87, 1, 5, 167770) He hoped Harijans would study the life and work of Booker T. Washington 1 , whom he looked upon as one of the great men of the world, and draw their inspiration from it.
('64', 87, 2, 6, 167940) As regards housing Harijans, Gandhiji said that perhaps there was not much to do in the case of village Harijans, and, as for city dwelling Harijans, it was the duty of Municipalities to provide housing facilities for them; it was too big a proposition for the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('64', 87, 2, 7, 168222) The Municipalities if they were efficient and mindful of their duty, could solve the problem with very little expenditure.
('64', 87, 3, 8, 168345) On being asked how Harijans could assert their right to draw water from public wells, Gandhiji said they should, if necessary, seek police aid and the protection of courts of law for the purpose.
('64', 87, 3, 9, 168541) Harijan, 6 7 1934
('64', 87, 4, 10, 168559) 124. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, POONA
('64', 87, 5, 11, 168596) June 24, 1934
('64', 87, 6, 12, 168610) The public meeting in the evening was a remarkable function.
('64', 87, 6, 13, 168671) Deputations
('64', 87, 7, 14, 168683) from the various districts of Maharashtra presented Gandhiji with their respective
('64', 87, 8, 15, 168766) purses, and then Gandhiji asked Shri Shankarrao Lavate, the well known veteran
('64', 87, 9, 16, 168845) public worker of Poona, who had come as a representative of the sanatanist
('64', 87, 10, 17, 168920) opposition, to address the meeting.
('64', 87, 10, 18, 168956) Shri Lavate said that he and his sanatanist
('64', 87, 11, 19, 169000) colleagues desired removal of untouchability no less than Gandhiji himself, but they
('64', 87, 12, 20, 169085) objected to legislation affecting the Hindu community as a whole being passed with
('64', 87, 13, 21, 169168) the help of the votes of the Government as well as other communities.
('64', 87, 14, 22, 169238) Gandhiji congratulated Shri Lavate on his courtesy and extreme moderation and was sorry that the audience should have betryaed any impatience while he was addressing them, whereas etiquette required that they should hear speakers patiently and not interrupt them while they were speaking.
('64', 87, 14, 23, 169527) Shri Lavate was a seasoned public worker.
('64', 87, 14, 24, 169569) When he came to Poona in 1915, he was told that, if there was any true servant of the public in Poona, it was certainly Shri Lavate.
('64', 87, 14, 25, 169702) When he saw him, he was put in mind of the rishis of old.
('64', 87, 14, 26, 169760) Everyone was aware of his services in the cause of prohibition.
('64', 87, 14, 27, 169824) His regard for him was as profound as ever, though for the moment he happened to be arrayed in opposition to himself, and he was not so simple as not to give due consideration to the views of men like Shri Lavate.
('64', 87, 14, 28, 170038) But he was afraid that Shri Lavate was labouring under a misunderstanding.
('64', 87, 14, 29, 170113) In the course of the present tour, he had not only not canvassed votes for the Temple entry Bill, but he had hardly ever referred to it at all, for he believed it was a technical problem which should be left for
('64', 87, 15, 30, 170325) 1 1856 1915; American Negro educator who was born a slave; founded the Tuskegee Institute for the training of Negroes in trades and professions.
('64', 88, 0, 1, 170470) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 89
('64', 88, 1, 2, 170515) the lawyers to grapple with.
('64', 88, 1, 3, 170544) He was certain that it was their duty to secure the passage of the Bill, as untouchability could not be abolished without flinging the temples open to Harijans.
('64', 88, 1, 4, 170705) But he did not want the Bill to be placed on the statute book, unless a majority of the Hindu members of the Assembly were in favour of it.
('64', 88, 1, 5, 170845) It would be sheer violence to get the Bill passed with the help of the Muslim or Christian votes.
('64', 88, 1, 6, 170943) He assured Shri Lavate and the other sanatanist friends that their fears were groundless.
('64', 88, 1, 7, 171033) He would be very glad, indeed, if the sanatanists in Poona could join the movement.
('64', 88, 1, 8, 171117) Savarna Hindus in villages have been reported to compel Harijans to eat carrion and carry dead cattle against their will, and assault them if they dared to exercise their common right of drawing water from public wells.
('64', 88, 1, 9, 171337) Why could not all join hands in dealing with such violent conduct?
('64', 88, 1, 10, 171404) Not one shastri had quoted a single verse in support of such untouchability.
('64', 88, 1, 11, 171481) He claimed to follow the Shastras as he knew them.
('64', 88, 1, 12, 171532) He ever asked God to give him courage to die for Truth as he knew it.
('64', 88, 1, 13, 171602) It was, therefore, that he called himself a sanatanist.
('64', 88, 1, 14, 171658) Harijan, 6 7 1934

('64', 93, 1, 2, 179582) 132. STATEMENT ON BOMB INCIDENT 1
('64', 93, 2, 3, 179616) POONA, June 25, 1934 I have had so many narrow escapes in my life that this newest one does not surprise me.
('64', 93, 2, 4, 179725) God be thanked that no one was fatally injured by the bomb, and I hope that those who were more or less seriously injured, will be soon discharged from hospital.
('64', 93, 3, 5, 179887) I cannot believe that any sane sanatanist could ever encourage the insane act that was perpetrated this evening.
('64', 93, 3, 6, 180000) But I would like sanatanist friends to control the language that is being used by speakers and writers claiming to speak on their behalf.
('64', 93, 3, 7, 180138) The sorrowful incident has undoubtedly advanced the Harijan cause.
('64', 93, 3, 8, 180205) It is easy to see that causes prosper by the martyrdom of those who stand for them.
('64', 93, 3, 9, 180289) I am not aching for martyrdom, but if it comes in my way in the prosecution of what I consider to be the supreme duty in defence of the faith I hold in common with millions of Hindus, I shall have well earned it, and it will be possible for the historian of the future to say that the vow I had taken before Harijans that I would, if need be, die in the attempt to remove untouchability was literally fulfilled.
('64', 93, 3, 10, 180701) Let those who grudge me what yet remains to me of this earthly existence know that it is the easiest thing to do away with my body.
('64', 93, 3, 11, 180833) Why then put in jeopardy many innocent lives in order to take mine which they hold to be sinful?

('64', 97, 6, 11, 189338) 138. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, AHMEDABAD 1
('64', 97, 7, 12, 189382) June 27, 1934 It is an auspicious thing for me that my public work in Ahmedabad in the Harijan cause begins with a women’s meeting.
('64', 97, 7, 13, 189514) At many women’s meetings and some men’s meetings I have said, whenever I thought necessary, that not only in India but all over the world, religion has been and will be safeguarded by women.
('64', 97, 7, 14, 189705) It was not, and is not, my intention to say that women have safeguarded religion by writing big treatises or delivering lectures.
('64', 97, 7, 15, 189835) They have rather safeguarded religion by their actions.
('64', 97, 7, 16, 189891) No religion has been propagated through lectures or books.
('64', 97, 7, 17, 189950) We regard certain books as religious books; but they are a propagation of the thoughts and deeds of virtuous men and women.
('64', 97, 7, 18, 190074) A work that is not backed by virtuous conduct, however beautiful the thoughts may be, cannot make a religious treatise.
('64', 97, 7, 19, 190194) Nor can it bring us the peace that the scriptures do.
('64', 97, 7, 20, 190248) When a confirmed liar says, ‘Speak the truth’, he fails to make any impression, although no one may have known that he ever uttered a lie.
('64', 97, 7, 21, 190387) But the act of a person who is persistent in his virtuous ways is bound to bear fruit even if he is completely silent about it.
('64', 97, 7, 22, 190515) If a live seed is sown in fertile soil, it is bound to sprout.
('64', 97, 7, 23, 190578) The same is true about the words in religious books.
('64', 97, 7, 24, 190631) I have said after due thought that
('64', 97, 8, 25, 190666) 1 Held in the Krishna Cinema under the auspices of sevn women’s associations
('64', 98, 0, 1, 190743) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 99
('64', 98, 1, 2, 190788) women have done most to safeguard religion.
('64', 98, 1, 3, 190832) Women’s capacity for sacrifice, suffering and patience cannot be found in man.
('64', 98, 1, 4, 190911) This can be attributed to many causes.
('64', 98, 1, 5, 190950) It is unnecessary to go into them here.
('64', 98, 1, 6, 190990) But the world believes what I have said.
('64', 98, 1, 7, 191031) That is why I am happy that my work here has begun with this function.
('64', 98, 1, 8, 191102) If you are convinced that untouchability is a social sin, you must strive hard to free yourself from that sin.
('64', 98, 1, 9, 191213) It is not enough that someone like me should go round and collect funds.
('64', 98, 1, 10, 191286) Behind my effort is the hope that I should be able to appeal to the hearts of women.
('64', 98, 1, 11, 191371) It is only when this happens that I would be able to complete my work.
('64', 98, 1, 12, 191442) The work would be partly done if I can appeal to the hearts of men.
('64', 98, 1, 13, 191510) I went to give my condolences to Lady Lakshmibai in Bombay.
('64', 98, 1, 14, 191570) What condolences could I give to her?
('64', 98, 1, 15, 191608) I stressed only one point.
('64', 98, 1, 16, 191635) I told her: ‘Give up your mourning and come out of the house.
('64', 98, 1, 17, 191697) Mourning will bring no credit, but Harijan work will bring credit to your widowhood.’ Lakshmibai has worked for the eradication of untouchability.
('64', 98, 1, 18, 191844) So, she told me: ‘‘You men may say anything.
('64', 98, 1, 19, 191889) But can you do anything if we are obstinate ?’’ I had to plead guilty.
('64', 98, 1, 20, 191960) ‘‘I know it by experience’’—she added: ‘‘What would you do if a woman does not obey you—a husband or father?
('64', 98, 1, 21, 192069) We women know only to say no.
('64', 98, 1, 22, 192099) And, are you men going to be in the house for all the twenty four hours?
('64', 98, 1, 23, 192172) You may instruct us to do something and go out; but how would you know later if we did not carry it out ?’’ What she said was absolutely true.
('64', 98, 1, 24, 192315) That is why I say that my work can be carried out only if I appeal to the hearts of women.
('64', 98, 1, 25, 192406) Men tell me: ‘‘We do wish to give up untouchability.
('64', 98, 1, 26, 192459) But to you wish to create domestic quarrels?
('64', 98, 1, 27, 192504) We are willing to have Harijans in our houses.
('64', 98, 1, 28, 192551) But what can we do if those who are in the house for all the twenty four hours would not allow them ?’’ So, if women realize that untouchability is a sin and has to be wiped out, men would not be able to hold fast to it.
('64', 98, 1, 29, 192772) It is beyond the powers of men.
('64', 98, 1, 30, 192804) This is the experience of most men.
('64', 98, 1, 31, 192840) That is why I want to firmly impress upon you women, that let any number of Brahmins and astrologers talk to you, you should firmly bear in mind that if you are good mothers, you would not discriminate between one child and another.
('64', 98, 1, 32, 193073) On the contrary, you would shower more affection on a dull, stupid and crippled child.
('64', 98, 1, 33, 193160) I have never known a mother who would cast off a stupid child and lavish her affection on an intelligent child.
('64', 98, 1, 34, 193272) Such a mother, if there is one, should be scorned.
('64', 98, 1, 35, 193323) At least I would do that.
('64', 98, 1, 36, 193349) A mother is bound to show more affection for her handicapped child.
('64', 98, 1, 37, 193417) If we men and women who are images of clay have such sense of justice regarding
('64', 99, 0, 1, 193497) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 99, 1, 2, 193539) our children and pay more attention to the crippled, how would God who has created us, who is our Father, who is Father of all fathers, who is the Father of theuniverse, the Creator of the entire living world, have a different sense of justice?
('64', 99, 1, 3, 193784) My reason does not accept that it is God’s will that the Harijans should be boycotted, that they should not be allowed to take water from wells and tanks, that they should not be allowed to enter temples, and that temples would be defiled if they entered them, and any fruit or bread, it touched by them, should be thrown away.
('64', 99, 1, 4, 194112) This is sheer superstition.
('64', 99, 1, 5, 194140) We do not find such a thing in Islam or Christianity.
('64', 99, 1, 6, 194194) Only Hinduism has specialized in regarding these people as worse than animals.
('64', 99, 1, 7, 194273) We give good water and food to cows and buffaloes, but to these people we give only our left over food, and that too, we throw at them from a distance for fear of touching them.
('64', 99, 1, 8, 194451) We do not feel ashamed of doing so.
('64', 99, 1, 9, 194487) We believe that those people are born to be so treated.
('64', 99, 1, 10, 194543) This is such an obvious thing that we can easily see it if we wish to.
('64', 99, 1, 11, 194614) Those who consider themselves sanatanists do not let us step in at all.
('64', 99, 1, 12, 194686) They tell us that the untouchables are untouchables by birth and we would incur sin by touching them.
('64', 99, 1, 13, 194788) I do not wish to say that such a thing is not to be found anywhere else in the world.
('64', 99, 1, 14, 194874) Such a thing exists even in America; but there is no pretence of religion about it.
('64', 99, 1, 15, 194958) My complaint against the Hindu men and women is that they indulge in such a thing in the name of religion.
('64', 99, 1, 16, 195065) If you tell me that it is adharma to touch a Harijan, I would ask, ‘From where did you get the idea ?’ I have not come across a single shastri who has established on the testimony of the Shastras that untouchability as practised today ever existed before.
('64', 99, 1, 17, 195321) I have studied our scriputures fairly well and have found in them no mention of untouchability as it is practised today.
('64', 99, 1, 18, 195442) I do not wish to discuss what sort of untouchability has a place in the Shastras.
('64', 99, 1, 19, 195524) I say that this untouchability of today should be wiped out.
('64', 99, 1, 20, 195585) Once we realize that it is sheer injustice, it is adharma, we shall be able to bring about her quickly all the reforms we desire.
('64', 99, 2, 21, 195715) I have dealt with these things to indicate what I expect from you.
('64', 99, 2, 22, 195782) You must study this subject.
('64', 99, 2, 23, 195811) Do whatever is not beyond your capacity.
('64', 99, 2, 24, 195852) Serving the Harijan when the time arises is within the capacity of everyone.
('64', 99, 2, 25, 195929) It is not enough to give money for them.
('64', 99, 2, 26, 195970) We must believe that they are not untouchables but are just like us.
('64', 99, 2, 27, 196039) Had they been untouchables by birth, instead of two eyes they would be having three eyes or one ear instead of two, or God would have put some such mark on them.
('64', 99, 2, 28, 196201) But God has not given them any such mark.
('64', 99, 2, 29, 196243) If there is
('64', 100, 0, 1, 196255) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 101
('64', 100, 1, 2, 196301) a Harijan girl in our midst, we would not be able to make her out at first sight from others.
('64', 100, 2, 3, 196395) Anyone who does not consider untouchability a sin need not put even a cowrie into this bag.
('64', 100, 2, 4, 196487) He who considers it a sin should give whatever he can and make expiation.
('64', 100, 2, 5, 196561) We would know that a particular lady has put a coin in the bag and the following day we would take some service from her.
('64', 100, 2, 6, 196683) You have shown your sympathy by parting with a coin.
('64', 100, 2, 7, 196736) It may as well be said that you have given your co operation.

('64', 100, 8, 16, 197270) 140. DISCUSSION WITH GUJARAT SWADESHI SANGH WORKERS 1
('64', 100, 9, 17, 197324) AHMEDABAD, June 28, 1934 For the purpose of this Institution (All India Swadeshi Sangh), swadeshi shall cover useful articles wholly manufactured in this country, through small industries which require for their existence continuous education of public opinion in their favour, and which will accept directions issued by the Board of this institution, as to the price of articles manufactured by them, and wages and welfare of the labour under their control.
('64', 100, 9, 18, 197783) Such swadeshi will, therefore, exclude articles
('64', 100, 10, 19, 197831) 1 At the Harijan Ashram (Satyagraha Ashram), Sabarmati
('64', 101, 0, 1, 197886) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 101, 1, 2, 197928) manufactured through large and organized industries which are able to take care of themselves and which can command State protection without popular aid.
('64', 101, 2, 3, 198082) Explaining his definition Gandhiji said that his definition was such as required no change.
('64', 101, 2, 4, 198174) He said that the lines on which swadeshi movement is conducted at present has made us voluntary agents of big manufactures, and this has resulted in their neglecting home industries.
('64', 101, 3, 5, 198357) Gandhiji was therefore of the opinion that big manufactures do not require any stimulus from them and his definition was framed with a view to removing unemployment.
('64', 101, 4, 6, 198523) In reply to a question whether raw material which could not be procured from India should be imported or not, Gandhiji replied in the affirmative and said he would certainly ask to import such raw materials as are not available in India.
('64', 101, 4, 7, 198761) The Bombay Chronicle, 30 6 1934

('64', 101, 10, 16, 199215) I thank you for the address which has just been read out and for the purse of Rs. 5001 for the Harijan work.
('64', 101, 10, 17, 199324) You have stated the truth [in your address] that you are quite well off compared to
('64', 101, 11, 18, 199408) 1 The source had reported : ‘‘This definition was found by some of the workers as not entirely practicable, and the Gujarat Swadeshi Sangh suggest a change in the definition which should be : ‘Goods which are manufactured in India in all its stages, and under the direction of the Management with labour and capital 75 per cent Indian, with Indian material as far as possible, shall be considered as swadeshi.
('64', 101, 11, 19, 199818) But in manufacture of goods, yarn—cotton, silk and woollen—should necessarily be Indian.’’’ Vide also pp.
('64', 102, 0, 1, 199924) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 103
('64', 102, 1, 2, 199970) other Harijans.
('64', 102, 1, 3, 199986) You have some money and gradually you are getting more and more educational facilities.
('64', 102, 1, 4, 200074) There are other Harijans who are considered lower than those who have contributed to this fund which means that there exists untouchability within untouchability.
('64', 102, 1, 5, 200237) I congratulate you on admitting that you have given this money as an atonement for that sin.
('64', 102, 1, 6, 200330) But please do not you believe that having atoned and having given this purse, you have acquired a right to consider yourselves superior and regard other Harijans as lower than you.
('64', 102, 1, 7, 200511) There are some people who are found atoning for their sins in this manner.
('64', 102, 1, 8, 200586) There are many who believe that once they visit the temple and offer rice, betel nut and money, they are entitled to commit sins.
('64', 102, 1, 9, 200716) There are also people who believe that sins can be committed and atoned for daily just as clothes get dirty every day and are washed daily.
('64', 102, 1, 10, 200856) It is therefore wrong if you have given these five thousand rupees as a passport for committing sin.
('64', 102, 1, 11, 200957) One who makes atonement should not consider others lower than himself.
('64', 102, 1, 12, 201028) I will show you an easy way of putting this in practice.
('64', 102, 1, 13, 201085) One must consider oneself lowest [in the world], that is to say that there can be no one lower than oneself.
('64', 102, 1, 14, 201194) We are ultimately bound to suffer degradation if we consider ourselves higher than others and this would mean that we have not done away with untouchability.
('64', 102, 1, 15, 201352) Those who have given money should make their atonement complete by removing the feeling of high and low among the sub castes like sweepers, scavengers, tanners, etc.
('64', 102, 1, 16, 201518) The caste Hindus who consider themselves higher than others, are also responsible.

('64', 109, 1, 22, 220442) From the testimony of modern history we can say that there is nothing which cannot be attained by human effort.
('64', 109, 1, 23, 220554) I cannot cite all the instances, but one I must.
('64', 109, 1, 24, 220603) In the city of Johannesbeurg in South Africa, the plague broke out in the Location where our people were staying.
('64', 109, 1, 25, 220717) Promptly the Location was locked up, police watchmen were posted and people were removed to a place thirteen miles away.
('64', 109, 1, 26, 220838) There in a couple of days they set up a tented village on beautiful land, and all people were accommodated in it.
('64', 109, 1, 27, 220952) The condition of that Location was better than this chawl.
('64', 109, 1, 28, 221011) And yet, while describing it, I had called it hell.
('64', 109, 1, 29, 221063) If that was hell, what I saw yesterday was a greater hell.
('64', 109, 1, 30, 221122) After removing the people thirteen miles away from that Location, setting up shops there and providing other conveniences, the Location was destroyed and all the things were burnt.
('64', 109, 1, 31, 221303) Compensation was given to those whose belongings were burnt.
('64', 109, 1, 32, 221364) I had even complained that the compensation was very little.
('64', 109, 1, 33, 221425) Please do not tell me, ‘Johannesburg is a mine of gold and where does Ahmedabad stand in comparison with it ?’ There are so many mills in Ahmedabad and the chawls I am speaking of belong to these mills.
('64', 109, 1, 34, 221628) Money spent in it would be rewarded.
('64', 109, 1, 35, 221665) We must resolve that the Harijans by whose labour we are able to maintain cleanliness in the houses and palaces leading a life of luxury should have at least for them not slums but well ventilated and well lit houses which are conducive to health.
('64', 109, 1, 36, 221913) If enough citizens resolve, this work can be done in a week.
('64', 109, 1, 37, 221974) I have told you how it can be
('64', 110, 0, 1, 222004) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 111
('64', 110, 1, 2, 222050) There are so many men and women volunteers here.
('64', 110, 1, 3, 222099) Doctors like Dr. Hariprasad have worked hard for the Ahmedabad Municipality.
('64', 110, 1, 4, 222176) Even though he is in Ootacamund, he is thinking of this same problem.
('64', 110, 1, 5, 222246) Balubhai has already told you this.
('64', 110, 1, 6, 222282) He wrote to me too: ‘I feel sorry that I am not there right now.
('64', 110, 1, 7, 222347) I am going to do at least this much work.’ He has now become the Chairman of the Sanitation Committee.
('64', 110, 1, 8, 222450) Hence, I have now a right to demand work from him.
('64', 110, 1, 9, 222501) Ahmedabad would be committing a great crime if we cannot keep the Harijans in good condition in spite of the favourable circumstances.
('64', 110, 1, 10, 222636) In 1915 I went round with Mr. Ewbank to see these chawls.
('64', 110, 1, 11, 222694) There is some improvement since then but it is just a drop in the ocean.
('64', 110, 1, 12, 222767) There should not be a single person in Ahmedabad who would lose his health by living in unhealthy surroundings.
('64', 110, 1, 13, 222879) If we can reach the most downtrodden classes of the society, we shall be able to reach the others.
('64', 110, 1, 14, 222978) There are some here who are considered expert sanatanists.
('64', 110, 1, 15, 223037) There would be none among them who would say that he hesitates to do this work.
('64', 110, 1, 16, 223117) I would not ask a single pice for this purse from those sanatanists who do not regard untouchability as a sin.
('64', 110, 1, 17, 223228) But it does not mean that I would not take their money for the houses of the Harijans.
('64', 110, 1, 18, 223315) If I take money from the Parsis, Muslims and Christians, why not from the sanatanists?
('64', 110, 1, 19, 223402) I would not take any money for this purse from those Hindus who do not give it in the spirit of atonement but let them at least build chawls for the Harijans.
('64', 110, 1, 20, 223561) Our scriptures do not tell us to keep the Harijans in the condition of animals.
('64', 110, 1, 21, 223641) The scriptures give no evidence of the untouchability we observe today.
('64', 110, 1, 22, 223713) A certain type of untouchability is observed all over the world.
('64', 110, 1, 23, 223778) We should not touch a dirty man.
('64', 110, 1, 24, 223811) But we have turned six crores of men into slaves.
('64', 110, 1, 25, 223861) We have considered them untouchables by birth.
('64', 110, 1, 26, 223908) Where is the evidence for it in the sacred books?
('64', 110, 1, 27, 223958) It is the dharma of all of us, the Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Parsis to see that no one in Ahmedabad is forced to live in unhealthy conditions.
('64', 110, 1, 28, 224107) Go and visit for yourselves the places which I have seen.
('64', 110, 1, 29, 224165) You will have to hold your handkerchiefs to your noses.
('64', 110, 1, 30, 224221) You will have first hand knowledge of the pitiable conditions in which the Harijans are living.
('64', 110, 1, 31, 224317) I fail to understand how we have borne it so long.
('64', 110, 1, 32, 224368) Do take up this matter in right earnest and deal with it immediately.
('64', 110, 1, 33, 224438) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 15 7 1934

('64', 112, 1, 2, 225395) 147. SPEECH AT MEETING OF CONGRESS SOCIALISTS, AHMEDABAD 1
('64', 112, 2, 3, 225454) June 30, 1934
('64', 112, 3, 4, 225468) Gandhiji was questioned why he welcomed the formation of the Socialist Party
('64', 112, 4, 5, 225545) within the Congress while objecting to its programme.
('64', 112, 4, 6, 225599) Gandhiji replied that on
('64', 112, 5, 7, 225624) examining the programme he found that certain items of the programme could be
('64', 112, 6, 8, 225702) modified.
('64', 112, 7, 9, 225712) Regarding the question of class struggle, Gandhiji agreed that in the present
('64', 112, 8, 10, 225790) stage of society class struggle did exist.
('64', 112, 8, 11, 225833) If class struggle implied violence it was
('64', 112, 9, 12, 225875) certainly against the Congress creed.
('64', 112, 10, 13, 225913) Socialists retorted that they did accept non violence out of political expediency.
('64', 112, 11, 14, 225996) Gandhiji had no objection to such an idea of non violent class struggle, and he
('64', 112, 12, 15, 226076) would support Congressmen participating in such a struggle.
('64', 112, 13, 16, 226136) Regarding the well known Gandhiji Jawahar correspondence 2 they had
('64', 112, 14, 17, 226204) fundam ental difference between them.
('64', 112, 14, 18, 226242) His agreement to a certain extent with the idea
('64', 112, 15, 19, 226290) of divesting of vested interests did not mean confiscation of property.
('64', 112, 16, 20, 226362) Regarding the recent Bombay resolution of the Working Committee, Gandhiji said that it did not refer to bona fide non violent socialists, but to those who talk
('64', 112, 17, 21, 226522) about violently overthrowing the present capitalist order and confiscation of
('64', 112, 18, 22, 226600) property.
('64', 112, 19, 23, 226610) Gandhiji admitted that the State must regulate the use of property in a wise and just manner.
('64', 112, 19, 24, 226704) He visualized a State where such private profiteering inequities could not exist.
('64', 112, 19, 25, 226786) Their programme should be educative and organizing of masses.
('64', 112, 19, 26, 226848) Regarding their duties and rights and privileges, if this meant development of class consciousness Gandhiji would not fight shy of the term, if masses organize and take charge of State for the attainment of the socialism he had in view.
('64', 112, 19, 27, 227085) He would welcome such a consummation.
('64', 112, 20, 28, 227123) Gandhiji believed in true democracy based on functional adult franchise.
('64', 112, 20, 29, 227196) I would certainly be glad if Congress socialists gather strength and take over charge of the Congress.
('64', 112, 21, 30, 227299) The Bombay Chronicle, 1 7 1934
('64', 112, 22, 31, 227330) 1 At the Harijan Ashram, Sabarmati 2 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 14 9 1933 and “Letter from Jawaharlal Nehru”, 13 9 1933
('64', 113, 0, 1, 227458) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
