('64', 113, 7, 12, 227916) 149. DISCUSSION WITH KATHIAWAR YOUTHS 1
('64', 113, 8, 13, 227956) BHAVNAGAR, July 1, 1934
('64', 113, 9, 14, 227980) Asked why he had not put up in Harijan Ashram, Gandhiji said he was at present out to convert savarna Hindus, and it was his duty not only to accept but even seek their invitations.
('64', 113, 10, 15, 228162) One of the young men questioned the propriety of Gandhiji taking such a large party with him on tour.
('64', 113, 10, 16, 228264) Gandhiji is careful of the pennies and he is still more careful of the pounds.
('64', 113, 10, 17, 228343) When he throws letters into the waste paper basket, he is careful to save the pins and the blank half sheets.
('64', 113, 10, 18, 228453) And he is naturally still more punctilious when expenditure of large sums of money is in question.
('64', 113, 10, 19, 228552) He said some members of the party were travelling at their own expense, and the rest had their expenses paid by a friend.
('64', 113, 10, 20, 228674) No charge whatever was made on the Harijan funds.
('64', 113, 10, 21, 228724) Being a born teacher, he carried some friends with him to be trained as apprentices.
('64', 113, 10, 22, 228809) He required the assistance of others in his own work, while still others were like the blind teats of the goat, which also he tried to milk as best he might.
('64', 113, 10, 23, 228967) A Kathiawari Bania as he was, he might fairly be expected to account to himself for every pie he spent.
('64', 113, 11, 24, 229071) Referring to a description of himself in another question as a defeated General, Gandhiji said he did not know what it was to be defeated.
('64', 113, 12, 25, 229210) Questioned if he was opposed to veth (forced labour) and, if yes, what should
('64', 113, 13, 26, 229288) be done to get it abolished, Gandhiji said his whole life had been dedicated to the
('64', 113, 14, 27, 229372) 1 This and the following item are extracted from ‘‘Weekly Letter’’.
('64', 114, 0, 1, 229440) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 115
('64', 114, 1, 2, 229486) purpose of doing away with veth—first in the family, then in South Africa and later on in the mother country.
('64', 114, 1, 3, 229596) If veth was imposed on the poor, servants of the public
('64', 114, 2, 4, 229652) must take it upon themselves.
('64', 114, 3, 5, 229682) Another question related to the menace of artificial methods of birth control which has now invaded India.
('64', 114, 3, 6, 229789) Gandhiji said that the national physique was half ruined as it was, and its ruin would be complete if they were foolish enough to copy such questionable practices.
('64', 114, 4, 7, 229953) Did they stand to lose anything if religion was destroyed, was one more poser.
('64', 114, 4, 8, 230032) Gandhiji answered that religion was the foundation upon which the world edifice was supported, and it would be dashed to the ground if the foundation was undermined.
('64', 114, 5, 9, 230198) The last question was whether they should not abolish the institution of the States.
('64', 114, 5, 10, 230283) Gandhiji said that as a satyagrahi he sought not to destroy but to transumute them into instruments of service.
('64', 114, 5, 11, 230395) There was nothing intrinsically bad about the institution itself.
('64', 114, 6, 12, 230461) Replying to other questions Gandhiji said that he had already established institutions wherein youths could work, but it was not his fault if they allowed themselves to die and that Kathiawari youths merely wanted to talk and did not want to do serious work.
('64', 114, 6, 13, 230720) If they were not satisfied with his programme of khadi and untouchability, he said they could better start new programmes and new institutions.
('64', 114, 6, 14, 230864) I want to fight a non violent battle.
('64', 114, 6, 15, 230902) If you are interested you work with me or else find out a new programme for yourselves.
('64', 114, 7, 16, 230990) In answer to other questions, Gandhiji said he never believed that he was defeated in his fight.
('64', 114, 7, 17, 231087) Had they ever heard a defeated man being welcomed in such a way and travelling at this old age for Harijan work with such zeal?
('64', 114, 7, 18, 231215) Harijan, 20 7 1934; also The Bombay Chronicle, 3 7 1934
('64', 114, 8, 19, 231271) 150. SPEECH TO HARIJANS, BHAVNAGAR
('64', 114, 9, 20, 231306) June 1, 1934
('64', 114, 10, 21, 231319) In the afternoon Gandhiji visited the Vankarvas near Ruvapari.
('64', 114, 10, 22, 231382) This quarter is far from the city, so that the vankars 2 do not receive adequate police protection and
('64', 114, 11, 23, 231485) are put to considerable inconvenience in the pursuit of their occupations, as well as in their dealings with the city.
('64', 114, 11, 24, 231604) It has long been under contemplation to remove this quarter to a more commodious site, and it may be hoped that the matter would be expedited, and the removal carried out at an early date.
('64', 114, 11, 25, 231793) The vankars should also be
('64', 114, 12, 26, 231820) invested with occupancy rights in the land they built upon, so that they might no
('64', 114, 13, 27, 231902) 1 What follows is reproduced from The Bombay Chronicle.
('64', 114, 14, 28, 231958) 2 Weavers
('64', 115, 0, 1, 231968) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 115, 1, 2, 232010) longer be liable to be shifted from place to place.
('64', 115, 1, 3, 232062) If a good locality is selected for Harijan quarters, Harijans will learn to observe the laws of cleanliness, as they will come in close with the savarnas.
('64', 115, 1, 4, 232217) But the Harijans, too, owe a duty to themselves.
('64', 115, 2, 5, 232266) they give up liquor and carrion and keep their person, clothes and sorroundings clean, they will help the reformer to break down the barrier which now divides them from the rest of the community.
('64', 115, 3, 6, 232462) Harijan, 20 7 1934
('64', 115, 4, 7, 232481) 151. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BHAVNAGAR 1
('64', 115, 5, 8, 232524) July 1, 1934 I thank you for the purse that you have given for Harijan work on behalf of Kathiawar.
('64', 115, 5, 9, 232624) We have so very little faith in Harijan work, and especially in such work among Kathiawaris, that even the resolve to collect Rs. 25,000 seemed very big to you.
('64', 115, 5, 10, 232785) You thought you would hardly be able to collect that much and, if you fell short, a few of you would add three or four thousand each and thus you hoped to collect Rs. 30,000 in all.
('64', 115, 5, 11, 232967) That seems a very big amount to you and that is why you have applauded it.
('64', 115, 5, 12, 233042) I am not much impressed.
('64', 115, 5, 13, 233067) You must have thought poorly of the contributions from other cities of Kathiawar when the figures were read out to you.
('64', 115, 5, 14, 233187) Only Rs. 203 from Wankaner?
('64', 115, 5, 15, 233215) And that too was not from all the people.
('64', 115, 5, 16, 233257) Only two or three persons had contributed that sum.
('64', 115, 5, 17, 233309) The same is the case with Morvi.
('64', 115, 5, 18, 233342) There are so many first class States in Kathiawar, and innumerable other States too.
('64', 115, 5, 19, 233427) Nor are kathiawaris beggers.
('64', 115, 5, 20, 233456) They are an enterprising people and are spread out in many parts.
('64', 115, 5, 21, 233522) But those who approach them for contributions do so with diffidence, and, therefore, the others also feel disinclined to give.
('64', 115, 5, 22, 233649) We rarely come across people who offer contributions on their own.
('64', 115, 5, 23, 233716) What is Rs. 30,000 compared to the importance of Harijan work?
('64', 115, 5, 24, 233779) It is true that even if we had collected three lakhs, money alone would not have been enough for eradicating untouchability.
('64', 115, 5, 25, 233904) For that the hearts of caste Hindus have to be touched.
('64', 115, 5, 26, 233960) Only then would that demon perish.
('64', 115, 5, 27, 233995) Those who look upon untouchability as God cannot but worship it.
('64', 115, 5, 28, 234060) It will perish in no time if the hearts of such people change.
('64', 115, 5, 29, 234123) Its end is bound to come even in spite of them, but Hindu dharma or caste Hindus will not get credit for
('64', 115, 6, 30, 234228) 1 This a”Notes” sub title Communal Representation” peared under the title ‘‘Limits of Untouchability’’.
('64', 116, 0, 1, 234332) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 117
('64', 116, 1, 2, 234378) When Harijans themselves are so awakened that they would not tolerate their present condition even for a moment, untouchability is bound to disappear.
('64', 116, 1, 3, 234529) But we shall not get credit for that.
('64', 116, 1, 4, 234567) We have, therefore, to accomplish the Herculean task of humbly reasoning with those who worship untouchability and convincing them that it is no God but a demon.
('64', 116, 1, 5, 234729) If we can do this much, we shall progress in our aim.
('64', 116, 1, 6, 234783) Wherever I go, I meet sanatanists and try to reason with them.
('64', 116, 1, 7, 234846) I know that there are sanatanists in Bhavnagar too.
('64', 116, 1, 8, 234898) There is nothing surprising in this.
('64', 116, 1, 9, 234935) Can there be any place without sanatanists?
('64', 116, 1, 10, 234979) I knew something about the sanatanists of Bhavnagar because a leaflet was published by them and some literature was sent to me too.
('64', 116, 1, 11, 235111) I always tell the sanatanists to think over what I say.
('64', 116, 1, 12, 235167) I will come to that point later.
('64', 116, 1, 13, 235200) At the moment I wish to put forward the sanatanists’ case before the reformers.
('64', 116, 1, 14, 235280) If the latter believe that they are superior to the sanatanists because they had awakened while the sanatanists were still sunk in darkness, they would not be able to melt their hearts.
('64', 116, 1, 15, 235466) I have good reason for saying this, if or sanatanists have complained to me.
('64', 116, 1, 16, 235543) They ask me: ‘‘Why should we come to you?
('64', 116, 1, 17, 235585) If we came, reformist newspapers would hold us up for ridicule.
('64', 116, 1, 18, 235649) They would distort what we might have said and put into our mouths statements we had never made.
('64', 116, 1, 19, 235746) And if we do not come, we stand condemned.
('64', 116, 1, 20, 235789) They will then say: ‘See, they did not go.
('64', 116, 1, 21, 235832) How could they go when they had no case ?’’ It is not that all news papers are doing this, but there is some truth in what these people say.
('64', 116, 1, 22, 235973) Some newspapers do misrepresent them.
('64', 116, 1, 23, 236011) Reformers may feel, having cited a few verses from the Manusmriti, that they had scored a victory over the sanatanists, but victory cannot be won in this way.
('64', 116, 1, 24, 236170) As we increasingly realize the greatness of the task, we should become ever more humble and should even feel greater respect for the sanatanists.
('64', 116, 1, 25, 236316) Why feel respect for them, you will ask.
('64', 116, 1, 26, 236357) A great many of them are hypocrites, and do evil in the name of religion.
('64', 116, 1, 27, 236431) I have already referred to this at some places.
('64', 116, 1, 28, 236479) But hypocrisy will always go on in the world.
('64', 116, 1, 29, 236525) But neither I nor the reformers believe that every sanatanist is a hypocrite.
('64', 116, 1, 30, 236603) Many of the sanatanists sincerely believe that untouchability as it is practised today should continue, otherwise there would be confusion of varnas.
('64', 116, 1, 31, 236753) It is difficult for people to give up things which they have been practising for a long time.
('64', 116, 1, 32, 236847) This is true of untouchability.
('64', 116, 1, 33, 236879) Moreover, we have practised it as dharma.
('64', 116, 1, 34, 236921) Hence I request the reformers not to malign sanatanists.
('64', 116, 1, 35, 236978) Argue your case with them, but do not forsake gentleness, moderation and humility while doing so.
('64', 117, 0, 1, 237076) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 117, 1, 2, 237118) I want to put one important and simple point before the sanatanists.
('64', 117, 1, 3, 237187) The sanatanist shastris have not been able to reply to my argument that untouchability in its modern form has no sanction in any Hindu Shastra.
('64', 117, 1, 4, 237331) No one has justified it.
('64', 117, 1, 5, 237356) Many sanatanists forget this term ‘modern’.
('64', 117, 1, 6, 237400) I had once occasion to discuss the problem with very learned shastris.
('64', 117, 1, 7, 237471) They intentionally asked me about this word ‘modern’.
('64', 117, 1, 8, 237525) I said that some sort of untouchability was practised all the world over and that we, too, had been observing it.
('64', 117, 1, 9, 237639) We may not touch a dirty person or a man who was smelling of liquor.
('64', 117, 1, 10, 237708) How can we touch him?
('64', 117, 1, 11, 237730) If we tried, the foul smell from his mouth would throw us reeling back several feet away.
('64', 117, 1, 12, 237820) This sort of untouchability can be practised even as between mother and son.
('64', 117, 1, 13, 237897) But this modern form of untouchability is a demon with not twenty but a thousand arms.
('64', 117, 1, 14, 237984) It keeps far away from us five to six crores of people.
('64', 117, 1, 15, 238040) If you ask what this modern untouchability is, I would reply, if the President of your Municipality and Pattanisaheb would forgive me, that it is what we see in the Bhangi quarters of Bhavnagar.
('64', 117, 1, 16, 238235) New quarters for them were to be built within three years.
('64', 117, 1, 17, 238294) But Pattanisaheb told the Municipality today to demolish the old quarters and build new ones immediately, and offered Rs. 30,000 for the purpose.
('64', 117, 1, 18, 238440) The President has agreed.
('64', 117, 1, 19, 238466) I should not, therefore, criticize them.
('64', 117, 1, 20, 238507) If, however, you wish to see modern untouchability, visit those quarters tomorrow morning.
('64', 117, 1, 21, 238598) Go a little further also.
('64', 117, 1, 22, 238624) You need not go anywhere outside Bhavnagar.
('64', 117, 1, 23, 238668) Visit the weavers’ quarters and see how they live.
('64', 117, 1, 24, 238719) They were born untouchables and will remain so till their death !
('64', 117, 1, 25, 238785) If in this State a weaver’s son wants to study, he can do so and join a school or college.
('64', 117, 1, 26, 238876) The State may even give him free education or the Harijan Sevak Sangh may help him, and after completing his studies he may be appointed a judge.
('64', 117, 1, 27, 239022) But he would still remain an untouchable !
('64', 117, 1, 28, 239065) We would go to him for justice, but we would take a bath if he happened to touch us.
('64', 117, 1, 29, 239150) We deal out such perverted justice to six crores in the name of untouchability.
('64', 117, 1, 30, 239230) Shall I show you still further what modern untouchability means?
('64', 117, 1, 31, 239295) The Manusmriti does not define an ‘untouchable’.
('64', 117, 1, 32, 239344) Or let us say the Government’s Census Report is our Manusmriti in this respect.
('64', 117, 1, 33, 239424) You have decided those born untouchables will remain so all their life.
('64', 117, 1, 34, 239496) But the Census Report says that there can be a change in their status.
('64', 117, 1, 35, 239567) Every ten years when the census is made, a great many people cease to be untouchables and many others become untouchables.
('64', 117, 1, 36, 239690) This is modern untouchability!
('64', 117, 1, 37, 239721) There may be some sanatanists here in this meeting.
('64', 117, 1, 38, 239773) If they do
('64', 118, 0, 1, 239784) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 119
('64', 118, 1, 2, 239830) not know the Shastras, let them go to others learned in them and tell them that I want them to show me if there is any sanction for modern untouchability in the Shastras.
('64', 118, 1, 3, 240001) I do not say this out of pride.
('64', 118, 1, 4, 240033) I have studied the Shastras and have found in them no sanction for untouchability.
('64', 118, 1, 5, 240116) I am not a pandit.
('64', 118, 1, 6, 240135) My knowledge of Sanskrit is very limited.
('64', 118, 1, 7, 240177) I have to take the help of translations and commentaries.
('64', 118, 1, 8, 240235) I, therefore, do not claim to be learned in the Shastras.
('64', 118, 1, 9, 240293) I cannot argue about their meanings.
('64', 118, 1, 10, 240330) When I was asked to do so, I replied that I was a simple man and could not argue about the meanings of the Shastras, and that it was for them to explain them to me.
('64', 118, 1, 11, 240495) I claim to be a votary of truth, and I wish to die trying to discover it, and pray to God to give me such strength.
('64', 118, 1, 12, 240611) Such a man is telling you that you have no sanction for this modern form of untouchability in the Shastras.
('64', 118, 1, 13, 240719) If anyone can show the contrary and if I feel that it is true, then I would readily admit it.
('64', 118, 1, 14, 240813) I have written and explained a number of times how I interpret the meaning of the Shastras.
('64', 118, 1, 15, 240905) If a teacher is not able to know the limitations of a student, or a man of knowledge those of an inquirer, then no heartbond can be established between them.
('64', 118, 1, 16, 241063) Sanatanists, therefore, should understand my limitations.
('64', 118, 1, 17, 241121) I have explained to the reformers how they should be gentle and humble towards the sanatanists, and I have asked the latter to understand what I am doing.
('64', 118, 1, 18, 241276) There is also the bug bear of temple entry.
('64', 118, 1, 19, 241320) I have not thrown open any temple without the consent of the public, and that too of the temple going public.
('64', 118, 1, 20, 241430) I did not include the votes of Arya Samajists, Harijans and those who did not believe in temples.
('64', 118, 1, 21, 241528) I counted the votes only of those who visited temples with sincere faith and threw open the temples only after ascertaining their support.
('64', 118, 1, 22, 241667) I have thrown open many temples in that manner and have received no complaints for having done so.
('64', 118, 1, 23, 241766) I see nothing wrong in throwing open temples thus.
('64', 118, 1, 24, 241817) So far as it lies in my power, I would not let a temple be thrown open if people going to that particular temple did not wish it and at present reformers do listen to me.
('64', 118, 1, 25, 241988) I do not want even the Temple entry Bill which has been introduced in the Central Legislative Assembly if the Hindu members of the Assembly do not accept it.
('64', 118, 1, 26, 242146) I do not want the Bill to be passed forcibly.
('64', 118, 1, 27, 242192) I consider myself a sanatanists.
('64', 118, 1, 28, 242225) I want to get the Bill passed in a manner consistent with this claim.
('64', 118, 1, 29, 242295) I do not take votes about the Bill in public meetings because it involves subtleties of Shastras and law.
('64', 118, 1, 30, 242401) The common man cannot understand them.
('64', 118, 1, 31, 242440) It is such a complicated matter that only lawyers and shastris can understand it.
('64', 118, 1, 32, 242522) I believe I possess the ability to simplify a complicated problem and explain it to the
('64', 119, 0, 1, 242610) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 119, 1, 2, 242652) common man, but I do not find it possible to do so in the case of this Bill.
('64', 119, 1, 3, 242729) That is why I have not taken votes in any meeting regarding the pros and cons of the Bill.
('64', 119, 1, 4, 242820) Of course the common man can decide whether or not such a Bill should be passed.
('64', 119, 1, 5, 242901) Representatives of the Hindu community had, on behalf of the community, taken a pledge in Bombay in September 1932 that henceforth they would not recognize the practice of untouchability in Hindu society.
('64', 119, 1, 6, 243106) It was also stated in that resolution that Harijans had equal rights with the caste Hindus in regard to the use of wells and dharmashalas and access to public institutions, including public temples.
('64', 119, 1, 7, 243305) It was further stated in it that when we got power in our hands we would pass legislation to this effect and would do so even now if it was possible.
('64', 119, 1, 8, 243455) The reference to legislation was made because it is not possible to progress in this matter without changing the law.
('64', 119, 1, 9, 243573) We have got to remove the obstacle that is lying like a mountain in our way.
('64', 119, 1, 10, 243650) Still I want to clear the misunderstanding that prevails regarding this Bill.
('64', 119, 1, 11, 243728) A charge has been levelled against me concerning it and by no less a person than Lavate, a public worker and yogi has been serving the people for many years.
('64', 119, 1, 12, 243886) He said in a public meeting in Poona that I wanted to get the Bill passed with the help of the votes of Muslims and Christians.
('64', 119, 1, 13, 244014) I laughed at this and wondered how a man like Lavate could believe such a thing.
('64', 119, 1, 14, 244095) He had just believed what he was told.
('64', 119, 1, 15, 244134) I opened his eyes and told him that what he believed was not true, and that the conditions regarding the Bill had been published in Harijan.
('64', 119, 2, 16, 244275) And now one last point.
('64', 119, 2, 17, 244299) You have recounted in your statement what work you had done.
('64', 119, 2, 18, 244360) It is all right so long as we do not go too closely into it.
('64', 119, 2, 19, 244421) There is nothing to feel proud of, if we take all the work done in Kathiawar into account.
('64', 119, 2, 20, 244512) If you want compliments for the work done, I will pay them, but with reservation.
('64', 119, 2, 21, 244594) You have achieved nothing great.
('64', 119, 2, 22, 244627) How is it that an enterprising people like the Kathiawaris are so lethargic in this work?
('64', 119, 2, 23, 244717) the enterprising among you do not observe untouchability.
('64', 119, 2, 24, 244775) Then why are they so negligent about this work?
('64', 119, 2, 25, 244823) I saw today a woman who was walking with the help of crutches in place of one leg.
('64', 119, 2, 26, 244906) In reply to my question, she said that the leg had got a gangrene and had to be amputated, and that if that had not been done the gangrene would have spread to the whole body.
('64', 119, 2, 27, 245082) Untouchability is a gangrenous limb of Hindu society and if measures are not taken to remove it the society would become crippled.
('64', 119, 2, 28, 245213) And a crippled society cannot go on like that, so that it will ultimately perish.
('64', 119, 3, 29, 245295) 1 Vide “Notes” sub title Communal Representation”
('64', 120, 0, 1, 245345) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 121
('64', 120, 1, 2, 245391) Can dharma be preserved if we cut off one of its limbs?
('64', 120, 1, 3, 245447) All the limbs of dharma are inseparable from one another.
('64', 120, 1, 4, 245505) Just as, if one brick is removed from an arch, the whole of it will collapse, so also if one limb of dharma perishes, if one brick from the structure gets loose and falls, the whole will collapse.
('64', 120, 1, 5, 245702) We are so much engrossed in other things that we do not see how backward our Hindu society is.
('64', 120, 1, 6, 245797) I for one see that.
('64', 120, 1, 7, 245817) But let no one deduce from this that I want Hindus to become superior to Muslims.
('64', 120, 1, 8, 245899) I have said several times that if the Hindus do this much self purification, then they will get whatever they want and we will be able to end the enmity which exists between Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Parsis.
('64', 120, 1, 9, 246113) So wonderful a thing is this.
('64', 120, 1, 10, 246143) It is life giving and not life destroying.
('64', 120, 1, 11, 246186) But this will be possible only if all Harijan workers are pure.
('64', 120, 1, 12, 246250) If their hearts have not become pure and they have not become selfless, they will not be able to serve dharma.
('64', 120, 1, 13, 246361) If such workers arise in Kathiawar, the tiger or, say, the demon of untouchability that flourishes here, is bound to perish.
('64', 120, 1, 14, 246486) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 8 7 1934
('64', 120, 2, 15, 246526) 152. LETTER TO N. C. KELKAR 1
('64', 120, 3, 16, 246556) July 2, 1934
('64', 120, 4, 17, 246569) DEAR MR. KELKAR 2, The unusual demand upon my time is my excuse for delay in replying to your letter of 22nd June last.
('64', 120, 4, 18, 246689) Instead of dealing directly with the points raised by you I propose to define my own policy regarding the Indian States.
('64', 120, 4, 19, 246810) The policy of non interference in the affairs of the States that the Congress has followed is wise and sound.
('64', 120, 4, 20, 246920) The States are independent entities under the British law.
('64', 120, 4, 21, 246979) That part of India which is described as British has no more power to shape the policy of the States than it has, say, that of Afghanistan or Ceylon.
('64', 120, 4, 22, 247129) I wish it were otherwise but I recognize my importance in the matter.
('64', 120, 4, 23, 247199) India of the States is undoubtedly an integral part of geographical India.
('64', 120, 4, 24, 247274) But that carries us no further than where we stand today.
('64', 120, 4, 25, 247332) Portuguese and French India are also an integral part of geographical India but we are powerless to shape the course of events there.
('64', 120, 4, 26, 247466) We enrol members from the States in the Congress.
('64', 120, 4, 27, 247516) We receive
('64', 120, 5, 28, 247527) 1 The letter was in reply to the addressee’s dated June 22, 1934; vide “Resolution on White Paper and Communal Award” 2 President, All India States’ People’s Conference
('64', 121, 0, 1, 247696) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 121, 1, 2, 247738) considerable assistance from them.
('64', 121, 1, 3, 247773) It is not want of appreciation or will that compels our non interference.
('64', 121, 1, 4, 247847) It is our helplessness.
('64', 121, 1, 5, 247871) It is my conviction that any attempt on the part of the Congress at interference can only damage the cause of the people in the States.
('64', 121, 1, 6, 248007) But there is nothing to prevent us from urging the States to adopt a certain policy.
('64', 121, 1, 7, 248092) I am of opinion that whatever we are able to accomplish in British India is bound to affect the States.
('64', 121, 1, 8, 248196) I would like the States to grant autonomy to their subjects and would like the Princes to regard themselves as, and be in fact, trustees for the people over whom they rule, drawing for themselves only a small and definite percentage of the income.
('64', 121, 1, 9, 248444) I have certainly not lost hope that the Princes will deem it a pride to become real trustees of their people.
('64', 121, 1, 10, 248554) I do not seek to destroy their status.
('64', 121, 1, 11, 248593) I believe in the conversion of individuals and societies.
('64', 121, 1, 12, 248651) What I said at the Round Table was in the nature of an appeal made to the Princes.
('64', 121, 1, 13, 248734) It certainly did not imply that whether they listened to the appeal or not, the Congress would enter the federation.
('64', 121, 1, 14, 248851) I had no authority to bind the Congress to any such thing.
('64', 121, 1, 15, 248910) The Congress entering the federation had to depend upon many other circumstances beyond the attitude of the Princes.
('64', 121, 1, 16, 249027) If ever federation comes, it will surely depend on mutual adjustment.
('64', 121, 1, 17, 249097) I hope I have covered all the points you have raised.
('64', 121, 1, 18, 249151) If I have not, please write to me again.
('64', 121, 1, 19, 249192) I have written this under great pressure of work.
('64', 121, 2, 20, 249242) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SHRI N. C. KELKAR ‘‘KESARI’’ OFFICE POONA CITY

('64', 125, 5, 11, 254937) 158. LETTER TO U. RAJAGOPALA KRISHNAIYYA
('64', 125, 6, 12, 254978) July 2, 1934
('64', 125, 7, 13, 254991) BHAI KRISHNAIYYA, Here are the replies to your queries : 1. There is no doubt that a union of dharma and artha is possible for an individual, the society and the nation.
('64', 125, 7, 14, 255161) But it is almost impossible to say when it might be achieved.
('64', 125, 7, 15, 255223) 2. My writings about non attachment to the result are an outcome of personal experience not on one occasion but many.
('64', 125, 7, 16, 255341) Even a hard working yet hungry farmer can attain self realization.
('64', 125, 7, 17, 255408) The wise men go to the length of saying that self realization though not impossible is certainly very hard to achieve for the man endowed with the three assets, that of wealth, health and intellect.
('64', 125, 7, 18, 255607) 3. An all pervading, conscious Power fills our universe which we call God.
('64', 125, 7, 19, 255682) We have to offer to it worship.
('64', 125, 7, 20, 255714) Even the fact that that power does not fulfil all our desires should cause us no concern.
('64', 125, 7, 21, 255804) 4. The Gita cannot be interpreted as one pleases, it has to be interpreted in accordance with rules of grammar, etc.
('64', 125, 7, 22, 255921) 5. The meaning of being transformed into God is clear enough.
('64', 125, 7, 23, 255983) It means a son is not content till he becomes like his father.
('64', 125, 8, 24, 256046) MOHANDAS GANDHI
('64', 125, 9, 25, 256062) From Hindi: C. W. 9238. Courtesy: U. Rajagopala Krishnaiyya

('64', 126, 3, 7, 256548) 160. SPEECH ON STATE GOSHALA, BHAVNAGAR 2
('64', 126, 4, 8, 256590) July 3, 1934 Before taking leave of Bhavnagar I cannot but make a passing reference to the State goshala, which I had the privilege to visit in company with my old friend, Swami Anand.
('64', 126, 4, 9, 256775) The goshala has a fine herd of Gir cattle, and it has a four year old bull which, according to the Maharajasaheb, no mean judge of cattle, is the finest animal of the kind he had seen in Kathiawar.
('64', 126, 4, 10, 256973) The State is doing very good service by maintaining this farm, but I hope it will not rest content with it, but also chalk out and work out a policy of cattle improvement in villages by placing a studbull in each village, castrating all other bulls whatever and, in the case of people letting loose a bull on religious grounds, insisting that it shall be first class animal and, if it is not, stopping the dedication altogether.

('64', 127, 1, 2, 257866) 162. LETTER TO MRIDULA SARABHAI
('64', 127, 2, 3, 257898) July 5, 1934
('64', 127, 3, 4, 257911) MRIDULA, I had received your letter.
('64', 127, 3, 5, 257948) I am surprised that even you have been led into an error.
('64', 127, 3, 6, 258006) You must have read the letter addressed to Bhogilal.
('64', 127, 3, 7, 258059) To say that swadeshi today is a fraud is not to condemn the people engaged in that work.
('64', 127, 3, 8, 258148) It is a warning to them.
('64', 127, 3, 9, 258173) I had even given the history of swadeshi in that conversation.
('64', 127, 3, 10, 258236) I have often said that cow protection today is a fraud and that is my belief.
('64', 127, 3, 11, 258314) And yet many pure hearted persons are engaged in that activity.
('64', 127, 3, 12, 258378) Even my colleagues in the field are in it.
('64', 127, 3, 13, 258421) I do not consider them knaves.
('64', 127, 3, 14, 258452) I have shown the way to genuine cow protection as against spurious cow protection.
('64', 127, 3, 15, 258535) You must be aware of it.
('64', 127, 3, 16, 258560) I have referred to the cow protection societies as cow devouring societies in Hind Swaraj.
('64', 127, 3, 17, 258651) Today also I think the same about them.
('64', 127, 3, 18, 258691) But I know that many men and women engaged in that fraudulent activity are extremely purehearted.
('64', 127, 3, 19, 258789) It is the same about the swadeshi fraud of today.
('64', 127, 3, 20, 258839) You and other colleagues are not knaves but have been innocently entangled in it.
('64', 127, 3, 21, 258921) It is my attempt to redeem them from it.
('64', 127, 3, 22, 258962) The result is my new concept of swadeshi.
('64', 127, 3, 23, 259004) Have you understood the point now?
('64', 127, 3, 24, 259039) If you have understood, remove the pain of those who have been hurt by my words.
('64', 127, 4, 25, 259120) Blessings from BAPU
('64', 127, 5, 26, 259140) From the Gujarati original: C. W. 11190. Courtesy: Sarabhai Foundation

('64', 127, 7, 28, 259251) July 5, 1934
('64', 127, 8, 29, 259264) Gandhiji reached Ajmer at night on the 4th, and on the 5th he addressed a women’s meeting the first thing in the morning.
('64', 127, 8, 30, 259386) He said he would not make any elaborate argument before them.
('64', 127, 8, 31, 259448) Everyone would agree that we are subject to the law of love.

('64', 127, 8, 35, 259954) So also, if quite a number of dirty savarna children could attend the public schools with impunity, was it right to exclude

('64', 128, 2, 5, 260393) 164. INTERVIEW TO HARIJAN SEVAKS
('64', 128, 3, 6, 260426) AJMER, July 5, 1934
('64', 128, 4, 7, 260446) In the course of his conversation with Harijan servants, Gandhiji carefully defined the conditions of Harijan service.
('64', 128, 4, 8, 260565) He wanted the workers to serve the Harijans in all sincerity.
('64', 128, 4, 9, 260627) This service was its own reward, and it had no selfish or political motive behind it whatever.
('64', 128, 4, 10, 260722) Their sole aim was the purification of religion.
('64', 128, 4, 11, 260771) There was no room in the movement for those who approached the question from a political standpoint, and they must leave it at the earliest opportunity, as their continuance in it was fraught with great injury to the cause.
('64', 128, 4, 12, 260995) They could never hope to convert savarna Hindus, if they cherished any political aims.
('64', 128, 4, 13, 261082) They alone should participate in the movement who accepted the principles of truth and non violence and who believed in temples as in integral feature of Hinduism.
('64', 128, 4, 14, 261246) Harijan, 20 7 1934

('64', 129, 1, 4, 262864) He could not bear with violence even in politics; much less could be brook it in religion.

('64', 129, 2, 7, 263140) Upon this Gandhiji said that it was an exhibition of gross discourtesy.

('64', 129, 2, 9, 263338) If they were not here prepared to hear the Pandit, it meant that they were not prepared to hear him either.
('64', 129, 2, 10, 263446) He never claimed infallibility for himself.
('64', 129, 2, 11, 263490) On the other hand, he had confessed to Himalayan blunders.

('64', 129, 2, 18, 264247) If so, he would have lived his life before them in vain.
('64', 129, 2, 19, 264304) They would kill the great movement, whereas if they restrained themselves untouchability would die with him.

('64', 134, 2, 5, 272413) 175. SPEECH TO SIND HARIJAN WORKERS, KARACHI 1
('64', 134, 3, 6, 272460) July 8, 1934
('64', 134, 4, 7, 272473) At Karachi, on the 8th instant, Gandhiji met the Harijan workers of Sind, who
('64', 134, 5, 8, 272551) complained that Kabulis who had lent money to Harijans harassed them a good deal
('64', 134, 6, 9, 272632) and refused to accept payment even when their exorbitant claim as regards the
('64', 134, 7, 10, 272710) principal and the interest was admitted in full.
('64', 134, 7, 11, 272759) Gandhiji advised that, in dealing with
('64', 134, 8, 12, 272798) these money lenders, they should seek the good offices of godfearing Mussalmans in
('64', 134, 9, 13, 272881) the first instance.
('64', 134, 9, 14, 272901) But their main work lay in so educating the Harijans that they
('64', 134, 10, 15, 272964) would cease to borrow money altogether for unproductive purposes and give up vices
('64', 134, 11, 16, 273047) like drink and gambling.
('64', 134, 11, 17, 273072) And when they did borrow, six per cent was the maximum
('64', 134, 12, 18, 273127) interest they should pay.
('64', 134, 12, 19, 273153) In Tharparkar, there are about 5,000 Bhils and Meghwads,
('64', 134, 13, 20, 273210) the original inhabitants and peasant proprietors of the district, who are fast losing
('64', 134, 14, 21, 273296) their lands and being reduced to the status of landless labourers and stand badly in
('64', 134, 15, 22, 273381) need of legislative protection.
('64', 134, 15, 23, 273413) Gandhiji said they might try to get such legislation
('64', 134, 16, 24, 273466) passed, but meanwhile a band of earnest workers must bury themselves in the heart of
('64', 134, 17, 25, 273551) this backward tract and dedicate their lives to its service.
('64', 134, 17, 26, 273612) Harijan, 27 7 1934
('64', 134, 18, 27, 273631) 176. SPEECH TO BUSINESSMEN, KARACHI 2
('64', 134, 19, 28, 273669) July 8, 1934 The Chariman has rightly observed that of late I have very little time for activities not directly connected with Harijan work; or, I may be said to have no time at all.
('64', 134, 19, 29, 273852) It is also ture that after such an extensive tour and the experience of walking in Utkal, I find myself rather exhausted mentally.
('64', 134, 19, 30, 273983) Now I am only hoping that the month of July will pass off without trouble so that I can rest my mind a little.
('64', 134, 19, 31, 274094) In this frame of mind I was not inclined in the beginning to accept the Chairman’s invitation to visit this place.
('64', 134, 19, 32, 274209) But I could not decline the invitation when I came to know that the Chairman of this Association is also the Chairman of the Harijan Sevak Sangh here, and carries on the Sangh’s activities admirably well.
('64', 134, 20, 33, 274414) 1 The speech is extracted from ‘‘Weekly Letter”.
('64', 134, 20, 34, 274463) 2 This appeared under the title “To the Businessmen of Karachi”.
('64', 135, 0, 1, 274528) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 135, 1, 2, 274570) As it is, I have always had good relations with everyone in India, including businessmen and other rich people.
('64', 135, 1, 3, 274682) I have been constantly receiving financial help from them for the poor in the country, for Daridranarayana, for Harijans and others.
('64', 135, 1, 4, 274815) But I feel it is necessary to make it clear that although I am friendly with the princes, officers, business men and the rich, I never forget that I am a representative of the workers.
('64', 135, 1, 5, 275000) It is my constant prayer to God that I may not, in any way disgrace myself as representative of workers, and, I may not ask anything for myself from the rich class.
('64', 135, 1, 6, 275165) I believe that I have led fifty years of my public life in this spirit.
('64', 135, 1, 7, 275237) I do believe that businessmen, the wealthy men and princes are inseparable limbs of India.
('64', 135, 1, 8, 275328) My duty does not demand that I should destroy one of these limbs in order to serve Daridranarayana.
('64', 135, 1, 9, 275428) My experience of many years has strengthened my belief that even if it is possible to liquidate these classes, Daridranarayana is not going to benefit by it.
('64', 135, 1, 10, 275586) What I desire and what is uppermost in my thoughts and dreams is that I should help as much as is possible in bringing about unity among all these classes, and devote my utmost energy to this cause.
('64', 135, 1, 11, 275785) It is also my experience that so far I have not by such activities harmed Daridranarayana.
('64', 135, 1, 12, 275876) I have seen that when I approach the poor, they accept me as one of them and shower affection on me.
('64', 135, 1, 13, 275977) And even now, I shall do for them whatever is possible.
('64', 135, 1, 14, 276033) Having laid the foundation stone of this building 1, I take it that you would not turn me away empty handed whenever I approach you for the much needed help for the Daridranarayana.
('64', 135, 1, 15, 276215) I presume that, as representatives of the Indian business community, you would not resort to dubious trade practices, would not exploit Daridranarayana and would see that their rights are not violated at your hands.
('64', 135, 1, 16, 276431) I expect that you would not indulge in any trade which may harm Daridrana rayana.
('64', 135, 1, 17, 276513) I know that all businessmen in India do not carry on their business in this spirit.
('64', 135, 1, 18, 276597) I also knowthat all the rich people do not use their wealth as if it really belonged to the poor.
('64', 135, 1, 19, 276695) In spite of that I am sure the number of rich persons who desire to be the trustees of their wealth is increasing.
('64', 135, 1, 20, 276810) They are striving hard and also succeeding in their efforts.
('64', 135, 1, 21, 276871) If we treat these rich people with decency, they would fulfil the expectations we have of them.
('64', 135, 1, 22, 276967) What benevolence would not teach them today, selfishness would teach them tomorrow.
('64', 135, 1, 23, 277051) Experience shows that altruism and self interest can be blended in trade.

('64', 137, 1, 2, 279358) 177. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KARACHI
('64', 137, 2, 3, 279397) July 8, 1934
('64', 137, 3, 4, 279410) At the public meeting in the evening, 30,000 people, including 5,000 ladies,
('64', 137, 4, 5, 279487) had turned up to hear Gandhiji, but they were rather disappointed, as the loudspeakers
('64', 137, 5, 6, 279574) failed and Swami Krishnanand 1 had to take their place as a human substitute.
('64', 137, 5, 7, 279652) Referring
('64', 137, 6, 8, 279662) to the Harijan quarters he had inspected, Gandhiji said he was deeply pained to see the chawls in Ranchhod lines, and he expected the Municipality to see that they no
('64', 137, 7, 9, 279829) longer disfigured the fair face of the city of Karachi.
('64', 137, 7, 10, 279885) Besides this, there were three
('64', 137, 8, 11, 279916) more places which peremptorily demanded improvement.
('64', 137, 8, 12, 279969) It did not redound to
('64', 137, 9, 13, 279991) Karachi’s credit that a single Harijan within its limits should be compelled to live in a
('64', 137, 10, 14, 280081) house which the tallest of its citizens would not gladly occupy.
('64', 137, 10, 15, 280146) The citizens,
('64', 137, 11, 16, 280160) therefore, should continuously press this matter upon the Municipality’s attention
('64', 137, 12, 17, 280243) until the remedy suited to each case was applied.
('64', 137, 13, 18, 280293) A band of sincere workers armed with prayer and purity as weapons
('64', 137, 14, 19, 280359) was what was needed for the work.
('64', 137, 14, 20, 280393) No caste distinctions should ever exist.
('64', 137, 14, 21, 280434) He desired
('64', 137, 15, 22, 280445) unity between communities wherein lay India’s salvation.
('64', 137, 15, 23, 280502) He requested the public
('64', 137, 16, 24, 280526) to nurse no grievance against sanatanists.
('64', 137, 16, 25, 280569) Love, persuasion and no force should be
('64', 137, 17, 26, 280609) applied in converting them to his viewpoint.
('64', 137, 17, 27, 280654) He expressed his inability to make a
('64', 137, 18, 28, 280691) long speech amidst the din of the unruly mob.

('64', 143, 0, 1, 288833) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 143, 1, 2, 288875) 187. STATEMENT ON FAST 1
('64', 143, 2, 3, 288900) [July 10, 1934 ] 2
('64', 143, 3, 4, 288919) Inquiry made by me into the unfortunate incident at Ajmer resulting in the cut received by Pandit Lalnath on the head shows that the black flag demonstration enraged those who saw the processionists, and, according to Pandit Lalnath, the public, which included volunteers, seized the flags and trampled them under foot.
('64', 143, 3, 5, 289239) A scuffle ensued in which Pandit Lalnath received the injury mentioned.
('64', 143, 3, 6, 289311) Happily, none of the other demonstrators received injuries worth the name.
('64', 143, 3, 7, 289386) But the guilt is enhanced by the fact that those in charge of the volunteers had specific insturctions to see that the black flag demonstrators were fully protected from molestation by the public.
('64', 143, 3, 8, 289583) It is no answer in defence that Pandit Lalnath and his party came in advance of the time appointed.
('64', 143, 3, 9, 289683) In my opinion, responsible men should have been posted at all points to afford protection to the demonstrators, and notices should have been put up at the meeting ground, warning the public against interfering with them in any shape or form.
('64', 143, 3, 10, 289925) That precaution was not taken and the pledge given to Pandit Lalnath, that he and his party would be free from molestation when they made the demonstration, was broken.
('64', 143, 3, 11, 290094) The pledge was given by me in the full faith that the captain of the volunteers was willing and able to carry it out.
('64', 143, 3, 12, 290212) I have no doubt he was a willing partner to the pledge.
('64', 143, 3, 13, 290268) That he was unable to redeem the pledge was quite clear.
('64', 143, 3, 14, 290325) But there can be no doubt that the final responsibility rests with me.
('64', 143, 3, 15, 290396) Indeed, no pledge was necessary.
('64', 143, 3, 16, 290429) In a movement claimed to be purely religious, non violence on the part of the public sympathizing with the movement must be presumed.
('64', 143, 3, 17, 290563) If I mentioned the pledge, I have done so to enhance the magnitude of the guilt and demonstrate the greater necessity of public penance on my part.
('64', 143, 3, 18, 290711) Pandit Lalnath always warned me that my persistence in the movement must result in widespread violence on the part of the symapthizing public.
('64', 143, 3, 19, 290854) I did not share his fear, nor do I share it now, in spite of his ability to show stray cases of violence done to black flag demonstrators.
('64', 143, 3, 20, 290993) But it is necessary for me to emphasize the fact that the movement, which is purely religious, admits of no violence on the part
('64', 143, 4, 21, 291122) 1 This appeared under the title “Gandhiji’s Impending Fast”.
('64', 143, 4, 22, 291183) 2 Associated Press of India released the statement from Karachi on this date.
('64', 144, 0, 1, 291261) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 145
('64', 144, 1, 2, 291307) of reformers even in spite of provocations.
('64', 144, 1, 3, 291351) The movement can only succeed by appealing to reason and touching the hearts of the opponents.
('64', 144, 1, 4, 291446) This is possible only through the purity and penance of reformers.
('64', 144, 1, 5, 291513) After much searching of the heart, I have decided to impose upon myself a fast of seven days, to commence on Tuesday noon August 7th, i.e., two days after my reaching Wardha, which I expect to do on the 5th of August next.
('64', 144, 1, 6, 291736) This is the least penance I owe to Pandit Lalnath and those sanatanists whom he represents.
('64', 144, 1, 7, 291828) God willing, the Harijan tour will finish at Benares on the 2nd of August next.
('64', 144, 1, 8, 291908) It is, perhaps, fitting that the end will be signalized by a penitential fast.
('64', 144, 1, 9, 291987) May it cover all errors, conscious or unconscious, of omission or commission, of me and my co workers.
('64', 144, 1, 10, 292090) The movement will not end with the fast.
('64', 144, 1, 11, 292131) Let it open a new and cleaner chapter in this struggle for the emancipation of nearly fifty million human beings from thraldom imposed in the sacred name of religion.
('64', 144, 1, 12, 292298) Let it also be a warning to those who are in, or will join, the movement that they must approach it with clean hands and hearts free from untruth and violence in thought, word and deed.
('64', 144, 1, 13, 292484) I hope no one will feel tempted to imitate the fast.
('64', 144, 1, 14, 292537) The cause will be best served by greater dedication.
('64', 144, 2, 15, 292590) Harijan, 13 7 1934

('64', 146, 1, 2, 293994) 192. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('64', 146, 2, 3, 294029) July 10, 1934 I see nothing wrong in Rajaji’s standing on the same platform with Bhulabhai.
('64', 146, 2, 4, 294121) But it is best that, even though doing all this, he should not join the Board or enter the Assembly.
('64', 146, 2, 5, 294222) I would dissuade even those who are not confirmed non co operators from entering the Assembly.
('64', 146, 2, 6, 294317) There will be too many who will be wanting to go.
('64', 146, 2, 7, 294367) All of them will not make a good show there, nor can all get elected.
('64', 146, 2, 8, 294437) We may assume that Rajaji and Rajendrababu, when they consider it desirable to join the Board or enter the Assembly, will [surely] do so.
('64', 146, 2, 9, 294575) They are always free to do it.
('64', 146, 2, 10, 294606) On the other hand, those like you who wish to keep themselves completely out are free to do that too.
('64', 146, 2, 11, 294708) [You may be sure that] nobody will be criticized on that ground.
('64', 146, 2, 12, 294773) And even if there is some criticism, you should not mind it.
('64', 146, 2, 13, 294834) In this age now, we ought to shed all fear and not to pay too much attention to what others do or think.
('64', 146, 2, 14, 294939) People may follow me in my intellectual experiments as long as they appeal to them.
('64', 146, 2, 15, 295023) My spiritual experiments require faith.
('64', 146, 2, 16, 295063) People may follow them, as far as their faith can lead them.
('64', 146, 2, 17, 295124) Let nobody force his reason or his heart to follow me.
('64', 146, 2, 18, 295179) As you will be reading in the papers about my impending fast, I don’t write more about it here.
('64', 146, 2, 19, 295275) Its necessity should be self evident.
('64', 146, 2, 20, 295313) I got your wire.
('64', 146, 2, 21, 295330) My health will survive the ordeal.
('64', 146, 2, 22, 295365) I will come through if I don’t have to carry too heavy a burden from day to day.
('64', 146, 2, 23, 295446) Having reached dinner time, why should I have a breakfast ?
('64', 146, 2, 24, 295506) 1 Have faith.
('64', 146, 2, 25, 295520) [From Gujarati] Bapuni Prasadi, pp.

('64', 147, 1, 2, 296021) contest between one Harijan and another.
('64', 147, 1, 3, 296062) Harijans should consult among themselves and select as many worthy candidates as there were seats, and these should have a walk over.
('64', 147, 1, 4, 296196) It would do them no good if these seats, instead of furnishing opportunities for service, were looked upon as conferring privilege.
('64', 147, 2, 5, 296328) With reference to the demand put forward by some Hairjans for the reservation of a certain percentage of posts in services, Gandhiji said they would perhaps be surprised to hear that there were hardly a few lakhs of Government posts in the whole of India.
('64', 147, 2, 6, 296584) Out of these few how many could after all be held by Harijans, and what would that mean to five crores of Harijans?
('64', 147, 2, 7, 296700) Gandhiji, therefore, advised the Harijans to leave these percentages severely alone and trust merit to command attention.

('64', 147, 3, 9, 296841) 194. SPEECH AT DAYARAM JETHAMAL SIND COLLEGE, KARACHI 1
('64', 147, 4, 10, 296897) July 10, 1934 This is not my first contact with you.
('64', 147, 4, 11, 296950) My contact with students has always been intimate whether they are students of Sind or any other province.
('64', 147, 4, 12, 297057) This kind of relationship exists since I returned from South Africa.
('64', 147, 4, 13, 297126) Therefore I have confidence, based on my experience, that I have a place in the hearts of the students.
('64', 147, 4, 14, 297230) Whenever I am asked, ‘How many children do you have?’ I reply, “Innumerable, and they keep on increasing daily”; there is no fall in the number.
('64', 147, 4, 15, 297375) Some of them die; but many more are born.
('64', 147, 4, 16, 297417) Some betray me and some even run away from me.
('64', 147, 4, 17, 297464) If I count the number of those who are born, it will outnumber the total of those who have run away from me, who have betrayed me and who are dead.
('64', 147, 4, 18, 297612) Such boys and girls are first born out of their mothers’ wombs and as they have faith come to me and, having transformed their lives, are reborn.
('64', 147, 4, 19, 297758) It was for this reason that I could not decline your invitation.
('64', 147, 4, 20, 297823) You should know that at the moment my mental and physical condition is such that I would not accept any invitation.
('64', 147, 4, 21, 297939) A girl in this city is on her death bed.
('64', 147, 4, 22, 297980) She wished that I should call on her.
('64', 147, 4, 23, 298018) To her grandmother, who came with the request, I had to say “If I come to see your child, [I must go and see other] sons and daughters of mine who are ill; how can I manage to see all of them?
('64', 147, 4, 24, 298211) If I call on one, how

('64', 148, 1, 2, 298343) can I turn down the request of another ?” I have still not been able to find a way out of this dilemma.
('64', 148, 1, 3, 298447) I hardened my heart and argued to myself, ‘After all I would not be able to save her by going there.
('64', 148, 1, 4, 298548) And so I will not go.’ Nursing the sick has been my habit but I hardened my feelings and restrained myself.
('64', 148, 1, 5, 298656) If it was difficult for me to call on that girl, then it was equally difficult to come here.
('64', 148, 1, 6, 298749) It is beyond my physical and mental strength these days to go about from place to place.
('64', 148, 1, 7, 298838) Normally money tempts me; but lately I have become free to great extent even from that temptation.
('64', 148, 1, 8, 298937) I am indifferent whether I get money or not.
('64', 148, 1, 9, 298982) I shall certainly carry on this work even if I do not get money.
('64', 148, 1, 10, 299047) For, this activity is after all carried on not by me but by God.
('64', 148, 1, 11, 299112) It is beyond the power of a single individual to bring about a change of heart in millions of caste Hindus.
('64', 148, 1, 12, 299220) Man cannot acquire such power even by self purification or penance.
('64', 148, 1, 13, 299288) By these means he merely becomes an instrument in the hands of God.
('64', 148, 1, 14, 299356) He can do nothing more.
('64', 148, 1, 15, 299380) I am experiencing this every day and every moment, and that makes me more and more humble.
('64', 148, 1, 16, 299471) The world alone can say whether or not there is humility in my words and actions.
('64', 148, 1, 17, 299553) But I am humble and my humility goes on increasing, because I know and realize my mental, physical and spiritual limitations.
('64', 148, 1, 18, 299679) With this introduction I would like to tell the students, boys and girls, that humility is the primary thing to be acquired.
('64', 148, 1, 19, 299804) One who is not humble cannot put one’s learning to proper use.
('64', 148, 1, 20, 299867) What does it matter if he has obtained double first class or has stood first?
('64', 148, 1, 21, 299945) One does not achieve everything by just passing an examination.
('64', 148, 1, 22, 300009) It is possible that it may help in securing a good job or a good marriage alliance.
('64', 148, 1, 23, 300093) But, if learning is to be put to proper use, if it is to be used only for the sake of service, one should acquire more and more humility every day.
('64', 148, 1, 24, 300241) No service is possible without it.
('64', 148, 1, 25, 300276) I know quite a few students who are proud of their B. A. Hons.
('64', 148, 1, 26, 300339) or engineering degrees.
('64', 148, 1, 27, 300363) The villagers would not even bother to look at them.
('64', 148, 1, 28, 300416) They would say: “How are we concerned with degrees?
('64', 148, 1, 29, 300468) How are you going to share our troubles ?” Nowhere in the 7,00,000 Indian villages would one find an instance of someone winning the affection of the villagers because he possessed high academic degrees.
('64', 148, 1, 30, 300672) Man should not use his intelligence and spiritual power to earn his livelihood and sustain himself.
('64', 148, 1, 31, 300772) For that purpose God has provided him with hands and legs, and with these he should do some common labour and earn his bread.
('64', 148, 1, 32, 300898) Can learning be used for earning thousands of rupees?
('64', 148, 1, 33, 300952) In the past even lawyers rendered their services free of charge.
('64', 148, 1, 34, 301017) This practice is prevalent even

('64', 149, 1, 2, 301091) A barrister cannot file a suit for his fees, for, his is supposed to be a profession of service.

('64', 149, 1, 4, 301215) To which student, boy or girl, can I say that the wealth of learning is meant for service?

('64', 149, 1, 6, 301328) Here they try to imitate the Sahibs and the Parsis.

('64', 149, 1, 28, 302951) Here, the boys accept the brides only if they bring thousands of rupees and with this money they want to go to Oxford to get degrees.
('64', 149, 1, 29, 303085) The very fact that you have invited me and are presenting me a purse implies your pledge that you would work for the Harijans.

('64', 152, 3, 6, 309330) 195. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('64', 152, 4, 7, 309363) KARACHI, July 11, 1934
('64', 152, 5, 8, 309386) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, These days I cannot write to you when I propose to do so.
('64', 152, 5, 9, 309462) I commenced this letter at 5.30 a.m.
('64', 152, 5, 10, 309499) after breakfast.
('64', 152, 5, 11, 309516) Just then a Parsi lady came in with her 15 year old daughter.
('64', 152, 5, 12, 309578) The latter has won the first place in tennis in the whole of India, but she has now lost interest in worldly things.
('64', 152, 5, 13, 309695) Her interest now is all in religion.
('64', 152, 5, 14, 309732) She, therefore, urged her mother to bring her to see me.
('64', 152, 5, 15, 309789) She gave ten rupees for the Harijan Fund and has now left after obtaining my autograph.
('64', 152, 5, 16, 309877) Please do not be unhappy at the news of my fast.
('64', 152, 5, 17, 309926) It is absolutely necessary.
('64', 152, 5, 18, 309954) Large crowds come to the meetings and sanatanists are on the war path.
('64', 152, 5, 19, 310025) People do not tolerate their conduct and, therefore, trouble is bound to follow.
('64', 152, 5, 20, 310106) People will not listen to mere exhortations.
('64', 152, 5, 21, 310151) One can convey one’s message to vast masses of people only by fasting.
('64', 152, 5, 22, 310222) Crowds at the meetings are larger than ever before and it is very difficult to control them.
('64', 152, 5, 23, 310315) Seven days will pass without any difficulty.
('64', 152, 5, 24, 310360) Please don’t worry in the least.
('64', 152, 5, 25, 310393) My health is perfectly all right.
('64', 152, 5, 26, 310427) In spite of heavy pressure of work, the blood pressure remains round about 150. That should be considered very good.
('64', 152, 5, 27, 310544) The weight is 104. I shall be happy if the rest of the tour is completed without further trouble.
('64', 152, 5, 28, 310642) August will be taken up by the fast and the gradual return to normal diet.
('64', 152, 5, 29, 310717) After that as God wills.

('64', 155, 13, 16, 315318) 199. INTERVIEW TO SIND JOURNALISTS 2
('64', 155, 14, 17, 315355) KARACHI, July 11, 1934
('64', 155, 15, 18, 315378) Mr. Punniah 3 at the outset said that the reasons adduced for embarking on his new fast were not convincing and that he should not undertake another fiery ordeal close on the heels of a strenous Harijan tour.
('64', 155, 15, 19, 315587) Gandhiji replied : The movement is of tremendous importance.
('64', 155, 15, 20, 315648) Nothing but a drastic measure like fasting can meet the situation.
('64', 155, 15, 21, 315715) You can influence the mass mind not through speeches or writings but only by something which is most well understood by the masses, that is suffering, and the most acceptable method is that of fasting.
('64', 155, 16, 22, 315917) 1 These two sentences are reproduced from Pilgrimage to Freedom.
('64', 155, 16, 23, 315982) 2 The source had reproduced the interview from Sind Observer.
('64', 155, 16, 24, 316044) 3 Editor, Sind Observer, and President of Sind Journalists’ Association
('64', 156, 0, 1, 316116) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 157
('64', 156, 1, 2, 316162) repeated experience here and in South Africa has been that, when well applied, it has been the most infallible remedy.
('64', 156, 1, 3, 316281) My lot has been cast with the masses, and I have always to take work from and through them.
('64', 156, 1, 4, 316373) The only language they understand is the language of the heart, and fasting when it is utterly unselfish is the language of the heart.
('64', 156, 2, 5, 316508) Gandhiji was acquainted with the news that the Bombay Congress circles viewed with alarm his contemplated fast and Congress friends were of opinion that the strain would be too much.
('64', 156, 2, 6, 316691) Gandhiji smilingly answered : I have no such fears, and physically speaking a fast after an exhaustive tour can only benefit the person who has undertaken the tour.
('64', 156, 3, 7, 316856) But then there is the risk.
('64', 156, 3, 8, 316884) Of course, I am risking.
('64', 156, 3, 9, 316909) I am not taking this fast for its physical effect.
('64', 156, 3, 10, 316960) Physically speaking, there is some kind of risk, because my body does not require a fasting cure.
('64', 156, 3, 11, 317058) Any fast must require some risk, otherwise it has no meaning.
('64', 156, 3, 12, 317120) It must involve torture of the flesh.
('64', 156, 3, 13, 317158) The decision is irrevocable.
('64', 156, 3, 14, 317187) I announced 1 at the Ajmer meeting that I would undertake some sort of penance.
('64', 156, 3, 15, 317267) The announcement was long overdue.
('64', 156, 3, 16, 317302) I reasoned with myself and with my friends and then came to the deliberate conclusion that fasting was the only penance that I should make.
('64', 156, 3, 17, 317442) Then the question was that of duration.
('64', 156, 3, 18, 317482) I would have undertaken a longer fast.
('64', 156, 3, 19, 317521) I do not want to produce any unnec essary shocks, and therefore I did not undertake the maximum period.
('64', 156, 3, 20, 317625) Friends who at the present moment are physically near me have realized the necessity of the fast.
('64', 156, 4, 21, 317723) Does it include also Kasturba ?
('64', 156, 4, 22, 317755) It has been my rare fortune that in all such matters she has never worried me, never argued with me, and has allowed me to have my own way, although she has felt the distress.
('64', 156, 4, 23, 317931) Therefore although she is my wife, I have not hesitated to say that she is one of the bravest women I have ever met in this respect.
('64', 156, 5, 24, 318064) Mr. Punniah then asked him about his views on the Sind separation issue, over which the people of this province were greatly agitated.
('64', 156, 5, 25, 318199) Gandhiji with a significant laughter and a nod of his head remarked : Now, you are taking me out of my depths.
('64', 156, 5, 26, 318310) It is not to be answered before the 3rd of August.
('64', 156, 6, 27, 318361) But then you have been participating in political discussions.
('64', 156, 7, 28, 318424) 1 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Ajmer”, 5 7 1934
('64', 157, 0, 1, 318475) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 157, 1, 2, 318517) But it was not for public consumption.
('64', 157, 1, 3, 318556) I am glad that a reference has been now made to it, and that I got an opportunity for expressing my sorrow at the breach of confidence indulged in by some young journalists who were permitted to be present at the Congress at the Khalikdina Hall meeting.
('64', 157, 1, 4, 318810) I told them that the procee dings ought not to be reported.
('64', 157, 1, 5, 318870) I consider that it is a breach of confidence to have reported unauthorized statements, and I felt that those who broke that promise had not observed the fundamental etiquette of journalism and it was gross impropriety.
('64', 157, 1, 6, 319089) I have a fairly high notion of the journalistic profession.
('64', 157, 2, 7, 319149) Has not the Harijan movement estranged the community for natinal politics ?
('64', 157, 2, 8, 319225) Not in the slightest degree.
('64', 157, 2, 9, 319254) Because, some people have used this movement as a cloak to divert the mind of the people from real politics.
('64', 157, 2, 10, 319363) As it is well known, I don’t believe in watertight compartments.
('64', 157, 2, 11, 319428) Politics, religion, social reform, economic uplift all these form parts of a whole.
('64', 157, 3, 12, 319512) Answering critics who are of the view that Council entry was a concession to weakness and that in his heart of hearts Gandhiji had no faith in such a programme, Gandhiji said; I have no such superiority complex.

('64', 157, 4, 18, 320164) The talk then turned to the Communal Award.

('64', 161, 1, 10, 329404) Some Parsis tell me that toddy does one good rather than harm.
('64', 161, 1, 11, 329467) Some may even say that the proportion of alcohol is more in whisky and less in toddy and lesser still if the toddy is fresh.
('64', 161, 1, 12, 329592) That way even those who take beer fool themselves.
('64', 161, 1, 13, 329643) I have seen drunkenness among people who take both these.
('64', 161, 1, 14, 329701) It is not as if those who do not drink toddy are unhealthy and those who take it do not have to go to the doctors.
('64', 161, 1, 15, 329816) I have seen a whole array of medicine bottles in the houses of some Parsi friends who are habitual toddy drinkers.
('64', 161, 1, 16, 329931) So I request the Parsis and would go on requesting them till I die that they must give up this evil thing.
('64', 161, 1, 17, 330038) If the Parsis in general give up liquor, those Parsis who earn their livelihood out of it would also be convinced.
('64', 161, 1, 18, 330153) You are people with great enterprise.
('64', 161, 1, 19, 330191) If you realize that this is not a worthy occupation, you would take up something else.
('64', 161, 1, 20, 330278) I can never persuade myself to believe that the Parsi community lacks the spirit do discovery and adventure and enterprise.
('64', 161, 1, 21, 330402) You are capable of finding your way where others may not.
('64', 161, 1, 22, 330460) You have given me Rs. 352 for Harijan work.
('64', 161, 1, 23, 330504) In a way, I have no right to ask money from you for that work.
('64', 161, 1, 24, 330567) I always ask money from you for everything.
('64', 161, 1, 25, 330611) But when I take money from you for the work which is meant for the Hindus it implies something else.
('64', 161, 1, 26, 330712) The direct objective of this activity is to wipe out untouchability which involves 50 million people.
('64', 161, 1, 27, 330814) This is such a great corroding factor in Hinduism that it has penetrated into other fields as well and untouchability has become a widespread thing.
('64', 161, 1, 28, 330963) A large number of wise Parsis come to me and say that the distinctions of high and low have always existed, and so I need not pursue this activity.
('64', 161, 1, 29, 331111) I ask them: “Since when have you become such Vedantists?
('64', 161, 1, 30, 331168) And when did you study the Hindu Shastras?” They might have read a few sacred books;
('64', 161, 2, 31, 331253) 1 A Parsi religious ceremony where a boy or a girl is invested with the sacred thread.
('64', 162, 0, 1, 331340) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 163
('64', 162, 1, 2, 331386) and since the Parsis have a custom of consulting astrologers, they might have heard something from them; and from that they might have come to the conclusion that the differences of high and low have existed since time immemorial.
('64', 162, 1, 3, 331617) Is untouchability something that the prophet Zoroaster preached?
('64', 162, 1, 4, 331682) The feeling of high and low is something Satanic.
('64', 162, 1, 5, 331732) It can never be divine.
('64', 162, 1, 6, 331756) The evil that is going on in the name of Hindu religion has penetrated all religions.
('64', 162, 1, 7, 331842) The same religions prevailing outside India may not have even the slightest tinge of it; but it has definitely entered those religions as soon as they landed in India.
('64', 162, 1, 8, 332010) It is such a dark well.
('64', 162, 1, 9, 332034) The other wide implication of removing untouchability is the feeling of brotherhood amongst all religions.
('64', 162, 1, 10, 332141) It does not mean doing away with the differences among religions.
('64', 162, 1, 11, 332207) Just as men have different names and faces, these religions also are different.
('64', 162, 1, 12, 332287) But just as men are all human in spite of their different names and forms, just as leaves of a tree though different as leaves are the same as leaves of the same tree, all religions though different are the same.
('64', 162, 1, 13, 332500) We must treat all religions as equal.
('64', 162, 1, 14, 332538) It is this lofty consequence of this activity that I have in mind.
('64', 162, 1, 15, 332605) But for it I would not have decided to devote my life to this work.
('64', 162, 1, 16, 332673) I am not such a fool that I would offer to sacrifice my life for a trifling job, go from village to village at the age of 65 and beg for two pice or even a pice.This work that I have begun not only means the liberation of 50 millions, but I have to melt the hardened hearts of the caste Hindus for their liberation.
('64', 162, 1, 17, 332989) If those hearts can be melted, untouchability which has gone so deep and whose impact is so widespread can be eradicated.
('64', 162, 1, 18, 333111) I do not hesitate of feel ashamed to take money from you for such a widespread activity.
('64', 162, 1, 19, 333200) I have shown you what the removal of untouchability should mean to you.
('64', 162, 1, 20, 333272) I am of course taking this money you have offered; but along with it I wish to carry away the hearts of the Parsi men and women, and seek your blessings that God should grant me rapid success in this work.
('64', 162, 2, 21, 333478) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 22 7 1934

('64', 165, 7, 13, 337283) 206. INTERVIEW TO PROVINCIAL CONGRESS LEADERS
('64', 165, 8, 14, 337329) LAHORE, July 13, 1934
('64', 165, 9, 15, 337351) Provincial Congress leaders including Lala Dunichand of Ambala, Raizada Hansraj and Lala Sham Lal met Gandhiji.
('64', 165, 9, 16, 337463) One of the questions discussed was that of the elimination of undesirable elements from the Congress in the new scheme of re organization.
('64', 165, 9, 17, 337602) Gandhiji admitted the existence of such elements, but he could not see his way under the present constitution of the Congress to prevent such undesirable elements from becoming members of the Congress.
('64', 165, 9, 18, 337804) The only way to keep such elements in check was to strengthen the better element in the Congress.
('64', 165, 10, 19, 337902) At the same time he pointed out that at the instance of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru a rule had been framed that if an office bearer of the Congress acted in a manner prejudicial to the discipline of the Congress, he could be dealt with.
('64', 165, 11, 20, 338135) The next topic discussed was that of lack of co operation among Congress
('64', 165, 12, 21, 338208) workers and leaders.
('64', 165, 12, 22, 338229) Gandhiji said that the only way in which this could be dealt with
('64', 165, 13, 23, 338295) was to evolve higher character and a noble spirit of service among Congress workers.
('64', 165, 14, 24, 338380) Gandhiji was then asked how power, influence and prestige could be secured for the Congress as that alone could enable the Congress to meet the reactionary and hostile forces in the country.
('64', 165, 14, 25, 338571) It was pointed out that if the country sent higher type of men to the legislatures, that would give some additional prestige and influence to the Congress.
('64', 165, 14, 26, 338727) Gandhiji agreed with this, but laid emphasis on the fact that Congressmen should acquire influence and position in the Councils by dint of their service and work.
('64', 166, 0, 1, 338890) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 167
('64', 166, 1, 2, 338936) The question of employing a large contingent of paid workers for every province next came up.
('64', 166, 1, 3, 339030) Gandhiji agreed with the proposal that a large number of paid workers to carry on the work of the Congress should be employed in every province; and to some extent already there were paid men in the All India and Provincial Congress organizations, though on a small scale.
('64', 166, 1, 4, 339303) Gandhiji was requested to remove the idea prevailing among the public regarding paid workers, and he said that he would write on the subject, though he had previously written on the subject.
('64', 166, 2, 5, 339494) The question of the Communal Award was also raised.
('64', 166, 2, 6, 339546) It was pointed out that if the Communal Award became an accomplished fact and a Constitution based on it became legal statute, it would become extremely difficult for any future national Government to undo the mischief that it would have done by that time .
('64', 166, 2, 7, 339804) Gandhiji replied that he recognized such evils in case of effect being given to the Communal Award but he saw no solution of the problem unless all parties concerned agreed to an equitable scheme.
('64', 166, 2, 8, 340001) The Tribune, 15 7 1934
('64', 166, 3, 9, 340024) 207. INTERVIEW TO HARIJAN DEPUTATION
('64', 166, 4, 10, 340061) LAHORE, July 13, 1934
('64', 166, 5, 11, 340083) That he was maturing the scheme to start an Industrial Home at Delhi for the Harijans was the information conveyed by Gandhiji to the Harijan deputation that met him this afternoon.

('64', 166, 10, 17, 340608) 208. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, LAHORE 1

('64', 168, 1, 2, 343674) untouchability is eradicated.

('64', 172, 4, 13, 350795) July 14, 1934 I am grateful to you for the purses you have presented me for the service of the Harijans.
('64', 172, 4, 14, 350900) One sister has presented me a garland 2 of yarn.
('64', 172, 4, 15, 350949) I felt very sad when I saw this garland.
('64', 172, 4, 16, 350990) It seems as if the sister who made this garland had no idea of the science of spinning.
('64', 172, 4, 17, 351078) This yarn can be put to no use.
('64', 172, 4, 18, 351110) As soon as yarn is spun it should be made into spools.
('64', 172, 4, 19, 351165) The state of this yarn is exactly as pitiable as our condition.
('64', 172, 4, 20, 351229) We are ourselves responsible for it.
('64', 172, 4, 21, 351266) The self is its own friend and also its own enemy.
('64', 172, 4, 22, 351317) This applies to girls, women and men equally.
('64', 172, 4, 23, 351363) I have had the acquaintance of countless girls during my tours.
('64', 172, 4, 24, 351427) Form the point of view of them all I am not a man but only a woman.
('64', 172, 4, 25, 351495) When I was in South Africa, I had realized that if I did not serve the cause of women, all my work would remain unfinished.
('64', 172, 4, 26, 351619) And perhaps this is the reason why when I go to a women’s assembly, the women there think that a friend has come in their midst.
('64', 172, 4, 27, 351748) I consider myself the father of thousands of girls.
('64', 172, 4, 28, 351800) It has always been my endeavour to be both father and mother to girls.
('64', 172, 4, 29, 351871) In this capacity I shall mention one thing to you here.
('64', 172, 4, 30, 351927) Outward show and fashion is increasing among the Punjabi girls.
('64', 172, 4, 31, 351991) I can see much luxury here.
('64', 172, 4, 32, 352019) Although this may not be true of all, it is true of most of you.
('64', 172, 4, 33, 352084) Our land is getting poorer day by day because of this destructive fashion.
('64', 172, 4, 34, 352159) Our civilization too has been encouraging this luxury.
('64', 172, 4, 35, 352214) If all of us fell

('64', 174, 1, 2, 354595) 217. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, LAHORE
('64', 174, 2, 3, 354634) July 14, 1934
('64', 174, 3, 4, 354648) Gandhiji in his speech thanked the women for the addresses and purses
('64', 174, 4, 5, 354718) presented 3 to him.
('64', 174, 4, 6, 354738) He asked the women to remove the curse of untouchability,
('64', 174, 5, 7, 354796) otherwise, he said, Hinduism would die.
('64', 174, 5, 8, 354836) The women of India, he said, had always
('64', 174, 6, 9, 354876) protected the religion of this country and they were embodiments of renunciation.
('64', 174, 7, 10, 354958) Gandhiji then explained the meaning of untouchability to the women.
('64', 174, 8, 11, 355026) had, he said, been cherishing the feeling of high and low amongst them so long.
('64', 174, 9, 12, 355106) feeling must be removed.
('64', 174, 9, 13, 355131) Unless this was removed untouchability could not go.
('64', 174, 9, 14, 355184) Tulsidas had told them the essence of religion in two words.
('64', 174, 9, 15, 355245) And that was this: daya
('64', 174, 10, 16, 355269) (charity and pity) was the foundation of all religions and that abhiman (pride) made
('64', 174, 11, 17, 355354) them feel high and low.
('64', 174, 11, 18, 355378) And when abhiman was removed form them and they took
('64', 174, 12, 19, 355431) resort to daya, then abhiman was lost and they became truly religious.
('64', 174, 13, 20, 355502) In the end Gandhiji appealed to the women to part with their ornaments and
('64', 174, 14, 21, 355577) make monetary contributions for the Harijan cause.
('64', 174, 14, 22, 355628) He also asked the women to cultivate the habit of simplicity and serve the Daridranarayana, because in that, he
('64', 174, 15, 23, 355740) said, lay their welfare.
('64', 174, 16, 24, 355765) Gandhiji once more thanked the women and concluded his speech amidst constant noise and uproar.
