('64', 175, 8, 23, 357378) 220. INTERVIEW TO AKALI AND KHALSA DURBAR DEPUTATION 1
('64', 175, 9, 24, 357433) LAHORE, July 15, 1934
('64', 175, 10, 25, 357455) Gandhiji enquired of the deputation the cause of the retirement of Master Tara Singh from Sikh politics.
('64', 175, 10, 26, 357560) Sardar Mangal Singh briefly explained the facts.
('64', 175, 11, 27, 357609) The deputationists then placed their point of view before Gandhiji regarding the Communal Award.
('64', 175, 11, 28, 357706) They expressed disapproval of the non committal policy of the Congress in the matter of Communal Award and said that the Sikhs had taken a
('64', 175, 12, 29, 357845) 1 According to the source, “About 50 Sikhs representing all progressive elements of the community” met Gandhiji at 9.15 a.m.
('64', 175, 12, 30, 357970) Sardul Singh Caveeshar was also present.
('64', 176, 0, 1, 358011) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 177
('64', 176, 1, 2, 358057) vow not to submit to it.
('64', 176, 1, 3, 358082) They, therefore, while supporting the Congress in all other matters, were determined to carry on their fight in the legislatures against the Communal Award and to otherwise safeguard Sikh rights.
('64', 176, 1, 4, 358278) They informed Gandhiji that the Khalsa Durbar had decided to run their own candidates in the coming Assembly elections.
('64', 176, 2, 5, 358398) Gandhiji, who listened to the viewpoint of the Sikhs with attention, replying, explained the Congress position and said that the rejection of the White Paper meant the rejection and the lapse of the Communal Award.
('64', 176, 2, 6, 358613) He added that no constitution would be acceptable to the Congress which did not satisfy the Sikhs.
('64', 176, 2, 7, 358712) Similarly the Congress would not reject what the Mussalmans wanted nor could it accept what the Hindus or Sikhs rejected.
('64', 176, 2, 8, 358834) Therefore if there was no Congress candidate among Sikhs, a Congress voter with conscientious scruples would abstain from voting.
('64', 176, 2, 9, 358964) But if there was an otherwise safe candidate against a reactionary, he would be free to use his vote to defeat the out and out reactionary.
('64', 176, 3, 10, 359104) The deputationists at this stage drew the attention of Gandhiji to the necessity
('64', 176, 4, 11, 359185) of issuing proper instructions to the anti untouchability workers to restrict
('64', 176, 5, 12, 359263) themselves to Harijan uplift work and to refrain from making it a religious
('64', 176, 6, 13, 359339) conversion propaganda.
('64', 176, 6, 14, 359362) This was needed, they said, because in the Punjab there were
('64', 176, 7, 15, 359423) so called untouchables who professed Sikh faith.
('64', 176, 8, 16, 359472) Gandhiji said that he had numerous complaints against Sikhs to the effect that
('64', 176, 9, 17, 359551) they were tempting Hindu Harijans to reject Hinduism and to become Sikhs.
('64', 176, 9, 18, 359625) If this
('64', 176, 10, 19, 359633) was the case it was certainly reprehensible.
('64', 176, 10, 20, 359678) For his part he did not believe in
('64', 176, 11, 21, 359713) coversion propaganda and it was no part of the Harijan Sevak Sangh’s plan.
('64', 176, 11, 22, 359788) The Tribune, 18 7 1934

('64', 177, 3, 5, 360846) 222. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, LAHORE 1
('64', 177, 4, 6, 360886) July 15, 1934
('64', 177, 5, 7, 360900) Ever since I first came to the Punjab, the Punjabis have showered their love on me.
('64', 177, 5, 8, 360984) They have always met me in their thousands but this time their numbers have been much greater than before, so much so the D. A. V. College Hostel ground in unable to accommodate this vast assembly.
('64', 177, 5, 9, 361182) To me this phenomenon is very satisfactory; for I have not come today with a political mission but for a mission which is purely religious and which I have been carrying on in a purely religious spirit.
('64', 177, 5, 10, 361385) The vast numbers that attend the meetings are to me a sign that it will be well with both the country and Hinduism.
('64', 177, 5, 11, 361501) There is no end to our difficulties but the vast meetings that I have been addressing leave no doubt in my mind that we shall be able to remove untouchability root and branch.
('64', 177, 5, 12, 361677) I have seen during my tour that thousands have attended the morning prayer; the sight that I witnessed at this morning’s prayer would have moved anyone and would have inspired faith even in an atheist.
('64', 177, 5, 13, 361879) They were about 10,000 in number but pin drop silence prevailed and they sat with rapt attention for about 25 minutes and I presume they thought of God alone in those moments.
('64', 177, 5, 14, 362055) All these experiences have deepened my faith in God and I feel that I am but an instrument in His hand.
('64', 177, 5, 15, 362159) He seems to have ordained that untouchability, which held its sway over Hindu society for hundreds of years, should now be abolished.
('64', 177, 5, 16, 362293) He seems to be bringing about a transformation in the hearts of savarna Hindus.
('64', 177, 5, 17, 362373) This vast meeting is a testimony to that transformation.
('64', 177, 5, 18, 362430) The object of this movement is neither to score a victory over any other community nor to increase the number of Hindus.
('64', 177, 6, 19, 362551) 1 The source had reported that this was a summary of Gandhiji’s speech obtained from his secretary by one of its representatives.
('64', 177, 6, 20, 362681) Gandhiji was inaudible at the meeting.

('64', 178, 1, 2, 362766) essentially a movement of self purification and of ridding Hinduism of the blot of untouchability.

('64', 178, 1, 4, 362977) I tell you, however, that I am made of common clay as much as you are and you will be able to gain nothing by merely seeing me.

('64', 179, 5, 8, 364371) 225. LETTER TO DILIP KUMAR ROY
('64', 179, 6, 9, 364402) July 16, 1934
('64', 179, 7, 10, 364416) MY DEAR DILIP, I have your letter and enclosures.
('64', 179, 7, 11, 364466) The letter came into my hands only yesterday.
('64', 179, 7, 12, 364512) It went first to Bombay and then by oversight remained with one of my helpers for some days.
('64', 179, 7, 13, 364605) My difficulty is fundamental.
('64', 179, 7, 14, 364635) I do not believe that my present activity is less conducive to self realization or merger in the Divine than abstention would be.
('64', 179, 7, 15, 364765) Sannyasa is not cessation of all physical activity.
('64', 179, 7, 16, 364817) It means to me cessation of all activity, mental or physical that is selfish.
('64', 179, 7, 17, 364895) If I could be convinced that cessation is the better way for me, I should adopt it at once.
('64', 179, 7, 18, 364987) I am no judge of poetry.
('64', 179, 7, 19, 365012) Of what use, therefore, can be any opinion of mine on your poems !
('64', 179, 7, 20, 365079) I have really no opinion to offer.

('64', 185, 1, 2, 373894) 233. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, LAHORE 1
('64', 185, 2, 3, 373934) July 17, 1934 I want you to keep up the practice you have now started of beginning your day’s work with early morning prayers as you have been doing with me these few days.
('64', 185, 2, 4, 374107) You may have them either privately in your own respective homes or congregationally in some central place in your localities.
('64', 185, 2, 5, 374233) It is impossible to exaggerate the importance of this prayer.
('64', 185, 2, 6, 374295) When one begins the day with a devout prayer all his day’s work will be informed with a spirit of purity and prayerfulness.
('64', 185, 2, 7, 374419) The time for it is the early hour of the dawn when the sun, the most luminous of God’s manifestations, reveals to us His witnessing presence in all that we do.
('64', 185, 2, 8, 374579) I shall tell you now one or two marks of genuine worshipper of God.
('64', 185, 2, 9, 374647) One is a spirit of friendliness and brotherhood for the oppressed and the depressed.
('64', 185, 2, 10, 374732) This cannot express itself better than by be friending the Harijan and you cannot befriend him in a better way than by getting off his back, so that he may no longer remain the beast of burden and the downtrodden creature that we have kept him for ages, and that he may breathe and move free.
('64', 185, 2, 11, 375025) The other mark is the service of Daridranarayana—India’s starving millions among whom are included, of course, the Harijans, but whereas the poorest of the poor, if he is not an untouchable, may move about free wherever he pleases, even the richest Harijan may not enter a Hindu temple and use a public well.
('64', 185, 2, 12, 375334) Whilst, therefore, the service of the Harijans lies in the eradication of untouchability, the service of the poor lies in enabling him to find work and to add to his scanty income.
('64', 185, 2, 13, 375515) The best way to do this thing is the habitual use of khaddar and daily sacrificial spinning.
('64', 185, 2, 14, 375608) If all the women of the Punjab were to make a resolve to give all their spare time to spinning, I am sure they would be able not only to clothe the whole of the Punjab but also to send out cloth to other provinces.
('64', 185, 2, 15, 375823) If you do these two things, I should unhesitatingly say that you are going nearer to God every day, provided that all that you do is
('64', 185, 3, 16, 375956) 1 The source had reported that this was ‘‘a translation made by Mahadev Desai’’.
('64', 186, 0, 1, 376037) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 187
('64', 186, 1, 2, 376083) done not for show or self advertisement but in a spirit of service and humanity.
('64', 186, 1, 3, 376164) There is a third thing which also I would declare to be the distinguishing mark of a man of prayer—the spirit of silence.
('64', 186, 1, 4, 376286) The noise and the din of meetings jar on me wherever I go.
('64', 186, 1, 5, 376345) You should all make a point of avoiding all bustle and noise and cultivating a spirit of orderliness and discipline.
('64', 186, 1, 6, 376462) These are three out of the many implications of prayer which I want you all to bear in mind.
('64', 186, 1, 7, 376555) The Tribune, 19 7 1934
('64', 186, 2, 8, 376578) 234. DISCUSSION WITH VOLUNTEERS 1
('64', 186, 3, 9, 376612) July 17, 1934
('64', 186, 4, 10, 376626) Gandhiji, in the course of a short speech said that the volunteers spent a lot of their time in looking after his personal comforts wherever he went.
('64', 186, 4, 11, 376776) They should instead look to their general duty and service of which they had taken a vow to fulfil.
('64', 186, 5, 12, 376876) Questioned, Gandhiji said he had no objection to the volunteers taking military training, but they must abstain from violence.
('64', 186, 5, 13, 377003) He asked them not to use violence even if women were attacked by the mob, because he thought that women were not helpless and they were strong enough to take care of themselves.
('64', 186, 6, 14, 377181) The Tribune, 19 7 1934

('64', 187, 4, 5, 378643) 236. SPEECH TO PUNJAB NATIONALIST WORKERS, LAHORE
('64', 187, 5, 6, 378693) July 17, 1934
('64', 187, 6, 7, 378707) Gandhiji said it was harder to carry out their programme of work than to go to jail.
('64', 187, 6, 8, 378792) He himself found it much easier to go to jail and spend a quiet time there reading his books and drinking goat’s milk than to carry out a strenuous and taxing programme in the country.
('64', 187, 6, 9, 378977) Gandhiji added humourously that Mrs. Gandhi had suggested to him to go to jail and have an easier time there than tire himself our with strenuous work outside.
('64', 187, 7, 10, 379137) Mahatma Gandhi added that their programme had to be worked out now and it would be wrong to think that they could wait till swaraj was achieved for completing it.
('64', 187, 7, 11, 379300) He advised the workers to distribute the work among themselves and carry it out sincerely.
('64', 187, 7, 12, 379391) Let truth be their motto and work would prosper.
('64', 187, 7, 13, 379440) This was a time of peace and their message should be one of peace.
('64', 187, 7, 14, 379507) Referring to the reception given to him at Lahore on his arrival, Gandhiji said he was slightly hurt physically by those who wanted to touch his feet.
('64', 187, 7, 15, 379658) He could well meet crowds of thousands of people if there was no noise.
('64', 187, 7, 16, 379730) Swaraj could not be attained by noise.
('64', 187, 7, 17, 379769) The Hindustan Times, 18 7 1934
('64', 187, 8, 18, 379800) 237. SPEECH TO KHADI WORKERS,LAHORE
('64', 187, 9, 19, 379836) July 17, 1934
('64', 187, 10, 20, 379850) Addressing the khadi workers, Gandhiji described khadi as annapurna (the
('64', 187, 11, 21, 379923) butter part of food), for, if our peasants took to spinning, they could have butter to add to their bread or rice.
('64', 187, 11, 22, 380038) The other cottage industries could support thousands at the most, while khadi was an indispensable cottage industry for crores.
('64', 187, 11, 23, 380166) Khadi could bring about an automatic adjustment between the supply and the demand, for the peasants would mainly produce it for themselves and their neighbours and but little transporta tion would be necessary.
('64', 187, 11, 24, 380377) He had found out that they could have first class, cheap
('64', 188, 0, 1, 380434) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 189
('64', 188, 1, 2, 380480) khadi, if weaver families spun the yarn to be woven by themselves.
('64', 188, 1, 3, 380547) Again, if a producer of cotton wanted cloth free of cost, he had only to carry out himself all the processes from picking to cotton to weaving.
('64', 188, 1, 4, 380691) This would not take the bread out of the weaver’s mouth, because, if the whole of India took to khadi, they would need twice as many weavers as there were now.
('64', 188, 1, 5, 380851) Khadi was the only swadeshi cloth; it was pure humbug to describe Indian mill cloth as swadeshi in the same breath as khadi.
('64', 188, 2, 6, 380976) Till now I have been very lenient but henceforward I cannot but be strict.
('64', 188, 2, 7, 381051) I recruited to the Charkha Sangh even those who did not know spinning in the hope that good workers would be found only from among such people.
('64', 188, 2, 8, 381195) I have now come to the conclusion that the latitude shown has been quite enough.
('64', 188, 2, 9, 381276) Every worker of the Charkha Sangh must learn and become fully proficient in ginning, carding and spinning.
('64', 188, 2, 10, 381383) He should be well versed in weaving also.
('64', 188, 2, 11, 381425) This will greatly facilitate our work in the villages and expedite the advent of freedom.
('64', 188, 2, 12, 381515) Harijan, 3 8 1934, also Khadi Jagat, May 1947
('64', 188, 3, 13, 381561) 238. INTERVIEW TO JOURNALISTS
('64', 188, 4, 14, 381591) LAHORE, July 17, 1934
('64', 188, 5, 15, 381613) The journalists, who numbered between twenty and thirty, desired a message from him but Gandhiji said he was not selling goods gratis and wanted them to pay the price for a message in the shape of a contribution to the Harijan Fund.
('64', 188, 5, 16, 381846) A ring came forth and then a few rupees and coppers totalling Rs. 16. .
('64', 188, 6, 17, 381918) Gandhiji said that .
('64', 188, 6, 18, 381939) if they were really serious about the message they should make up Rs. 50 .
('64', 188, 7, 19, 382014) A member of the staff of one of the papers present undertook to make up the balance required and remit it in the evening.
('64', 188, 8, 20, 382136) Gandhiji responded by saying that of course he did credit business and would give a message on that basis .
('64', 188, 8, 21, 382244) He said : The extraordinary enthusiasm with which I was greeted at the Lahore railway station and which has been sustained throughout my five days stay in the Punjab has been a matter of great joy as it has been also a matter equally of great enthusiasm.
('64', 188, 9, 22, 382499) How I wish all this enthusiasm turned into the direction of a solid, continuous and constructive work.
('64', 188, 9, 23, 382602) It behoves the Punjab leaders to harness this enthusiasm, which is running waste.
('64', 188, 9, 24, 382684) It is a matter of joy also that the people, rich and poor alike,
('64', 188, 10, 25, 382749) 1 What follows is translated from the Hindi report in Khadi Jagat.
('64', 189, 0, 1, 382816) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 189, 1, 2, 382858) spontaneously came to offer their quota to the Harijan Purse Fund.
('64', 189, 1, 3, 382925) To me it is sure that the donors believe in the removal of the curse of untouchability from Hinduism.
('64', 189, 1, 4, 383027) Referring to morning mass prayers, Mahatma Gandhi said that there was complete silence and revered attention.
('64', 189, 1, 5, 383137) That was evidently observed by vast audiences when verses were chanted.
('64', 189, 1, 6, 383209) It was to him a sure sign of their heart felt co operation in this movement of self purification.
('64', 189, 2, 7, 383307) Concluding, Mahatma Gandhi said that the one thing that saddened him most was the condition of the Harijans in Lahore which he thought testified to the criminal neglect by the Municipality of its most deserving employees and citizens.
('64', 189, 2, 8, 383542) Mahatma Gandhi referred particularly to lighting and sanitary arrangements and want of tap water in the Harijan quarters.
('64', 189, 2, 9, 383664) I know that Municipal finances all over India are in a bad plight.
('64', 189, 2, 10, 383731) But surely its effect ought not be visited upon these most deserving and useful employees and citizens.
('64', 189, 2, 11, 383835) I hope, therefore, that complaints about insufficiency of water, want of light and sanitary conveniences, will receive immediate attention.
('64', 189, 2, 12, 383975) Whatever be the difficulties in the Munici pality, surely this essential humanitarian work should not be allowed to suffer.
('64', 189, 2, 13, 384099) I have a great deal to say about the manner of living, conditions of work, and economic condition of these people, but I do not want unnecessarily to burden this message and I want the attention of the public and Municipality to be concentrated upon the grievance that is crying and capable of immediate redress.

('64', 190, 1, 2, 385308) in Calcutta.
('64', 190, 1, 3, 385321) The Chittaranjan Sevasadan was now a flourishing institution under the fostering care of Dr. Bidhan Roy.
('64', 190, 1, 4, 385426) It was a remarkable coincidence that both these great Indian leaders cherished in their heart the idea of social service, especially service of women.
('64', 190, 1, 5, 385577) The nation could not achieve greatness, unless our women were fitted to stand shoulder to shoulder with the men.
('64', 190, 1, 6, 385690) Most of their leading men were social servants by choice and politicians only from necessity.
('64', 190, 1, 7, 385784) They were powerful advocates of social reform.
('64', 190, 1, 8, 385831) Everyone knew Lalaji as a great social worker, and he would have chosen social service as his life work if had the choice.

('64', 190, 2, 12, 386252) There was no greater Harijan servant than Lalaji had been.
('64', 190, 2, 13, 386311) Tuberculosis hospitals were unfortunately a necessity, but Gandhiji trusted that the medical men in charge would attend to prevention no less than to the cure of the terrible scourge.
('64', 190, 2, 14, 386495) The prevalence of tuberculosis in India, which was the land of perpetual sunshine, was rather inexplicable and required investigation.
('64', 190, 2, 15, 386630) The medical staff of the hospital had the unique opportunity of studying the causes of tuberculosis among their patients and discovering means of prevention.
('64', 190, 2, 16, 386788) In the end, Gandhiji congratulated all who had helped to build this Hospital and hoped that they would help it with money.

('64', 190, 4, 19, 387131) A model town hardly deserved the name if it slavishly followed the bad old tradition of segregating Harijans, who did for society what every mother did for her own children.
('64', 190, 4, 20, 387305) Then, again, he had heard that they lived in bad houses and were put to great hardship with regard to water.
('64', 190, 4, 21, 387414) He trusted the good people of Model Town would investigate the complaint and fulfil their promise to treat Harijans on a footing of equality with themselves.

('64', 191, 1, 2, 387928) 241. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('64', 191, 2, 3, 387972) LAHORE, July 17, 1934
('64', 191, 3, 4, 387994) When he was asked whether there was any hope of his abandoning the seven day’s fast he has announced to begin on the 7th August, now that Pandit Lal Nath had made an appeal to him to reconsider his decision, and in the light of the statement recently made by the Secretary, Rajputana Harijan Board, Mahatma Gandhi said : There is no possibility of abandoning the fast.
('64', 191, 4, 5, 388363) Replying to a further enquiry whether he was prescribing any penance for the Secretary of the Rajputana Harijan Board, as he had been asked by the Secretary, Mahatma Gandhi said that no penance save greater watchfulness was necessary on the part of the Secretary.
('64', 191, 5, 6, 388627) The next question was whether Mahatma Gandhi thought that his health would not be put to undue strain by this fast, following as it would his strenuous Harijan tour.
('64', 191, 5, 7, 388793) The Mahatma replied that he did not anticipate any permanent injury.
('64', 191, 6, 8, 388862) Replying to an enquiry whether there was any possibility of avoiding an election fight between the Hindu Maha Sabha and the Congress and of retaining Pandit Malaviya and Mr. Aney on the Congress Parliamentary Board, Mahatma Gandhi stated : I can only say I shall try to avoid a split.
('64', 191, 7, 9, 389147) Mahatma Gandhi had no idea of this programme after the Harijan tour and the fast.
('64', 191, 8, 10, 389229) The final question was regarding the manner in which the Harijan Fund would be spent.
('64', 191, 8, 11, 389315) The Mahatma said that three fourths would return to the source from where it came, provided it could usefully be spent there.
('64', 191, 8, 12, 389441) The balance would be used for constructive work.
('64', 191, 8, 13, 389490) The Tribune, 19 7 1934

('64', 195, 2, 10, 395286) 248. IN PRAISE OF WALKING
('64', 195, 3, 11, 395312) In the middle of the railway and the motor car to which fellow workers have dragged me again from the slow but steady and fruitful quiet walks in Orissa, it is pleasant to receive reflections like the following :
('64', 195, 4, 12, 395525) Your pilgrimage makes my heart sing.
('64', 195, 4, 13, 395562) It is a yajna (sacrifice) worthy
('64', 195, 5, 14, 395595) of those for whom you perfom it.
('64', 195, 5, 15, 395628) Forgive my presumption!
('64', 195, 5, 16, 395652) But I feel all aglow
('64', 195, 6, 17, 395673) when I think of it.
('64', 195, 6, 18, 395693) Somehow your rushing about in a motor car in the cause of
('64', 195, 7, 19, 395751) Harijans seemed to be queer, incongruous.
('64', 195, 7, 20, 395793) I see this as a wholly spiritual problem, and that you should approach it on foot, as a true pilgrim, satisfies
('64', 195, 8, 21, 395905) me through and through like perfect music, or a magnificent sunset.
('64', 195, 8, 22, 395973) So, I feel, should Daridranarayana (the starving millions) be approached.
('64', 195, 8, 23, 396047) Forgive me.
('64', 195, 9, 24, 396059) My words are an involuntary exclamation of a musician, in ecstasy over a tambura flawlessly in tune.
('64', 195, 9, 25, 396160) People say, ‘But how many villages can he cover
('64', 195, 10, 26, 396208) on foot?’ My heart says, ‘Yes, but how many souls he will touch !’ Surely,
('64', 195, 11, 27, 396283) souls matter more than villages and one pilgrim is worth a thousand
('64', 195, 12, 28, 396351) propagandists.
('64', 195, 12, 29, 396366) How I wish other fellow workers will realize the beauty and the necessity of pilgrimages on foot for Harijan work.
('64', 195, 12, 30, 396481) People’s hearts cannot be touched by a mad rush through space.
('64', 195, 12, 31, 396544) They can be by quiet, personal, intimate contact with them.
('64', 195, 12, 32, 396604) Rushing in motor cars and railway trains dazes one and makes one powerless for clear thinking for the time being.
('64', 195, 12, 33, 396718) But hardly has he recovered from the shock when he has to prepare to receive another.
('64', 195, 12, 34, 396804) And so there is no chance of recovery, either for the occupant or for his victims.
('64', 195, 12, 35, 396887) I know that the present programme cannot be substantially varied.
('64', 195, 12, 36, 396953) But the remarks
('64', 196, 0, 1, 396969) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 197
('64', 196, 1, 2, 397015) quoted above should be treasured for any future programme, and the one for the few remaining weeks should be so shaped as to fit in with the idea of no rush.
('64', 196, 1, 3, 397173) Let there be as few visits as possibe during my stay in the principal places.
('64', 196, 1, 4, 397251) My presence ought not to be exploited on behalf of other causes, however meritorious they may be.
('64', 196, 1, 5, 397349) Let my mind be concentrated, as far as may be, on the Harijan cause.

('64', 198, 5, 11, 400691) 252. DISCUSSION WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF THE DEPRESSED CLASSED 1
('64', 198, 6, 12, 400755) [On or before July 21, 1934] 2
('64', 198, 7, 13, 400786) Gandhiji had no difficulty in showing them that the term ‘Depressed Classes’
('64', 198, 8, 14, 400863) had itself a bad odour which the name ‘Harijan’ had certainly not, but he assured them
('64', 198, 9, 15, 400950) that he would be the last man to impose even a term of endearment on those who did
('64', 198, 10, 16, 401033) not like it.
('64', 198, 10, 17, 401046) Among the other grievances was the one that they were not given a
('64', 198, 11, 18, 401112) majority of seats on the Harijan Board.
('64', 198, 11, 19, 401152) Gandhiji explained to them at length the
('64', 198, 12, 20, 401193) penitential character of the work that the organization of the caste Hindus had set
('64', 198, 13, 21, 401277) before itself and that, whilst they were in no way called upon to share in the act of
('64', 198, 14, 22, 401363) penitence, they would do better to form an independent advisory board, in order to
('64', 198, 15, 23, 401446) inspect and review the work of the Harijan Sevak Sangh Board, and to offer helpful
('64', 198, 16, 24, 401529) advice and guidance.
('64', 198, 16, 25, 401550) This was not only their privilege but their duty.
('64', 198, 16, 26, 401600) Their other duty which they could perform much more effectively than savarna reformers was internal
('64', 198, 17, 27, 401700) reform, viz., weaning from carrion eating, drink, etc., those Harijans who were
('64', 198, 18, 28, 401780) addicted to them.
('64', 198, 18, 29, 401798) Finally he implored them not to be impatient—though they had
('64', 198, 19, 30, 401859) every right to—as during the last two years a marvellous change had come over the
('64', 198, 20, 31, 401941) mentality of caste Hindus.
('64', 198, 20, 32, 401968) For, when action precedes mental change, it may well be
('64', 198, 21, 33, 402024) mechanical and fruitless, but, when it is the result of a change of mind and heart, it
('64', 198, 22, 34, 402111) has a vitality of which everyone feels the warmth and glow.
('64', 198, 23, 35, 402171) Harijan, 10 8 1934

('64', 199, 0, 1, 402319) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 199, 1, 2, 402361) 253. SPEECH AT CHITTARANJAN SEVA SADAN, CALCUTTA
('64', 199, 2, 3, 402410) July 21, 1934 We Indians as a nation are lacking in self confidence.
('64', 199, 2, 4, 402479) It is often said against us by our critics that we are deficient in constructive abilities and that we are incapable of running and managing successfully big public institutions.
('64', 199, 2, 5, 402658) The steady progress that the Seva Sadan has shown under the capable guidance of Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy and Sir Nilratan Sircar constitutes the most effective reply to this charge.
('64', 199, 2, 6, 402838) The other day I was called upon to perform the opening ceremony of Gulabdevi Charitable Hospital at Lahore.
('64', 199, 2, 7, 402946) 1 I want to share with you the reflection which that occasion gave rise to in my mind.
('64', 199, 2, 8, 403033) Is it not surprising that both the late Lala Lajpat Rai and the late Deshbandhu Das who were the foremost political leaders of their time and who had passed their entire life in political struggles, should at the time of their death assign all their property not for any political object but for purely philanthropic and charitable object?
('64', 199, 2, 9, 403373) It is a phenomenon for our critics to reflect upon and digest.
('64', 199, 2, 10, 403436) It shows that our essential talent runs always in the direction of service and philanthropy.
('64', 199, 2, 11, 403529) But we are forced into politics against our will owing to extraneous circumstances with the result that our innermost urge for constructive work is smothered and remains unfulfilled.
('64', 199, 2, 12, 403712) This was just what the late Lokamanya lamented also.
('64', 199, 2, 13, 403765) As the whole world knows, twice he was imprisoned and on both these occasions he utilized his time and talents not for writing any political work but for producing religious and scientific works.
('64', 199, 2, 14, 403961) On one occasion it was the celebrated Gita Rahasya and on the other the monumental work on the antiquity of the Vedas that has since become famous throughout the world.
('64', 199, 2, 15, 404130) If I repeat what I have already remarked, this again proves the fact that although today politics may seem to engross our entire being, the ideal that our soul craves for is service, our innermost bent is religious not in the narrow or parochial sense but in the broadest sense of the term, and if we are often compelled to engage in politics it is in order to clear the way for the exercise of our constructive talent.
('64', 199, 2, 16, 404550) You know how close Deshbandhu and I had come together particularly towards the close of Deshbandhu’s life during our stay
('64', 199, 3, 17, 404672) 1 Vide “Speech at Gulabdevi Tuberculosis Hospital, Lahore”, 17 7 1934
('64', 200, 0, 1, 404742) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 201
('64', 200, 1, 2, 404788) together at Darjeeling.
('64', 200, 1, 3, 404812) I was looking forward to his fullest co operation in the prosecution of the constructive programme which we had planned together.
('64', 200, 1, 4, 404942) But God had willed otherwise and within a week of that meeting Deshbandhu passed away.
('64', 200, 1, 5, 405029) It always gives me supreme pleasure to be able to do anything for the ideal that we held in common.
('64', 200, 1, 6, 405129) I therefore gladly availed of the invitation of Dr. Bidhan Roy to perform the present ceremony 1 .
('64', 200, 1, 7, 405228) I would appeal to you to render all help that you are capable of to this institution.
('64', 200, 1, 8, 405314) This is the least that you owe to the memory of the late Deshbandhu.
('64', 200, 1, 9, 405383) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 22 7 1934
('64', 200, 2, 10, 405415) 254. DISCUSSION WITH STUDENTS
('64', 200, 3, 11, 405445) [July 21, 1934] 2
('64', 200, 4, 12, 405463) QUESTION: Believing that mass revolution is the only means to achieve
('64', 200, 5, 13, 405533) freedom, do you believe it a practical proposition that the mass will and can remain
('64', 200, 6, 14, 405618) absolutely non violent in thought and action in spite of all possible provocations in
('64', 200, 7, 15, 405704) the course of such revolution?
('64', 200, 7, 16, 405735) It may be possible for an individual to attain that
('64', 200, 8, 17, 405787) standard but do you think that it is possible for the masses to attain that standard of
('64', 200, 9, 18, 405875) non violence in action?
('64', 200, 10, 19, 405899) GANDHIJI: This is a strange question coming from you at this time of the day, for the entire course of our non violent fight bears testimony to the fact that wherever violence has broken out, it has broken out not on the part of the masses but, if I may put it like that, on the part of the classes, that is, it was manipulated by the intellectuals.
('64', 200, 10, 20, 406249) Even in violent fighting, though the individual sometimes lets himself go and forgets everything the mass of the fighting force dares not and does not.
('64', 200, 10, 21, 406401) It resorts to arms only under orders and has to suspend fire in response to orders, no matter how great the individual impulse to revenge or retaliation might be.
('64', 200, 10, 22, 406564) There is no prima facie reason why under non violence the mass, if disciplined, should be incapable of showing the discipline which in organized warfare a fighting force normally does.
('64', 200, 10, 23, 406749) Besides, a non violent General has this special advantage: he does not require thousands of leaders to successfully carry on his fight.
('64', 200, 10, 24, 406885) The non violent message does not require so many for transmission.
('64', 200, 10, 25, 406952) The example of a new true men or
('64', 200, 11, 26, 406985) 1 Gandhiji laid the foundation stone of the children’s wing of the Seva Sadan.
('64', 200, 11, 27, 407064) 2 From Amrita Bazar Patrika, 22 7 1934. The source has ‘‘July 18, 1934’’, which is evidently incorrect.
('64', 201, 0, 1, 407168) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 201, 1, 2, 407210) women if they have fully imbibed the spirit of non violence is bound to infect the whole mass in the end.
('64', 201, 1, 3, 407316) This was just what I experienced in the beginning of the movement.
('64', 201, 1, 4, 407383) I found that people actually believed that in my heart of hearts I favoured violence even when I preached non violence.
('64', 201, 1, 5, 407503) That was the way they had been trained to read and interpret the utterances of the leaders.
('64', 201, 1, 6, 407595) But when they realized that I meant what I said, they did observe non violence indeed under the most trying circumstances.
('64', 201, 1, 7, 407718) There has been no repetition of Chauri Chaura.
('64', 201, 1, 8, 407765) As for non violence in thought God alone is judge.
('64', 201, 1, 9, 407816) But this much is certain that non violence in action cannot be sustained unless it goes hand in hand with non violence in thought.
('64', 201, 2, 10, 407947) Do you think co operation between the exploited and the exploiters is at all possible to attain the ideals you stand for?
('64', 201, 2, 11, 408069) Do you not think that time has come when Congress should take a definite stand for the rights of the masses irrespective of the interests of the capitalists and the landlord?
('64', 201, 2, 12, 408244) Do you not think that it is not possible to organize the masses effectively on nationalistic programme and workers have no need or no other alternative but to array themselves against the capitalists and landlords for the exploited tenants and labour?
('64', 201, 2, 13, 408496) Do you not think that a class war is inevitable and interested classes must perish for the sake of a greater humanity?
('64', 201, 2, 14, 408615) I never said that there should be co operation between the exploiter and the exploited so long as exploitation and the will to exploit persist.
('64', 201, 2, 15, 408759) Only I do not believe that the capitalists and landlords are all exploiters by an inherent necessity or that there is a basic or irreconcilable antagonism between their interests and those of the masses.
('64', 201, 2, 16, 408963) All exploitation is based on the co operation willing or forced, of the exploited.
('64', 201, 2, 17, 409046) However much we may detest admitting it, the fact remains that there would be no exploitation if people refuse to obey the exploiter.
('64', 201, 2, 18, 409180) But self comes in and we hug the chains that bind us.
('64', 201, 2, 19, 409234) This must cease.
('64', 201, 2, 20, 409251) What is needed is not the extinction of the landlords and the capitalists but transformation of the existing relationship between them and the masses into something healthier and purer.
('64', 201, 2, 21, 409437) You ask ‘whether the time has not come when the Congress should stand for the rights of the masses as opposed to the interests of the capitalists and the landlords’.
('64', 201, 2, 22, 409603) My reply is that ever since the Congress had come on the scene it has done nothing else whether it was dominated by the Moderates or the Extremists.
('64', 201, 2, 23, 409752) From its very inception under A. O. Hume it has sought to represent the masses.
('64', 201, 2, 24, 409832) That indeed was its origin, and a study of its history of nearly half a centrury would prove to the hilt that the Congress has been all through progressively representative of the masses.
('64', 202, 0, 1, 410020) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 203
('64', 202, 1, 2, 410066) Do I not think that time has come when Congress should take a definite stand for the rights of the masses irrespective of the interests of the capitalists and the landlords?
('64', 202, 1, 3, 410240) No, we, the so called friends of the masses, will only dig our and their graves if we took that stand.
('64', 202, 1, 4, 410343) I would like to use the landlords and capitalists for the service of the masses as the late Sir Surendranath used to do.
('64', 202, 1, 5, 410464) We must not sacrifice the interests of the masses to the capitalists.
('64', 202, 1, 6, 410534) We must not play their game.
('64', 202, 1, 7, 410563) We must trust them to the measure of their ability to surrender their gains for the service of the masses.
('64', 202, 1, 8, 410670) Do you think that the so called privileged classes are altogether devoid of nationalistic sentiments?
('64', 202, 1, 9, 410772) If you think so, you will be doing grave injustice to them and disservice to the cause of the masses.
('64', 202, 1, 10, 410874) Are not they too exploited by the rulers?
('64', 202, 1, 11, 410916) They are not insusceptible to the higher appeal.
('64', 202, 1, 12, 410965) It has invariably been my experience that a kind word uttered does go home to them.
('64', 202, 1, 13, 411049) If we win their confidence and put them at their ease we will find that they are not averse to progressively sharing their riches with the masses.
('64', 202, 1, 14, 411196) Moreover, let us ask ourselves with the masses, have we bridged the gulf between the surging millions and us?
('64', 202, 1, 15, 411306) Let us who live in glass houses not throw stones.
('64', 202, 1, 16, 411356) To what extent do you share the life of the masses?
('64', 202, 1, 17, 411408) I confess that with me it is still an aspiration.
('64', 202, 1, 18, 411458) We ourselves have not completely shed the habits of living that we say the capitalists are notorious for The idea of class war does not appeal to me.
('64', 202, 1, 19, 411608) In India class war is not only inevitable but it is avoidable if we have understood the message of non violence.
('64', 202, 1, 20, 411721) Those who talk about class war as being inevitable have not understood the implications of non violence or have understood them only skin deep.
('64', 202, 2, 21, 411865) How can the rich help the poor without the rich being poor themselves?
('64', 202, 2, 22, 411936) Richness or capitalism is a system which tries to perpetuate the colossal difference between capital and labour in order to maintain its position and status.
('64', 202, 2, 23, 412094) Is it therefore possible to effect any compromise between them without greatly injuring the interests of either?
('64', 202, 2, 24, 412207) The rich can help the poor by using their riches not for selfish pleasure, but so as to subserve the interests of the poor.
('64', 202, 2, 25, 412331) If they do so there will not be that unbridgeable gulf that today exists between the ‘haves’ and the ‘have nots’.
('64', 202, 2, 26, 412445) Class divisions there will be, but they will then be horizontal, not vertical.
('64', 202, 2, 27, 412524) Let us not be obsessed with catchwords and seductive slogans imported from the West.
('64', 202, 2, 28, 412609) Have we not our own distinct Eastern traditions?
('64', 202, 2, 29, 412658) Are we not capable of finding our own solution to the question of capital and labour?
('64', 202, 2, 30, 412744) What is the system of varnashrama but a means of harmonizing the difference
('64', 203, 0, 1, 412820) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 203, 1, 2, 412862) between high and low, as well as between capital and labour?
('64', 203, 1, 3, 412923) All that comes from the West on this subject is tarred with the brush of violence.
('64', 203, 1, 4, 413006) I object to it because I have seen the wreckage that lies at the end of this road.
('64', 203, 1, 5, 413089) The more thinking set even in the West today stand aghast at the abyss for which their system is heading.
('64', 203, 1, 6, 413195) And I owe whatever influence I have in the West to my ceaseless endeavour to find a solution which promises an escape from the vicious circle of violence of exploitation.
('64', 203, 1, 7, 413366) I have been a sympathetic student of the Western social order and I have discovered that underlying the fever that fills the souls of the West there is a restless search for truth.
('64', 203, 1, 8, 413547) I value that spirit.
('64', 203, 1, 9, 413568) Let us study our Eastern institutions in that spirit of scientific inquiry and we shall evolve a truer socialism and a truer communism than the world has yet dreamed of.
('64', 203, 1, 10, 413738) It is surely wrong to presume that Western socialism or communism is the last word on the question of mass poverty.
('64', 203, 2, 11, 413854) We want to be precise as to what you mean by non violence.
('64', 203, 2, 12, 413913) If by non violence you mean absence of personal hatred, we have no objection to it.
('64', 203, 2, 13, 413997) What we object to is your identifying non violence with non killing.
('64', 203, 2, 14, 414066) Wars are waged not on personal lines but to vindicate national honour or interests.
('64', 203, 2, 15, 414150) Issues have always been fought with the maximum amount of force both moral and physical.
('64', 203, 2, 16, 414239) When all can successfully use physical force for the triumph of our national ideals and when it is the shortest cut, why do you object to it?
('64', 203, 2, 17, 414381) Besides, the world is not even now advanced enough to appreciate moral persuasion.
('64', 203, 2, 18, 414464) My ahimsa does rule out the use of all force otherwise than moral.
('64', 203, 2, 19, 414531) But it is one thing to say that physical force has been or is today being used in the world for the settlement of national issues; quite another thing to say that it should continue so to be used.
('64', 203, 2, 20, 414728) Wecannot afford to blindly imitate the West.
('64', 203, 2, 21, 414773) In the West, if they do certain things they have antidotes for them too; we have not.
('64', 203, 2, 22, 414859) Take the instance of birth control.
('64', 203, 2, 23, 414895) It may seem to work well there, but if we took to the practice of birth control as it is being advocated in the West, in ten years there will be a race of eunuchs in India.
('64', 203, 2, 24, 415068) Similarly, if we take to violence after the West we shall soon be bankrput as the West is fast becoming.
('64', 203, 2, 25, 415173) Only the other day, I was having a talk with a European friend.
('64', 203, 2, 26, 415237) He was appalled at the prospect of wholesale exploitation of the coloured races of the world by the highly industrialized nations of the West with which civilization is today confronted.
('64', 203, 2, 27, 415424) The principle of non violence is today passing through a period of probation.
('64', 203, 2, 28, 415502) The forces of the spirit are engaged in life and death grapples with brute force.
('64', 203, 2, 29, 415584) Let us in this crisis not shrink from the test.
('64', 204, 0, 1, 415632) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 205
('64', 204, 1, 2, 415678) What has the Congress done or what should it do in connection with the young men and women of Bengal detained without trial?
('64', 204, 1, 3, 415803) I have given you my solution.
('64', 204, 1, 4, 415833) If we work the Congress organization non violently and honsetly we shall be able to purge it of its corruptions today.
('64', 204, 1, 5, 415952) It is reeking with corruption, and Bengal, I must confess to my sorrow, has been the worst sinner in this respect.
('64', 204, 1, 6, 416067) I will promise you that every one of these detenus is discharged.
('64', 204, 1, 7, 416133) But then our non violence will have to be real in thought, word and deed.
('64', 204, 2, 8, 416207) We regard all those elements in our society as Harijans who in one way or other are being exploited or kept suppressed.
('64', 204, 2, 9, 416327) Your satyagraha movement is always for those who are downtrodden.
('64', 204, 2, 10, 416393) Why then a separate Harijan movement?
('64', 204, 2, 11, 416431) It is not a separate Harijan movement that I am conducting.
('64', 204, 2, 12, 416491) Its significance is world wide.
('64', 204, 3, 13, 416523) Is it yet time for the youths of India to force a social re ordering?
('64', 204, 3, 14, 416593) Should it follow or precede any further political effort towards swaraj?
('64', 204, 3, 15, 416666) The two things—the social re ordering and the fight for political swaraj—must go hand in hand.
('64', 204, 3, 16, 416761) There can be no question of precedence or division into water tight compartments here.
('64', 204, 3, 17, 416848) But a new social order cannot be ‘forced’; that would be a remedy worse than the disease.
('64', 204, 3, 18, 416938) I am an impatient reformer.
('64', 204, 3, 19, 416966) I am all for thorough going, radical, social re ordering; but it must be an organic growth, not a violent super imposition.
('64', 204, 3, 20, 417090) What is the utility of trying to keep a number of pseudo nationalist Muslims within the Congress fold by allowing them illegitimate and illogical concessions which are only increasing their insatiable hunger?
('64', 204, 3, 21, 417299) If the Muslim nationalists are ‘pseudo nationalists’, we too are ‘pseudo nationalists’.
('64', 204, 3, 22, 417387) Let us therefore eradicate that word from our dictionary.
('64', 204, 3, 23, 417445) I do not know that an ‘illogical concession’ means, but you will never find me supporting an illegitimate concession.
('64', 204, 3, 24, 417563) That is common ground between us.

('64', 204, 4, 26, 417746) It is historically not true that the participation of the Congress in the Khilafat movement is responsible for the embitterment of the communal relations.
('64', 204, 4, 27, 417901) The fact is just the other way about, and I shall always maintain that the Congress did well in standing by our Mussalman compatriots in their fight for the Khilafat.

('64', 205, 1, 2, 418131) 255. SPEECH AT TOWN HALL, CALCUTTA 1
('64', 205, 2, 3, 418168) July 21, 1934
('64', 205, 3, 4, 418182) Replying in Hindi, Gandhiji expressed regret for want of knowledge of the Bengali language although it had always been one of the cherished dreams of his life that he should learn his beautiful and sweet language—a language the wealth of which had been immensely increased by the contributions of his Gurudev, Rabindranath Tagore.
('64', 205, 4, 5, 418513) He recalled the occasion when he received another civic address from the hands
('64', 205, 5, 6, 418592) of Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das and made a touching reference to his close and
('64', 205, 6, 7, 418670) intimate association with Deshpriya Jatindra Mohan Sen Gupta whom he no more
('64', 205, 7, 8, 418747) found by his side today.
('64', 205, 8, 9, 418772) As regards the good words had been said about him in the address, Gandhiji
('64', 205, 9, 10, 418847) received them as their blessings.
('64', 205, 9, 11, 418881) What could he say to them in reply?
('64', 205, 9, 12, 418917) He would only
('64', 205, 10, 13, 418931) fervently pray to God that this great Corporation become an ideal body, that it could
('64', 205, 11, 14, 419017) set up such an example as might with profit be emulated by other municipal
('64', 205, 12, 15, 419092) institutions.
('64', 205, 13, 16, 419106) Calcutta with its beautiful parks, big thoroughfares and magnificent buildings was rightly called the City of Palaces but they could not overlook the fact that the picture had its other side too.
('64', 205, 13, 17, 419302) On the one hand, there were these gorgeous things which the city could be well proud of and on the other, there was the miserable condition of the bastis in which the Harijans lived.
('64', 205, 13, 18, 419485) The contrast distressed him very
('64', 205, 14, 19, 419518) He had an opportunity of visiting some Harijan quarters in the morning and it pained him very much to see the wretched state in which these people lived, without air, without light and without sufficient water for drinking.
('64', 205, 14, 20, 419742) He was a Harijan himself by adoption and it would be no exaggeration to say that he felt uneasy in that place.
('64', 205, 14, 21, 419853) They must not forget that it was these scavengers and sweepers of the city who were responsible for the cleanliness and the health of this big city.
('64', 205, 14, 22, 420002) It was his prayer to the Councillors of the Corporation that they should make provision of some amount of money every year for removing the various grievances of these people.
('64', 205, 14, 23, 420178) He appealed to them in the name of humanity and justice to devote a little of their time and attention to this noble cause.
('64', 205, 15, 24, 420302) Concluding, Gandhiji said that his attention had been drawn to the big headlines in newspapers regarding the dispute over the Mayoral election.
('64', 205, 15, 25, 420446) He hoped that there would be no repetition of the same, and appealed to the Councillors to see that all sections of the Corporation could work with one common purpose of serving
('64', 205, 16, 26, 420624) 1 Nalini Ranjan Sarkar, the Mayor, presented the civic address in the afternoon.
('64', 205, 16, 27, 420705) The address was printed in Bengali on white khaddar.

('64', 206, 1, 2, 420804) the interests of the city, without any distinction of caste, colour and creed.
('64', 206, 1, 3, 420883) He hoped that this great body would work in a way as could make it the object of pride and admiration to the whole of Hindustan.

('64', 206, 2, 5, 421044) 256. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CALCUTTA 1
('64', 206, 3, 6, 421086) July 21, 1934
('64', 206, 4, 7, 421100) He began by expressing regret that he could not make his stay in Calcutta longer, for he was leaving Bengal that very night in connection with the Harijan work.
('64', 206, 4, 8, 421261) The presence of such a huge gathering, continued Gandhiji, demonstrated that the people of Bengal would not and could not forget their work for Harijans.
('64', 206, 4, 9, 421415) So far he had collected Rs. 65,000 in Calcutta for that noble work and, before he left that city that night, he hoped to receive further contributions.
('64', 206, 4, 10, 421567) Even the Bengal Bus Syndicate, he was glad to find, had come forward to identify itself with that cause by contributing Rs. 501. Harijan work was such that it could not but be dear to all classes of people, even to those who called themselves sanatanists.
('64', 206, 4, 11, 421823) They could not but ignore that cause without ceasing to be human.
('64', 206, 5, 12, 421889) Continuing, he said that some mazdurs (labourers), who had gathered there in
('64', 206, 6, 13, 421966) large numbers, asked him as to what he had done for their welfare.
('64', 206, 6, 14, 422033) To the service of Harijans he had already dedicated his life and thereby he had been doing his service to the labour also.
('64', 206, 7, 15, 422156) He was also working for the cause of popularizing charkha and this was a work in which was involved the welfare of millions of poor Harijans.
('64', 206, 7, 16, 422298) Beause he was serving the cause of these poor labourers, he was himself leading the life of a labourer and had embraced poverty, for their joy was his joy and their sorrow was his sorrow.
('64', 206, 7, 17, 422486) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 22 7 1934
('64', 206, 8, 18, 422518) 257. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 2
('64', 206, 9, 19, 422564) July 21, 1934 When I agreed to go to Calcutta for three days in order to try to compose the domestic differences, Dr. B. C. Roy wrote to me inquiring how all the workers could be brought together and whether I considered Maulana Abul Kalam Azad to be a neutral party for issuing invitation to workers.
('64', 206, 9, 20, 422866) I wrote immediately, saying that the

('64', 207, 1, 8, 423694) I have had a full and frank discussion with the different groups, and as a result of this discussion I came to the conclusion that, if party feeling was to be avoided, the Congress organization must be freed of manipulation of votes, even what amounts to a purchase of a vote.
('64', 207, 1, 9, 423971) It is most essential to avoid such manipulation, especially in Bengal where party feeling runs very high.
('64', 207, 1, 10, 424077) I am happy to be able to say that nearly 22 out of 48 districts assured me through their representatives that they endorsed my suggestion and also assured me that they would have unopposed elections.
('64', 207, 1, 11, 424277) If the representatives of the districts named are able to make good their claim, it would be a happy augury for the future, and the example of such a large number of districts was bound to prove infectious.
('64', 207, 1, 12, 424484) In any event I have no remedy to suggest for purging the Congress organization in Bengal of all the undesirable elements.
('64', 207, 1, 13, 424606) It would be impossible to run the Bengal Congress organization, or for that matter any Congress organization, until and unless the vast majority of Congressmen make up their minds to work the Congress with absolute honesty.
('64', 207, 1, 14, 424830) Let it not be forgotten that my suggestion does not mean in any shape or form the suppression of the Election Board with Mr. M. S. Aney as the final arbitrator.
('64', 207, 1, 15, 424991) He would still have to scrutinize papers received from districts having unopposed election.

('64', 207, 1, 17, 425256) It is to be hoped, therefore, that my suggestion will commend itself to all Congressmen, no matter to which party they belong.
('64', 207, 1, 18, 425383) I am sure that without purity and honesty in the Congress organization it would not be possible to rid Bengal of the many special ills from which she is suffering.

('64', 208, 5, 7, 426263) 258. LETTER TO SANATANISTS
('64', 208, 6, 8, 426290) [July 22, 1934] 2
('64', 208, 7, 9, 426308) In reply to a letter of an orthodox sanatanist of Benares, Mahatma Gandhi says that he is always prepared to hear the discussion of pundits with a view to obtaining correct interpretation of the Shastras on the subject of untouchability, but if the conclusion arrived at by the President was not convincing to him he will not be bound to accept it.

('64', 210, 1, 2, 430527) 260. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KANPUR 1
('64', 210, 2, 3, 430567) July 22, 1934 I thank you for your purse of Rs. 11,000, but you will allow me to say that it is not worthy of the open handedness which you have taught me to associate with Cawnpore.
('64', 210, 2, 4, 430750) I am certain that you would have given me many times as much, if you had realized the magnitude of the task before us.
('64', 210, 2, 5, 430869) There are some people in Cownpore who look upon the Harijan movement as irreligious and have issued a large number of leaflets for public consumption.
('64', 210, 2, 6, 431020) I was sorry to find that these were full of palpa ble falsehoods and insidious half truths, exaggerations and distortions.
('64', 210, 2, 7, 431143) How I wish that these statements were made unintentionally !
('64', 210, 2, 8, 431204) For instance, it is said that reformers in some place slaughtered sanatanists without mercy, but I know nothing about it.
('64', 210, 2, 9, 431326) If I did, I need scarcely say that I would take strong action to check it.
('64', 210, 2, 10, 431401) What a deep tragedy it is that these falsehoods are spread in the name of sanatana dharma?
('64', 210, 2, 11, 431492) I appeal to the sanatanists to stop this campaign of falsehoods.
('64', 210, 2, 12, 431557) You would give lakhs where you now give thousands, if you understood the far reaching character of the Harijan movement.
('64', 210, 2, 13, 431678) Nevertheless, our goal cannot be achieved by collections, no matter how large they are; it will be achieved only with the melting of savarna Hindu hearts.
('64', 210, 2, 14, 431833) When a gift is token of a change of heart, its value is multiplied a hundredfold.
('64', 210, 2, 15, 431915) This is a movement of purification.
('64', 210, 2, 16, 431951) It has nothing to do with the counting of heads.
('64', 210, 2, 17, 432000) It is not a movement designed to fight Muslims or others.
('64', 210, 2, 18, 432058) We do not seek to make goondas of Harijans.
('64', 210, 2, 19, 432102) We seek to make them worthy citizens.
('64', 210, 2, 20, 432140) If we succeed, the world will benefit as well as we.
('64', 210, 2, 21, 432193) At present the world would be fully justified in despising us and our faith for our maltreatment of five crores of our own kith and kin in the name of religion.
('64', 210, 2, 22, 432354) I have regard for the black flaggers no less than for the reformers and, if it was at all possible, I would gladly go away as they wish me to do.
('64', 210, 2, 23, 432500) But I consider it my religious duty to bear witness to the truth as I see it, and any number of black flags, or even a bomb or a revolver cannot prevent me from discharging it by such means as are open to me.
('64', 210, 2, 24, 432709) I am but an imperfect being and not a tapasvi 2 who

('64', 211, 1, 3, 433055) I can only speak to such as are inclined to hear me, and for this I am going about from place to place, although I long for rest from the toil of continuous travel.
('64', 211, 1, 4, 433220) Let me tell the sanatanists who claim to be monopolists of religious truth that I believe in the same Shastras as they do.
('64', 211, 1, 5, 433343) I have profound disagreement with them as regards interpretation.

('64', 211, 1, 7, 433539) And that is exactly what I am doing.

('64', 211, 1, 10, 433825) Let me repeat the implications of this movement.
('64', 211, 1, 11, 433874) It is limited to the removal of the feeling of superiority and inferiority and has nothing to do with inter dining and intermarriage.

('64', 211, 1, 17, 434294) There is no need, nor can I spare time, for such propaganda.
('64', 211, 1, 18, 434355) I only place the essentials or religion before the people for their acceptance.
('64', 211, 1, 19, 434435) The movement claims for the Harijans the same social, civic and religious rights as belong to any other Hindu.
('64', 211, 1, 20, 434546) As regards temple entry, you should know that no temple is opened to Harijans except with the full consent of those who attend that temple for worship.

('64', 211, 1, 22, 434747) Not a single pie from the Harijan Fund is spent on temple building.

('64', 211, 1, 24, 434945) As this is a Harijan tour, I do not often speak about khadi, although my faith in it is as strong as ever.
('64', 211, 1, 25, 435052) But you must not forget that khadi supports a large number of Harijan spinners and weavers.
('64', 211, 1, 26, 435144) It will never do for you to give a second place to khadi in your thoughts.

('64', 216, 6, 17, 442954) July 23, 1934
('64', 216, 7, 18, 442968) NARAHARI, I have been wanting to write to you for a long time, but couldn’t do so till today.I felt, too, that since Mahadev had been released, it wouldn’t matter if I didn’t write.
('64', 216, 7, 19, 443150) If I expressed disappointment on hearing that you would not be able to go to Wardha, I don’t remember why; I didn’t feel disappointed.
('64', 216, 7, 20, 443285) I was afraid that you wouldn’t like to go there, and I had expressed my fear to Jamnalalji.
('64', 216, 7, 21, 443377) The reasons which you have given are sound.The reason about the Vidyapith is not valid.
('64', 216, 7, 22, 443465) If it is, it is such as can be overcome.
('64', 216, 7, 23, 443506) But the reasons regarding temperament are so strong that they require no support from others.
('64', 216, 7, 24, 443600) It is not a small responsibility to take charge of Wardha.

('64', 216, 7, 26, 443713) Perhaps Prema may be such a woman.
