('64', 219, 7, 12, 447713) 272. SPEECH AT OPENING OF TILAK HALL, KANPUR 1
('64', 219, 8, 13, 447760) July 24, 1934 I am thankful to you for inviting me to perform this sacred ceremony this morning.
('64', 219, 8, 14, 447857) When I learnt early this morning that I had to come here, my memory went beck to the day 20 years ago when I first visited Cawnpore as a stranger.
('64', 219, 8, 15, 448004) It was the late Babu Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi then a youth unknown to me, who then housed me in his press which was also his residence, for nobody else would dare harbour me.
('64', 219, 8, 16, 448179) I was then an utter stranger to the bulk of our country men.
('64', 219, 8, 17, 448240) Whatever little was known of me was through my services in South Africa.
('64', 219, 8, 18, 448313) Neither the people nor the Government knew what I would do here.
('64', 219, 8, 19, 448378) Nor did I myself know what was in store for me or what part I was to play in the national affairs.
('64', 219, 8, 20, 448477) It was a happy coincidence that Tilak Maharaj came to this city that very day and was accorded a very hearty reception.
('64', 219, 8, 21, 448597) To me the association with this city is bound up with the memory of Ganesh Shankar.
('64', 219, 8, 22, 448681) I came to know him more intimately later on and found in him a simple, straight forward, upright, selfless servant of the nation.
('64', 219, 8, 23, 448811) You know more than I do of the services he rendered through various channels to this city in particular and the country in general.
('64', 219, 8, 24, 448943) He was a lover of the Hindi language.
('64', 219, 8, 25, 448981) The Pratap founded by him is a living monument of that
('64', 219, 9, 26, 449036) 1 This appeared as “an authorized translation of Gandhiji’s speech”.
('64', 220, 0, 1, 449105) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 221
('64', 220, 1, 2, 449151) As we all know he crowned a life of service with a heroic death.
('64', 220, 1, 3, 449216) I cannot describe to you how I miss him today on my first visit to this city after his death.
('64', 220, 1, 4, 449310) Tilak’s vast learning, his immense sacrifice and his life long service has won for him a unique place in the hearts of the people.
('64', 220, 1, 5, 449441) He it was who infused life into the nation with the mantra of swaraj to the achievement of which his whole life was dedicated.
('64', 220, 1, 6, 449568) But the thing to which I want to draw your attention today was his outlook and catholicity in matters of religion.
('64', 220, 1, 7, 449683) He was a live sanatanist.
('64', 220, 1, 8, 449709) No one in his lifetime nor even now could claim deeper or vaster knowledge of the Shastras than he possessed.
('64', 220, 1, 9, 449819) His masterwork—the ‘commentary on the Gita’ 1 —is unsurpassed and will remain so for a long time to come.
('64', 220, 1, 10, 449925) Nobody has yet carried on more elaborate research in questions arising from the Gita and the Vedas.
('64', 220, 1, 11, 450025) It was not without deep study and careful research that he had declared that there was no sanction in the Shastras for untouchability as it is practised today.
('64', 220, 1, 12, 450185) I can bear witness to the fact that he had eliminated the distinctions of high and low from his own life.
('64', 220, 1, 13, 450291) He did not believe in untouchability based on birth and never hesitated to mix freely with so called untouchables.
('64', 220, 1, 14, 450406) I carried on anti untouchability work in those days as I do now.
('64', 220, 1, 15, 450471) I remember my many conversations with him on this subject and I can bear testimony to the fact that he was wholeheartedly with me and keenly desired the abolition of untouch ability from Hinduism.
('64', 220, 1, 16, 450668) It is relevant to refer to his opinion today, for it is said in some quarters nowadays that this anti untouchability movement is subversive of religion.
('64', 220, 1, 17, 450821) I can give you many more reminiscences of his liberal outlook in other fields of life also.
('64', 220, 1, 18, 450913) His contribution of the growth of the political life of the people has been unparalleled.
('64', 220, 1, 19, 451003) But I believe his commentary on the Gita will be a more lasting monument to his memory.
('64', 220, 1, 20, 451091) It will survive even the successful termination of the struggle for swaraj.
('64', 220, 1, 21, 451167) Even then his memory will remain as fresh as ever on account of his spotless purity of life and his great commentary on the Gita.
('64', 220, 1, 22, 451297) We owe to the memory of the great leader whom we revere that we should strive ceaselessly for completing the structure of swaraj of which he laid the foundation.
('64', 220, 1, 23, 451459) Let this hall be but an outward token of our intense desire to make that effort to the best of our ability.
('64', 220, 1, 24, 451567) The Leader, 29 7 1934
('64', 220, 2, 25, 451589) 1 Gita Rahasya
('64', 221, 0, 1, 451604) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 221, 1, 2, 451646) 273. DISCUSSION WITH SANATANISTS 1
('64', 221, 2, 3, 451681) KANPUR, [July 24, 1934] 2
('64', 221, 3, 4, 451707) QUESTION: How is this temple entry agitation of yours going to benefit the Harijans materially?
('64', 221, 3, 5, 451803) Are you sure that they want it?
('64', 221, 4, 6, 451835) GANDHIJI: It is for the material benefit of the Harijans.
('64', 221, 4, 7, 451893) It is for the spiritual benefit of the savarna Hindus, who have to purify themselves and who owe a debt to the Harijans, If untouchability is a sin and if the Harijans are as good Hindus as the rest of us, they have as much right to enter the temples as the others.
('64', 221, 4, 8, 452159) Whether they can get any material benefit from it, or even spiritual benefit or salvation, or whether they themselves want it or not, is beside the point.
('64', 221, 4, 9, 452314) The point is whoever cares to go to a temple, provided he observes the rules observed by all other Hindus, ought to have the right to do so.
('64', 221, 4, 10, 452455) He may be a sinner,but it is precisely because we are all sinners that we would like to go to temples to wash out our sins there.
('64', 221, 4, 11, 452585) A saint need not go there.
('64', 221, 4, 12, 452612) The sanat anists may expect him to observe all the rules of outward cleanliness that they themselves observe,but nothing more.
('64', 221, 5, 13, 452739) But the Shastras are against temple entry.
('64', 221, 5, 14, 452782) Why not frankly say that you want to found a new Shastra?
('64', 221, 5, 15, 452840) I believe in the same Shastras as you do; only my interpr etation is different.
('64', 221, 5, 16, 452920) I am not a shastri myself,but if there is a section which contends that the Shastras enjoin untouchability, there is another equally strong section of pandits and shastris who no doubt say that there is no sanction in the Shastras for untouchability as it is practised today.
('64', 221, 6, 17, 453196) But if you destroy untouchability, the untouchables will invade our professions and occupations.
('64', 221, 6, 18, 453293) They will have sweetmeat shops, for instance.
('64', 221, 6, 19, 453339) All self restraint in matters of food will be swept away.
('64', 221, 7, 20, 453397) You forget that the Harijan campaign has nothing to do with questions of food and drink, it seeks to destroy untouchability as it is
('64', 221, 8, 21, 453530) 1 This is extracted from “Some Misconceptions” by Mahadev Desai who explains: “The organizers of the reception in Cawnpore had set apart a certain time exclusively for the sanatanists .
('64', 221, 8, 22, 453716) There were, however, no opposing pundist there.
('64', 221, 8, 23, 453764) But there was a young man (who afterwards I found was an oil dealer) who had a list of several questions…which, naturally, someone more learned had written up for him and which represent the misconceptions that still have possession of the santanist mind.” 2 From The Leader
('64', 222, 0, 1, 454039) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 223
('64', 222, 1, 2, 454085) practised today.
('64', 222, 1, 3, 454102) There are numerous shops being run by non Hindus and non Brahmins.
('64', 222, 1, 4, 454169) No one compels the Hindus or the Brahmins among them to go to these shops.
('64', 222, 1, 5, 454244) There are orthodox Brahmins who would not touch food cooked by anyone else.
('64', 222, 1, 6, 454320) They are quite welcome to their self imposed restrictions, which will remain untouched for all time.
('64', 222, 2, 7, 454421) But why do you say untouchability is a sin, when our own mothers and sisters and daughters are treated as untouchables four days in the month?
('64', 222, 2, 8, 454564) You must know that some kind of untouchability is practised not only by us, Hindus,but by people of all faiths—Parsis, Mussalmans, Christians.
('64', 222, 2, 9, 454707) But do we treat our mothers and sisters as untouchables for the rest of the month?
('64', 222, 2, 10, 454790) Do we spurn them, do we fling our food remains at them even during the period of untoucha bility?
('64', 222, 2, 11, 454888) Do we keep them out of our houses?
('64', 222, 2, 12, 454923) For God’s sake, don’t forget that you are subjecting the so called untouchables to insults and outrages that you would not dare to impose on anyone else.
('64', 222, 3, 13, 455077) Those insults and outrages are unknown here.
('64', 222, 3, 14, 455122) You had better go to places where they are practised.
('64', 222, 3, 15, 455176) Will you accompany me?
('64', 222, 4, 16, 455199) Why should we?
('64', 222, 4, 17, 455214) It is enough that we are not guilty.
('64', 222, 4, 18, 455251) We invite them to our caste dinners.
('64', 222, 4, 19, 455288) And fling remains at them, don’t you?
('64', 222, 5, 20, 455326) But you, reformers, do not so much as fling the remains at them.
('64', 222, 5, 21, 455391) In your zeal for reform, you starve them.
('64', 222, 5, 22, 455433) We don’t starve them.
('64', 222, 5, 23, 455455) Whilst we observe untouchability, we have that much sympathy for them.
('64', 222, 5, 24, 455526) You always say the Harijan campaign has nothing to do with questions of eating and drinking or with the question of marriage.
('64', 222, 5, 25, 455652) Why, then, did you marry your boy Devdas to a Brahmin girl?
('64', 222, 5, 26, 455712) This is an irrelevant question.
('64', 222, 5, 27, 455744) But I must answer it.
('64', 222, 5, 28, 455766) The marriage was no part of the Harijan movement.
('64', 222, 5, 29, 455816) I did not allow the marriage as a leader of the anti untouchability campaign, but I allowed it as a Hindu reformer.
('64', 222, 5, 30, 455932) As a reformer of Hinduism, I want to restore the ancient varnashramadharma to its pristine purity.
('64', 222, 5, 31, 456031) Varnashramadharma lays down the functions and duties of various classes according to their special aptitudes and gifts and has nothing to do with questions of marraige and food and drink.
('64', 222, 5, 32, 456219) Now that you have raised the question of my son’s marriage, I shall summarize the considerations that weighed with me and would weigh with me on all such occasions: (1) The four varnas do not exist today, and, therefore, it is the duty of those who believe in the varnas to restore them by observing the
('64', 223, 0, 1, 456523) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 223, 1, 2, 456565) sovereign principles of purity and self restraint.
('64', 223, 1, 3, 456616) Let me tell you that, when I was told that there was mutual attachment between the two young people in question, I asked them to impose self restraint on themselves for a period of five years—not meet each other, not even to correspond with each other—and thus to prove the purity of their attachment.
('64', 223, 1, 4, 456918) They fulfilled the conditions and even then would not have the marriage until it was blessed by their parents.
('64', 223, 1, 5, 457029) (2) Even assuming that varnas exist,instances are not wanting in Mahabharata and other work of inter varna marriages.
('64', 223, 1, 6, 457147) (3) After all is said and done, the laws and codes governing personal conduct apply to the times in which they were framed.
('64', 223, 1, 7, 457271) The ruling principle is self restraint.
('64', 223, 1, 8, 457311) There are, besides, numerous texts in our smritis which contradict one another, and hence we cannot blindly accept every text as gospel truth.
('64', 223, 1, 9, 457454) We have to prove them on the touchstone of truth and non violence.
('64', 223, 1, 10, 457521) There are things, for instance, in Manusmriti which no author believing in ahimsa could ever have written and which run counter to the precepts in the same great work, precepts which would do credit to the spiritual genius of any race or clime.
('64', 223, 1, 11, 457766) I must expunge those texts as apocryphal, as we do in the case of many verses of doubtful authenticity which have crept into a much more recent work like, for instance, Tulsidas’s Ramayana.
('64', 223, 1, 12, 457956) For me, the text of Manu defining sanatana dharma—eternal religion—is all sufficing :
('64', 223, 2, 13, 458042) That dharma is eternal which is always observed by saintly men of learning, free form ill will and passion, and which appeals to one’s hridaya or sense of right
('64', 223, 3, 14, 458203) and justice.
('64', 223, 3, 15, 458216) As regards my own practice in matters of food and drink, everyone knows that I eat food from the hands of any human being, provided it is clean and pure.
('64', 223, 3, 16, 458370) It is a purely personal question and nota social question at all.
('64', 223, 3, 17, 458436) I am not out for reform in the matter, as I know that it can take care of itself, and I, therefore, do not seek to air my views in public.
('64', 223, 3, 18, 458575) My own sister would not eat food cooked by many, certainly not food touched by a Harijan, But I would not strive with her.
('64', 223, 3, 19, 458698) It should be enough for me that she discards untouchability and refuses to regard a human being an untouchable because of his birth.
('64', 223, 3, 20, 458831) Harijan, 24 8 1934
('64', 224, 0, 1, 458850) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 225
('64', 224, 1, 2, 458896) 274. SPEECH TO U. P. HARIJAN WORKERS, KANPUR 1
('64', 224, 2, 3, 458943) [July 24, 1934] 2
('64', 224, 3, 4, 458961) As regards the general complaint of municipal neglect, Gandhiji said they must rouse the members from their lethargy by directly approaching them as well as by educating the voters, who could then be expected to keep the members straight.
('64', 224, 3, 5, 459200) He was glad to learn that the non Hindu members of Cawnpore Municipality co operated whole heartedly with the Hindus as regards the welfare work among its Harijan employees, and he was sure that the Mussalman members of other municipalities, too, would be equally sympathetic when, as guardians of not one section but of the whole body of the public, they realized that ours was a purely humanitarian movement which had nothing to do with politics, that Harijans ministered to non Hindus no less than to Hindus and that insanitary conditions in Harijan quarters were a potential source of danger ot the whole of the city.
('64', 224, 3, 6, 459822) It was a notorious fact that Harijans did not enjoy the same amenitites as regards water supply, light,etc.
('64', 224, 3, 7, 459930) as the rest of the citizens did.
('64', 224, 4, 8, 459963) But irrespective of what the municipalities might do or fail to do, the Sangh
('64', 224, 5, 9, 460041) must try to secure decent liveing conditions for Harijans.
('64', 224, 5, 10, 460100) And this could be done with
('64', 224, 6, 11, 460128) ease and without any heavy expenditure.
('64', 224, 6, 12, 460168) First, they must see to the proper drainage
('64', 224, 7, 13, 460212) and cleaning of the Harijan quarters and the making of roads.
('64', 224, 7, 14, 460274) Slight repairs should be
('64', 224, 8, 15, 460299) carried out in the houses so as to allow a free passage to light and air.
('64', 224, 8, 16, 460373) If they placed
('64', 224, 9, 17, 460388) before municipalities a modest programme of improving the sanitation of Harijan
('64', 224, 10, 18, 460468) quarters, they would make a small grant of money to the Sangh and make them their
('64', 224, 11, 19, 460550) agents in carrying it out, for municipalities might not have at hand the worker
('64', 224, 12, 20, 460630) required, or if the workers were there, they might not have a keen interest in work of
('64', 224, 13, 21, 460717) this nature.
('64', 224, 14, 22, 460730) Secondly, they must obtain for Harijans a good supply of water.
('64', 224, 14, 23, 460794) Harijans in villages were worse off in this respect than their fellows in cities.
('64', 224, 14, 24, 460876) They had yet to develop strength enough to assert and maintain their right to draw water from public wells by seeking the protection of courts or otherwise.
('64', 224, 14, 25, 461033) Meanwhile the Sangh must construct for them good wells from which even the savarnas would be tempted to take
('64', 224, 15, 26, 461142) water for themselves, and during the period that these wells were under construction, reformers, must draw water for the Harijans and pour it into their pots.
('64', 224, 16, 27, 461301) Thirdly, the Sangh should establish good perparatory schools for Harijan children, where the teachers would not make a fetish of the 3 R’s, but try to teach their pupils to keep their person and clothes clean, so as to enable them at the end of six months to take their place in a line with savarna children of the same age.
('64', 224, 17, 28, 461626) 1 This appeared under the title : “Harijan Workers’ Guide”.
('64', 224, 17, 29, 461686) 2 From Valji G. Desai’s “Weekly Letter”
('64', 225, 0, 1, 461726) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 225, 1, 2, 461768) this, kindliness was more essential in a teacher then scholarship.
('64', 225, 1, 3, 461835) The Sangh would do well even to bring out a Harijan preparatory schoolmaster’s guide, showing him how he should impart to his charges the cultural training which savarna children received
('64', 225, 2, 4, 462023) in their homes.
('64', 225, 3, 5, 462039) Fourthly, as regrads Ashrams, he thought they had better fight shy of that big word and rather call their institutions ‘Chhatralayas’ (hostels) or ‘Udyogalayas’.
('64', 225, 3, 6, 462201) Personally he did not like that the institution at Sabarmati was called Harijan Ashram.
('64', 225, 3, 7, 462289) In these hostels they might supplement the ordinary education of the inmates at schools by teaching them some industry and religion, not through text books but in actual pracitce.
('64', 225, 3, 8, 462469) The superintendent must see that the members used their hands and feet and told the truth in their actual lives, insteand of merely reading copybook maxims about it.
('64', 225, 3, 9, 462635) In fact, he should be as father to them.
('64', 225, 3, 10, 462676) A couple of such institutions in each province should go a long way in the spread of culture and serve the purpose of comprehensive propaganda.
('64', 225, 4, 11, 462820) As regards total abstinence, Gandhiji said they could make an impression only if they entered into the drunkards’ lives and established an intimate personal relation with them.
('64', 225, 4, 12, 462997) It was no use merely getting them to sign a pledge.
('64', 225, 4, 13, 463049) They must find out the reasons why people took to drink.
('64', 225, 4, 14, 463106) They must devise substitutes for it, such as milk and tea, and organize games, lectures and such other diversions.
('64', 225, 5, 15, 463221) Finally, Gandhiji expressed his emphatic opinion that they had hardly touched the fringe of their problem so long as they had not penetrated into the villages, which were the stronghold of untouchability and where alone they could strike it a death blow.

('64', 228, 1, 2, 468149) So far as work for the Harijans was concerned, Mahatma Gandhi invited the pepople to go and see for themselves the plight of the Harijans all over India.
('64', 228, 1, 3, 468303) Regarded as outcastes they were denied even the elementary rights of human beings in the name of religion.
('64', 228, 1, 4, 468410) Those who countenanced untouchability were guilty of a grave social sin.
('64', 228, 1, 5, 468483) To keep more than 6,00,00,000 people outside the pale of the society in the name of religion was an unpardonable act for which there was no justification.
('64', 228, 2, 6, 468638) In South Africa and America the whites showed the same aversion and intolerance to the members of the darker races as were being shown in India by the caste people to the members of the Depressed Classes, but in those countries the whites had taken up that attitude as a political weapon for their own aggrandizement.
('64', 228, 2, 7, 468956) They did not take recourse to religion as was being done by the caste Hindus in India to justify their action.
('64', 228, 3, 8, 469067) Due to this impossible attitude, for which there was no justification, people like Dr. Ambedkar, for whose intelligence, sincerity and other sterling qualities he had the highest respect though he differed from him on the Harijan question, were regarded as untouchables by the Hindu society.
('64', 228, 3, 9, 469359) The Depressed Classes were not born depressed but had been kept oppressed for centuries by the cast Hindus.
('64', 228, 4, 10, 469467) There was no justification for the theory advanced by the caste Hindus that the Depressed Classes had been born as untouchables for their sins in their previous lives.
('64', 228, 4, 11, 469635) It was rank injustice and sin to deny the rights of human beings to the members of the Depressed Classes.
('64', 228, 5, 12, 469741) The surest way of serving God, according to all religions, is to serve the poor.
('64', 228, 5, 13, 469822) By using khadi people could easily do that.
('64', 228, 5, 14, 469866) If the use of khadi became more popular millions of people in India, who were now starving, would be assured of at least one full meal.
('64', 228, 5, 15, 470002) A person buying even one rupee worth of khadi could be sure that fifteen annas of it would go to the poor and keep them from starvation.

('64', 229, 2, 5, 471163) 281. ANSWERS TO ZAMINDARS 1
('64', 229, 3, 6, 471191) July 25, 1934
('64', 229, 4, 7, 471205) QUESTION.
('64', 229, 4, 8, 471215) The karachi Congress passed a resolution laying down the fundamental rights of the people and, since it recognized private property, nationalist zamindars have supported the Congress.
('64', 229, 4, 9, 471399) But the new Socialist Party in the Congress threatens the extinction of private property.
('64', 229, 4, 10, 471489) How would it affect the Congress policy?
('64', 229, 4, 11, 471530) Do you not think that this will precipitate class war?
('64', 229, 4, 12, 471585) Will you prevent it?
('64', 229, 5, 13, 471606) ANSWER.
('64', 229, 5, 14, 471614) The Karachi resolution can be altered only by an open session of the next Congress, but let me assure you that I shall be no party to dispossessing the propertied classes of their private property without just cause.
('64', 229, 5, 15, 471831) My object is to reach your hearts and convert you so that you may hold all your private property in trust for your tenants and use it primarily for their welfare.
('64', 229, 5, 16, 471994) I am aware of the fact that within the ranks of the Congress a new party called the Socialist Party is coming into being and I cannot say what would happen if that party succeeds in carrying the Congress with it.
('64', 229, 5, 17, 472207) But I am quite clear that if a strictly honest and unchallen geable referendum of our millions were to be taken, they would not vote for wholesale expropriation of the propertied classes.
('64', 229, 5, 18, 472395) I am working for the co operation and co ordination of capital and labour and of landlords and tenants.
('64', 229, 5, 19, 472499) It is open to you to join the Congress as much as it is open to the poorest by paying the fee of four annas and subscribing to the Congress creed.
('64', 229, 5, 20, 472646) But I must utter a note of warning .
('64', 229, 5, 21, 472683) I have always told the mill owners that they are not exclusive owners of the mills.
('64', 229, 5, 22, 472767) Workmen are equal sharers in the ownership.
('64', 229, 5, 23, 472811) In the same way, I would tell you that the ownership of your land belongs as much to the ryots as to you and you may not squander your gains in luxurious or extravagant
('64', 229, 6, 24, 472980) 1 According to the source, this appeared as “reported by Mahadev Desai” and “revised by Gandhiji”.
('64', 229, 6, 25, 473079) Gandhiji answered the questions which “the zamindars read out to him”.
('64', 230, 0, 1, 473150) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 231
('64', 230, 1, 2, 473196) living, but must use them for the wellbeing of the ryots.
('64', 230, 1, 3, 473254) Once you make your ryots experience a sense of kinship with you and a sense of security that their interests as members of the family will never suffer at your hands, you may be sure that there cannot be a class war between you and them.
('64', 230, 1, 4, 473492) Class war is foreign to the essential genius of India which is capable of evolving a form of communism broad based on the fundam ental rights of all and equal justice to all.
('64', 230, 1, 5, 473667) The Ramarajya of my dream ensures the rights alike of prince and pauper.
('64', 230, 1, 6, 473740) You may be sure that I shall throw the whole weight of my influ ence in preventing class war.
('64', 230, 1, 7, 473834) I do not know what I am going to do after the termination of my self imposed restriction on August 3, but I shall try my best to avoid going back to prison.
('64', 230, 1, 8, 473991) But it is difficult to predict anything with certainty in a situation of which I am unaware today.
('64', 230, 1, 9, 474090) But supposing that there is an attempt unjustly to deprive you of your property, you will find me fighting on your side.
('64', 230, 2, 10, 474211) We propose to support Congress candidates in the next Assembly elections.
('64', 230, 3, 11, 474285) But we have our misgiving about the policy they will adopt in the Assembly.
('64', 230, 4, 12, 474361) you persuade the Parliamentary Board to dispel our fears?
('64', 230, 4, 13, 474419) I invite you to discuss this thing with the members of the Parlia mentary Board.
('64', 230, 4, 14, 474500) I know however that no member will talk of expro priation or extinction of private property.
('64', 230, 4, 15, 474593) They will certainly insist on a radical reform in your relations with the ryots but that should be no new thing to you.
('64', 230, 4, 16, 474713) Even Sir Malcolm Hailey 1 and Lord Irwin appealed to you to realize and live up to the spirit of the times., If you will only do this, you may be sure that we shall be able to evolve an indigenous socialism of the purest type.
('64', 230, 4, 17, 474940) Socialism and communism of the West are based on certain conceptions which are fundamentally differnt from ours.
('64', 230, 4, 18, 475053) One such conception is their belief in the essential selfishness of human nature.
('64', 230, 4, 19, 475135) I do not subscribe to it, for I know that the essential difference between man and brute is that the former can respond to the call of spirit in him and can rise superior to the passions that he owns in common with the brute and therefore superior to selfishness and vilence which belong to brute nature and not to the immortal spirit of man.
('64', 230, 5, 20, 475478) 1 Governor of U.P.
('64', 231, 0, 1, 475497) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 231, 1, 2, 475539) That is the fundamental conception of Hinduism, which has years of penance and austerity at the back of the discovery of their truth.
('64', 231, 1, 3, 475673) That is why whilst we had had saints who have burnt out their bodies and laid down their lives in order to explore the secrets of the soul, we have none as in the West who have laid down their lives in exploring the remotest or highest regions of earth.
('64', 231, 1, 4, 475927) Our socialism or communism should theref ore be based on non violence and on the harmonious co operation of labour and capital and the landlord and the tenant.
('64', 231, 1, 5, 476087) There is nothing in the Congress creed or policy that need frighten you.
('64', 231, 1, 6, 476160) All your fears and misgivings, permit me to tell you, are those of a guilty conscience.
('64', 231, 1, 7, 476248) Wipe out the injustice that you may have been consciously or unconsciously guilty of and shed all fear of the Congress and Congressmen.
('64', 231, 1, 8, 476384) Once You turn a new leaf in the relations between zamindars and ryots, you will find us on your side jealously guarding your private rights and property.
('64', 231, 1, 9, 476538) When I say “us”, I have Pandit Jawaharlal also in mind, for I am sure that on this essential principle of non violence there is no differnce between us.
('64', 231, 1, 10, 476691) He does indeed talk of nationalization of property, but it need not frighten you.
('64', 231, 1, 11, 476773) The nation cannot own property except by vesting it in individuals.
('64', 231, 1, 12, 476841) It simply ensures its just and equitable use and prevents all possible misuse, and I do not think you can have any possible objection to holding your property for the benefit of the ryots.
('64', 231, 1, 13, 477030) The ryots have themselves no greater ambition than to live in peace and freedom and they will never grudge you your possession of property provided you use it for them.
('64', 231, 2, 14, 477199) You have been almost avoiding us and the villages.
('64', 231, 2, 15, 477250) Why not have candidates belonging to the rural classes?
('64', 231, 2, 16, 477306) You may be sure that we are going to penetrate the villages and establish healthy relations with you.

('64', 232, 7, 17, 478242) 284. DISCUSSION WITH CONGRESS, HARIJAN AND KHADI WORKERS
('64', 232, 8, 18, 478299) KANPUR, July 26, 1934
('64', 232, 9, 19, 478321) Mahatma Gandhi had another busy day in the course of which he held illuminating discussions with Congress, Harijan, and khadi workers.
('64', 232, 9, 20, 478456) He gave them sound advice on many matters and pointed out that they must develop a very high sense of discipline without which no real advancement was possible.
('64', 232, 9, 21, 478617) He pointed out that the volunteers like others had their shortcomings but it was neither difficult nor impossible to overcome them.
('64', 232, 9, 22, 478749) They must keep before themselves the high ideals which impelled them to render service to their fellow brothers and keep in view that they were servants of the people and as such always prepared to render them help in every possible way.
('64', 232, 9, 23, 478987) He pointed out that they should be ever ready to suffer for the cause of the country and discharge the duties entrusted to them honestly and faithfully and diligently.
('64', 232, 9, 24, 479155) Volunteers, he said, had great obligations and it was more difficult to discharge those obligations than it was to speak about their duties.
('64', 232, 10, 25, 479296) He exhorted khadi workers to carrty on their work unceasingly and nothing
('64', 232, 11, 26, 479370) should deter them from carrying on khadi sales, for the use of khadi alone was the
('64', 232, 12, 27, 479453) surest way of serving God and the service of God was the service of the poor.
('64', 232, 12, 28, 479531) The use
('64', 232, 13, 29, 479539) of khadi would provide food to the starving millions .
('64', 232, 13, 30, 479594) Mahatma Gandhi is reported
('64', 232, 14, 31, 479621) to have pointed our to Congressmen to seek the co operation of non Congress
('64', 232, 15, 32, 479697) workers, give them offices and serve under them.
('64', 232, 15, 33, 479746) Let them have no distinction
('64', 232, 16, 34, 479775) between Congress and non Congressmen, he said, for Harijan work interested
('64', 232, 17, 35, 479850) everybody alike.
('64', 232, 17, 36, 479867) He felt that healthy co operation between Congress and non

('64', 233, 2, 3, 480042) appealed to them to seek the help of non Congress workers as much as they possibly
('64', 233, 4, 4, 480125) The Congress workers asked for his views on class war and desired to know if it could be non violent.
('64', 233, 4, 5, 480227) He replied that it could not be non violent in the form in which it was spoken of today.
('64', 233, 4, 6, 480316) Whenever there came up question of crushing anybody it became violence.

('64', 233, 6, 16, 481517) Whenever there came up question of crushing anybody it became violence.

('64', 234, 1, 2, 482848) Balkrishna Sharma questioned whether we should ameliorate the tenants’ condition while zamindars were there.

('64', 234, 7, 16, 484519) found after attempting to penetrate into the masses’s mind all these years since 1920

('64', 236, 3, 5, 487976) 287. DISCUSSION WITH SOCIALISTS’ DEPUTATION 1
('64', 236, 4, 6, 488022) BENARES, July 27, 1934
('64', 236, 5, 7, 488045) The deputationists, who were invited by Gandhiji for a free and open discussion, are reported to have told him that the Congress programme as it stood fell far short of the socialist demand and that he should use his influence with the Congress executive to adopt the socialist programme as envisaged in the Patna resolution of the Socialists’ Conference.
('64', 236, 6, 8, 488401) Gandhiji is understood to have deprecated frequent and unwarranted socialist attacks on the Congress executive and its programme and plainly told socialists that they should either be prepared to abide by the Congress decision without attempting to create unnecessary splits in Congress ranks or take over charge of the Congress machinery including its executive.
('64', 236, 6, 9, 488765) He and other members of the executive were prepared to hand over control and make room for them if they so desired.
('64', 236, 7, 10, 488881) The socialists, who were evidently taken aback, came out disappointed in the main, but somewhat mollified by the assurance that Gandhiji gave them that he would put their suggestions before the Working Committee and after full consultation with them get the Committee to pass a resolution clearly defining the Congress attitude towards socialism, confiscation of property, etc.

('64', 237, 5, 10, 490020) 289. MANIFESTO OF CONGRESS PARLIAMENTARY BOARD 1
('64', 237, 6, 11, 490069) BENARES, July 29, 1934 The Parliamentary Board appointed by the All India Congress Committee at its meeting at Patna on May 19 appeals to the voters of the Legislative Assembly at the forthcoming elections to record their votes in favour of Congress candidates.
('64', 237, 6, 12, 490331) The Congress policy has been declared and the Board has received mandate from the Working Committee in the following resolution 2 passed by that body at Bombay on June 18. Though much has been written for and against the part of the resolution regarding the so called Communal Award, the line is absolutely clear so far as Congress candidates are concerned.
('64', 237, 6, 13, 490689) By common consent it is intrinsically bad.
('64', 237, 6, 14, 490732) It is anti national.
('64', 237, 6, 15, 490753) But the Congress cannot refuse to take into,account the attitude of Mussalmans in general, who seem to want the Award; nor can the Congress accept it as the Hindus and Sikhs reject it.
('64', 237, 6, 16, 490938) No other policy than that explained above is consistent with the aim and history of the Congress, which has throughout stood for peace and unity and founded all its activities on the firm belief that the various communities of India will act justly and honourably towards one another.
('64', 237, 6, 17, 491223) The only thing, therefore, that Congress candidates and the Congress can do is to promote and assist in securing an agreed solution.
('64', 237, 6, 18, 491356) Suffice it to say that we shall never reach such a solution by

('64', 238, 1, 5, 491999) If the Award is bad, the White Paper is worse.

('64', 238, 1, 7, 492253) The White Paper is in no way designed to secure complete or even partial independence.
('64', 238, 1, 8, 492340) It can easily retard the nation’s progress towards it.

('64', 238, 1, 17, 493516) Time will show what the position of the Congress is in the country.
('64', 238, 1, 18, 493584) The voters at the forthcoming elections also may show it somewhat.

('64', 238, 1, 22, 494096) We have in contemplation the former.

('64', 240, 1, 2, 496933) legislature.

('64', 240, 1, 4, 497081) In order to end the exploitation of the masses, political freedom must include real economic freedom of the starving millions.
('64', 240, 1, 5, 497208) The economic policy of the Party will, therefore, be in accordance with the fundamental rights and the economic programme contained in the Karachi resolution of the All India Congress Committee.
('64', 240, 1, 6, 497403) The Board, therefore, appeals to voters to unmistakably show that they stand for the Congress methods and objective and that they condemn the present bureaucratic rule and its methods.

('64', 240, 2, 8, 497609) 290. SPEECH ON MANIFESTO OF CONGRESS PARLIAMENTARY BOARD, BENARES
('64', 240, 3, 9, 497675) July 29, 1934
('64', 240, 4, 10, 497689) It is understood that in the course of discussion on the manifesto of the Parliamentary Board at the joint meeting of the Working Committee and the Parliamentary Board, Mahatma Gandhi made a most powerful and moving speech in support of the manifesto.
('64', 240, 4, 11, 497941) He wanted to remove one misapprehension about the Congress Parliamentary Board.
('64', 240, 4, 12, 498021) He had come to the conclusion that parliamentary mentality had come to stay in the Congress.
('64', 240, 4, 13, 498114) It was no longer a question of the obstructionist policy alone of the old Swaraj Party.
('64', 240, 4, 14, 498202) The Parliamentary Board’s idea was of contesting the elections to go to legislatures and remain there for the rejection of the White Paper, the convening of a constituent assembly, the repeal of repressive laws and the carrying on of a constructive programme and other national activities of the Congress to the extent opportunities were available.
('64', 240, 5, 15, 498551) Referring to the work of the old Swaraj Party, Mahatma Gandhi is reported to have said that he felt satisfied that they had rendered a good account of themselves in the legislatures.
('64', 240, 5, 16, 498734) There was not a single speech of the late Pandit Motilal Nehru of which the nation need be ashamed.
('64', 240, 5, 17, 498834) They had produced a good moral effect.
('64', 240, 6, 18, 498873) Answering a question whether Congressmen may not be in a minority.
('64', 240, 6, 19, 498940) Mahatma Gandhi said that while hoping for a majority, he was willing to concede that they might be in minority; but all depended on the personnel of the minority.
('64', 240, 7, 20, 499103) Referring to Mr. Satyamurti, he said that even if he were in the minority of one, he (Mahatma Gandhi) was confident that he would give a good account of himself.
('64', 240, 7, 21, 499265) The Congress was also learning by experience as the Government was.
('64', 240, 7, 22, 499333) Several things in connection with civil disobedience and other matters might not have happened as they had happened, had Congressmen been in the legislatures.
('64', 241, 0, 1, 499492) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('64', 241, 1, 3, 499854) Even if civil disobedience were to be re started, the Congress might not call on Congress members in the legislatures to come out, for after all, even if a crore of Indians offered civil disobedience they could easily spare about a thousand Congressmen for work in the legislatures.

('64', 241, 6, 10, 500705) 291. SPEECH AT CENTRAL BOARD MEETING OFHARIJAN SEVAK SANGH, BENARES 1
('64', 241, 7, 11, 500775) July 29, 1934 There are two questions on which I have to speak to you —one in connection with the nature of the whole organization and the other in connection with the idea of having a training institution for workers for a period or for life.
('64', 241, 7, 12, 501019) To take up the first question, I know there is a general desire to introduce an element of democracy—voting, election, etc.—into our organization.
('64', 241, 7, 13, 501166) I was torn between two oppo sites; but, after having gone through this nine months’ tour, I have come to the conclusion that in an organization like ours there is no room for election, democracy or anything of that sort.
('64', 241, 7, 14, 501387) Ours is a different kind of institution.
('64', 241, 7, 15, 501428) It is not a people’s organization in the ordinary sense.
('64', 241, 7, 16, 501485) We handle money merely as self appointed trustees, using it solely for the benefit of the Harijans, and in such a manner that it finds its way directly into their pockets.
('64', 241, 7, 17, 501657) Ours is an organization formed with a view to doing our duty by those whom we have
('64', 241, 8, 18, 501740) 1 Published under the title “A Talk to the Workers”, this appeared as “a condensed summary” of Gandhiji’s speech “at the conclusion of the proceedings” at Kashi Vidyapith on July 28 and 29.
('64', 242, 0, 1, 501930) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 243
('64', 242, 1, 2, 501976) despised.
('64', 242, 1, 3, 501986) We are an organization to give effect to the pledge given to Harijans at Bombay by the great meeting 1 held under the chairm anship of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviyaji.
('64', 242, 1, 4, 502152) The people who pay to the Harijan Fund do so, we assume, in a penitent spirit, and all we have to do is to utilize it for the Harijans.
('64', 242, 1, 5, 502288) To run an elective institution means expense and delay.
('64', 242, 1, 6, 502344) Our aim is to distribute the funds among the Harijans with as little expenditure and delay as possible.
('64', 242, 1, 7, 502448) We do not want any intervening medium between Harijans and ourselves.
('64', 242, 1, 8, 502518) We are mere trustees, and the trust descends to those whom we appoint.
('64', 242, 1, 9, 502589) There are people who say the donors ought to have a voice in the administration.
('64', 242, 1, 10, 502670) I should say, they do not know.
('64', 242, 1, 11, 502702) To me, he who pays a pie is as much a donor as, say, Ghanshyamdas Birla, who pays ten to fifty thousand.
('64', 242, 1, 12, 502807) Maybe, the value of that pie is greater than the ten thousand rupees that Ghanshyamdas may give.
('64', 242, 1, 13, 502904) I have seen in Orissa poor people untying their knots and parting with their coppers.
('64', 242, 1, 14, 502990) That has given me more hope and greater pleasure than the thousands, however willingly given.
('64', 242, 1, 15, 503084) The thousands without the coppers would be of little use in this cause of self purification.
('64', 242, 1, 16, 503177) But the thousands of the poor donors will never receive the vote.
('64', 242, 1, 17, 503243) We do not even know their names.
('64', 242, 1, 18, 503276) And still we are as much responsible to them as to the big donors, or even more.
('64', 242, 1, 19, 503357) We are a charitable institution, depending for its existence upon honest and efficient management.
('64', 242, 1, 20, 503456) And if we are to have the highest amount of efficiency, we have to select the best and the most honest workers.
('64', 242, 1, 21, 503568) Having said this, I leave it entirely to you to decide.
('64', 242, 1, 22, 503624) I look at the movement as purely religious, moral or humanitarian.
('64', 242, 1, 23, 503691) It is to me purely one of reparation and penitence.
('64', 242, 1, 24, 503743) I do not know to what extent all the lakhs of donors share with me the belief in the penitential character of the work.
('64', 242, 1, 25, 503863) But so far as I am concerned, I would declare that there is nothing in my mind save the desire to expiate for sins we have been guilty of all these years.
('64', 242, 1, 26, 504018) Therefore I cannot think of the movement in terms of any political end.

('64', 253, 2, 11, 526535) I have been asked by Acharya Anandshankar Dhruva to say a few words on the Gita to the students of the Kashi Vishvavidyalaya.
('64', 253, 2, 12, 526661) It is not without hesitation that I have accepted the invitation.
('64', 253, 2, 13, 526727) What right can a layman like myself have to discourse on a theme like this in the presence of a savant like him?
('64', 253, 2, 14, 526840) I have neither his profound scholarship, nor the deep study of our ancient religious lore which Pandit Malaviyaji, for instance, has.
('64', 253, 2, 15, 526974) Sardar Vallabhbhai, in his charcteristic manner, asked me this morning whether scavengers, cultivators, and weavers like him and me were not altogether out of court in a city of pundits like Kashi and in the presence of such learned pundits as Malaviyaji and Acharya Dhruva, and in a way he was right.

('64', 253, 2, 18, 527537) I am here to bear witness to the fact that in the Yeravda Prison it gave him more strength and sustenance than meat and drink.
('64', 253, 2, 19, 527664) To read the Gita in the original he set about learning Sanskrit with the help of Pandit Satavalekar’s Sanskrit self instructor, and once he had started on it, the book seldom left his hands.
('64', 253, 2, 20, 527855) It occupied him from morning till night.
('64', 253, 2, 21, 527896) It was not an obsession of an unoccupied mind, as you might be tempted to think, but the result of deep thought.

('64', 254, 1, 2, 528353) the Vedas?
('64', 254, 1, 3, 528364) The Bhagavata?
('64', 254, 1, 4, 528379) Devipurana?
('64', 254, 1, 5, 528391) Early in my childhood I had felt the need of a scripture that would serve me as an unfailing guide through the trials and temptations of life.
('64', 254, 1, 6, 528534) The Vedas could not supply that need, if only because to learn them would require fifteen to sixteen years of hard study at a place like Kashi, for which I was not ready then.
('64', 254, 1, 7, 528710) But the Gita, I had read somewhere, gave within the compass of its 700 verses the quintessence of all the Shastras and the Upanishads.
('64', 254, 1, 8, 528845) That decided me.
('64', 254, 1, 9, 528862) I learnt Sanskrit to enable me to read the Gita.
('64', 254, 1, 10, 528911) Today the Gita is not only my Bible or my Koran; it is more than that—it is my mother.
('64', 254, 1, 11, 528998) I lost my earthly mother who gave me birth long ago; but this eternal Mother has completely filled her place by my side ever since.
('64', 254, 1, 12, 529130) She has never changed, She has never failed me.
('64', 254, 1, 13, 529178) When I am in difficulty or distress, I seek refuge in Her bosom.
('64', 254, 1, 14, 529243) Often in the course of my struggle against untouchability, I am confronted with conflicting opinions delivered by doctors of learning.
('64', 254, 1, 15, 529378) Some of them tell me that untouchability as it is practised today has no sanction in Hinduism and they bless my efforts to eradicate it; but there are some others who maintain that untouchability has been an essential part of Hinduism from the very beginning.
('64', 254, 1, 16, 529638) Which authority should I follow under the circumstances?
('64', 254, 1, 17, 529695) I feel absolutely at sea.
('64', 254, 1, 18, 529721) The Vedas and the smritis are of no avail to me.
('64', 254, 1, 19, 529770) I then approach the Mother and say, “Mother, these learned pundits have put me in a predicament.
('64', 254, 1, 20, 529867) Help me out of my perplexity.” And the Mother, with a smile, says in reply: “The assurance 1 held out by me in the ninth chapter is not meant for the Brahmins only, but for the sinner and the outcaste, the downtrodden and the disinherited, too.’ But in order to be worthy of that promise, we must be obedient and devoted children of the Mother and not disobedient and disloyal children, who only make a pretence of devotion.
('64', 254, 1, 21, 530292) It is sometimes alleged against the Gita that it is too difficult a work for the man in the street.
('64', 254, 1, 22, 530392) The criticism, I venture to submit, is ill founded.
('64', 254, 1, 23, 530444) The Gita enabled the late Lokamanya, out of his encyclopaedic learning and study, to produce a monumental commentary.
('64', 254, 1, 24, 530562) For him it was a store house of profound truths to exercise his intellect upon.
('64', 254, 1, 25, 530642) But that need not scare away a lay reader.
('64', 254, 1, 26, 530685) If you find all the eighteen chapters too difficult to negotiate, make a careful study of the first three chapters only.
('64', 254, 1, 27, 530806) They will give you in a
('64', 254, 2, 28, 530830) 1 Bhagavad Gita, IX.

('64', 255, 1, 2, 530893) nutshell what is propounded in greater detail and from different angles in the remaining fifteen chapters.
('64', 255, 1, 3, 531000) Even these three chapters can be further epitomized in a few verses that can be selected from these chapters.
('64', 255, 1, 4, 531110) Add to this the fact that at three distinct 1 places the Gita goes even further and exhorts to us to leave alone all ‘isms’ and take refuge in the Lord alone, and it will be seen how baseless in the charge that the message of the Gita is too subtle or complicated for lay minds to understand.
('64', 255, 1, 5, 531403) The Gita is the universal Mother.
('64', 255, 1, 6, 531437) She turns away nobody.

('64', 255, 1, 11, 531738) It is reserved only for the humble in spirit who brings to Her worship a fullness of faith and an undivided singleness of mind.
('64', 255, 1, 12, 531866) There never was a man who worshipped Her in that spirit and went back disappointed.
('64', 255, 1, 13, 531950) Our students are prone to be upset by trifles.

('64', 255, 1, 16, 532170) It teaches us that we have a right to action only but not to the fruit thereof and that success and failure are one and the same thing at bottom.
('64', 255, 1, 17, 532316) 2 It calls upon us to dedicate ourselves, body, mind and soul, to pure duty, and not to become mental voluptuaries at the mercy of all chance desires and undisciplined impulses.
('64', 255, 1, 18, 532494) As a satyagrahi, I can declare that the Gita is ever presenting me with fresh lessons.
('64', 255, 1, 19, 532581) If somebody tells me that this is my delusion, my reply to him would be that I shall hug this delusion as my richest treasure.

('64', 255, 1, 21, 532801) I am a lover and devotee of Tulsidas.
('64', 255, 1, 22, 532839) I adore the great spirit that gave to an aching world the allhealing mantra of Ramanama.
('64', 255, 1, 23, 532928) But I am here today, not to present Tulsidas to you, but to ask you to take up the study of the Gita, not in a carping or critical spirit, but in a devout and reverent spirit.

('64', 260, 3, 14, 542336) 305. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, BENARES 1
('64', 260, 4, 15, 542378) [August 2, 1934] 2
('64', 260, 5, 16, 542397) It is a tragedy that religion for us means today nothing more than restriction on food and drink, nothing more than adherence to a sense of superiority and inferiority.
('64', 260, 5, 17, 542566) Let me tell you that there cannot be grosser ignorance than this.
('64', 260, 5, 18, 542632) Birth and observance of forms cannot determine one’s superiority or inferiority.
('64', 260, 5, 19, 542713) Character is the only determining factor.
('64', 260, 5, 20, 542755) God did not create men with the badge of superiority or inferiority, and no scripture which labels a human being as inferior or untouchable because of his or her birth can command our allegience; it is a denial of God and Truth which is God.
('64', 260, 5, 21, 542997) God, who is the embodiment of Truth and Right and Justice, can never have sanctioned a religion or practice which regards a fifth of our vast population as untouchables.

('64', 260, 5, 25, 543424) But no work or conduct can render a man or woman untouchables for all time.

('64', 261, 1, 2, 543818) Ramayana—declares in no uncertain terms that whoever seeks refuge in Him, whoever takes His name, shall be free from sin.
('64', 261, 1, 3, 543940) That covenant is for all mankind.
('64', 261, 1, 4, 543974) There is another simple test that I want you to apply to this question.
('64', 261, 1, 5, 544046) Every species, human and sub human, has some distinguishing mark, so that you can tell a man from a beast, or a dog from a cow and so on.
('64', 261, 1, 6, 544184) Have the so called untouchables any distingui shing mark declaring them to be untouchables?
('64', 261, 1, 7, 544276) They are as much human as every one of us, and we do not regard even sub human beings as bearing the mark of untouchability.

('64', 261, 1, 11, 544581) The only way in which we can expiate this sin of centuries is to befriend the Harijans by going to their quarters, by hugging their children as you do your own, by interesting yourselves in their welfare, by finding out whether they get enough to eat, whether they get pure water to drink, whether they have the fresh light and air that you enjoy as of right.
('64', 261, 1, 12, 544941) The other way is for each of you to start the spinning sacrifice and to pledge vourselves to wear khadi, which supports millions of these submerged human beings.
('64', 261, 1, 13, 545103) The spinning sacrifice will help you in some slight measure to identify yourselves with them, and every yard of khadi you wear will mean some coppers going into the pockets of the Harijans and the poor.
('64', 261, 1, 14, 545306) The last thing is to contribute your mite to the Harijan Fund, which has no other end but the amelioration of the lot of the Harijans.

('64', 270, 5, 27, 563075) 2 According to the source, Gandhiji was then “asked to give his impressions about the Harijan tour”.
('64', 271, 0, 1, 563176) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 271, 1, 2, 563218) finished without interruption and according to the programme that was settled from time to time.
('64', 271, 1, 3, 563315) The impression left on my mind is that untouchability is on its last legs.
('64', 271, 1, 4, 563390) Millions who attended the meetings were not all utterly ignorant of all I had to say to them.
('64', 271, 1, 5, 563484) They were certainly not indifferent.
('64', 271, 1, 6, 563521) The intensive propaganda carried on by sanatanists had left no room for ignorance or indifference.
('64', 271, 1, 7, 563620) Nothing was left undone to prejudice the mass mind against the movement.
('64', 271, 1, 8, 563693) The grossest falsehoods were broadcast.
('64', 271, 1, 9, 563733) It would be wrong, therefore, to say that the attendance of multitudes at the meetings was purely a personal compliment to me and had no reference to my message.
('64', 271, 1, 10, 563895) I am quite sure that the message has appealed to the reason of the masses.
('64', 271, 1, 11, 563970) I am also fully aware that all of them are not yet ready to translate their beliefs into practice.
('64', 271, 1, 12, 564069) But I consider it a tremendous gain that the masses have begun to believe in the truth of the message.
('64', 271, 1, 13, 564172) It makes the task of the workers easier than before.
('64', 271, 1, 14, 564225) To show how heartily the masses have taken part in the movement.
('64', 271, 1, 15, 564290) I should mention that the eight lakhs of rupees collected during the past nine months represent contributions from the poorest.
('64', 271, 1, 16, 564418) It has occupied hours, from day to day, of our accountants to count coppers and small coins, whether collected at public meetings or at railway stations.
('64', 271, 1, 17, 564572) People are not known to contribute to the cause which they have utterly disliked.
('64', 271, 1, 18, 564654) The third thing I should say about the tour is that a demonstrable awakening, on a large scale, has taken place among the Harijans.
('64', 271, 1, 19, 564786) Many of them have made unsolicited statements before me that the position had considerably advanced and that they had confidence that untouchability would be a thing of the past in the near future.
('64', 271, 1, 20, 564984) I share their confidence.
('64', 271, 1, 21, 565010) If the movement goes on as it is doing at present— and I have no doubt that it will go on—it must cause daily increasing awakening among Harijans and when they fully realize how they can substantially help themselves, and how in many cases the law is with them, whether savarna Hindus like it or not, Harijans would make good their position.
('64', 271, 1, 22, 565352) I would, of course, hope that savarna Hindus will realize the wickedness of untouchability as it is practised today and get rid of it themselves rather than that they should be compelled to do so by circumstances beyond their control.
('64', 271, 1, 23, 565587) Whatever happens, untouchability cannot survive for many years.
('64', 271, 1, 24, 565651) Much mischievous agitation has been led on this question in spite of my having cleared the position at the beginning stage of the Harijan tour.
('64', 271, 1, 25, 565795) No temple was opened where there was not a virtual consensus of opinion, in favour of opening, on the part of those who
('64', 272, 0, 1, 565915) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 273
('64', 272, 1, 2, 565961) were in the habit of visiting those temples.
('64', 272, 1, 3, 566006) Nobody has ever suggested that when practically the whole congregation is in favour of such opening, the temple should not be opened.
('64', 272, 1, 4, 566140) As to the Temple entry Bill, I hold that it is a legal necessity.
('64', 272, 1, 5, 566206) But I have declared times without number that I would be no party to forcing the Bill through the Assembly by the vote of a mixed majority.
('64', 272, 1, 6, 566346) It is, therefore, that Mr. C. Rajagopalachariar is ascertaining independently Hindu sentiment in the legislature and if Hindu sentiment is against the Bill, so far as I am concerned, it will be withdrawn.
('64', 272, 1, 7, 566551) With all these reservations, therefore, all agitation against the measures ought to die, unless I commit a breach of faith.
('64', 272, 1, 8, 566675) How I wish that the undivided attention of all Hindus was concentrated on the ameliorative measures that have been adopted by the Harijan Sevak Sangh !
('64', 272, 2, 9, 566827) Let me finally add that no money has been spent during these nine months in connection with the temple entry agitation or the Bill.
('64', 272, 2, 10, 566959) No temple has been built out of Harijan purses.
('64', 272, 3, 11, 567007) The Hindu, 3 8 1934

('64', 273, 2, 3, 567370) August 4, 1934
('64', 273, 3, 4, 567385) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I thought I would write a few lines before the fast which commences in two days’ time.
('64', 273, 3, 5, 567493) We are in a train just now.
('64', 273, 3, 6, 567521) We shall reach Wardha tomorrow morning.
('64', 273, 3, 7, 567561) Devdas had come to Kashi.
('64', 273, 3, 8, 567587) He parted from us at Allahabad.
('64', 273, 3, 9, 567619) This time it may be said that I have already begun the fast; but how can I claim merit for it?
('64', 273, 3, 10, 567714) Not being well during the last two days I have not taken milk for four days.
('64', 273, 3, 11, 567791) For two days I have been eating only fruit, and that too in small quantity.
('64', 273, 3, 12, 567867) Even so, my strength and weight have remained satisfactory.
('64', 273, 3, 13, 567927) That means that the body has lost nothing yet except the toxins.
('64', 273, 3, 14, 567992) There is, therefore, no cause at all for worry.
('64', 273, 3, 15, 568040) By the time you get this letter, everything will have been over.
('64', 273, 3, 16, 568105) Hence it even seems unnecessary to write all this.
('64', 273, 3, 17, 568156) But I thought you should know my condition as it is today.
('64', 273, 3, 18, 568215) Sushila seems to be giving you excellent help.
('64', 273, 3, 19, 568262) If she had a stronger body, she could have done much more.
('64', 273, 3, 20, 568321) But what she is able to do is quite satisfactory.
('64', 273, 3, 21, 568371) You must have received the name selected for Arun and sent to you.
('64', 273, 3, 22, 568438) Ramdas’s health causes anxiety.
('64', 273, 3, 23, 568470) He has become very much emaciated.
('64', 273, 3, 24, 568505) If you can get passes for him and Dr. Sharma, I would send them over there.
('64', 273, 3, 25, 568581) But don’t ask for them as a special favour.
('64', 273, 3, 26, 568625) If they can be obtained in the natural course, it is all right.

('64', 274, 1, 2, 569023) 318. TALK ON RAMANAMA 1
('64', 274, 2, 3, 569047) August 4, 1934 2
('64', 274, 3, 4, 569064) Ramanama to me is all sufficing.
('64', 274, 3, 5, 569097) There are as many names of God as His manifestations, but sages have, as a result of their lifelong penance, devised names to be uttered by the devotees, in order to be able to commune with the Nameless.
('64', 274, 3, 6, 569301) There are other mantras than Ramanama, but for me that is supreme.
('64', 274, 3, 7, 569368) It has become part of my life.
('64', 274, 3, 8, 569399) When [I was] a child, my nurse taught me to repeat Ramanama whenever I felt afraid or miserable and it has been second nature with me with growing knowledge and advancing years.
('64', 274, 3, 9, 569577) I may even say that the work is in my heart, if not actually on my lips, all the twenty four hours.
('64', 274, 3, 10, 569677) It has been my saviour and I am ever stayed on it.
('64', 274, 3, 11, 569728) In the spiritual literature of the world, the Ramayana of Tulsidas takes a foremost place.
('64', 274, 3, 12, 569819) It has charms that I miss in the Mahabharata and even in Valmiki’s Ramayana.
('64', 274, 3, 13, 569896) Harijan, 17 8 1934
('64', 274, 4, 14, 569915) 319. INTERVIEW AT JABALPUR 3
('64', 274, 5, 15, 569944) August 4, 1934
('64', 274, 6, 16, 569959) Mahatma Gandhi, in spite of weakness, appeared cheerful.
('64', 274, 6, 17, 570016) Interviewed, he said that at present he was quite well and his temperature was normal.
('64', 274, 6, 18, 570103) He also stated that he would commence his seven days’ fast from August 7. He also inquired about the local political atmosphere and party quarrels.
('64', 274, 7, 19, 570251) Replying, Seth Govind Das said that though the atmosphere is tense with party feelings, efforts are being made to bring about a satisfactory compromise between the rival groups of the workers, adding that in the event of a satisfactory compromise not being arrived at, he along with his friends had decided to retire from political arena and patiently wait for the time when his service will be required by the motherland.
('64', 274, 8, 20, 570674) Mahatma Gandhi expressed approval of Seth Govind Das’s views and said that in order to avoid conflict and friction, he had always advised loyal Congressmen to retire from the field of party feeling and to devote their energies in other constructive and solid programme.

('64', 275, 7, 9, 571622) [August 6, 1934] 2
('64', 275, 8, 10, 571641) With the completion of the tour and the year of probation during which I was to devote myself wholly to the Harijan cause and take no active part in politics, many have begun to speculate about my immediate future activity.
('64', 275, 8, 11, 571865) Happily, the fast is to predetermine my course during it and for some time after.
('64', 275, 8, 12, 571947) But, even apart from the fast, I should like to say that, whilst it is open to me to speak and write on politics, I propose to keep myself aloof from them as much as possible.
('64', 275, 8, 13, 572123) The joy of the past self restraint is too fresh to fade from the memory and to induce volubility of political speech.
('64', 275, 8, 14, 572241) My partiality for Harijan and kindered causes persists and will persist, I hope, to the end of my life.
('64', 275, 8, 15, 572345) And what is true of my general attitude is truer still of Harijan.
('64', 275, 8, 16, 572412) No doubt I shall have to do more political work.
('64', 275, 8, 17, 572461) I may be compelled to resort to civil resistance.
('64', 275, 8, 18, 572511) But the Harijan will remain what it has been ever since its inception.
('64', 275, 8, 19, 572582) It will rigorously eschew all politics.
('64', 275, 8, 20, 572622) But now that I expect to have some time for them, it will, I hope, deal with constructive causes, more especially those that have direct connection

('64', 276, 2, 5, 573753) 322. SWADESHI
('64', 276, 3, 6, 573767) [August 6, 1934] 1
('64', 276, 4, 7, 573786) Early in the year, if not immediately after my convalescence last year, I was called upon by those who were interested in swadeshi to frame a definition so as to answer the many difficulties that faced them.
('64', 276, 4, 8, 573994) I had to bear in mind the various shades of swadeshi in textiles.
('64', 276, 4, 9, 574060) I put together the definitions that were suggested.
('64', 276, 4, 10, 574112) I had correspo ndence with Shri Shivarao and Shri Jalbhai Naoroji and well as others.
('64', 276, 4, 11, 574198) I failed to frame a definition that would suit all cases and found that it was impossible to frame an exhaustive definition .
('64', 276, 4, 12, 574324) As I was travelling far and wide, I had the opportunity of observing things and of seeing how swadeshi organizations were functioning.
('64', 276, 4, 13, 574459) I came to the conclusion that the existing practice was an unconscious fraud upon the public and that many workers of ability were wasting their energy in a vain effort.
('64', 276, 4, 14, 574629) They were practising self deception.
('64', 276, 4, 15, 574666) This strong language, whilst it correctly describes my mental attitude, is not intended to cast any reflection whatsoever upon the workers in swadeshi organizations.
('64', 276, 4, 16, 574832) They were doing their best without realizing that they were moving in a vicious circle and labouring under self deception.
('64', 276, 4, 17, 574955) Let me explain what I mean.
('64', 276, 4, 18, 574983) We were holding exhibitions of things that were in no need of special help or of advertisement for their sale.
('64', 276, 4, 19, 575094) In their case, our interposition can either stimulate the prices of their wares or set up unhealthy rivalries between flourishing but competing firms.
('64', 276, 4, 20, 575245) We may profess to gratuitously help textile, sugar and rice mills and, respectively, kill the village spinning wheel, the handloom and their product, khadi, the village cane crusher and its product, the vitamin laden and nourishing gur or molasses, and the hand pounder
('64', 276, 5, 21, 575515) 1 Vide the preceding item, footnote 1.
('64', 277, 0, 1, 575554) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 277, 1, 2, 575596) and its product, unpolished rice, whose pericarp, which holds the vitamins, is left intact by these pounders.
('64', 277, 1, 3, 575706) Our clear duty is, therefore, to investigate the possibility of keeping in existence the village wheel, the village crusher and the village pounder, and, advertising their products, discovering their qualities, ascertaining the condition of the workers and the number displaced by the power driven machinery and discovering the methods of improving them, whilst retaining their village character, to enable them to stand the competition of the mills.
('64', 277, 1, 4, 576157) How terribly and criminally we have neglected them !
('64', 277, 1, 5, 576210) Here, there is no antagonism to the textile or the sugar or the rice mills.
('64', 277, 1, 6, 576286) Their products must be preferred to the corresponding foreign products.
('64', 277, 1, 7, 576358) If they were in danger of extinction from foreign competition, they should receive the needed support.
('64', 277, 1, 8, 576461) But they stand in no such need.
('64', 277, 1, 9, 576493) They are flourishing in spite of foreign competition.
('64', 277, 1, 10, 576547) What is needed is protection of the village crafts and the wokers behind them from the crushing competition of the power driven machinery, whether it is worked in India or in foreign lands.
('64', 277, 1, 11, 576737) It may be that khadi, gur and unpolished rice have no intrinsic quality and that they should die.
('64', 277, 1, 12, 576835) But, except for khadi, not the slightest effort has been made, so far as I am aware, to know anything about the fate of the tens of thousands of villagers who were earning their livelihood through crushing cane and pounding rice.
('64', 277, 1, 13, 577065) Surely, there is in this work enough for an army of patriots.
('64', 277, 1, 14, 577127) The reader will say, ‘but this is very difficult work’.
('64', 277, 1, 15, 577183) I admit.
('64', 277, 1, 16, 577192) But it is most important and equally interesting.
('64', 277, 1, 17, 577242) I claim that this is true, fruitful and cent per cent swadeshi.
('64', 277, 1, 18, 577306) But I have as yet merely touched the fringe of the question.
('64', 277, 1, 19, 577367) I have merely sampled three big organized industries and shown how voluntary swadeshi agencies need to concentrate their attention solely on the corresponding unorganized village industries that are dying for want of voluntary and intelligent, organized help.
('64', 277, 1, 20, 577627) There are numberless other village, and even town, crafts that need public support, if they are to live and thus maintain the thousands of poor artisans depending upon them for their daily bread.
('64', 277, 1, 21, 577823) Every ounce of work in this direction tells.
('64', 277, 1, 22, 577868) Every hour given to this work means the sustenance of some deserving workers.
('64', 277, 1, 23, 577946) It is my certain conviction that, if work is done on a systematic basis in this direction, the department doing it will become self supporting, new talent will be stimulated, the educated as well as the uneducated unemployed will find honourable employment without displacing anyone and crores will be added yearly to the wealth of this
('64', 278, 0, 1, 578283) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 279
('64', 278, 1, 2, 578329) country, which is getting progressively impoverished.
('64', 278, 1, 3, 578383) Here is enough profitable and entertaining work and to spare for all the swadeshi leagues put together.
('64', 278, 1, 4, 578487) The recent resolution 1 of the Working Committee on ‘swadeshi’ means all this and much more.
('64', 278, 1, 5, 578580) It provides limitless work for the creative genius in the country.
('64', 278, 1, 6, 578647) Harijan, 10 8 1934

('64', 280, 5, 18, 582266) 327. STATEMENT ON FAST 1
('64', 280, 6, 19, 582291) August 6, 1934 As I enter upon the seven days’ fast from tomorrow (Tuesday), I would like to re emphasize the necessity on the part of Harijan workers helping the cause by greater personal purification and greater concentration on the work before them.
('64', 280, 6, 20, 582544) The monster of untoucha bility will not be killed without constant and ceaseless effort on the part of workers who have faith in the mission and who have by patient toil built up personal purity and integrity.
('64', 280, 6, 21, 582754) Let everyone also realize that fasting is not for everyone and for every occasion.
('64', 280, 6, 22, 582837) Fasting without faith may even lead to disastrous consequences.
('64', 280, 6, 23, 582901) All such spiri tual weapons are dangerous when handled by unqualified persons.
('64', 280, 6, 24, 582980) I would like to utter a word of warning to Congressmen and Congress workers.
('64', 280, 6, 25, 583057) During the coming seven days I shall be filled with thoughts about them as I have been during the past month.
('64', 280, 6, 26, 583167) The acrimony with which Congress elections have been fought in some places and the unclean methods adopted by Congress workers by manipulating votes and grossly abusing the rule about habitual wearing of khadi have filled me with horror and dismay.
('64', 280, 6, 27, 583416) The constitution provides for truthful and non violent methods.
('64', 280, 6, 28, 583480) In some provinces, at some elections, truth and non violence have been conspicuous by their absence.
('64', 280, 6, 29, 583581) Though my fast has nothing to do with these unclean methods, how I wish Congress workers will detect my
('64', 280, 7, 30, 583685) 1 Extracted from “The Purification Week”.
('64', 280, 7, 31, 583727) According to Mahadev Desai this was written by Gandhiji “towards the evening”.
('64', 281, 0, 1, 583806) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 281, 1, 2, 583848) anguish in the words I have written and lighten it during the purification week by resorting to self introspection and resolving to make the Congress an organization in keeping with its creed, so that anyone who cares may without difficulty find it to be a living embodiment of its creed.
('64', 281, 1, 3, 584137) I shall certainly be praying for its purification.
('64', 281, 1, 4, 584188) Purity of this, the greatest national organization cannot but help the Harijan movement, since the Congress is also pledged to the removal of the curse.
('64', 281, 1, 5, 584341) Finally, I ask all friends, whether in India or outside, no matter to what faith or race they may belong, to pray that God may bless the forthcoming little penance.
('64', 281, 1, 6, 584506) Harijan, 17 8 1934

('64', 282, 6, 33, 587483) today and to ask you not to worry.

('64', 283, 1, 2, 587749) would reach you only after the fast will have become a faint memory?
('64', 283, 1, 3, 587818) That the fast is a fitting finish to the Harijan tour I have no doubt.
('64', 283, 1, 4, 587889) It is a great spiritual instrument.
('64', 283, 1, 5, 587925) That Protestantism has virtually discarded it is a distinct loss to it and the world seeing what a power it is today in the world.
('64', 283, 1, 6, 588056) However, I must not argue about it.
('64', 283, 1, 7, 588092) If it is a desideratum of the soul, there are too many seekers after truth among Protestants not to feel the want of it sooner or later.
('64', 283, 1, 8, 588229) During this month I shall be resting in Wardha and collecting my thoughts.
('64', 283, 1, 9, 588304) What is in store for me in September I do not know.

('64', 283, 1, 11, 588376) To go to the Frontier Province or to Bengal or to both alternately is a craving of the soul.
('64', 283, 1, 12, 588469) Where to go first I do not know.

('64', 283, 1, 21, 589188) I go to the Frontier to find the truth and act accordingly.

('64', 283, 1, 26, 589616) What occupies my mind at present is how to achieve the purity of the Congress and to rid the Ashram here of subtle untruth and breaches of brahmacharya.
('64', 283, 1, 27, 589769) Perhaps you are not sufficiently interested in such things.

('64', 284, 1, 2, 590074) 330. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, WARDHA 1
('64', 284, 2, 3, 590114) August 7, 1934 I can say from experience that fasting is an essential part of Ashram life.
('64', 284, 2, 4, 590205) The assault on Lalnath was certainly the occasion of the fast, but as I have said in my public statement 2, this fast is intended for the purification of many.
('64', 284, 2, 5, 590365) If I were to have regard to all the incidents and happenings that have prompted me to take such a step, I should have to go on a much longer fast.
('64', 284, 2, 6, 590512) But I am painfully aware of my own physical and spiritual limitations and hence could not think of a longer fast.
('64', 284, 2, 7, 590626) Our Ashram was certainly in my mind when I made the decision to fast.
('64', 284, 2, 8, 590696) There are two enemies against which we must guard—untruth and impurity.
('64', 284, 2, 9, 590768) Purity of the mind is essential for the observance of all the vows.
('64', 284, 2, 10, 590836) If the mind is not pure, no amount of physical restraint would avail.
('64', 284, 2, 11, 590906) The Gita teaches us that the man who restrains the organs of action, whilst he allows the mind to run after the objects of the senses, is a hypocrite.
('64', 284, 2, 12, 591057) 3 We may fail to restrain the mind, but let us not be hypocrites.
('64', 284, 2, 13, 591123) If we fail, let us own up, rather than be guilty of the double sin of untruth and want of restraint.
('64', 284, 2, 14, 591224) For not only telling lies is untruth, but guilty silence or hiding one’s state of mind from one’s guardians is also untruth.
('64', 284, 2, 15, 591349) Let my fast spur you on to further self purification and self introspection.
('64', 284, 2, 16, 591426) We have also to remember that one of the objects of the Ashram is the abolition of untouchability, it is one of our eleven vows 4 .
('64', 284, 2, 17, 591558) Now an effective observance of that vow is impossible without an observance of the other vows, especially of truth and non–violence.
('64', 284, 2, 18, 591691) In fact, no worker in the cause of removal of untouchability—and we are all workers in the cause—is fitted for it, unless and until he is pledged to observe truth and non violence in thought, word and deed.
('64', 284, 2, 19, 591898) In a word, no service is possible without self purification.
('64', 284, 2, 20, 591959) If, therefore, we think more and more of self purification as a result of this fast, we should be able to bring about the proper atmosphere.
('64', 284, 2, 21, 592100) I shall be constantly thinking of you this whole week and I want you to co operate with me.
('64', 284, 2, 22, 592192) I am hoping that God will pull me through this ordeal, and I know that all of you will help me with your prayers.
('64', 284, 3, 23, 592306) Harijan, 17 8 1934
