('64', 288, 1, 2, 596879) 336. DISCUSSION WITH GUJARAT VIDYAPITH TEACHERS 1
('64', 288, 2, 3, 596929) [AfterAugust 14, 1934] 2
('64', 288, 3, 4, 596954) The real work of the Vidyapith lies in the villages.
('64', 288, 3, 5, 597007) I have been stressing this point ever since the inception of the Vidyapith, but until a couple of years ago, when it was declared an illegal organization and most of our professors and boys were imprisoned, we laboured under the impression that the work could be carried on only through a central institute situated in the capital town of Gujarat.
('64', 288, 3, 6, 597355) But under the altered conditions, and now that we have some breathing time to put our heads together and to collect our thoughts we shall do well to hark back to the original conception and think of our future work in its terms.
('64', 288, 3, 7, 597584) Each member of a live institution must be a living embodiment of the ideals of the institution, wherever he may be, and when such a state of things is brought about, it is the same thing whether the institution has a habitation and a corporate existence or not.
('64', 288, 3, 8, 597846) I would, therefore, expect every one of you who has cherished the ideals of the Vidyapith and who is pledged to serve it to go straight to the villages and start living those ideals there.
('64', 288, 3, 9, 598035) Each one of you will thus be a peripatetic Vidyapith, teaching the ideals by means of his own personal example.
('64', 288, 3, 10, 598147) It is quite conceivable that a host of workers, after having lived the life in the villages according to the ideals of the Vidyapith, re establish the central institute in a village.
('64', 288, 3, 11, 598330) But we are not in that position today.
('64', 288, 3, 12, 598369) We have yet to gain all that experience on which alone you can build the new Vidyapith.
('64', 288, 3, 13, 598457) The centre of this village worker’s life will be the spinning wheel.
('64', 288, 3, 14, 598526) I am sorry I have not been able yet to bring home to anyone the message of the spinning wheel in all its implications.
('64', 288, 3, 15, 598645) The reason is that my life itself is not a true echo of the message.
('64', 288, 3, 16, 598714) But it came home to me again and again during my nine months’ peregrinations in India.
('64', 288, 3, 17, 598801) We have not yet sufficiently realized that hand spinning is a supplementary industry of universal application and scope in India.
('64', 288, 3, 18, 598931) The village weaver cannot live but for the spinning wheel.
('64', 288, 3, 19, 598990) He gets his yarn no doubt from the mills, but he is doomed to destruction, if he is
('64', 288, 4, 20, 599074) 1 The discussion appeared under the title “What Is Village Work” as a summary of Gandhiji’s talk, with the following introductory note by Mahadev Desai : “During his convalescence after the fast, Gandhiji has been giving part of his time each day to workers coming with their doubts and difficulties.
('64', 288, 4, 21, 599375) Among these were some of the professors of the Gujarat Vidyapith.” Gandhiji broke his fast on August 14, 1934. 2 ibid
('64', 289, 0, 1, 599493) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 289, 1, 2, 599535) to remain for ever dependent on the mills.
('64', 289, 1, 3, 599578) Today, the spinning–wheel has established itself in our economic life only to the extent that it is needed to minister to the clothing needs of the new class of khadi weavers that has sprung up during the past decade.
('64', 289, 1, 4, 599796) But a large body like the Spinners’ Association cannot justify its existence to fulfil that limited object.
('64', 289, 1, 5, 599904) The idea at the back of khadi is that it is an industry supplementary to agriculture and co–extensive with it, that it is the life–breath of millions of Harijan weavers who derive their sustenance from it.
('64', 289, 1, 6, 600110) The spinning wheel cannot be said to have been established in its own proper place in our life, until we can banish idleness from our villages and make every villge home a busy hive.
('64', 289, 1, 7, 600293) Unemployment and idleness of millions must lead to bloody strife.
('64', 289, 1, 8, 600359) Khadi is the only alternative to this and not the so–called socialism, which presupposes industrialism.
('64', 289, 1, 9, 600463) The socialism that India can assimilate is the socialism of the spinning–wheel.
('64', 289, 1, 10, 600543) Let the village worker, therefore, make the wheel the central point of his activities.
('64', 289, 1, 11, 600630) The worker will not be spinning regularly but will be working for his bread with the adze or the spade or the last, as the case may be.
('64', 289, 1, 12, 600766) All his hours minus the eight hours of sleep and rest will be fully occupied with some work.
('64', 289, 1, 13, 600859) He will have no time to waste.
('64', 289, 1, 14, 600890) He will allow himself no laziness and allow others none.
('64', 289, 1, 15, 600947) His life will be a constant lesson to his neighbours in ceaseless and joy–giving industry.
('64', 289, 1, 16, 601038) Bodily sustenance should come from body labour, and intellectual labour is necessary for the culture of the mind.
('64', 289, 1, 17, 601152) Division of labour there will necessarily be, but it will be a division into various species of body labour and not a division into intellectual labour to be confined to one class and body labour to be confined to another class.
('64', 289, 1, 18, 601381) Our compulsory or voluntary idleness has to go.
('64', 289, 1, 19, 601429) If it does not go, no panacea will be of any avail, and semi–starvation will remain the eternal problem that it is.
('64', 289, 1, 20, 601545) He who eats two grains must produce four.
('64', 289, 1, 21, 601587) Unless the law is accepted as universal, no amount of reduction in population would serve to solve the problem.
('64', 289, 1, 22, 601699) If the law is accepted and observed, we have room enough to accommodate millions more to come.

('64', 290, 1, 2, 602187) bilities.
('64', 290, 1, 3, 602197) If he will go to the village as a teacher, he will go there no less as a learner.
('64', 290, 1, 4, 602279) He will soon find that he has much to learn from the simple villagers.
('64', 290, 1, 5, 602350) He will enter into every detail of village life, he will discover the village handicrafts and investigate the possibilities of their growth and their improvement.
('64', 290, 1, 6, 602513) He may find the villagers completely apathetic to the message of khadi, but he will, by his life of service compel interest and attention.
('64', 290, 1, 7, 602652) Of course, he will not forget his limitations and will not engage in, for him, the futile task of solving the problem of agricultural indebtedness.
('64', 290, 1, 8, 602800) Sanitation and hygiene will engage a good part of his attention.
('64', 290, 1, 9, 602865) His home and his surroundings will not only be a model of cleanliness, but he will help to promote sanitation in the whole village by taking the broom and the basket round.
('64', 290, 1, 10, 603038) He will not attempt to set up a village dispensary or to become the village doctor.
('64', 290, 1, 11, 603122) These are traps which must be avoided.
('64', 290, 1, 12, 603161) I happened during my Harijan tour to come across a village where one of our workers who should have known better had build a pretentious building in which he had housed a dispensary and was distributing free medicine to the villages around.
('64', 290, 1, 13, 603402) In fact, the medicines were being taken from home to home by volunteers and the dispensary was described as boasting a register of 1,200 patients a month!
('64', 290, 1, 14, 603557) I had naturally to criticize this severely.
('64', 290, 1, 15, 603601) That was not the way to do village work, I told him.
('64', 290, 1, 16, 603654) His duty was to inculcate lessons of hygiene and sanitation in the village folk and thus to show them the way of preventing illness, rather than attempt to cure them.
('64', 290, 1, 17, 603821) I asked him to leave the palace like building and to hire it out to the Local Board and to settle in thatched huts.
('64', 290, 1, 18, 603937) All that one need stock in the way of drugs is quinine, castor oil and iodine and the like.

('64', 290, 1, 25, 604635) Do not proceed on the assumption that you cannot proceed with rural instruction without first teaching the children or adults how to read and write.

('64', 291, 1, 2, 604826) Lots of useful information on current affairs, history, geography and elementary arithmetic, can be given by word of mouth before the alphabet is touched.
('64', 291, 1, 3, 604981) The eyes, the ears and the tongue come before the hand.

('64', 299, 1, 3, 618579) He said he would continue to stay in Wardha during convalescence unless some pressing engagement took him out of it.
('64', 299, 1, 4, 618696) If you ask me whether I thought anything about the Congress during the seven days, I can say as I have stated in the columns of Harijan That I constantly thought of Congressmen.
('64', 299, 1, 5, 618874) I was not thinking in terms of politics and therefore not of what the Congress had to gain in the wake of independence, but I was concentrating on the great necessity of achieving internal purity.
('64', 299, 1, 6, 619071) Letters have been coming to me from Congressmen confirming my fears about corrupt methods that have crept into the Congress ranks over Congress elections and the like.
('64', 299, 1, 7, 619239) How I wished, during all the seven days that I was lying on my bed, that every man and woman belonging to the Congress would realize that he or she was in it, not in order to mount to office and fame, but to render mute service to the country !
('64', 299, 1, 8, 619484) I cannot understand the mutual mudslinging and violence of speech toward one another.
('64', 299, 1, 9, 619570) Civil disobedience is certainly not for those who have not learnt the art of voluntary obedience to law, even when it is irksome.
('64', 299, 1, 10, 619700) This elementary principle seems to have been altogether forgotten, or else one could not witness spirit of indiscipline and disobedience to laws and rules which we have ourselves enacted and to which we have voluntarily pledged ourselves to render obedience.
('64', 299, 1, 11, 619959) For me, therefore, every other thing has paled into insignif icance before this prime necessity of achieving internal purity, for I do feel that just as without the purity of Harijan workers untouch ability would not be removed so also do I feel that the Congress, as a powerful national organization, will perish unless it is sustained by internal purity of those who compose that organization.
('64', 299, 1, 12, 620355) At present, I have no other message to give, for my mind is still preoccupied with this predominant feeling.
('64', 299, 1, 13, 620464) The Hindu, 16 8 1934

('64', 301, 0, 1, 622496) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 301, 1, 2, 622538) 350. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU Unrevised August 17, 1934
('64', 301, 2, 3, 622596) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, Your passionate and touching letter 1 deserves a much longer reply than my strength will permit.
('64', 301, 2, 4, 622713) I had expected fuller grace from the Government.
('64', 301, 2, 5, 622762) However your presence has done for Kamala and incidentally for Mama what no drugs or doctors could have done.
('64', 301, 2, 6, 622872) I hope that you will be allowed to remain longer than the very few days you expect.
('64', 301, 2, 7, 622956) I understand your deep sorrow.
('64', 301, 2, 8, 622987) You are quite right in giving full and free expression to your feelings.
('64', 301, 2, 9, 623060) But I am quite sure that from our common standpoint a closer study of the written word will show you that there is not enough reason for all the grief and disappointment you have felt.
('64', 301, 2, 10, 623245) Let me assure you that you have not lost a comrade in me.
('64', 301, 2, 11, 623303) I am the same as you knew me in 1917 and after.
('64', 301, 2, 12, 623351) I have the same passion that you knew me to possess for the common goal.
('64', 301, 2, 13, 623424) I want complete independence for the country in the full English sense of the term.
('64', 301, 2, 14, 623508) And every resolution that has pained you had been framed with that end in view.
('64', 301, 2, 15, 623588) I must take full responsibility for the resolutions and the whole conception surrounding them.
('64', 301, 2, 16, 623683) But I fancy that I have the knack for knowing the need of the time.
('64', 301, 2, 17, 623751) And the resolutions are a response thereto.
('64', 301, 2, 18, 623795) Of course here comes in the difference of our emphasis on the method or the means which to me are just as important as the goal and in a sense more important in that we have some control over them whereas we have none over the goal if we lose control over the means.
('64', 301, 2, 19, 624062) Do read the resolution about ‘loose talk’ dispassionately.
('64', 301, 2, 20, 624121) There is not a word in it about socialism.
('64', 301, 2, 21, 624164) Greatest consideration has been paid to the socialists some of whom I know so intimately.
('64', 301, 2, 22, 624254) Do I not know their sacrifice?
('64', 301, 2, 23, 624285) But I have found them as a body to be in a hurry.
('64', 301, 2, 24, 624335) Why should they not be?
('64', 301, 2, 25, 624359) Only, if I cannot march quite as quick, I must ask them to halt and take me along with them.
('64', 301, 2, 26, 624452) That is literally my attitude.
('64', 301, 2, 27, 624483) I have looked up the dictionary meaning of socialism.
('64', 301, 2, 28, 624537) It takes me no further than where I was before I read the definition.
('64', 301, 2, 29, 624607) What will you have me to read to know its full content?
('64', 301, 3, 30, 624663) 1 Dated August 13; vide “Letter from Jawaharlal Nehru”, 13 8 1934
('64', 302, 0, 1, 624729) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 303
('64', 302, 1, 2, 624775) have read one of the books Masani 1 gave me and now I am devoting all my spare time to reading the book recommended by Narendra Deva.
('64', 302, 1, 3, 624909) You are hard on the members of the Working Committee.
('64', 302, 1, 4, 624963) They are our colleagues such as they are.
('64', 302, 1, 5, 625005) After all we are a free institution.
('64', 302, 1, 6, 625042) They must be displaced, if they do not deserve confidence.
('64', 302, 1, 7, 625101) But it is wrong to blame them for their inability to undergo the sufferings that some others have gone through.
('64', 302, 1, 8, 625213) After the explosion I want construction.
('64', 302, 1, 9, 625254) Therefore now, lest we do not meet, tell me exactly what you will have me to do and who you think will best represent your views.
('64', 302, 1, 10, 625384) As to the trust 2, I was not present.
('64', 302, 1, 11, 625422) Vallabhbhai was.
('64', 302, 1, 12, 625439) Your attitude betrays anger.
('64', 302, 1, 13, 625468) You should trust the trustees to do their duty.
('64', 302, 1, 14, 625516) I did not think there was anything wrong.
('64', 302, 1, 15, 625558) I was too preoccupied to concentrate on it.
('64', 302, 1, 16, 625602) I shall now study the papers and everything.
('64', 302, 1, 17, 625647) Of course your feelings will be fully respected by other trustees.
('64', 302, 1, 18, 625714) Having given you this assurance, I would ask you not to take this matter so personally as you have done.
('64', 302, 1, 19, 625819) It more becomes you generous nature to give the same credit to your co trustees for regard for Father’s memory that you would take for yourself.
('64', 302, 1, 20, 625964) Let the nation be the custodian of Father’s memory and you only as one of the nation.
('64', 302, 1, 21, 626050) I hope Indu is well and likes her new life.
('64', 302, 1, 22, 626094) And what about Krishna?

('64', 305, 1, 2, 628692) 355. LETTER TO BHASKAR MUKHERJI
('64', 305, 2, 3, 628724) August 18, 1934
('64', 305, 3, 4, 628740) MY DEAR BHASKAR, I have read your letter to Mahadev of the 15th instant.
('64', 305, 3, 5, 628813) I cannot help thinking that you have closed down the scavengers’ schools much too hastily.
('64', 305, 3, 6, 628904) The Section 91 that you quote, I certainly do not read in the manner you do.
('64', 305, 3, 7, 628981) It does not prohibit the Corporation from using even a part of the lakh of rupees for education among scavenger boys and girls.
('64', 305, 3, 8, 629109) On the contrary, I should read the Section to compel the Corporation to use a part of the funds amongst the scavengers.
('64', 305, 3, 9, 629229) The Section to be of any use can only mean that the Corporation will begin by spending the money among the poorest, and surely not among the fashionable suburbs of Calcutta for instance.
('64', 305, 3, 10, 629416) Has the Corporation taken legal opinion on the interpretation of the Section in question?
('64', 305, 3, 11, 629506) If, therefore, there is any chance of the Corporation retracing its steps in the matter, I ask for its reconsideration.
('64', 305, 3, 12, 629626) With reference to the penultimate paragraph of your letter I would like you to tell me in detail what work the Corporation has done, and is doing, for Harijans and what sum is spent during the past twelve months in their behalf.
('64', 305, 3, 13, 629855) That I am dictating this letter shows that I am gaining strength.
('64', 305, 3, 14, 629921) Jawaharlal’s release has brought relief to poor Kamala and relieved Jawaharlal’s many friends of a great burden of anxiety over Kamala’s ill health.
('64', 305, 3, 15, 630070) My love to baby and children.
('64', 305, 3, 16, 630100) I hope you are doing well in every respect.
('64', 305, 4, 17, 630144) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('64', 305, 4, 18, 630174) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('64', 308, 1, 2, 632926) 359. LETTER TO CALCUTTA CONGRESSMEN
('64', 308, 2, 3, 632962) August 19, 1934 I am afraid that your optimism is ill grounded, for I have seen nothing as yet to shake my confidence in the correctness of the Working Committee’s resolution.
('64', 308, 2, 4, 633138) The utmost limit within which accommodation was possible was prescribed in Benares.
('64', 308, 2, 5, 633222) There it stands.
('64', 308, 2, 6, 633239) Nobody approves of the Award—much less has anybody acquiesced in it.
('64', 308, 2, 7, 633308) Everybody condemns it.
('64', 308, 2, 8, 633331) But a Congressman, because he is a Congressman, can neither accept it nor reject it because if he did one or the other he would be taking sides and therefore not represent the whole nation.
('64', 308, 2, 9, 633521) I can easily respond to your optimism but if it is based on the belief that I shall any way influence the Working Committee to reconsider the resolution, I am afraid that your optimism is ill grounded.
('64', 308, 2, 10, 633723) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 24 8 1934

('64', 314, 1, 4, 641316) There is no possibility of my leaving the Congress immediately.

('64', 314, 1, 8, 641546) I seem to be obstructing the growth of the Congress.

('64', 314, 1, 10, 641735) Is it not your duty to save the Congress from it?
('64', 314, 1, 11, 641785) There may be no harm [in my remaining in the Congress] so long as I can think of some means of fighting the rot, but what can I do if I cannot think of any way except leaving the Congress?
('64', 314, 1, 12, 641974) My doing so will rid it of hypocrisy.

('64', 314, 1, 14, 642236) But that won’t be possible till I leave.

('64', 314, 1, 16, 642375) If the Congress removes them despite my opposition, would not that amount to expelling me?
('64', 314, 1, 17, 642466) Would it be desirable to let things go that far?

('64', 314, 1, 19, 642581) If you can come over, we shall discuss them at leisure.
('64', 314, 1, 20, 642637) We shall also have to think what I should do in September or after I have regained strength.

('64', 314, 1, 22, 642776) The time is drawing near for taking a decision.

('64', 319, 5, 9, 650506) 374. LETTER TO S. GANESAN
('64', 319, 6, 10, 650532) August 21, 1934
('64', 319, 7, 11, 650548) MY DEAR GANESAN, I am glad that your venture is making steady progress.
('64', 319, 7, 12, 650620) Don’t be in a hurry, but build on a solid foundation.
('64', 319, 7, 13, 650674) If the boy in question was merely a nominal convert and knew nothing of Christianity or of any religion in fact, in my opinion he never ceased to belong to the relegion of his birth.
('64', 319, 7, 14, 650857) And then there is no question of reconversion.
('64', 319, 7, 15, 650904) If, however, he was a bona fide convert it is none of your business to reconvert him.
('64', 319, 7, 16, 650990) His faith must be personal to him and he has to be answerable to God for what he actually is.
('64', 319, 7, 17, 651084) I hope this is quite clear.
('64', 319, 7, 18, 651112) There can be no objection to your admitting Christian boys, but they cannot be a charge on the ordinary Harijan Funds.
('64', 319, 7, 19, 651231) You have to procure scholarships for them from personal friends, if the students are otherwise deserving.
('64', 319, 7, 20, 651337) It would be a pity if they had to be turned out for want of funds.
('64', 319, 7, 21, 651404) And yet it would be wrong to disburse their expenses out of the Harijan Funds which are intended solely for Hindus.
('64', 319, 9, 22, 651520) BAPU SHRI S. GANESAN 8 PYCROFTS ROAD TRIPLICANE, MADRAS
('64', 319, 10, 23, 651576) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('64', 326, 2, 3, 660871) August 22, 1934
('64', 326, 3, 4, 660887) MY DEAR AGATHA, This is merely to tell you that I am slowly rebuilding the body.
('64', 326, 3, 5, 660968) The seven days’ rest was good at the price of seven or eight pounds of flesh.
('64', 326, 3, 6, 661046) I knew your anxiety which you showed in your letter and cable.
('64', 326, 3, 7, 661109) I could not avoid the fast.
('64', 326, 3, 8, 661137) Friends have to put up with that part of me.
('64', 326, 3, 9, 661182) For this last may not be the last of my fasts.
('64', 326, 3, 10, 661229) I can survive discredit by the world and not by myself.
('64', 326, 3, 11, 661285) Of the current events you will know from Mahadev and Pyarelal and the cuttings that Chandrashankar may be sending you.
('64', 326, 3, 12, 661404) These letter(s) are not, I think, duplicated to Mira.

('64', 326, 3, 17, 661633) 1 I expect to have full accounts from you and Polak.

('64', 326, 4, 19, 661723) He may be here on 26th.
('64', 326, 4, 20, 661747) Till then do not be anxious about the future.
('64', 326, 4, 21, 661793) I have no cut and dried plan.
('64', 326, 4, 22, 661823) Of course Bengal and the Frontier with Abdul Ghaffar Khan as the centre piece are there.
('64', 326, 4, 23, 661912) But I see no clear line of action.
('64', 326, 4, 24, 661947) I want to precipitate nothing.
('64', 326, 4, 25, 661978) But things may become impossible for me any moment.
('64', 326, 4, 26, 662030) I must have room to move.
('64', 326, 4, 27, 662056) The Black Hole will suffocate anybody—much more me, an open air creature.
('64', 326, 4, 28, 662130) A most unnatural condition is becoming naturalized in this unhappy land.
('64', 326, 4, 29, 662203) This is written to give you my mental condition, not to expect more from you than you are doing.
('64', 326, 4, 30, 662300) What can you the handful do, if we here can do nothing?
('64', 326, 4, 31, 662356) And I admit that we are doing nothing or not enough.
('64', 326, 4, 32, 662409) It is in this atmosphere that I have to act when this convalescence in finished.
('64', 326, 4, 33, 662490) You must not be alarmed.
('64', 326, 4, 34, 662515) What I have described is nothing new.
('64', 326, 4, 35, 662553) You know these things.

('64', 326, 4, 37, 662673) Not even all the ordinary civil disobedience prisoners have been discharged.

('64', 326, 4, 42, 662975) This gives no
('64', 326, 5, 43, 662989) 1 Vide “Letter to Agatha Harrison”, 7 8 1934

('64', 328, 4, 7, 665056) 386. LETTER TO S. N. GANGULI
('64', 328, 5, 8, 665085) August 22, 1934
('64', 328, 6, 9, 665101) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('64', 328, 6, 10, 665134) You are quite right in saying that I have not been able to discover any royal road to physical brahmacharya.
('64', 328, 6, 11, 665243) All that I can say is that you have to persevere along the lines suggested by me.
('64', 328, 6, 12, 665325) Pure food, fresh air and moderate amount of exercise are to yield the desired result.
('64', 328, 6, 13, 665411) Pranayama and some asanas have been reported also to produce good results.
('64', 328, 6, 14, 665486) Hipbaths are also valuable.
('64', 328, 6, 15, 665514) Mustard oil is a condiment which should be eschewed.
('64', 328, 6, 16, 665567) In fact, I would advise you to eschew all oils.
('64', 328, 6, 17, 665615) Vegetables should be boiled.
('64', 328, 6, 18, 665644) Starchy vegetables should be avoided, and so should be pulses.
('64', 328, 6, 19, 665707) You need not worry about milk.
('64', 328, 6, 20, 665738) Honey is no substitute for milk.
('64', 328, 6, 21, 665771) You should take a fair quantity everyday.
('64', 328, 6, 22, 665813) And above all you should persevere in praying and have faith that your prayer will be answered.

('64', 331, 0, 1, 669567) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 331, 1, 2, 669609) 389. STATEMENT TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('64', 331, 2, 3, 669655) [ On or before August 23, 1934 ] 2
('64', 331, 3, 4, 669690) What was offered was freedom of speech and vote to elect candidates who had real conscientious scruples over the acceptance of the Working Committee’s resolution on the Communal award.
('64', 331, 3, 5, 669875) This would not satisfy Panditji.
('64', 331, 3, 6, 669908) He desired full freedom of action for all.
('64', 331, 3, 7, 669951) This amounted to a nullification of the Working Committee’s resolution which the Committee could not do.
('64', 331, 3, 8, 670056) It was a mistake to suppose that the Working Committee’s resolution was a virtual acceptance of the Award.
('64', 331, 3, 9, 670163) The Committee neither accepted nor rejected the Award and thus proved its impartiality and national character.
('64', 331, 3, 10, 670274) It was the only way to arrive at an agreed solution which was sure to come if Congressmen, Hindus, Mussalmans and others, loyally and seriously worked out the resolution.
('64', 331, 4, 11, 670445) Mahatma Gandhi was then asked if Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya’s new organization could run the elections in the name of the Congress.
('64', 331, 4, 12, 670578) He replied that the Parliamentary Board was the only authorized body which could function in the name of the Congress.
('64', 331, 4, 13, 670697) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 24 8 1934

('64', 338, 0, 1, 681528) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 339
('64', 338, 1, 2, 681574) 401. INTERVIEW TO KHADI WORKERS 1
('64', 338, 2, 3, 681608) [On or before August 24, 1934] 2 Khaddar in a sense is purely an economic proposition.
('64', 338, 2, 4, 681695) A khaddar organization must be a business concern before everything else.
('64', 338, 2, 5, 681769) The democratic principle, therefore, cannot apply to it.
('64', 338, 2, 6, 681826) Democracy necess arily means a conflict of will and ideas, involving sometimes a war to the knife between these different ideas.
('64', 338, 2, 7, 681955) There can be no room for such conflict within a business organization.
('64', 338, 2, 8, 682026) Imagine parties, groups and the like in a business concern.
('64', 338, 2, 9, 682086) It must break to pieces under their weight.
('64', 338, 2, 10, 682130) But a khadi organization is more than a business concern.
('64', 338, 2, 11, 682188) It is a philanthropic institution designed to serve demos.
('64', 338, 2, 12, 682247) Such an institution cannot be governed by popular fancy.
('64', 338, 2, 13, 682304) There is no room in it for personal ambition.
('64', 338, 2, 14, 682350) “In reorganizing your khadi production, you should not forget that the science of khadi, in some respects, works on diametrically opposite lines to that of ordinary business.You know how Adam Smith in his Wealth of Nations, after laying down certain principles according to which economic phenomena are governed, went on to describe certain other things which constituted the “disturbing factor” and prevented economic laws from having free play.
('64', 338, 2, 15, 682797) Chief among these was the ‘human element’.
('64', 338, 2, 16, 682840) Now, it is this ‘human element’ on which the entire economics of khadi rests; and human selfishness, Adam Smith’s “pure economic motive”, constitutes the “disturbing factor” that has got to be overcome.
('64', 338, 2, 17, 683043) What applies to the production of mill cltoh, therefore, does not apply to khaddar.
('64', 338, 2, 18, 683127) Debasing of quality, adulteration, pandering to the baser tastes of humanity, are current staple in commercialized production; they have no place in khadi, nor has the principle of highest profit and lowest wages any place in khadi.
('64', 338, 2, 19, 683360) On the contrary, there is no such thing as pure profit in khadi.
('64', 338, 2, 20, 683425) And there should be no loss.
('64', 338, 2, 21, 683454) Loss there is, because we, the workers, are still incompetent novices.
('64', 338, 2, 22, 683525) In khadi, the prices realized return to the prime producers, the spinners, the others getting no more than their hire.
('64', 338, 3, 23, 683644) 1 This appeared under the title “Khadi—A New Orientation” as a “gist of Gandhiji’s remarks” to prominent khadi workers of Andhra, including Pattabhi Sitaramayya, Sitarama Sastri and Narayana Raju, The discussion continued for two days.
('64', 338, 3, 24, 683880) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 26 8 1934, which had reported that Pattabhi Sitaramayya left Wardha for Madras on August 24, 1934.
('64', 339, 0, 1, 684008) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 339, 1, 2, 684050) Then, take the question of standardization.
('64', 339, 1, 3, 684094) You cannot enforce it in khaddar.
('64', 339, 1, 4, 684128) As Rajagopalachari once remarked, a poor, ordinary spinner cannot always spin thread of a uniform quality.
('64', 339, 1, 5, 684235) She is not a machine.
('64', 339, 1, 6, 684257) Today she may be unwell, tomorrow her child may be ill and her mind will be distracted.
('64', 339, 1, 7, 684345) If you have love for the poor spinner or her child, you will not insist on having smooth, even thread always, but be satisfied with what she can give, so long as she gives her best in the condition in which she finds herself at the moment.
('64', 339, 1, 8, 684585) The sacred touch of her hand gives life and history to khadi which the machine made yarn can never give.
('64', 339, 1, 9, 684690) The art that is in the machine made article appeals only to the eye, the art in khadi appeals first to the heart and then to the eye.
('64', 339, 1, 10, 684824) I would, therefore, deprecate the bleaching of khadi.
('64', 339, 1, 11, 684878) It adds to the cost of production, affects the durability of cloth and makes the detection of fraud ever so much more difficult.
('64', 339, 1, 12, 685007) We must not pamper the popular fancy, but seek to cultivate a new taste.
('64', 339, 1, 13, 685080) A few washes in the ordinary course will suffice to make khadi perfectly white and give it a softness which bleaching destroys.
('64', 339, 1, 14, 685208) We must make everybody contribute his or her mite to reduce all unnecessary cost.
('64', 339, 1, 15, 685290) If, then, we treat khadi, not as an article of commerce, but as one necessary for the sustenance of semi starved millions, we must penetrate the spinner’s home had induce her to wear khadi made from her own yarn.
('64', 339, 1, 16, 685503) This at once reduces the cost of production and ensures automatic distribution.
('64', 339, 1, 17, 685583) So far, we have simply tried to manufacture khadi for the city people.
('64', 339, 1, 18, 685654) From insignificant begin nings, the production of khaddar has grown to several lakhs per year.
('64', 339, 1, 19, 685749) We have multiplied varieties.
('64', 339, 1, 20, 685779) But that does not satisfy me now.
('64', 339, 1, 21, 685813) Khadi was conceived with a much more ambitious object, i.e., to make our villages starvation proof.
('64', 339, 1, 22, 685913) This is impossible, unless the villagers will wear khadi themselves, sending only the surplus to the cities.
('64', 339, 1, 23, 686022) The singular secret of khadi lies in its salability in the place of its production and use by the manufacturers themselves.
('64', 339, 1, 24, 686146) Our overhead charges are today much too high for me.
('64', 339, 1, 25, 686199) If we concentrate attention on the central mission of khadi, they will be consi derably reduced.
('64', 339, 1, 26, 686296) The rules governing the reduction of the price of khadi are somewhat, if not wholly, different from those that apply to purely commercial articles produced chiefly for profit.
('64', 339, 1, 27, 686472) In khadi, there is a limitation to the improvement of tools.
('64', 339, 1, 28, 686533) But there is no limitation to the improvement fo human intelligence and honesty.
('64', 339, 1, 29, 686614) If we despair of these two, we must despair of khadi.
('64', 339, 1, 30, 686668) In khadi, therefore, we reduce cost by eliminating middlemen as far as is
('64', 340, 0, 1, 686742) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 341
('64', 340, 1, 2, 686788) consistent with the smooth running of the organization, which itself will be unnecessary when khadi is self supporting and self acting.
('64', 340, 1, 3, 686924) The science of khadi is still in its infancy.
('64', 340, 1, 4, 686970) It is a developing scie nce.
('64', 340, 1, 5, 686999) With every new discovery that I make in it, the realization comes to me all the more vividly how little I know of that science.
('64', 340, 1, 6, 687127) There is no other country in the world , with the possible exception of China, that is potentially so rich as India, with its inexhaustible, untapped reserves of man power.
('64', 340, 1, 7, 687300) Tap these reserves, and you at once banish poverty from this country; and hand spinning is the means by which this could be done.
('64', 340, 1, 8, 687430) All that we have done so far in khadi was necessary.
('64', 340, 1, 9, 687483) Without it we could not have reached the present stage.
('64', 340, 1, 10, 687539) But we have yet only touched the fringe of the problem.
('64', 340, 1, 11, 687595) We heve now need to take another step.
('64', 340, 1, 12, 687634) If , therefore, you will have autonomy for Andhra khadi, you can have it for the asking and without much trouble about the discharge of your obligations.
('64', 340, 1, 13, 687788) There is nothing to prevent you from working along the lines suggested by me.

('64', 340, 2, 15, 687885) 402. NOTES
('64', 340, 3, 16, 687896) ITS PHYSICAL EFFECT A few words about the physical effect of the recent fast will not be out of place.
('64', 340, 3, 17, 687999) No matter how much spiritually inclined a person may be, a physical act cannot but produce its corresponding physical effect.
('64', 340, 3, 18, 688125) The latter may be regulated or reduced by the spiritual effort, but it can never be completely overcome.
('64', 340, 3, 19, 688230) And as I have often fasted for health reasons, i.e., for physical effect, I have not failed to study from that standpoint all the fasts that were taken from spiritual motives.
('64', 340, 3, 20, 688406) During all the four fasts undertaken for the Harijan cause, I have noticed a particular dislike for water, whether wlith or without soda or salt, and whether hot or cold.
('64', 340, 3, 21, 688577) I have been able to bear, but only just bear, aerated water.
('64', 340, 3, 22, 688638) This inability to drink water has been the greatest drawback in my fasts.
('64', 340, 3, 23, 688712) I must mention that, being largely a fruitarian and having abstained from condiments of every description, except salt, practically for the past forty yeras, I rarely drink water even in the ordinary course.
('64', 340, 3, 24, 688920) All the liquid I need comes from the fresh juicy fruit and the non starch vegetables and honey and hot water drinks.
('64', 340, 3, 25, 689037) I have known many friends who have gone through long fasts, but I do not know anyone who had had the dislike for water
('64', 341, 0, 1, 689156) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 341, 1, 2, 689198) that I had.
('64', 341, 1, 3, 689210) Medical friends who have kindly helped me during my fasts have not been able to suggest anything within the permissible limits whereby they could make me drink water freely.
('64', 341, 1, 4, 689384) They have suggested and adopted remedies to reduce the evil effect of inability to drink enough water.
('64', 341, 1, 5, 689487) My purpose is to compare notes with those who have any knowledge of fasting and to discover a means whereby the dislike of water could be cured.
('64', 341, 1, 6, 689632) Though I do not know them, surely, there must be people who develop during their fasting periods the same repugnance to water that I do.
('64', 341, 1, 7, 689769) If any light can be thrown on the question, it will help many persons like me.
('64', 341, 1, 8, 689848) Much as I should like to avoid having to fast, I cannot make myself believe that the recent fast was the last in my life.
('64', 341, 1, 9, 689970) It is a matter beyond my control.
('64', 341, 2, 10, 690004) THE AJMER INCIDENT
('64', 341, 3, 11, 690023) Although Shri Ramnarayan Chaudhri and Shri Durgaprasad Chaudhri, captain of the volunteers in Ajmer, do not in any way wish to be absolved from any blame that may attach to them for forgetfulness or negligence in connection with the Ajmer incident, they are most anxious to have the blame removed from the volunteers who have been condemned in the Press and who they hold to be utterly blameless.
('64', 341, 3, 12, 690420) They have made careful investigations and find that not a single volunteer was involved in doing injury to Swami Lalnath or his party.
('64', 341, 3, 13, 690555) The investigation papers have been sent to me.
('64', 341, 3, 14, 690602) The only deadly piece of evidence in favour of the theory of the gulit of the volunteers has been utterly discredited.
('64', 341, 3, 15, 690721) The confessor appears to have been altogether a fictitious person, no trace can be found of him.
('64', 341, 3, 16, 690818) The newspaper that published the confession has failed to produce the name of the writer, and the Editor has made such acknowledgement in his paper and expressed regret for having published an unauthentic letter.
('64', 341, 3, 17, 691031) All the evidence, therefore, that I have hitherto received goes to show that no volunteer was involved in the affray.
('64', 341, 3, 18, 691149) My own statement has nothing in it to warrant the inference that the volunteers had actually assaulted Swami Lalnath or any of his party.
('64', 341, 3, 19, 691287) I had simply said that Swami Lalnath had said that volunteers were involved.
('64', 341, 3, 20, 691364) But in this belief he was evidently mistaken.
('64', 341, 3, 21, 691410) No trace was found of the volunteer described by him.Since the Ajmer volunteers have come in for a great deal of public criticism, it was necessary to give my own opinion in the matter.
('64', 341, 3, 22, 691596) The fact, however, that in my opinion no volunteer seems to have committed the assault does not imply that the fast was in any way unnecessary.
('64', 341, 3, 23, 691740) That the assault was committed is not
('64', 342, 0, 1, 691778) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 343
('64', 342, 1, 2, 691824) to be denied, nor can it be denied that those who took part in the affray were of the reformer group.
('64', 342, 1, 3, 691926) The fact also remains that Shri Ramnarayan Chaudhri forgot to give the necessary instructions and take adequate precautions against the mishap.
('64', 342, 1, 4, 692070) The fast was, therefore, clearly necessary, and I am thankful to God that He gave me the strength to take and go through it.
('64', 342, 1, 5, 692195) Those who handle purity movements cannot be too vigilant.
('64', 342, 1, 6, 692253) The legal maxim has it that ‘Law’, i,e., God, ‘helps the wakeful, never the sleepy.’
('64', 342, 2, 7, 692338) AN ENGLISH FRIEND’S WARNING An English friend sends the following message :
('64', 342, 3, 8, 692414) We, English people, do not understand this fasting of yours.
('64', 342, 3, 9, 692475) We were hardly
('64', 342, 4, 10, 692490) able to tolerate your previous fasts.
('64', 342, 4, 11, 692528) But you will be discredited, if you repeat any more
('64', 342, 5, 12, 692580) of these.
('64', 342, 5, 13, 692590) I know that this warning has been sent out of concern for my reputation.
('64', 342, 5, 14, 692663) I know the Protestant dislike for fasts.
('64', 342, 5, 15, 692704) But, inspite of all the wish to stand well with my English friends, I am really helpless in this matter.
('64', 342, 5, 16, 692809) I am not responsible for these fasts.
('64', 342, 5, 17, 692847) I do not undertake them for my amusement.
('64', 342, 5, 18, 692889) I would not torture the flesh for the love of fame.
('64', 342, 5, 19, 692941) Though I bear joyfully the pangs of hunger and many other physical discomforts of fasting, let no one imagine that I do not suffer.
('64', 342, 5, 20, 693073) These fasts are bearable only because they are imposed upon me by a higher Power and the capacity to bear the pain also comes from that Power.
('64', 342, 5, 21, 693216) I can only plead with that Power that He may not put me through any more ordeals of that nature.
('64', 342, 5, 22, 693313) But if my pleading goes in vain and another fast comes my way, I must take it, even though I may have to risk a wreckage of all the reputation I may possess for sanity and what not.
('64', 342, 5, 23, 693495) ‘For, what shall it profit a man if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul?’
('64', 342, 6, 24, 693585) Harijan, 24 8 1934

('64', 345, 10, 15, 698200) I did not remember what my legal position was in the Vidyapith, so I enquired about it and was told that I had none, but that, morally speaking, they regarded me as its Chancellor and all the teachers had agreed among themselves that I should be permitted to intervene in its affairs whenever I wished to do so.

('64', 347, 1, 2, 700892) 408. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('64', 347, 2, 3, 700925) August 24, 1934
('64', 347, 3, 4, 700941) BHAISHRI VALLABHBHAI, I got your letter and wire.
('64', 347, 3, 5, 700991) I am not sending a wire in reply to your wire, since I have already written to you yesterday on that very subject.
('64', 347, 3, 6, 701106) 1 If you have not issued any statement as suggested in that letter, you may state as follows :
('64', 347, 4, 7, 701201) I have read the proceedings of the new party formed by Pandit Malaviyaji and Shri M. S. Aney.
('64', 347, 4, 8, 701295) I have read telegrams and letters asking me to clarify certain points.
('64', 347, 4, 9, 701366) In my opinion it is not proper to use the Congress name without the Congress authority.The party may be called the National Party of Congressmen if its composition strictly confirmed to Congress men.
('64', 347, 4, 10, 701566) But without the authority of the Congress duly received it cannot with propriety be called the Congress National Party especially when it is formed deliberately to propagate a policy in direct contradiction to that which is the official policy of the Congress.
('64', 347, 4, 11, 701827) The adoption of the Congress name cannot but confuse the popular mind and I would respectfully urge Panditji to reconsider the position and adopt another name for the party which he had a perfect right to form for the education of Congressmen and others.
('64', 347, 4, 12, 702082) There other point I should like to emphasize is that no one but the Congress Parliamentary Board can run elections in the name of the Congress.
('64', 347, 4, 13, 702226) Lastly in the midst of the unfortunate differences between Pandit Malaviyaji and Sjt.
('64', 347, 4, 14, 702312) Aney and the Working Committee I hope that all Congressmen will loyally support the policy enunciated in the resoultion of the Working Committee regarding the Communal Award.
('64', 347, 5, 15, 702487) If you wish to make any changes in this, you may do so.
('64', 347, 5, 16, 702543) Rejendrababu’s letter was rather strange.There can be only one reply to it.
('64', 347, 5, 17, 702619) The Congress certainly cannot assume responsibility for providing the money and we cannot raise funds at present through private efforts.

('64', 351, 1, 2, 706450) 414. LETTER TO DR.
('64', 351, 1, 3, 706469) B. C. ROY
('64', 351, 2, 4, 706479) August 25, 1934
('64', 351, 3, 5, 706495) DEAR DR.
('64', 351, 3, 6, 706504) BIDHAN, Yes, I have recovered from the effects of the fast in the sense that there is no untoward consequence.
('64', 351, 3, 7, 706615) I am steadily but slowly regaining strength.
('64', 351, 3, 8, 706660) I have no desire to have a meeting of the Working Committee.
('64', 351, 3, 9, 706721) But, if it is needed by the Parliamentary Board, I have no doubt that Sardar Vallabhbhai will call it.
('64', 351, 3, 10, 706824) But have you need for it?
('64', 351, 3, 11, 706850) I have a telegram from Maulana Saheb and Sardar sardul Singh who evidently desire a meeting of the Working Committee at the same time as the Parliamentary Board meeting.
('64', 351, 3, 12, 707020) If such is also your feeling, then of course the Working Committee must meet.
('64', 351, 3, 13, 707098) I am loath to be dragged to Bombay just now.
('64', 351, 3, 14, 707143) Jamnalalji from his sick bed has been warning me not to leave Wardha before I have reached 110 lb.
('64', 351, 3, 15, 707242) I am now 98 lb.
('64', 351, 3, 16, 707258) and I am gaining at the rete of less than 1 2 lb.
('64', 351, 3, 17, 707308) Supposing that I keep up that pace, it would not be before the 20th September that I can leave Wardha.
('64', 351, 3, 18, 707411) But of course Jamnalalji is exacting and he can be over ruled if both the meetings must take place in Bombay, and that in the early part of September and if my presence is a necessity.
('64', 351, 3, 19, 707596) All these things I leave to you to decide and then move Sardar Vallabhbhai accordingly.
('64', 351, 3, 20, 707684) Of course the appropriation of the name ‘Congress’ by Panditji’s party is a bad job.
('64', 351, 3, 21, 707769) No one can act in the name of the Congress without due authority.
('64', 351, 3, 22, 707835) I believe Sardar Vallabhbhai would be issuing a statement 1 in the matter.
('64', 351, 3, 23, 707910) You must have seen the brief statement 2 that I have issued.
('64', 351, 4, 24, 707971) I hope you do not want the Working Committee to lay down the procedure at the present stage to be followed by Congressmen in the Assembly.
('64', 351, 4, 25, 708110) If an amendment of the character you describe is brought before the meeting just now I think it would be better not to say anything.
('64', 351, 4, 26, 708243) But the Parliamentary Board is the best judge to decide as to what is necessary.
('64', 351, 4, 27, 708324) But should an amendment be moved, you have correctly interpreted my own opinion as to the clear duty of Congress members.
('64', 351, 4, 28, 708446) They must vote against a resolution or amendment
('64', 351, 5, 29, 708495) 1 Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 24 8 1934 2 Vide “Statement to Associated Press of India”, 23 8 1934
('64', 352, 0, 1, 708602) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 353
('64', 352, 1, 2, 708648) accepting the Award.
('64', 352, 1, 3, 708669) And since they cannot vote for rejection, naturally they must abstain from voting in regard to a resolution or amendment rejecting the Award.
('64', 352, 2, 4, 708811) I am glad that so many districts had undisputed elections.
('64', 352, 2, 5, 708870) I wish the rest of the districts would follow the good example set by the overwhelming majority of the districts.
('64', 352, 2, 6, 708984) But if a fight is inevitable, I think that the decisions of Mr. Aney should be loyally followed.
('64', 352, 3, 7, 709081) Yours sincerely, DR.
('64', 352, 3, 8, 709102) BIDHAN CHANDRA ROY CALCUTTA
('64', 352, 4, 9, 709130) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('64', 353, 1, 2, 710012) 416. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH
('64', 353, 2, 3, 710046) August 25, 1934
('64', 353, 3, 4, 710062) NARAHARI, Since Kakasaheb has resigned from the Board of Trustees of the Vidyapith, the question arises as to what should be done regarding the village improvement scheme of Shri Nagindas Amulakhrai.
('64', 353, 3, 5, 710262) As desired by Shri Nagindas, I had appointed a committee to implement the scheme.
('64', 353, 3, 6, 710344) On thinking about it, I now feel that the committee should be made completely independent of the Vidyapith, and that Sardar Vallabhbhai should be appointed its President and Raojibhai its Secretary.
('64', 353, 3, 7, 710543) The latter should be appointed for one year.
('64', 353, 3, 8, 710588) Kakasaheb has rightly deposited the money of the Nagindas Trust with Jamnalalji.
('64', 353, 3, 9, 710669) After the latter is all right, we may, if necessary, make some other arrangement.
('64', 353, 3, 10, 710751) I have another fund also under my control.
('64', 353, 3, 11, 710794) Kakasaheb has deposited that amount, too, with Jamnalalji.
('64', 353, 3, 12, 710853) For the convenience of keeping accounts and from other points of view I think it would be desirable ot amalgamate this amount with the Nagindas Trust money.
('64', 353, 3, 13, 711010) The late Punjabhai had donated an ear marked sum and, on my advice, entrusted the Vidyapith with the responsibility of editing and publishing Jain literature through a committee.
('64', 353, 3, 14, 711189) I have a moral respon sibility in this matter too.
('64', 353, 3, 15, 711240) In view of the present circumstances, I would suggest that that work also should be carried on independently of the control of the Vidyapith.
('64', 353, 3, 16, 711382) I suggest the following names as Trustees of such an independent body: 1. Narahari Parikh 4. Maganbhai Desai 2. Valji Desai 5. Nilkanth Mashruwala 3. Ramniklal Modi 6. Gopaldas Patel If, besides these, we can get a learned and pious Jain, I think it would be desirable to invite him also to become one of the Trustees.
('64', 353, 3, 17, 711701) We shall have to look out for such a person.
('64', 353, 3, 18, 711746) If you can think of any name, please let me know.
('64', 353, 3, 19, 711796) In this programme, so far we have paid attention to publication of material from the original sources of the Agamas together with a transl ation.
('64', 353, 3, 20, 711942) If, instead, we make selections from this vast field of literature which might be useful to the people, or get such selections made, and publish them, I think the late Punjabhai’s object would be better fulfilled.
('64', 354, 0, 1, 712156) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 355
('64', 354, 1, 2, 712202) It was always Punjabhai’s wish that Shri Rajchandra’s birth anniversary should be fittingly celebrated.
('64', 354, 1, 3, 712306) We should assume the respo nsibility for this.
('64', 354, 1, 4, 712353) But whereas in Punjabhai’s time people were content with holding meetings on the anniversary day, I think it would do greater credit to the committee and give greater peace to the soul of Shrimad if some constructive work could be done on that day.
('64', 354, 1, 5, 712602) The committee should consider whether this should be done by publishing some literature or arranging a lecture on the anniversary day or in some other manner.
('64', 354, 1, 6, 712761) The anniversary falls on the next Kartik Purnima.
('64', 354, 1, 7, 712811) We should, therefore, think and decide in time how it should be celebrated on this occasion.
('64', 354, 2, 8, 712904) Blessings from BAPU
('64', 354, 3, 9, 712924) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S. N. 9063
('64', 354, 4, 10, 712969) 417 LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL

('64', 357, 6, 11, 716912) 421. LETTER TO G. R. SAHGAL
('64', 357, 7, 12, 716940) August 26, 1934
('64', 357, 8, 13, 716956) MY DEAR SAHGAL, I was glad to receive your very prompt letter giving me all the information I wanted except one.
('64', 357, 8, 14, 717069) I wonder if with all your attainments it would be proper for you, with wife and children , to give your services to a Harijan institution for Rs. 150. And it is not so much the small maintenance that you require as the fact that I cannot provide, perhaps for some years, the scope that your abilities would need.
('64', 357, 8, 15, 717382) I have not in mind the bringing into being of a mighty Harijan institution.
('64', 357, 8, 16, 717458) It would be a small affair with big promise in a somewhat distant future.
('64', 357, 8, 17, 717532) Will you be content to allow your abilities to lie fallow?
('64', 357, 8, 18, 717591) You will just tell me what is the urge.
('64', 357, 8, 19, 717631) And is your wife in hearty co operation with you in coming down from Rs. 750 per month to Rs. 150, when I suppose even now you could command, if not Rs. 750 per month, something very near it?
('64', 357, 9, 20, 717823) Yours sincerely,
('64', 357, 10, 21, 717840) SHRI G. R. SAHGAL C/O GURUKULA SUPA, via NAVSARI

('64', 358, 1, 2, 717984) 422. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('64', 358, 2, 3, 718017) August 26/27, 1934
('64', 358, 3, 4, 718036) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, Mahadev must have replied to your letter.
('64', 358, 3, 5, 718096) Raja arrived suddenly today and was in a great hurry to return.
('64', 358, 3, 6, 718160) Since I spent a good deal of time with him I am late with the post.
('64', 358, 3, 7, 718228) Aney also came and saw me.
('64', 358, 3, 8, 718255) All that I can say about him is that he brought a message of love from Malaviyaji and asked me if I had any reply to give.
('64', 358, 3, 9, 718378) I told him that if they cared for propriety they should put up their candidates after consulting us and should not put up anybody simply to fight the Congress.
('64', 358, 3, 10, 718538) He left soon, as he had to catch the train for Nagpur, and said that he would come again.
('64', 358, 3, 11, 718628) The new Party has confused the situation, but apart from that I don’t think it will be able to do much harm.
('64', 358, 3, 12, 718737) Bhulabhai came.
('64', 358, 3, 13, 718753) I had a wire from the Maulana.

('64', 365, 7, 18, 729244) 431. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PHATAK
('64', 365, 8, 19, 729275) August 30, 1934
('64', 365, 9, 20, 729291) MY DEAR HARIBHAU, I have your letter.
('64', 365, 9, 21, 729329) My position on the cow is not that the cow might be superior to the buffalo in giving milk.
('64', 365, 9, 22, 729421) If cow protection is part of Hinduism, then we must abjure buffalo milk even if it is superior to cow’s milk.
('64', 365, 9, 23, 729531) Such is the conception of religion.
('64', 365, 9, 24, 729567) You cannot apply to it the bare rule of utility.
('64', 365, 9, 25, 729616) If we would prefer buffalo milk , then by and by the buffalo would become the object of worship and the cow would disappear, as she is fast disappearing.
('64', 365, 9, 26, 729770) Having said this, I can say that all the information that I possess goes to show that, all things considered, cow’s milk is superior to buffalo milk.
('64', 365, 9, 27, 729920) But it is a question whcih does not much interest me, because I am sure that it would be possible to obtain medical testimony in favour of the superiority of the cow’s milk over buffalo milk and vice versa.
('64', 365, 10, 28, 730127) 1 Vide “Statement to Associated Press of India”, 23 8 1934
('64', 366, 0, 1, 730186) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 367
('64', 366, 1, 2, 730232) Therefore , in matters of this character, the safest thing is to steer clear of expert opinion.
('64', 366, 1, 3, 730328) If we worship the cow, we must give her preference over all, irrespective of the quality of the different milk that different animals may give.
('64', 366, 2, 4, 730472) Yours sincerely, BAPU SHRI HARIBHAU PHATAK SADASIV PETH, POONA
('64', 366, 3, 5, 730535) From a photostat: G. N. 1372

('64', 369, 0, 1, 734447) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 369, 1, 2, 734489) 437. THAT ILL FATED MEASURE
('64', 369, 2, 3, 734517) The ill fated Temple entry Bill deserved a more decent burial, if it deserved it at all, than it received at the hands of the mover of the Bill.
('64', 369, 2, 4, 734662) It was not a Bill promoted by an individual for his personal satisfaction.
('64', 369, 2, 5, 734737) It was a Bill promoted by, and on behalf of, the refor mers.
('64', 369, 2, 6, 734798) The mover should, therefore, have consulted reformers and acted under instructions from them.
('64', 369, 2, 7, 734892) So far as I am aware, there was hardly any occasion for the anger into which he allowed himself to be betrayed or the displeasure which he expressed towards Congressmen.
('64', 369, 2, 8, 735062) On the face of it, it was, and was designed to be, a measure pertaining to religion, framed in pursuance of the solemn declaration 1 publicly made in Bombay at a meeting of representative Hindus who met under the chairmanship of Pandit Malaviyaji on 25th September, 1932. The curious may read the declaration printed almost every week on the front page of Harijan.
('64', 369, 2, 9, 735427) Therefore, every Hindu, caste or Harijan, was interested in the measure.
('64', 369, 2, 10, 735500) It was not a measure in which Congress Hindus were more interested than the other Hindus.
('64', 369, 2, 11, 735590) To have, therefore, dragged the Congress name into the discussion was unfortunate.
('64', 369, 2, 12, 735673) The Bill deserved a gentler handling.
('64', 369, 2, 13, 735711) Having not a moment to spare myself during the exacting and swift Harijan tour, I had asked Shri Rajagopalachari, in pursuance of the pledge given by me at public meetings and to sanatanist friends in private and in these columns, to ascertain informally (as it could only be done informally) the views of the Hindu members of the Assembly, as, I thought , if it was discovered that the majority was opposed to it, steps should be taken to have the Bill withdrawn.
('64', 369, 2, 14, 736176) This was the very simple issue on which the Bill could either have been dropped or proceeded with.
('64', 369, 2, 15, 736275) Both the sanatanists and the reformers would have understood the position.
('64', 369, 2, 16, 736350) Its fate ought not to have been decided on a side issue.
('64', 369, 2, 17, 736407) If C. Rajagopalachari or I had committed a mistake, we should have been made to pay for it.
('64', 369, 2, 18, 736499) But the Bill was above persons.
('64', 369, 2, 19, 736531) Right or wrong, it enunciated a great principle and, therefore, deserved a more decent treatment than it received.
('64', 369, 2, 20, 736646) As for the part played by the Government, this journal’s policy is to avoid as much as possible criticism of the Government.
('64', 369, 2, 21, 736771) But I should like to say that, with the material before it, the Government
('64', 369, 3, 22, 736846) 1 Vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932
('64', 370, 0, 1, 736917) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 371
('64', 370, 1, 2, 736963) could only have taken the course it did.
('64', 370, 1, 3, 737004) But the public should know that on behalf of the reformers there was not only no attempt made to canvass public opinion but a decision was deliberately arrived at that no attempt should be made to obtain signatures of the public in general in favour of the Bill, it being left open to expert bodies to send representations if they chose.
('64', 370, 1, 4, 737342) This was duly announced in these pages.
('64', 370, 1, 5, 737382) My co workers and I came to the conclusion that the questions underlying the circulation were too technical for the public to decide.
('64', 370, 1, 6, 737516) Thus, the question was not whether Harijans should or should not enter public Hindu temples precisely on the same terms as the others.
('64', 370, 1, 7, 737651) The question was whether there should be any legislation in the matter and, if there should be, whether the Bill was good on its merits .
('64', 370, 1, 8, 737789) In my opinion, both these questions were too technical to be put before the public.
('64', 370, 1, 9, 737873) Surely, it is not impossible to conceive occasions when legislative help or interference is indispensable even in matters of religion.
('64', 370, 1, 10, 738008) As a matter of fact, there are many cases of such legislation.
('64', 370, 1, 11, 738071) But it was difficult to get an intelligent vote from the public.
('64', 370, 1, 12, 738136) Then, on the merits, it was equally difficult to show to the public that the Bill was purely of a permissive nature and that no temple could be opened without the consent of the majority of the temple going public.
('64', 370, 1, 13, 738351) Such public education is not impossible under congenial circumstances.
('64', 370, 1, 14, 738422) But it is well nigh impossible when party feeling runs high and truth is at a discount.
('64', 370, 1, 15, 738510) The temple entry battle has to continue.
('64', 370, 1, 16, 738551) The promise made to Harijans must be redeemed and the temples have to be flung open.
('64', 370, 1, 17, 738636) If they can be, without legislative sanction, no one would be more glad than the reformers.
('64', 370, 1, 18, 738728) Not that they want a single temple to be opened where the majority of savarna Hindus who are in the habit of using them are opposed.
('64', 370, 1, 19, 738861) Law’s assistance is invoked because lawyers opine that the law prevents such opening even where an overwhelming majority of temple goers are agreeable.
('64', 370, 1, 20, 739013) If such is the case, the permissive legislation is peremptory.
('64', 370, 1, 21, 739076) Law alone can undo what law has done, whether it is judge made or statutory or customary.
('64', 370, 1, 22, 739166) But reformers will wait till such time as the passing of legislation becomes irresistible.
('64', 370, 1, 23, 739257) But waiting is only for the wakeful.
('64', 370, 1, 24, 739294) The hasty withdrawal of the Bill teaches its own lesson.
('64', 370, 1, 25, 739351) There is no cause for disappointment.
('64', 370, 1, 26, 739389) Redoubled effort is required.
('64', 370, 1, 27, 739419) It is not necessary to
('64', 371, 0, 1, 739442) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 371, 1, 2, 739484) know or prove that Harijans want temple entry.
('64', 371, 1, 3, 739531) Removal of the sin is necessary for the satisfaction of the savarna Hindus who have realized that untouchability is a canker eating into the vitals of Hinduism, which, if not removed in time, must kill Hinduism.
('64', 371, 2, 4, 739743) M. K. GANDHI Harijan, 31 8 1934
('64', 371, 3, 5, 739775) 438. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ
('64', 371, 4, 6, 739804) August 31, 1934
('64', 371, 5, 7, 739820) MY DEAR RAJBHOJ, Your letter of 25th August astonished me, for you have now taken up a position in connection with the work of the Harijan Sevak Sangh which is contrary to what you had taken up some time ago and in your correspondence and conversations with me.
('64', 371, 5, 8, 740082) It may be that experience has altered your view.
('64', 371, 5, 9, 740131) If such is the case, I have nothing to say except that you have based your criticism on insufficient data.
('64', 371, 5, 10, 740238) You know that I have repeatedly expressed my opinion that Harijan Sevak Sangh is an organization of penitents.
('64', 371, 5, 11, 740349) Therefore it cannot be predominantly manned by Harijans.
('64', 371, 5, 12, 740406) It has got to do the repentance in the manner that the penitent savarnas may consider to be the most suitable.
('64', 371, 5, 13, 740517) It it does not appeal to the Harijans, it would be no doubt unfortunate.
('64', 371, 5, 14, 740590) Then the penitents must try again.
('64', 371, 5, 15, 740625) But they have got to learn the art of repentance from bitter experience.
('64', 371, 5, 16, 740698) As I have said to you personally so often, and you seemed also to agree, the better and more effective method of influencing the policy of Harijan Sevak Sanghs would be for local Harijans to form representative Advisory Boards to study sympathetically the activities of the local Sanghs, and then advise them, criticize them and make concrete suggestions.
('64', 371, 5, 17, 741054) If such Advisory Boards are formed everywhere, the work done by the Harijan Boards will be naturally much more effective than it is today.
('64', 371, 5, 18, 741193) But even as it is, the Boards have nothing to be ashamed of.
('64', 371, 5, 19, 741254) If you will follow the columns of Harijan from week to week, you will surely be astonished at the way the money all over India is being distributed among Harijans.
('64', 371, 5, 20, 741418) It can be shown from records that many institutions managed by Harijans are being substantially supported from funds collected by Harijan Boards.
('64', 372, 0, 1, 741564) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 373
('64', 372, 1, 2, 741610) will find also, if you study the figures, that the extent of distribution of funds directly among Harijans and Harijan institutions is progressively increasing.
('64', 372, 1, 3, 741771) Extraordinary precautions are being taken to ensure the impartial distribution of funds.
('64', 372, 1, 4, 741860) You are altogether wrong in thinking that accounts of distributions are not published.
('64', 372, 1, 5, 741947) Reports by provincial branches are published from time to time.
('64', 372, 1, 6, 742011) They are available for inspection by the public and you can test the accuracy to my statement by turning over the columns of Harijan and even by application of local offices for copies of their reports.
('64', 372, 1, 7, 742214) I am asking Thakkar Bapa to let me have a consolidated account for publication in Harijan, and you will be yourself astonished at the amounts spent for Harijan institutions and students all over India.
('64', 372, 1, 8, 742416) As to temple entry, you will find that practically nothing has been spent either on opening of temples or on the building of new temples, and throughout the nine months’ tour, the reports of my speeches in the columns of Harijan will show you conclusively that the temple entry question occupies the least part of them.
('64', 372, 1, 9, 742736) The Harijan Sevak Sanghs have concentrated on some of the very things that you mention.
('64', 372, 1, 10, 742824) If they have not tackled all the items, it is not for want of will but for want of capacity to overtake all the items at once.
('64', 372, 1, 11, 742951) Your attack upon the Maharashtra Harijan Board comes with ill grace.
('64', 372, 1, 12, 743020) An out and out supporter of the Harijan cause, namely, Mr. Devdhar, is the President of the Provincial Board.
('64', 372, 1, 13, 743130) He began this long before the Harijan Board came into existence, and probably before the birth of many of us.
('64', 372, 1, 14, 743240) So far as I am aware, he has never been accused of lukewarmness over this reform.
('64', 372, 1, 15, 743322) If you have any specific complaints against the locl Board, don’t you think that your first duty is to send those complaints to the local Board, and if you do not get relief or satisfaction, to take your appeal to the Central Board?
('64', 372, 1, 16, 743555) And then if you find that your complaint has gone unheeded, you will be justified in exposing the respective Boards in the public.
('64', 372, 1, 17, 743686) As it is, you have nothing but a vague allegation against the Maharashtra Board which, in my opinion, has deserved a better treatment.
('64', 372, 2, 18, 743821) Yours sincerely,
('64', 372, 3, 19, 743838) M. K. GANDHI SHRI P. N. RAJBHOJ 207 GHORPADE PETH, POONA 2
('64', 372, 4, 20, 743897) From a photostat: G.N. 786; also Harijan, 7 9 1934

('64', 374, 4, 15, 746319) 441. TERRIBLE OPPRESSION
('64', 374, 5, 16, 746344) I have been receiving reports from several quarters about the oppression of the Harijans in the area surrounding Talaja.
('64', 374, 5, 17, 746465) Even after assuming an element of exaggeration in them and making allowance for it, what remains is shocking enough.
('64', 374, 5, 18, 746582) It is difficult to understand how man can be so cruel.
('64', 374, 5, 19, 746637) The tragedy of it is that the Harijans were quite innocent.
('64', 374, 5, 20, 746697) Because there was an epidemic of the plague among cattle and they died, it was supposed that this was the doing of the Harijans.
('64', 374, 5, 21, 746826) And so the latter were harassed and beaten almost to death, and in some cases actually to death, with the result that, to escape this oppression they left their homes and belongings and took shelter inTalaja.
('64', 374, 5, 22, 747035) It is all the more distressing that such things should happen in a model State like Bhavnagar.
('64', 374, 5, 23, 747130) I do not say this in order to blame the State.
('64', 374, 5, 24, 747177) I see from the letters and telegrams I have received that the officials are alert, and I hope that these cruel happenings will be fully investigated, the innocent Harijans will get justice and be resettled in their homes, and the guilty will be forced to compensate the Harijans who have been injured and make good the losses of those whose belongings have been destroyed, and steps will be taken to ensure that such things do not happen again.
('64', 374, 5, 25, 747622) What is specially lamentable is the fact that even in a progressive State the people are stony hearted towards the Harijans, treat them as less than animals and do not hesitate to beat them up
('64', 375, 0, 1, 747815) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 375, 1, 2, 747857) half dead or dead and do not even fear being punished with hanging or rigorous imprisonment.
('64', 375, 1, 3, 747950) Many people seem to argue that they need fear authority or God in beating or killing a Harijan no more then they need to do so in beating or killing cats and dogs, and their reasoning is not completely unjustified either.
('64', 375, 1, 4, 748172) The help that the Government or State can give in such matters is not much.
('64', 375, 1, 5, 748248) It can punish the guilty after the event and force the guilty village to pay compensation.
('64', 375, 1, 6, 748339) But where a strong public opinion has not been cultivated against such things, the State cannot produce big results.
('64', 375, 1, 7, 748456) At the root of the Talaja atrocities are utter ignorance and superstition.
('64', 375, 1, 8, 748531) It is the duty of Harijan workers to dispel this darkness.
('64', 375, 1, 9, 748590) They should explain to the people that epidemics of the plague are known to occur occasionally in all countries of the world, and that outside India nobody is suspected when such an epidemic occurs.
('64', 375, 1, 10, 748789) The people in those countries merely regard it as a natural calamity, employ blameless remedies for eradicating the plague and give medicines to the cattle.
('64', 375, 1, 11, 748946) This should be done vigorously and ceaselessly in villages sunk in ignorance.
('64', 375, 1, 12, 749024) In this connection I have received a heart rending letter from a Harijan.
('64', 375, 1, 13, 749098) Since it is worth reading by every caste Hindu, I reproduce below its important part : 1
('64', 375, 2, 14, 749187) [From Gujarati]
('64', 375, 3, 15, 749203) Harijanbandhu, 2 9 1934
('64', 375, 4, 16, 749227) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('64', 375, 4, 17, 749264) The correspondent, who was serving Harijans in as many ways as he could as atonement for the cruel treatment of them by caste Hindus, had described the cruel lot of Harijans in Saurashtra and appealed to Gandhiji to save them.
('64', 376, 0, 1, 749491) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 377

('64', 378, 7, 11, 753492) 446. LETTER TO BIRENDRA NATH GUHA
('64', 378, 8, 12, 753526) September 2, 1934

('64', 381, 4, 4, 757124) Your letter was full of descriptions.
('64', 381, 4, 5, 757162) It seems your work is going on very well.

('64', 381, 4, 10, 757387) This is a virgin field of work.

('64', 381, 4, 12, 757496) The plan which I have and which I have explained in Harijan is based on one line of approach only.

('64', 381, 4, 14, 757642) Let me see now to how many persons you can explain it.

('64', 386, 2, 3, 764009) September 3, 1934
('64', 386, 3, 4, 764027) SHANTIKUMAR, Mr. Mung of Burma came and saw me two days ago.
('64', 386, 3, 5, 764088) He said that to Haji’s request he plunged into the Burmese question and carried on such a powerful agitation that it even told on his health.
('64', 386, 3, 6, 764230) He has incurred, he says, an expense of Rs. 2,000. Since there has been no result, neither the company nor Haji would now accept his demand.
('64', 386, 3, 7, 764371) They deny any understanding with him.
('64', 386, 3, 8, 764409) He also expressed a desire to see you.
('64', 386, 3, 9, 764448) I have replied to him that everybody takes up such work of his own free will and for the good of his people.
('64', 386, 3, 10, 764557) If somebody refuses to keep his promise, one should blame one’s own stupidity.
('64', 386, 3, 11, 764636) All the same, I have advised him to write to you.
('64', 386, 3, 12, 764686) If Haji gave a moral undertaking of any kind, I am of the view that Mr. Mung should be reimbursed the expense which he has incurred.
('64', 386, 3, 13, 764819) Please let me know what the facts of the case are.
('64', 386, 3, 14, 764870) I hope you are doing well.

('64', 388, 1, 2, 767216) 461. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('64', 388, 2, 3, 767251) September 4, 1934 I got your letter.
('64', 388, 2, 4, 767288) I chanced to see your writing on karmayoga only yesterday and glanced through it.
('64', 388, 2, 5, 767370) I will read it now if I get time.
('64', 388, 2, 6, 767404) What is this about music and cinema?
('64', 388, 2, 7, 767441) Do they wish to turn the Congress session into a Felix Circus or Barnum show?
('64', 388, 2, 8, 767519) But, then, what can I say in this matter?
('64', 388, 2, 9, 767561) I do love music, but everything is good in its place.
('64', 388, 2, 10, 767615) If the three or four days of the Congress session are crowded with such activities, the atmosphere of seriousness will disappear.
('64', 388, 2, 11, 767745) Even if they wish to arrange such programmes, somebody may be given a contract for them.
('64', 388, 2, 12, 767834) I am of the view, however, that no such programmes can be arranged at the place where the [nation’s] parliament meets.
('64', 388, 2, 13, 767953) But we have turned the Congress into a tamasha.
('64', 388, 2, 14, 768001) Inclusion of genuine Indian music in a cent per cent swadeshi exhibiton is legitimate.
('64', 388, 2, 15, 768088) But only traditional instruments should be used in such a programme.
('64', 388, 2, 16, 768157) I can see no room at all for a band.
('64', 388, 2, 17, 768194) You may show this to Sardar.
('64', 388, 2, 18, 768223) But if you wish to maintain discreet silence, you may do so.
('64', 388, 2, 19, 768284) You must have heard from Sardar about the step I am contemplating.
('64', 388, 2, 20, 768351) I will not, therefore, waste a few minutes of my time by writing about it here.
('64', 388, 2, 21, 768431) Why inquire about my health?
('64', 388, 2, 22, 768460) It was tested yesterday.
('64', 388, 2, 23, 768485) I was busy with the pen the whole day.
('64', 388, 2, 24, 768524) There was no ill effect.
('64', 388, 2, 25, 768549) I dont’t know, however, if somebody here writes to you and gives you a different report.
('64', 388, 3, 26, 768638) [From Gujarati]
