('64', 389, 0, 1, 768673) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 389, 1, 2, 768715) 462. DISCUSSION WITH DODD 1
('64', 389, 2, 3, 768743) September 4, 1934
('64', 389, 3, 4, 768761) DODD: I have come to India 2, 10,000 miles, to see Taj which is a monument of the past and Mahatma Gandhi which is a symbol of the future.
('64', 389, 4, 5, 768900) GANDHIJI: But why not become a living Taj than a dead Taj?
('64', 389, 4, 6, 768959) And why not a monument of the present than of the future ?
('64', 389, 5, 7, 769018) Is there any chance of your coming to America?
('64', 389, 5, 8, 769065) Could we kidnap you to America?
('64', 389, 5, 9, 769097) We hear, you know, so much of kidnappers nowadays.
('64', 389, 5, 10, 769148) No, for the simple reason that I should be of no use there.
('64', 389, 5, 11, 769208) If I came there, it would be to demonstrate the secret and the beauty and the power of non violence.
('64', 389, 5, 12, 769309) I should not be able to do it today.
('64', 389, 5, 13, 769346) I have not yet carried complete conviction to my own countrymen.
('64', 389, 6, 14, 769411) What is your main objective, Mr. Gandhi ?
('64', 389, 6, 15, 769453) The main objective is obvious and it is to gain independence, not for the literate and the rich in India, but for the dumb millions.
('64', 389, 7, 16, 769586) I know.
('64', 389, 7, 17, 769594) I have often come across that expression in your writings.
('64', 389, 7, 18, 769653) What are your methods?
('64', 389, 7, 19, 769676) Not many methods, but the one method of unadulterated truth and non violence.
('64', 389, 7, 20, 769754) But you might ask me, ‘How are non violence and truth expressed and applied?’ I would say at once that the central fact in my programme is the spinning wheel.
('64', 389, 7, 21, 769913) I know that Americans are startled when I say this.
('64', 389, 7, 22, 769965) What can be the meaning of this pet obsession, they ask.
('64', 389, 8, 23, 770022) Not all Americans.
('64', 389, 8, 24, 770041) Our daily paper one day criticized the spinning wheel programme and in the very next column had an article describing people working with the shovel on a public thoroughfare, forty doing the work of a single machine.
('64', 389, 8, 25, 770258) In a letter to the editor, I drew his attention to the incongruity and told him that, just as we were fighting unemp loyment, India, too, was fighting unemployment.
('64', 389, 8, 26, 770423) But with you, Mr. Gandhi, it is moral and spiritual symbol, too?
('64', 389, 8, 27, 770488) Yes, of truth and non violence.
('64', 389, 8, 28, 770520) When as a nation we adopt the spinning wheel, we not only solve the question of unemployment but we declare that we have no intention of exploiting any nation, and we also end the exploitation of the poor by the rich.
('64', 389, 8, 29, 770738) It is a spiritual force
('64', 389, 9, 30, 770762) 1 This appeared as “A Talk with an American Friend” in Harijan.
('64', 389, 9, 31, 770826) The date line and the first two paragraphs are reproduced from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('64', 389, 9, 32, 770930) 2 Dodd was in charge of a girls’ college in America.
('64', 390, 0, 1, 770983) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 391
('64', 390, 1, 2, 771029) which in the initial stages works slowly, but as soon as it gets started, it begins working in geometrical progression, i.e., when it gets into the life of the people.When I say I want independence for the millions, I mean to say not only that the millions may have something to eat and to cover themselves with, but that they will be free from the exploitation of people here and outside.
('64', 390, 1, 3, 771419) We can never industrialize India, unless, of course, we reduce our population from 350 millions to 35 millions or hit upon markets wider than our own and dependent on us.
('64', 390, 1, 4, 771590) It is time we realized that, where there is unlimtied human power, complicated machinery on a large scale has no place.
('64', 390, 1, 5, 771710) An Indian economist told me once that every American had 36 slaves, for, the machine did the work of 36 slaves.
('64', 390, 1, 6, 771822) Well, Americans may need that, but not we.
('64', 390, 1, 7, 771865) We cannot industrialize ourselves, unless we make up our minds to enslave humanity.
('64', 390, 1, 8, 771949) Then, we have to fight untouchability.
('64', 390, 1, 9, 771988) Untouchability of a kind is everywhere.
('64', 390, 1, 10, 772028) A coal porter coming from a coalmine would not stretch out his hand to shake yours.
('64', 390, 1, 11, 772112) He would say he would wash himself cle clean first.
('64', 390, 1, 12, 772164) But the moment a man has rendered himself clean, he should cease to be untouchable.
('64', 390, 1, 13, 772248) Here however we have regarded a part of one population as perpetually untouchable.
('64', 390, 1, 14, 772331) 1 We are trying to abolish that untouchability.
('64', 390, 1, 15, 772379) Added to their untouchability is unemployment, which they share in common with a vast number of others.
('64', 390, 1, 16, 772483) You, too, have got the unemployment problem, but it is of your own creation.
('64', 390, 1, 17, 772560) Our unemployment is not entirely of our creation, but, however it came about, I am sure that, if my method was universalized in India,we should not onlyfind work for those that exist but for those to come.
('64', 390, 1, 18, 772766) That is, we should easily be able to tackle our population problem.
('64', 390, 1, 19, 772834) The problem is to double the penny a day which is the average income of a poor Indian.
('64', 390, 1, 20, 772921) If we can achieve that, it would be quite enough at least till we find a better method.
('64', 390, 1, 21, 773009) The spinning wheel, by utilizing the idle hours of the nation, produces additional wealth; it does not, it was never meant to, displace existing employment.
('64', 390, 1, 22, 773166) Give me a thing which would increase the daily income of the millions of our impoverished people more than the spinning wheel, and I should gladly give up the spinning wheel.
('64', 390, 2, 23, 773341) I quite see.
('64', 390, 2, 24, 773354) We talk of shortening of the hours of work, but as to what they are
('64', 390, 3, 25, 773422) to do in their spare hours, we do not seem for a moment to trouble ourselves about.
('64', 390, 4, 26, 773506) 1 This sentence is reproduced from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('64', 391, 0, 1, 773582) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 391, 1, 2, 773624) I would ask one more question, Mr. Gandhi.
('64', 391, 1, 3, 773667) I have the opportunity of speaking to many young men and women and I should like you to tell me what you consider your most satisfactory achievement—I will not say your greatest achievement, lest.
('64', 391, 1, 4, 773864) I should embarrass you.
('64', 391, 1, 5, 773888) In other words, what should I put before the young people as a thing that they should aspire after in life?
('64', 391, 1, 6, 773996) It is a difficult question.
('64', 391, 1, 7, 774024) I do not know what to say.
('64', 391, 1, 8, 774051) I can simply say this: I do not know whether you will call it an achievement or not, but I may say that, in the midst of humiliation and so called defeat and a tempestuous life, I am able to retain my peace, because of an undying faith in God, translated as Truth.
('64', 391, 1, 9, 774316) We can describe God as millions of things, but I have for myself adopted the simple formula— “Truth is God’’.
('64', 391, 2, 10, 774426) I see it, I see it.
('64', 391, 2, 11, 774446) You have achieved peace in a world of confusion and turmoil.
('64', 391, 2, 12, 774507) But several American friends say to me, ‘You cannot have peace unless you believe in Jesus.’ Well, I tell you I have peace, though I do not believe in Jesus as the only son of God.
('64', 391, 3, 13, 774688) I am glad you said this.
('64', 391, 3, 14, 774713) May I ask you to let me know your conception of Christ ?
('64', 391, 3, 15, 774770) I consider him as a historical person—one of the greatest amongst the teachers of mankind.
('64', 391, 3, 16, 774861) I have studied his teachings as prayerfully as I could, with the reverence of a Christian, in order to discover the Truth that is buried in them.
('64', 391, 3, 17, 775007) I have done so, just as I have done about the teachings of other teachers.
('64', 391, 4, 18, 775082) In this connection, may I ask your opinion on the missionaries’ work in India?
('64', 391, 4, 19, 775161) Have they wronged India ?
('64', 391, 4, 20, 775187) I should not say intentionally.
('64', 391, 4, 21, 775219) They, of course, come here as critics, they exaggerate our social evils, they criticize our religion.
('64', 391, 4, 22, 775321) But that does not matter.
('64', 391, 4, 23, 775347) All their criticism has but served to make us more conscious of our weaknesses and more alive to our duties.
('64', 391, 5, 24, 775456) But that, I suppose, you say of missionaries as individuals, not of missionary
('64', 391, 6, 25, 775535) societies as such ?
('64', 391, 6, 26, 775555) I should not draw that distinction, for, missionary societies have certain pre conceived notions of our society and religion which the members propagate.
('64', 391, 6, 27, 775709) Thirty five years ago, for instance, as I was passing through Zanzibar, I went to the Bible Society to purchase a copy of the Bible and with that I was given a report of work done by a mission there.
('64', 391, 6, 28, 775909) I was astounded to find therein that a missionary could
('64', 392, 0, 1, 775965) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 393
('64', 392, 1, 2, 776011) count his work in the terms of £.
('64', 392, 1, 3, 776045) A convert meant so many shillings, as to a recruiting agent a recruit means so many rupees.
('64', 392, 1, 4, 776137) One cannot think of a religion in the terms of the number of its adherents.
('64', 392, 2, 5, 776213) What, Mr. Gandhi, has been your greatest disappointment ?
('64', 392, 2, 6, 776271) Frankly, I have no sense of disappointment, excepting, perhaps, that sometimes I am disappointed with myself, inasmuch as I cannot control the fleeting thoughts as much as I should like to.
('64', 392, 2, 7, 776461) That’s all.
('64', 392, 3, 8, 776473) What is the source of your ideals ?
('64', 392, 4, 9, 776509) The source is truth or the uttermost identity with all life.
('64', 392, 4, 10, 776570) Truth is the realization of God.
('64', 392, 5, 11, 776603) One last thing, Mr. Gandhi.
('64', 392, 5, 12, 776631) I am coming from the Congress of the Baptist
('64', 392, 6, 13, 776676) Christians in Germany.
('64', 392, 6, 14, 776699) They took a firm stand on peace and racialism.
('64', 392, 6, 15, 776746) I spoke there
('64', 392, 7, 16, 776760) on the ‘Gospel of the Day’ and spoke ‘on strict honesty and integrity in the business
('64', 392, 8, 17, 776846) of our life’ and ‘war as the most insane and unchristian thing on earth’.
('64', 392, 8, 18, 776920) I made, in
('64', 392, 9, 19, 776931) conclusion, an appeal to all, coupled with my own declaration, that true Christians
('64', 392, 10, 20, 777015) everywhere should refuse to shoot down their Christian brethren whenever
('64', 392, 11, 21, 777088) Governments decided to go to war against any other nation.
('64', 392, 11, 22, 777147) How much does that
('64', 392, 12, 23, 777166) proposition come near you ?
('64', 392, 12, 24, 777194) It would come very near me, if you were to drop out the word ‘Christian’ and said only ‘brethern’.
('64', 392, 12, 25, 777293) I should refuse to shoot down any human being, black or white, Christian or non Christian.
('64', 392, 12, 26, 777384) Your declaration must apply to the whole humanity.
('64', 392, 13, 27, 777435) I mean it.
('64', 392, 13, 28, 777446) I said ‘Christian brethren’, as I was addressing a group of Christians.
('64', 392, 13, 29, 777518) That is all right.
('64', 392, 13, 30, 777537) I have to give this warning, because sometimes it is thought that there is nothing wrong in shooting down so called savages.
('64', 392, 14, 31, 777662) No, no.
('64', 392, 15, 32, 777670) Harijan, 14 9 1934; also from the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('64', 393, 0, 1, 777871) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 393, 1, 2, 777913) 463. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('64', 393, 2, 3, 777946) [Before] September[5], 1934 1
('64', 393, 3, 4, 777976) DEAR VALLABHBHAI, After much deliberation and discussions with friends who have been to Wardha recently, I have come to the conclusion that the best interests of the Congress and the nation will be served by my completely severing all official or physical connection with the Congress, including the original membership.
('64', 393, 3, 5, 778297) This does not mean that I cease to take any interest in an organization with which I have been intimately connected since 1920 and which I have worshipped since my youth.
('64', 393, 3, 6, 778468) In spite of all I have recently said about the corruption that has crept into the organization, it still remains, in my opinion, the most powerful and the most representative nationl organization in the country.
('64', 393, 3, 7, 778680) It has a history of uninterrupted noble service and sacrifice from its inception.
('64', 393, 3, 8, 778762) Its progress has been unbroken and steady.
('64', 393, 3, 9, 778805) It has weathered storms as no other institution in the country has.
('64', 393, 3, 10, 778873) It has commanded the largest measure of sacrifice of which any country would be proud.
('64', 393, 3, 11, 778960) It has today the largest number of self sacrificing men and women of unimpeachable character.
('64', 393, 3, 12, 779054) It is not with a light heart that I leave this great organization.
('64', 393, 3, 13, 779121) But I feel that my remaining in it any longer is likely to do more harm than good.
('64', 393, 3, 14, 779204) I miss at this juncture the association and advice of Jawaharlal who is bound to be the rightful helmsman of the organization in the near future.
('64', 393, 3, 15, 779350) I have, therefore, kept before me his great spirit.
('64', 393, 3, 16, 779402) And I feel that whilst his great affection for me would want to keep me in the Congress, his reason would endorse the step I have taken.
('64', 393, 3, 17, 779539) And since a great organization cannot be governed by affections but by cold reason, it is better for me to retire from a field where my presence results in arresting full play of reason.
('64', 393, 3, 18, 779726) Hence in leaving the organization I feel that I am in no sense deserting one who is much more than a comrade and whom no amount of political differences will ever scparate from me.
('64', 393, 3, 19, 779907) Nor by retiring at this critical juncture am I less true to Babu Rajendra Prasad who will in all probability be the President to the
('64', 393, 4, 20, 780040) 1 Gandhiji had been having discussions on his withdrawal from active leadership of the Congress; vide the following item.
('64', 393, 4, 21, 780162) In his letter dated August 20 to the addressee, Gandhiji had said that he would “prepare a draft” and send it to him.
('64', 393, 4, 22, 780280) This letter appears to be a draft of his “Statement to the Press” which was finally released on September 17, 1934
('64', 394, 0, 1, 780395) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 395
('64', 394, 1, 2, 780441) forthcoming Congress, and who unlike Jawaharlal shares most of my ideals and whose sacrifice for the nation, judged whether in quality or quantity, is not to be excelled.
('64', 394, 1, 3, 780612) Then there is the Congress Parliamentary Board which would perhaps not have come into being, unless I had encouraged its formation with my whole heart.
('64', 394, 1, 4, 780764) It supplies a want that was felt be many staunch and true Congressmen.
('64', 394, 1, 5, 780835) It was necessary, therefore, to bring it into being.
('64', 394, 1, 6, 780888) Such services as I am capable of rendering will still be at its disposal as at any Congressman’s.
('64', 394, 1, 7, 780986) It must command the full support of all Congressmen who have no insuperable objection to the entry of Congressmen into the existing legislatures.
('64', 394, 1, 8, 781132) I should be sorry if the Board lost a single vote because of my withdrawal.
('64', 394, 1, 9, 781208) I fear none of the consequences dreaded by some friends, for I know my ground.
('64', 394, 1, 10, 781287) A tree is no more hurt by a ripe fruit falling from it than would the Congress be by my going out of it.
('64', 394, 1, 11, 781392) Indeed the fruit will be dead weight, if it did not fall when it was fully ripe.
('64', 394, 1, 12, 781473) Mine is that condition.
('64', 394, 1, 13, 781497) I feel that I am a dead weight on the Congress now.
('64', 394, 1, 14, 781549) There is a growing and vital difference of outlook between many Congressmen and myself.
('64', 394, 1, 15, 781637) My presence more and more estranges the intelligentsia from the Congress.
('64', 394, 1, 16, 781711) I feel that my policies fail to convince their reason, though strange as it may appear, I do nothing that does not satisfy my own reason.
('64', 394, 1, 17, 781849) But my reason takes me in a direction just the opposite of what many of the most intellectual Congressmen would gladly and enthusiastically take, if they were not hampered by their unexampled loyalty to me.
('64', 394, 1, 18, 782056) No leader can expect greater loyalty and devotion than I have received from intellectually minded Congressmen even when they have protested and signified their disapproval of the policies I have laid before the Congress.
('64', 394, 1, 19, 782277) I feel that for me any more to draw upon this loyalty and devotion is to put an undue strain upon them.
('64', 394, 1, 20, 782381) I wish that those who strongly disapprove of my method would outvote me and compel my retirement.
('64', 394, 1, 21, 782479) I have tried to reach that position but I have failed.
('64', 394, 1, 22, 782534) They would cling to me till the end.
('64', 394, 1, 23, 782571) The only way I can requite such loyalty is by voluntary retirement.
('64', 394, 1, 24, 782639) I cannot work in opposition when ther are some fundamental differences between the Congress intelligentsia and me.
('64', 394, 1, 25, 782754) Ever since my entry into public life I have never acted in that manner.
('64', 394, 2, 26, 782826) Then there is the growing group of socialists.
('64', 394, 2, 27, 782873) Jawaharlal is their

('64', 395, 1, 2, 782964) undisputed leader.
('64', 395, 1, 3, 782983) I know pretty well what he wants and stands for.
('64', 395, 1, 4, 783032) He claims to examine everything in a scientific spirit.
('64', 395, 1, 5, 783088) He is courage personified.
('64', 395, 1, 6, 783115) He has many years of service in front of him.
('64', 395, 1, 7, 783161) He has an indomitalble faith in his mission.
('64', 395, 1, 8, 783206) The socialist group represents his views more or less, though probably their mode of execution is not exactly his.
('64', 395, 1, 9, 783321) That group is bound to grow in influence and importance.
('64', 395, 1, 10, 783378) I have welcomed the group.
('64', 395, 1, 11, 783405) Many of them are respected and self sacrifcing co workers.
('64', 395, 1, 12, 783464) With all this, I have fundamental differences with them on the programme published in their authorized pamphlets.
('64', 395, 1, 13, 783578) But I would not, by reason of the moral pressure I may be able to exert, suppress the spread of the ideas propounded in their literature.
('64', 395, 1, 14, 783716) My remaining in the Congress would amount to the exercise of such pressure.
('64', 395, 1, 15, 783792) I may not interfere with free expression of those ideas, however distasteful some of them may be me.
('64', 395, 2, 16, 783893) For me to dominate the Congress in spite of these fundamental differences is almost a species of violence which I must refrain from.
('64', 395, 2, 17, 784026) Their reason must be set free at any cost.
('64', 395, 2, 18, 784069) Having discovered this undisputable fact, I would be disloyal to the Congress if, even at the risk of losing all my reputation, I did not leave the Congress.
('64', 395, 2, 19, 784227) But there is no danger to my reputation or that of the Congress, if I leave only to serve it better in thought, word and deed.
('64', 395, 2, 20, 784354) I do not leave in anger or in a huff, nor yet in disappointment.
('64', 395, 2, 21, 784419) I have no disappointment in me.
('64', 395, 2, 22, 784451) I see before me a bright future for the country.
('64', 395, 2, 23, 784500) Everything will go well, if we are true to ourselves.
('64', 395, 2, 24, 784554) I have no other programme before me save the Congress programme now before the country.
('64', 395, 3, 25, 784642) In this and various other ways I would love to serve the Congress in my own humble manner.
('64', 395, 3, 26, 784733) Thus living in complete detachment, I hope, I shall come closer to the Congress.
('64', 395, 3, 27, 784814) Congressmen will then accept my services without being embarrassed or oppressed.
('64', 395, 3, 28, 784895) One word to those who have given me their whole hearted devotion in thought, word and deed in the pursuit of the common goal.
('64', 395, 3, 29, 785021) My physical withdrawal from the Congress is not to be understood to mean an invitation to them to withdraw.
('64', 395, 3, 30, 785129) They will remain in the Congress fold so long as the Congress needs them and work out such common ideals as they have assimilated.
('64', 395, 3, 31, 785260) Yours, BAPU Mahatma, Vol. III, pp.

('64', 396, 1, 2, 785376) 464. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('64', 396, 2, 3, 785404) September 5, 1934 I am surprised that a responsible paper like The Hindu should have published, without reference to me, unauthorized news about a serious decision said to have been made by me.
('64', 396, 2, 4, 785598) Surely the Wardha correspondent could have the news confirmed or denied.
('64', 396, 2, 5, 785671) 1 It was wrong to disclose incomplete and unauthorized reports of confidential conversa tions.
('64', 396, 2, 6, 785766) I may say that there have been discussions with co workers in the matter but no final decision have been taken.
('64', 396, 2, 7, 785878) According to my wont, I am sharing with friends, who happen to come to Wardha, the thoughts that dominate me.
('64', 396, 2, 8, 785988) Public life will become impossible if exchange of views in the process of formation is at all published, especially if they are reported as if they are decisions.
('64', 396, 2, 9, 786151) Whatever the decision that may be arrived at, it has and will have no connection whatsoever with Malaviyaji and Mr. Aney.
('64', 396, 2, 10, 786273) Whilst every effort will be made to reconcile differences and conduct the election campaign without friction with the new party that has been created by Malaviyaji, there is no doubt whatsoever in my mind or that of the members of the Working Committee that the Congress Parliamentary Board should, with the full backing of the Working Committee, prosecute the election campaign and in doing so give full effect to the resolution of the Working Committee on the Communal Award, in which it has an abiding faith and which, it believes, is the only effective method of bringing about an agreed solution between the communities concerned.
('64', 396, 2, 11, 786909) The Hindu, 5 9 1934
('64', 396, 3, 12, 786929) 1 According to The Hindustan Times, 5 4 1934, the correspondent had reported: “Mahatma Gandhi has decided to withdraw from the active leadership of the Congress.
('64', 396, 3, 13, 787091) The decision, it is understood, is due to differences with Pandit Malaviya and others.” Vide also “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 19 8 1934.

('64', 398, 1, 2, 788411) 467. LETTER TO DR.
('64', 398, 1, 3, 788430) N. R. DHARMAVIR
('64', 398, 2, 4, 788446) September 5, 1934
('64', 398, 3, 5, 788464) DEAR DR.
('64', 398, 3, 6, 788473) DHARMAVIR 1,
('64', 398, 4, 7, 788486) I thank you for your letter.

('64', 406, 1, 2, 801744) 478. VILLAGE TANNING AND ITS POSSIBILITIES
('64', 406, 2, 3, 801787) Village tanning is as ancient as India itself.
('64', 406, 2, 4, 801834) No one can say when tanning became a degraded calling.
('64', 406, 2, 5, 801889) It could not have been so in ancient times.
('64', 406, 2, 6, 801933) But we know today that one of the most useful and indispensable industries has consigned probably a million people to hereditary untouchability.
('64', 406, 2, 7, 802078) An evil day dawned upon this unhappy country when labour began to be despised and, therefore, neglected.
('64', 406, 2, 8, 802183) Millions of those who were the salt of the earth, on whose industry this country depended for its very existence, came to be regarded as low class and the microscopic leisured few became the privileged classes, with the tragic result that India suffered morally and materially.
('64', 406, 2, 9, 802461) Which was the greater of the two losses it is difficult, if not impossible, to estimate.
('64', 406, 2, 10, 802550) But the criminal neglect of the peasants and the artisans has reduced us to pauperism, dulness and habitual idleness.
('64', 406, 2, 11, 802668) With her magnificent climate, lofty mountains, mighty rivers and an extensive seaboard, India has limitless resources, whose full exploitation in her village should have prevented poverty and disease.
('64', 406, 2, 12, 802869) But the divorce of the intellect from body labour has made of us perhaps the shortest lived, most resourceless and most exploited nation on earth.
('64', 406, 2, 13, 803016) The state of village tanning is, perhaps, the best proof of my indictment.
('64', 406, 2, 14, 803091) It was the late Madhusudan Das who opened my eyes to the great crime against a part of humanity.
('64', 406, 2, 15, 803188) He sought to make reparation by opening what might be called an educational tannery.
('64', 406, 2, 16, 803273) His enterprise did not come up to his expectations, but he was responsible for the livelihood of hundreds of shoemakers in Cuttack.
('64', 406, 2, 17, 803405) It is estimated that rupees nine crores worth of raw hide is annually exported from India and that much of it is returned to her in the shape of manufactured articles.
('64', 406, 2, 18, 803573) This means not only a material but also an intellectual drain.
('64', 406, 2, 19, 803636) We miss the training we should receive in tanning and preparing the innumerable articles of leather we need for daily use.
('64', 406, 2, 20, 803759) Tanning requires great technical skill.
('64', 406, 2, 21, 803799) An army of chemists can find scope for their inventive talent in this great industry.
('64', 406, 2, 22, 803885) There are two ways of developing it.
('64', 406, 2, 23, 803922) One for the uplift of Harijans living in the villages and eking out a bare sustenance, living in filth and degradation and consigned to the village ghetto, isolated and away from the village proper.
('64', 406, 2, 24, 804121) This way means in part re organization of villages and taking art, education, cleanliness, prosperity and dignity to them.
('64', 406, 2, 25, 804244) This means also the application of chemical talent to village
('64', 407, 0, 1, 804306) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 407, 1, 2, 804348) uplift.
('64', 407, 1, 3, 804356) Tanning chemists have to discover improved methods of tanning.
('64', 407, 1, 4, 804419) The village chemist has to stoop to conquer.
('64', 407, 1, 5, 804464) He has to learn and understand the crude village tanning, which is still in existence but which is fast dying owing to neglect, not to say want of support.
('64', 407, 1, 6, 804620) But the crude method may not be summarily scrapped, at least not before a sympathetic examination.
('64', 407, 1, 7, 804719) It has served well for centuries.
('64', 407, 1, 8, 804753) It could not have done so, if it had no merit.
('64', 407, 1, 9, 804800) The only research I know in this direction is being carried on in Santiniketan, and then it was started at the now defunct Ashram at Sabarmati.
('64', 407, 1, 10, 804944) I have not been able to keep myself in touch with the progress of the experiment at Santiniketan.
('64', 407, 1, 11, 805042) There is every prospect of its revival at the Harijan Ashram, which the Sabarmati Ashram has now become.
('64', 407, 1, 12, 805147) These experiments are mere drops in the ocean of possible research.
('64', 407, 1, 13, 805215) Cow preservation is an article of faith in Hinduism.
('64', 407, 1, 14, 805268) No Harijan worth his salt will kill cattle for good.
('64', 407, 1, 15, 805321) But, having become untouchable, he has learnt the evil habit of eating carrion.
('64', 407, 1, 16, 805401) He will not kill a cow but will eat with the greatest relish the flesh of a dead cow.
('64', 407, 1, 17, 805487) It may be physiologically harmless.
('64', 407, 1, 18, 805523) But psychologically there is nothing, perhaps, so repulsive as carrioneating.
('64', 407, 1, 19, 805601) And yet, when a dead cow is brought to a Harijan tanner’s house, it is a day of rejoicing for the whole household.
('64', 407, 1, 20, 805716) Children dance round the carcass, and as the animal is flayed, they take hold of bones or pieces of flesh and throw them at one another.
('64', 407, 1, 21, 805853) As a tanner, who is living at the Harijan Ashram, describing the scenes at his own now forsaken home, tells me, the whole family is drunk with joy at the sight of the dead animal.
('64', 407, 1, 22, 806033) I know how hard I have found it working among Harijans to wean them from the soul destroying habit of eating carrion.
('64', 407, 1, 23, 806151) Reformed tanning means the automatic disappearance of carrion eating.
('64', 407, 1, 24, 806221) Well, here is the use for high intelligence and the art of dissection.
('64', 407, 1, 25, 806292) Here is also a mighty step in the direction of cow preservation.
('64', 407, 1, 26, 806357) The cow must die at the hands of the butcher, unless we learn the art of increasing her capacity of milk giving, unless we improve her stock and make her male progeny more useful for the field and carrying burdens, unless we make scientific use of all her excreta as manure and unless, when she and hers die, we are prepared to make the wisest use of her hide, bone, flesh, entrails, etc.
('64', 407, 1, 27, 806746) I am just now concerned only with the carcass.
('64', 407, 1, 28, 806793) It is well to remember here that the village tanner, thank God, has to deal only with the carcass, not the slaughtered animal.
('64', 407, 1, 29, 806920) He has no means of
('64', 408, 0, 1, 806939) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 409
('64', 408, 1, 2, 806985) bringing the dead animal in a decent way.
('64', 408, 1, 3, 807027) He lifts it, drags it, and this injures the skin and reduces the value of the hide.
('64', 408, 1, 4, 807111) If the villagers and the public knew the priceless and noble service the tanner renders, they will provide easy and simple methods of carrying it, so as not to injure the skin at all.
('64', 408, 1, 5, 807295) The next process is flaying the animal.
('64', 408, 1, 6, 807335) This requires great skill.
('64', 408, 1, 7, 807362) I am told that none, not even surgeons, do this work better or more expeditiously than the village tanner does with his village knife.
('64', 408, 1, 8, 807497) I have inquired of those who should know.
('64', 408, 1, 9, 807539) They have not been able to show me an improvement upon the village tanner.
('64', 408, 1, 10, 807614) This is not to say that there is none better.
('64', 408, 1, 11, 807660) I merely give the reader the benefit of my own very limited experience.
('64', 408, 1, 12, 807732) The village tanner has no use for the bone.
('64', 408, 1, 13, 807776) He throws it away.
('64', 408, 1, 14, 807795) Dogs hover round the carcass, whilst it is flayed, and take away some, if not all, of the bones.
('64', 408, 1, 15, 807892) This is a dead loss to the country.
('64', 408, 1, 16, 807928) The bones, if powdered fine, apart from their other uses, make valuable manure.
('64', 408, 1, 17, 808008) What remains after the dogs have taken away their share is transported to foreign countries and returns to us in the shape of handles, buttons, etc.
('64', 408, 1, 18, 808157) The second way is urbanizing this great industry.
('64', 408, 1, 19, 808207) There are several tanneries in India doing this work.
('64', 408, 1, 20, 808261) Their examination is outside the scope of this article.
('64', 408, 1, 21, 808317) This urbanization can do little good to the Harijans, much less to the villages.
('64', 408, 1, 22, 808398) It is a process of double drain from the villages.
('64', 408, 1, 23, 808449) Urbanization in India is slow but sure death for her villages and villagers.
('64', 408, 1, 24, 808526) Urbanization can never support ninety per cent of India’s population, which is living in her 7,00,000 villages.
('64', 408, 1, 25, 808638) To remove from these villages tanning and such other industries is to remove what little opportunity there still is for making skilled use of the hand and the head.
('64', 408, 1, 26, 808803) And when the village handicrafts disappear, the villagers working only with their cattle on the field, with idleness for six or four months in the year, must, in the words of Madhusudan Das, be reduced to the level of the beast and be without proper nourishment, either of the mind or the body, and, therefore, without joy and without hope.
('64', 408, 1, 27, 809144) Here is work for the cent per cent swadeshi lover and scope for the harnessing of technical skill to the solution of a great problem.
('64', 408, 1, 28, 809278) The work fells three apples with one throw.
('64', 408, 1, 29, 809322) It serves the Harijans, it serves the villagers and it means honourable employment for the
('64', 409, 0, 1, 809413) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 409, 1, 2, 809455) middle class intelligentsia who are in search of employment.
('64', 409, 1, 3, 809516) Add to this the fact that the intelligentsia have a proper opportunity of coming in direct touch with the villagers.
('64', 409, 1, 4, 809633) Harijan, 7 9 1934

('64', 418, 5, 29, 823329) 488. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('64', 418, 6, 30, 823360) September 8, 1934
('64', 418, 7, 31, 823378) NARANDAS, I have your letter of the 6th.
('64', 418, 7, 32, 823419) I have asked Narahari to inquire into the facts regarding the dairy and let me have his opinion.
('64', 418, 7, 33, 823516) I will not forget about this matter.
('64', 418, 7, 34, 823553) I am still not able to take sufficient rest.
('64', 418, 7, 35, 823598) I have again started getting up at 2.30. The bed itself pushes me out and I welcome that.
('64', 418, 7, 36, 823688) It is 3.30 just now.
('64', 418, 7, 37, 823709) I have started writing this after finishing one to Jamnalal.
('64', 418, 7, 38, 823770) I can’t think what to do regarding Chimanlal and Sharda.
('64', 418, 7, 39, 823827) One thing is clear to me.
('64', 418, 7, 40, 823853) Sharda’s living with Chimanlal may not be for
('64', 419, 0, 1, 823899) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 420
('64', 419, 1, 2, 823941) her good.
('64', 419, 1, 3, 823951) If her devotion to her father has become her sole passion, she may, though ill herself, sacrifice her health in nursing Chimanlal.
('64', 419, 1, 4, 824082) We come across many such instances in Europe.
('64', 419, 1, 5, 824128) I don’t remember to have seen any among us.
('64', 419, 1, 6, 824172) But the education which we give is certainly likely to produce girls of this type.
('64', 419, 1, 7, 824255) Such idealism endures only if it grows spontaneously.
('64', 419, 1, 8, 824309) If Sharda does not possess this spirit, she should have regard for her health and leave Chimanlal.
('64', 419, 1, 9, 824408) She may come and live here.
('64', 419, 1, 10, 824436) There are other girls of her age here, and among them there are ten Gujarati girls even, including Vali.
('64', 419, 1, 11, 824541) The climate also is excellent.
('64', 419, 1, 12, 824572) I, too, shall be here for some time.
('64', 419, 1, 13, 824609) In any case my headquaters will continue to be here.
('64', 419, 1, 14, 824662) There are good arrangements for study, too.
('64', 419, 1, 15, 824706) It is desirable that one who is ill should not nurse another sick person.
('64', 419, 1, 16, 824780) Shakaribehn should undertake to look after Chimanlal.
('64', 419, 1, 17, 824834) The latter should stop eating solid food and live only on milk and fruit.
('64', 419, 1, 18, 824908) A pure milk diet has been found to have beneficial effect, but I think such an experiment is too drastic.
('64', 419, 1, 19, 825014) A mixed diet of milk and fruit is found best.
('64', 419, 1, 20, 825060) Even if such a diet brings on weakness, I would advise Chimanlal not to mind it but persevere in the experiment patiently.
('64', 419, 1, 21, 825183) Sharma is at Sabarmati now.
('64', 419, 1, 22, 825211) He has renounced everything in order to live with Ramdas.
('64', 419, 1, 23, 825269) That is why he has taken Ramdas with him and gone to Sabarmati.
('64', 419, 1, 24, 825333) Ba has gone there to look after Ramdas.
('64', 419, 1, 25, 825373) You may, if you wish, consult Sharma [regarding Chimanlal]; I have had experience of his goodness.
('64', 419, 1, 26, 825472) I cannot say, though, anything regarding his competence as a doctor.
('64', 419, 1, 27, 825541) All the same, there can be no harm in consulting him.
('64', 419, 1, 28, 825595) Milk and fruit, however, are both food and medicine.
('64', 419, 1, 29, 825648) Anybody who is not benefited by them is hardly likely to be benefited by anything else.
('64', 419, 1, 30, 825736) Water and sun treatments also should go on at the same time.
('64', 419, 1, 31, 825797) The chief thing in my advice is the suggestion regarding Sharda.
('64', 419, 1, 32, 825862) Both of you should please think over it.
('64', 419, 1, 33, 825903) My personal needs are being looked after by Prabhavati, Amtussalaam, Vasumati and Om.
('64', 419, 1, 34, 825989) Amala also does some work.
('64', 419, 1, 35, 826016) But I am really afraid that she will go off her head one day.
('64', 419, 1, 36, 826078) She is hardly in her senses.
('64', 419, 1, 37, 826107) She is growing thinner everyday.
('64', 419, 1, 38, 826140) And now she has become impatient to marry.
('64', 419, 1, 39, 826183) I observe that she is not free from passion.
('64', 419, 1, 40, 826228) In consequence of her trying to suppress it, it has become uncontrollable.
('64', 419, 1, 41, 826303) She hopes to be mother of twelve children.
('64', 419, 1, 42, 826346) She is 37 at present.
('64', 419, 1, 43, 826368) Let us see what she does.
('64', 419, 1, 44, 826394) I don’t have the courage now to send her to you or somewhere else.
('64', 419, 1, 45, 826461) She is trying to get a job in some college.
('64', 419, 1, 46, 826505) I don’t mind if she succeeds by her own efforts.

('64', 428, 3, 4, 837984) Lord of humility, dwelling in the little pariah hut, help us to search for Thee throughout that fair land watered by Ganges, Brahmaputra and Jumna.
('64', 428, 3, 5, 838132) Give us receptiveness, give us openhear tedness, give us Thy humility, give us the ability and willingness to identify ourselves with the masses of India.

('64', 428, 3, 7, 838434) Let us be embodiments of self sacrifice, embodiments of godliness, humility personified, that we may know the land better and love it more.

('64', 436, 5, 15, 853309) 512. MORE ON SWADESHI I would like to resume the thread of my remarks on swadeshi in the Harijan of 10th August.
('64', 436, 5, 16, 853422) 1 Take the special occupations of Harijans.
('64', 436, 5, 17, 853466) There is a meaning behind the over two thousand Harijan castes.
('64', 436, 5, 18, 853530) Most of them denote their respective occupations—basket making, broom making, rope weaving, durri weaving, etc.
('64', 436, 5, 19, 853642) If a complete list was made of them, they would make an imposing list.
('64', 436, 5, 20, 853713) They are occupations which either need encouragement, or should be deliberately destroyed if they are useless or unprofitable.
('64', 436, 5, 21, 853840) But who is to decide whether they are profitable or unprofitable, useless or otherwise?
('64', 436, 5, 22, 853928) If there was a true swadeshi organization, if would be its duty to find out the turth about all these innumerable handicrafts and interest themselves in these craftsmen.
('64', 436, 5, 23, 854098) The ink with which I am writing comes from Tenali.
('64', 436, 5, 24, 854149) It supports about 12 workers.
('64', 436, 5, 25, 854179) It is making headway against odds.
('64', 436, 5, 26, 854214) I had three more specimens sent to me by different makers, all no doubt struggling like the Tenali group.
('64', 436, 5, 27, 854320) They interested me.
('64', 436, 5, 28, 854340) I entered into correspondence with them.
('64', 436, 5, 29, 854381) But I could do no more for them.
('64', 436, 5, 30, 854414) A swadeshi organization will examine the samples of these inks in a scientific manner and guide them and encouage the most promising ones.
('64', 436, 5, 31, 854553) It is a good and growing industry, requiring expert chemical knowledge.
('64', 436, 6, 32, 854625) 1 Vide “Swadeshi”, 6 8 1934

('64', 437, 1, 2, 854695) In Cawnpore, a man sent me samples of the paper his friend was manufacturing in a village nearby.
('64', 437, 1, 3, 854793) I enquired into the concern.
('64', 437, 1, 4, 854822) It supports about nine men.
('64', 437, 1, 5, 854850) The paper was stout and glossy.
('64', 437, 1, 6, 854882) However, it was not good enough for writing.
('64', 437, 1, 7, 854927) Men engaged in the manufacture are eking out the barest livelihood.
('64', 437, 1, 8, 854995) The skill is supplied by an old man nearing the crematorium.
('64', 437, 1, 9, 855056) The whole concern may perish with him, if it is not properly guided.
('64', 437, 1, 10, 855125) I was told that, if there were enough orders, the paper could be supplied at the same cost as the mill–made article.
('64', 437, 1, 11, 855242) I know that hand made paper can never supply the daily growing demand for paper.
('64', 437, 1, 12, 855323) But lovers of the seven hundred thousand villages and their handicrafts will always want to use hand made paper, if it is easily procurable.
('64', 437, 1, 13, 855464) Those who use hand made paper know that it has a charm of its own.
('64', 437, 1, 14, 855531) Who does not know the famous Ahmedabad paper?
('64', 437, 1, 15, 855577) What mill made paper can beat it in durability or polish!
('64', 437, 1, 16, 855635) The account books of the old style are still made of that paper.
('64', 437, 1, 17, 855700) But it is probably a perishing industry like many such others.
('64', 437, 1, 18, 855763) With a little encouragement, it ought never to perish.
('64', 437, 1, 19, 855818) If there was supervision, the processes might be improved and the defects that are to be noticed with some of this hand made paper may be easily removed.
('64', 437, 1, 20, 855972) The economic condition of the numberless people engaged in these little known trades is well worth investigating.
('64', 437, 1, 21, 856086) They will surely allow themselves to be guided and advised and feel thankful to those who would take interest in them.
('64', 437, 1, 22, 856205) I hope I have given enough illustrations to show how vast 1 and uncultivated this field of true swadeshi is.
('64', 437, 1, 23, 856314) It is capable of limitless expansion and of producing, without any capital outlay, new wealth in the country and providing honourable employment to those who are today starving for want of it.

('64', 438, 1, 2, 856597) 513. WHY NOT ‘HARIJAN’ ?
('64', 438, 3, 3, 856622) THE EDITOR, “HARIJAN”
('64', 438, 5, 4, 856644) I was rather pained to find that the keen intellect of Mr. Mahadev Desai missed the real point involved in the representation made by “some friends who met Gandhiji claiming to be representatives of the Harijans or rather ‘Depressed Classes’ as they preferred to call them” (See Harijan of August 10,
('64', 438, 6, 5, 856945) ’34, p.
('64', 438, 6, 6, 856953) 206, col.
('64', 438, 6, 7, 856963) 1 The “bad odour” attaching to the term ‘Depressed Classes’ is a surety of its ultimate extinction and complete disappearance along with the development of consciousness amongst these classes leading to the unification and consequent solidification of the general Hindu community at large, which, we all know, is the aim of Gnadhiji in his great and unique endeavour.
('64', 438, 6, 8, 857331) But the sweetness of the term “Harijan” is likely to perpetuate the gulf between them and the savarna Hindus, which is surely not
('64', 438, 7, 9, 857461) desired by Gandhiji.
('64', 438, 7, 10, 857482) This point should have been noticed by Mr. Mahadev Desai, whose use of the adjective ‘curious’ appears to be remarkable and at the same time regrettable, coming as it does from one of the closest associates of Gandhiji.
('64', 438, 8, 11, 857702) I myself feel interested in the matter as one belonging to this great class, but feel indifferent to the appellation that others may choose to give, excepting, of course, the result it is likely to have on the future positon of the great community in the large Hindu fold.
('64', 438, 9, 12, 857975) Will you kindly show this to Mr. Mahadev Desai?
('64', 438, 10, 13, 858023) I am, etc.
('64', 438, 11, 14, 858034) H. K. MULLICK Mahadev Desai has passed the foregoing to me.
('64', 438, 11, 15, 858094) I know Sjt.
('64', 438, 11, 16, 858106) Mullick, as I had the pleasure of meeting him in Calcutta during the recent visit.
('64', 438, 11, 17, 858189) I can share his nervousness and his preference for an odious appellation so long as the stigma of untouchability persists.
('64', 438, 11, 18, 858312) But I invite Sjt.
('64', 438, 11, 19, 858330) Mullick to enter into the feeling of reformers who have no untouchability in them and who, therefore, have a horror of using an odious name for those whom they love and are eager to serve to the best of their ability.
('64', 438, 11, 20, 858548) Add to this the fact that tens of thousands of untouchables do not like the words achhut, asprishya and the like and that they do like the word ‘Harijan’.
('64', 438, 11, 21, 858703) The aim of us all is the
('64', 438, 12, 22, 858728) 1 Vide “Discussion with Represent
('64', 439, 0, 1, 858762) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 440
('64', 439, 1, 2, 858804) same—total extinction of untouchability.
('64', 439, 1, 3, 858845) When that happy day arrives, either the word ‘Harijan’ will disappear or we shall all be proud to be called Harijans—devotees of God—deserving to be so described, having been free of the virus of high and low.

('64', 439, 2, 5, 859074) 514. NOT ARGUMENT, BUT EXPERIENCE
('64', 439, 3, 6, 859108) For me non violence, like Truth, is my eternal creed for every activity.
('64', 439, 3, 7, 859181) That I often fail to act up to it in many activities in my dealings with the sub human family proves my weakness; it cannot and does not affect the truth of the creed or my faith in it.
('64', 439, 3, 8, 859367) I am but a weak aspirant ever failing, ever trying.
('64', 439, 3, 9, 859419) My failures make me more vigilant than before and intensify my faith.
('64', 439, 3, 10, 859489) I can see with the eye of faith that the observance of the twin doctrine of Truth and Non violence has possibilities of which we have but a very inadequate conception.
('64', 439, 3, 11, 859657) If these two should pervade the whole of our being, how much more in the purely religious war against untouchability?
('64', 439, 3, 12, 859775) I, therefore, gladly share with Harijan workers the following extracts from an intimate letter received from an American friend who discloses the working of his mind and declares his faith in non violence achieved, though, perhaps, not yet fully, after laborious search:
('64', 439, 4, 13, 860046) You may have gathered from my last conversation with you that I was
('64', 439, 5, 14, 860114) turning from my faith in the principle of non violence.
('64', 439, 5, 15, 860170) I had been troubled by doubts
('64', 439, 6, 16, 860200) concerning this principle, and that was why I wanted so much to talk with you.
('64', 439, 7, 17, 860279) think that was very foolish of me, for, it should be evident that great moral and
('64', 439, 8, 18, 860361) spiritual truths can never have their validity established through arguments.
('64', 439, 9, 19, 860439) have to be tested in the fire of experience, which I have not done in my own life to
('64', 439, 10, 20, 860524) any large extent.
('64', 439, 10, 21, 860542) I am persuaded that it would require a much stricter discipline than I
('64', 439, 11, 22, 860613) have yet known for me to prove by my own experience that non violence is eternally
('64', 439, 13, 23, 860696) But I am able to accept it as one of the great fundamentals of my faith by my observation of the fruits it has produced in the lives of others.
('64', 439, 13, 24, 860840) To associate intimately with such men as Rajendrababu is a privilege for which one may thank God.
('64', 439, 13, 25, 860938) I have seen that he and several others whom I might mention, who have accepted the principle of non violence in their own lives, have been able to purify themselves from all the greed, the lust, the self seeking, the hatred, the fear which obsesses so many who have caught a vision of a glorious future but are obstructed by these
('64', 440, 0, 1, 861269) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 441
('64', 440, 1, 2, 861315) enemies within the gates from fighting successfully with the enemy without.
('64', 440, 1, 3, 861391) It is not what non violence has done to those who oppose you that is to me significant, but what it has done for you and that very small minority who have in their hearts become non violent.
('64', 440, 1, 4, 861582) Sicne I believe this is a moral universe, it must follow, as night follows day, that such development of character can never arise out of experiments with falsehood, and, by the same token, I believe that Jesus is right, at least in the long run, when he says that “they who take the sword will perish by the sword”.
('64', 440, 2, 5, 861899) 1 I am certain that the only virtue which you need to exercise for the ultimate success of your struggle is that of patience.
('64', 440, 3, 6, 862025) 2 So far as your own leadership in India is concerned, you did not develop your qualities of leadership in a day, nor were you born with tehse qualities.
('64', 440, 3, 7, 862179) I consider that you are the product of a long discipline of supreme loyalty to truth as you saw it and that you have arrived at your present position through a long and arduous experience.
('64', 440, 3, 8, 862368) While Europeans may be untrained in the exercise of non violence, I do not think human nature is essentially different in Europe from that of India, and the only way they can learn non violence is through practice.
('64', 440, 3, 9, 862583) There are bound to be many failures, many heart breaks, many defeats, as has been true and is still true in your case.
('64', 440, 3, 10, 862702) But If it is truth, it can never be forsaken.
('64', 440, 4, 11, 862748) Harijan, 14 9 1934

('64', 440, 10, 23, 863258) Hindu society here engages dancing girls—especially during marriages and festivals of the deity—to sing obscene songs accompanied by obscene gestures before the pious deity and sets a bad example before the newly wed couple.

('64', 440, 11, 25, 863561) Young men here are trying their best to root out this evil.

('64', 448, 2, 3, 875451) September 15, 1934
('64', 448, 3, 4, 875470) BHAISHRI MAVALANKAR, I have your letter.
('64', 448, 3, 5, 875511) There is no connection between the Vidyapith library and Kaka’s idea of leaving Gujarat.
('64', 448, 3, 6, 875600) If the original Trustees had no right to hand over the library, its gift would remain illegal even if made at a meeting attended by all.
('64', 448, 3, 7, 875737) If you think that the Trustees had a right to make the gift, I believe Sardar wishes to take no action regarding Kaka’s other error.
('64', 448, 3, 8, 875870) Being one of the Trustees, he only wants to know what his duty is.
('64', 448, 3, 9, 875937) I don’t think anything can be said about that.
('64', 448, 3, 10, 875984) But personally I wouldn’t blame Kaka for this ignorance of law if it is such.
('64', 448, 3, 11, 876062) The serious error committed by Kaka, may be unintentionally, was that, though he had not secured the consent of the Trustees, he allowed a sentence implying that it had been secured to stand in the letter 1 to the Collector.
('64', 448, 3, 12, 876287) Kaka decided to atone for this carelessness by resigning from all the trusts.
('64', 448, 3, 13, 876365) Sardar has had nothing to do with this.
('64', 448, 3, 14, 876405) However, Kaka’s resignation only solved the moral problem and has no connection whatever with the question of whether or not he should remain in Gujarat.
('64', 448, 3, 15, 876559) He has been waiting for a long time to run away from Gujarat.
('64', 448, 3, 16, 876621) We need not go into the reasons for that.
('64', 448, 3, 17, 876663) But the final decision whether he should leave or not rests with me.
('64', 448, 3, 18, 876732) Sardar will have had no part in it.
('64', 448, 3, 19, 876768) I will not let Kaka run away.
('64', 448, 3, 20, 876798) He will leave only if I feel helpless.
('64', 448, 3, 21, 876837) You and other co workers, however, should have no worry or fear.
('64', 448, 3, 22, 876902) You should merely give your professional opinion as a lawyer as to the legal loophole.

('64', 449, 0, 1, 877251) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 449, 1, 2, 877293) APPENDICES
('64', 449, 2, 3, 877304) APPENDIX I RESOLUTION ON WHITE PAPER AND COMMUNAL AWARD 1
('64', 449, 3, 4, 877362) The following is the authorized report of the Working Committee resolution on the policy of Congress regarding the White Paper proposals and the Communal Award:
('64', 449, 4, 5, 877523) The Congress Parliamentary Board having asked the Working Committee to enunciate the Congress policy on the White Paper proposals and the Communal Award, the Working Committee declares the Congress policy on these matters as follows:
('64', 449, 5, 6, 877757) The White Paper in no way expresses the will of the people of India, has been more or less condemned by almost all the Indian political parties, and falls far short of the Congress goal, if it does not retard the progress towards it.
('64', 449, 5, 7, 877991) The only satisfactory alternative to the White Paper is a constitution drawn up by a Constituent Assembly, elected on the basis of adult suffrage or as near it as possible, with the power, if necessary, to the important minorities to have their representatives elected exclusively by the electors belonging to such minorities.
('64', 449, 6, 8, 878318) The White Paper lapsing, the Communal Award must lapse automatically.
('64', 449, 6, 9, 878388) Among other things it will be the duty of the Constituent Assembly to determine the method of representation of important minorities and make provisions for otherwise safeguarding their interests.
('64', 449, 7, 10, 878585) Since, however, the different communities in the country are sharply divided on the question of the Communal Award, it is necessary to define the Congress attitude on it.
('64', 449, 7, 11, 878756) The Congress claims to represent equally all the communities composing the Indian Nation and, therefore, in view of division of opinion it can neither accept nor reject the Communal Award as long as the division of opinion lasts.
('64', 449, 7, 12, 878986) At the same time it is necessary to redeclare the policy of the Congress on the Communal question.
('64', 449, 8, 13, 879085) No solution that is not purely national can be propounded by the Congress.
('64', 449, 8, 14, 879160) But the Congress is pledged to accept any solution falling short of the national, which is agreed to by all the parties concerned, and, conversely to reject and solution which is not agreed to by any of the said parties.
('64', 449, 9, 15, 879381) 1 Vide “Speech at Meeting of Congress Parliamentary Board, Bombay”, 16 6 1934, “Manifesto of Congress Parlimentary Board”, 29 7 1934 and “Letter to N. C. Kalkar”, 17 8 1934
('64', 450, 0, 1, 879554) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 451
('64', 450, 1, 2, 879600) Judged by the national standard the Communal Award is wholly unsatisfactory besides being open to serious objection on other grounds.
('64', 450, 2, 3, 879734) It is, however, obvious that the only way to prevent untoward consequences of the Communal Award is to explore the ways and means of arriving at an agreed solution and not by any appeal on this essentially domestic question to the British Government or any other outside authority.
('64', 450, 3, 4, 880016) The Bombay Chronicle, 18–6–1934
('64', 450, 4, 5, 880048) APPENDIX II LETTER FROM N. C. KELKAR 1
('64', 450, 5, 6, 880087) “KESARI” OFFICE, POONA 2, June 22, 1934
('64', 450, 6, 7, 880127) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('64', 450, 7, 8, 880143) The people in the Indian States desire to ascertain your individual opinion on certain matters affecting themselves, so that we may move the Congress to consider, in the light of your opinion, the desirability of defining its policy on certain questiions more precisely than at present and modifying it somewhat on certain others.
('64', 450, 8, 9, 880474) The first question that we would bring to your notice in this connection is the necessity of the Congress taking up for solution problems pertaining to the States.
('64', 450, 8, 10, 880638) The Congress has now given up its traditional policy of “keeping itself unspotted” from the States.
('64', 450, 8, 11, 880738) It recruits members in the States and brings them under the control of its district and provincial committees.
('64', 450, 8, 12, 880849) The accession of strength that it has thus received from the States is by no means negligible; nor are these members sleeping partners in the Congress activities, although these activities concern mostly British India alone.
('64', 450, 8, 13, 881074) On the other hand, even in such movements as civil disobedience, they have proved good comrades in arms and have cheerfully borne their share of the burden, realizing that British India and Indian India are essentially one and indivisible and that the concerns of one are necessarily the concerns of the other also.
('64', 450, 9, 14, 881390) We think that time has now arrived for the Congress to respond to this spirit of good comradeship exhibited by the States’ people by putting all its weight and prestige behind their efforts at self emancipation.
('64', 450, 9, 15, 881602) At the Madras (1927) and Calcutta (1928) sessions the Congress no doubt pleaded for the establishment of democratic swaraj in the Indian States and extended its sympathy to the inhabitants thereof.
('64', 450, 9, 16, 881800) The Calcutta resolution is well worth quoting here is exteno.
('64', 450, 10, 17, 881862) 1 Vide “Letter to N. C. Kelkar”, 2 7 1934
('64', 451, 0, 1, 881904) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('64', 451, 1, 2, 881946) The Congress urges no the ruling Princes of the Indian States to introduce responsible government based on representative institutions in the States, and to issue immediately proclamations or enact laws guaranteeing elementary and fundamental rights of citizenship, such as rights of association, free speech, free Press and security of person and property.
('64', 451, 2, 3, 882304) This Congress further assures the people of the Indian states of its sympathy with and support in their legitimate and peaceful struggle for the attainment of full responsible government in the States.
('64', 451, 3, 4, 882506) We make no doubt that a similar resolution will be reiterated at the sessions that will be held hereafter.
('64', 451, 3, 5, 882613) But may we not hope that the Congreesmen in British Indian will lend active help to the people in the Indian States in achieving political freedom even as the Congressmen in Indian India gave a measure of help to British Indians in their attempts to realize their destiny?
('64', 451, 3, 6, 882886) Of the two, British Indians are much the more advanced, but in fact help has flown far more from the States’ people to British Indians than from British Indians to the States’ people.
('64', 451, 3, 7, 883070) Do you not think it desirable to advise British Indians, in the name of the Congress to support actively, even by undergoing suffering if necessary, all legitimate movements for the establishment of popular government in the Indian States under the aegis of their rulers?
('64', 451, 3, 8, 883342) Such comradeship shown on both sides, it appears to us, will cement the two Indians far more firmly than any formal federation can.
('64', 451, 4, 9, 883474) Another question, of even greater urgency, on which the Congress must determine its policy is its attitude towards those parts of the White Paper scheme which relate to the Indian States.
('64', 451, 4, 10, 883662) The authorities of the Congress have declared the scheme to be unacceptable because it does not satisfy the aspirations of the Indian people.
('64', 451, 4, 11, 883804) May we say that the provisions concerning the States are far from acceptable to the States’ people and may we hope that the actual acceptance or otherwise of these provisions will be made to depend upon their wishes?
('64', 451, 4, 12, 884021) The future constitution of India which, according to the Congress intentions, is to take the place of the White Paper constitution, will be based upon the principle of self determination given effect to by a Constituent Assembly.
('64', 451, 4, 13, 884251) Is it implied that the federal scheme that will be evolved by this Assembly will be the result of an agreement between the people in British India on the one hand and those in the Indian States on the other?
('64', 451, 5, 14, 884459) While on this subject it would be well to refer to the apprehensions that have arisen in the mind of the Indian States’ people by some passages in your speeches at the Round Table Conference.
('64', 451, 5, 15, 884651) You pleaded earnestly in this Conference with the rulers of the Indian States for allowing the States representatives in the Federal Legislature to be chosen by election and for allowing the fundamental rights of the States’ people to be written into the federal constitution and placed under the protection of the Federal Court.
('64', 451, 5, 16, 884981) But your pledings on this occasion have given rise
('64', 452, 0, 1, 885032) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 453
('64', 452, 1, 2, 885078) to an impression that if the Princes did not agree, as they did not and they do not agree, you would accept a constitution in which provisions of the kind that you suggested did not find a place.
('64', 452, 1, 3, 885274) If this impression is well founded, we cannot help saying, and saying it straightout, that you have done a grave wrong to the States’ people.
('64', 452, 1, 4, 885416) If you think that nomination by the Princes, for instance, must be acquiesced in, if necessary, in the existing circumstances, we will only beg you to refer the matter to the States’ people themselves in order to ascertain what their wishes are in this respect.
('64', 452, 1, 5, 885678) The right of self determination of the Indian States’ people is no less sacred than that of British Indians.
('64', 452, 2, 6, 885787) But it has been explained to us that in expressing your views in favour of
('64', 452, 3, 7, 885862) the election of the States’ representativs and the protection of the fundamental rights
('64', 452, 4, 8, 885950) of the States’ people in the way you did, you wished it to be understood by the rulers
('64', 452, 5, 9, 886037) of the States that if they did not agree to do what you urged upon them, you would not
('64', 452, 6, 10, 886124) admit them into the federation.
('64', 452, 6, 11, 886156) You meant these to be essential conditions of
('64', 452, 7, 12, 886202) federation, but you did not express yourself in this categorical manner only because,
('64', 452, 8, 13, 886288) at the time you spoke, federation was still shrouded in uncertainty.
('64', 452, 8, 14, 886357) If this be your
('64', 452, 9, 15, 886373) meaning, we would entreat you to make it clear beyond the possibility of doubt, for
('64', 452, 10, 16, 886457) we know that the rulers of the States are putting a ditterent interpretation upon what
('64', 452, 11, 17, 886544) you said.
('64', 452, 11, 18, 886554) They are representing that you are ready to put up with nomination by the
('64', 452, 12, 19, 886628) Princes, for instance, for an indefinite length of time.
('64', 452, 12, 20, 886685) It is necessary that your
('64', 452, 13, 21, 886711) meaning should be made plain, for the Swarajist Conference at Ranchi made it known
('64', 452, 14, 22, 886794) that their party (which is now only a wing of the Congress) would follow the lines of
('64', 452, 15, 23, 886880) your speeches in framing the future constitution.
('64', 452, 15, 24, 886930) Since, in the final determination of
('64', 452, 16, 25, 886967) the Congress policy on these points your personal views plays such a decisive part,
('64', 452, 17, 26, 887051) we are anxious to know whether election of the States’ people and Declaration of
('64', 452, 18, 27, 887132) Rights in their interest are, in your opinion, merely desirable features of a federation
('64', 452, 19, 28, 887221) or essential conditions thereof.
('64', 452, 19, 29, 887254) There are various other matters connected with the
('64', 452, 20, 30, 887305) federal constitution which require careful consideration on the part of the Congress,
('64', 452, 21, 31, 887391) but we do not wish to trouble you with them at the present moment.
('64', 452, 21, 32, 887458) We would only
('64', 452, 22, 33, 887472) beg you to give us an unequivocal statement of your views on the point raised in this
('64', 452, 23, 34, 887558) letter.
('64', 452, 24, 35, 887566) Yours sincerely,

('64', 453, 1, 2, 887676) APPENDIX III
('64', 453, 2, 3, 887689) RESOLUTION ON SWADESHI 1
('64', 453, 3, 4, 887714) Doubts having arisen on the Congress policy in regard to swadeshi, it has become necessary to reaffirm the Congress position on it in unequivocal terms.
('64', 453, 4, 5, 887867) Notwithstanding what was done during the civil resistance struggle, no competition is permissible on Congress platform and in Congress exhibitions between mill made cloth and hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('64', 453, 4, 6, 888074) Congressmen are expected to use and encourage the use of only hand spun and hand woven khadi, to the exclusion of any other cloth.
('64', 453, 5, 7, 888205) In regard to articles other than cloth, the Working Committee adopts the following formula for the guidance of all Congress organizations:
('64', 453, 6, 8, 888344) The Working Committee is of opinion that the activities of Congress organizations relating to swadeshi shall be restricted to useful articles manufactured in India through cottage and other small industries which are in need of popular education for their support, and which will accept the guidance of the Congress organizations in regulating prices and in the matter of the wages and welfare of labour under their control.
('64', 453, 7, 9, 888769) This formula must not be interpreted to mean any modification of the unbroken policy of the Congress to promote the swadeshi spirit in the country and to encourage the personal use of only swadeshi articles.
('64', 453, 7, 10, 888977) The formula is a recognition of the fact that the large and organized industries which can or do command State aid are in no need of the services of Congress organizations or any Congress effort in their behalf.
('64', 453, 8, 11, 889189) The History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I, pp.
('64', 453, 9, 12, 889246) APPENDIX IV RESOLUTION ON DISCIPLINE 2
('64', 453, 10, 13, 889285) All Congressmen, whether they believe in the Congress programme and policies or not, are expected, and office bearers and members of the Executive are in honour bound, to carry them out, and that office bearers and members of the Executive who carry on propaganda or act against the Congress programme and policies are, in accordance with the rules made by the A.I.C.C. dated May 24, 1929, under Article of the Constitution, clearly guilty of breach of discipline and liable to disciplinary action.
('64', 453, 11, 14, 889784) The History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I, pp.

('64', 454, 0, 1, 889940) VOL. 64 : 20 MAY, 1934 15 SEPTEMBER, 1934 455
('64', 454, 1, 2, 889986) APPENDIX V LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('64', 454, 2, 3, 890028) ANAND BHAWAN, ALLAHABAD, August 13, 1934
('64', 454, 3, 4, 890069) MY DEAR BAPU,
('64', 454, 4, 5, 890083) After just six months of absolute seclusion and little exercise I have felt rather lost in the anxiety, excitement and activity of the past 27 hours.
('64', 454, 4, 6, 890233) I feel very tired.
('64', 454, 4, 7, 890252) I am writing this letter to you at midnight.
('64', 454, 4, 8, 890297) All day there have been crowds of people coming.
('64', 454, 4, 9, 890346) If I have the chance I shall write to you again, but I doubt if I shall be able to do so for some months.
('64', 454, 4, 10, 890452) I am, therefore, going to indicate to you briefly how I have reacted to the various major Congress decisions of the last five months or so.
('64', 454, 4, 11, 890592) My sources of information have naturally been strictly limited but I think that they were sufficient to enable me to form a fairly correct idea of the general trend of events.
('64', 454, 5, 12, 890768) When I heard that you had called off the C. D. movement I felt unhappy.
('64', 454, 5, 13, 890840) Only the brief announcement reached me at first.
('64', 454, 5, 14, 890889) Much later I read your statement and this gave me one of the biggest shocks I have ever had.
('64', 454, 5, 15, 890982) I was prepared to reconcile myself to the withdrawal of C.D. But the reasons you gave for doing so and the suggestions you made for future work astounded me.
('64', 454, 5, 16, 891140) I had a sudden and intense feeling, that something broke inside me, a bond that I had valued very greatly had snapped.
('64', 454, 5, 17, 891259) I felt terribly lonely in this wide world.
('64', 454, 5, 18, 891302) I have always felt a little lonely almost from childhood up.
('64', 454, 5, 19, 891363) But a few bonds strengthened me, a few strong supports held me up.
('64', 454, 5, 20, 891430) That loneliness never went, but it was lessened.
('64', 454, 5, 21, 891479) But now I felt absolutely alone, left high and dry on a desert island.
('64', 454, 6, 22, 891550) Human beings have an enormous capacity for adapting themselves and so I too adapted myself to some extent to the new conditions.
('64', 454, 6, 23, 891679) The keenness of my feelings on the subject, which amounted almost to physical pain, passed off; the edge was dulled.
('64', 454, 6, 24, 891796) But shock after shcok, a succession of events sharpened that edge to a fine point, and allowed my mind or feelings no peace or rest.
('64', 454, 6, 25, 891929) Again I felt that sensation of spiritual isolation, of being a perfect stranger out of harmony, not only with the crowds that passed me, but also with those whom I had valued as dear and close comrades.
('64', 454, 6, 26, 892132) My stay in prison this time became a greater ordeal for my nerves than any previous visit had been.
('64', 454, 6, 27, 892232) I almost wished that all newspapers might be kept away from me so that I might be spared these repeated shocks.
('64', 454, 7, 28, 892344) Physically I kept fairly well.
('64', 454, 7, 29, 892375) I always do in prison.

('64', 455, 2, 5, 892916) But vanity and conceit triumphed and the intellectual apparatus that functions within me refused to admit defeat.
('64', 455, 2, 6, 893030) If the ideals that had spurred me to action and had kept me buoyed up through stormy weather were right—and the conviction of their rightness ever grew within me—they were bound to triumph though my generation might not live to witness that triumph.
